webTitle: How to see the Aurora Borealis from Britain

fields.headline: How to see the Aurora Borealis from Britain
fields.standfirst:
What are the best, easiest and cheapest ways to see the Aurora Borealis, preferably in Britain?
TP Cooper
fields.trailText: What are the best, easiest and cheapest ways to see the Aurora Borealis, preferably in Britain?
fields.body:
Really good displays of the aurora borealis, the Northern Lights, are fairly uncommon in the UK, and are certainly better the further north you go. However, I would recommend that TP Cooper visits the website set up by physicists at York university who are studying the phenomenon. Not only is there a lot of information and some great photographs on www.aurorawatch.york.ac.uk but if you register with the site, they will e-mail you or send text messages to your mobile phone to alert you that the aurora are likely to occur and when and where will be the best time and place to see them.
Dave Taylor

I have seen spectacular aurora while staying on two campsites some 170 miles apart in Scotland. Both were on the edge of the clifftops, one at Applecross overlooking Skye and the Western Isles - the other at Thurso near John O'Groats. There are some good photographs at www.netreal.co.uk/aurora/index3 htm, taken from Fortrose near Inverness.
Norman Meyer

The best place to see the aurora borealis in Britain is in the Shetland Islands. Clear, frosty nights are the best time, so you need to look at the weather forecast beforehand, and even then you may not be guaranteed a sighting. Once there, you would have to keep watch, since the aurora can happen in a fleeting moment or last, on and off, for a whole night.Shetland is, however, a very expensive place to get to. fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Osborne House | London Aquarium | Canaston Woods | Fleet Air Arm Museum | Fishing in Somerset | New Lanark Mill
fields.body:
End of an era

Monday is the centenary of Queen Victoria's death at Osborne House, her magnificent holiday home on the Isle of Wight. Although the estate does not officially open until January 31, the grounds will be open to the public on the 22nd "for quiet contemplation", aided by a lone piper at 1.30pm.

Monday, 10am-2pm. Free. York Avenue, Isle of Wight (01983 200022).

Watery trek

Enter a subterranean aquatic world on the banks of the Thames. Follow the darkened trail through various habitats, from British rivers to Amazonian rainforest, accompanied by suitable watery soundtracks.

Open daily 10am-6pm. £8/£5, family £22. Annual tickets with unlimited entry available in two weeks' time: £30/£18/ family £75. County Hall, Riverside Building, Westminster Bridge Rd, London SE1 (020-7967 8000).

Welsh ride

Canaston Woods in Pembrokeshire is a great place to go mountain biking along traffic-free, purpose-built signed trails. The colour-coded signs and the map of the woods show both easy surfaced family trails and the more demanding and often muddy bridleways.

Bicycle hire: Mike's Bikes, 17 Prendergast, Haverfordwest (01437 760068). Woods: 8 miles east of Haverfordwest on A40. Tourist information: 01437 763110.

Flying visit

The Fleet Air Arm Museum is Europe's largest naval aviation museum, with six acres of aircraft, mainly undercover. Follow the development of British aviation from wooden biplanes to Concorde and use interactive displays to torpedo a submarine and take to the bridge of an aircraft carrier.

Open daily 10am-4.30pm. £7/£5/ family £23. Yeovilton, Somerset (01935 840565).

Line engaged

A new leaflet, Perfectly Hooked, gives details of 20 places around South Somerset and West Dorset where you can fish, from £3 to £18 a day. Most are for coarse fishermen - one site boasts over 21 species - but there is also fly-fishing for brown and rainbow trout.

Leaflet from local tourist information centres or the South Somerset tourism office (01935 462684).

Industrial heritage

An 18th-century complex of cotton mills and stone-built workers' houses is now a World Heritage Site. New Lanark Mill, founded by the political visionary Robert Owen on the banks of the River Clyde, is an industrial museum par excellence, offering tours, a steam engine, a massive water wheel, a hotel and shops.

Open daily 11am-5pm. £3.75/£2.50/ family £9.95/£12.50. Lanark, Scotland (01555 661345).

fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: The latest conditions from the slopes
fields.body:
Most resorts have had extremely low temperatures, bright sunny weather and great skiing and boarding. More snow is forecast for the French Alps and the Italian Dolomites bringing poor visibility but refreshing the lower slopes.

Austria

Bright, cold weather, but some slopes are becoming worn.

France

Some new snow has refreshed the higher pistes, but rocks are showing through lower down.

Switzerland

Regular snow falls mean the best snow cover in Europe.

Italy

Low temperatures have helped maintain excellent conditions.

Andorra

Much-needed snow at last. Some lower slopes are still slushy.

North America

With new snow in Colorado and Utah, the week ahead looks very promising. Some Canadian resorts are still waiting for the big powder dumps they are famous for, but snow cover is still good.

For the latest snow conditions in more than 250 resorts, check out www.skiclub.co.uk

fields.headline: Ski tips
fields.trailText: Handy hints for the snow-bound traveller
fields.body:
* Moves are afoot to ban heli-skiing in Italy, according to the non-governmental environmental group CIPRA (Commission Internationale pour la Protection des Alpes).

Helicopter companies are barred from landing skiers on mountain tops across the border in France, though they are able to operate scenic flights and to carry passengers between some resorts.

The Italians have been more relaxed about it, but the authorities there have been coming under heavy pressure from environmentalists, who argue that just one flight over remote slopes can cause serious disturbance to wildlife across an entire valley.

The Italian senate has voted in favour of a law preventing landings and take-offs - and overflights less than 550m above ground - in the Alps and Apennines . In the former it applies at 1,500m above sea level, in the latter at over 1,000m. The only exceptions would be rescue and training operations, and flights to re-provision mountain huts and restaurants, or to carry out construction work that cannot be completed any other way.

Andreas Götz, director of the Liechtenstein-based CIPRA, says he expects the law to be ratified by Italy's chamber of deputies later this year.

* Self-catering specialist Interhome (020-8891 1294 www.interhome.com) is knocking 30% off the weekly price of some accommodation in the Alps for customers booking less than a week before they travel.

In the French resort of Les Deux Alpes , the price of a two-room apartment sleeping up to five people, for a week starting January 27), has been cut from £272 to £195. Two-room apartments for up to four people in Megève and Chtel are down from £254 to £183, and from £271 to £197 respectively.

In Switzerland, the price of a studio for up to three people drops from £423 to £313, and an apartment for up to six in Crans Montana from £414 to £297. Discounts apply only to the property rental, although the firm can also arrange Channel car ferry and tunnel crossings for £190.

* For skiers inclined to take off independently for North America, transatlantic air fares again look attractive this season.

Non-stop midweek return flights with British Airways from Gatwick to Denver are on offer for £267.20 and from Heathrow to Boston for £199. There are respective supplements of £10 and £4 each way if you fly at weekends. You must book by January 29 and fly out by the end of next month, staying at least one Saturday night. Trailfinders (020-7937 5400) can offer the Boston deal for £195. It also has TWA flights to Vancouver via St Louis for £271, also with a minimum stay of one Saturday night, and charter seats to Calgary on Canada 3000 for £315. Both deals are from Gatwick and are available for departures until April 6 and March 24 respectively. Remember that the week beginning February 17 is a particularly busy US holiday period, which also means Canadian resorts are crowded, so book accommodation before you go. The same applies to British Columbia in late March.

* Airtours (0800 0288844) is offering a day's skiing in the French resort of Chamonix for £89 - half the original price - including a return flight from Manchester on Monday, February 5 and transfers. Weather and air traffic control allowing, you depart at 7am and arrive in Chamonix at about 11am, which leaves time for about six hours on the snow. A lift pass and ski and boot hire cost around £40 and can be arranged on the coach from the airport.

* The Swiss resort of Arosa stages its hot-air balloon festival next weekend (January 27). Inghams (020-8780 4400 www.inghams.com) can provide a weekend there for £351, or a week for £491, with flights from Heathrow and train transfers. For a supplement, you can also fly from Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds-Bradford, Bristol, Sheffield, Newcastle or Glasgow.

fields.headline: Hard dazed night
fields.standfirst: Andrew Gilchrist goes to the Catalan capital for 12 hours to check out the club scene
fields.trailText: Andrew Gilchrist goes to Barcelona for 12 hours to check out the club scene
fields.body:
Friday 11pm Thirty minutes after the plane touches down, we find ourselves in Benidorm. Not Benidorm on the Costa del Sol, but a retro bar of the same name on Barcelona's Carrera de Joaquin Costa. Spookily decorated in the style of a 50s sitting room - with hostess trolleys, Bakelite fittings and weird family portraits hanging on drab flock wallpapered walls - this drinking den is stuffed with young Spaniards, for some reason passing wigs around without laughter or comment, as if it's the most normal thing to do in Barcelona on a Friday night. Maybe it is. Curly wigs, silver wigs - there's even a kinky bloke in a silk balaclava, dancing to Fame under a tiny glitterball. Barcelona is famous for its top-class museums and great restaurants, but we've come to the capital of Catalonia to sample its legendary nightlife, an idea that only starts to make sense after we sink a few beers and a few glasses of red wine with Coca-Cola (all the rage in Spain right now, according to, well, an Australian at the bar).

1am Next is Bar Iposa, a cool, orange and white-tiled split-level bar on a tree-lined square. Then it's on to La Rambla, a kaleidoscopic mile-long boulevard where you'll find cafés, restaurants, kiosks, shopfronts with splendid art nouveau lettering, plus, of course, hordes of revellers, diners, buskers, prostitutes and transvestites. There's a faint scent of the sea as we turn a corner and enter Bar Marsella, where they sell absinthe for Pta500 (£1.90) a glass. This is a fine atmospheric establishment, with peeling paint, faded wood trim, a long marble-top bar, mirrored glass cabinets holding dusty old bottles . . . and a barman from Motherwell. It's a young crowd, well-dressed, lots of black round necks and chunky leather jackets. Already they've had two hours more drinking time than English pubs get on a Friday but all around is friendly clatter and chat, not fists and broken glass.

2.30am More red wine and Cokes, this time in the London Bar, which is as long and narrow as three train carriages end to end but with much less atmosphere. All continental class and character seems to have evaporated in the sweaty chaos, although there is a woman through the back singing Spanish songs - but not loud enough to drown out all the British accents. 3am If you keeled over in Moog and spent the whole evening lying on your back, you could still have a good time in this medium-sized, kicking nightclub thanks to the leopard-skin ceiling over the upstairs dancefloor. Here, exceedingly young Spaniards, most of whom should be tucked up in bed, are dancing to loud, cheesy disco in loud, cheesy clothes. Meanwhile, downstairs, a bunch of DJs in what seems to be a reinforced air-raid shelter are bombarding the 200 or so people packed on to the dancefloor with a raw mixture of house, garage and God knows what else.

3.40am We take a taxi along wide open boulevards towards the waterfront, glimpsing the tips of tall ships above swaying palm trees, and then on to what is reputed to be one of Barcelona's best nightclubs: the mighty Woman Caballero.

4am Now this really is something. Everything about Woman Caballero is on a grand scale, from the hefty measures of spirits the bar staff unleash into glasses six inches tall to the Ducados cigarette machine in the foyer that's the size of a small boat. And then there's the dancefloor, sorry, the first dancefloor, so big that it feels outdoor. Finley Quaye gets the floor packed; then M People clear it in seconds.

4.45am Take a wrong turn and stumble across the salsa room, a more intimate place with blue and yellow tiles, beautifully ornate mosaics, carpets hanging from the walls - and hypnotic dancing. The wildly energetic bartender slams golfball-shaped ice into a glass and pounds the counter as a group of young girls in neat, white, sleeveless shirts spring into a sort of three-way salsa-cum-belly-dance.

5am Get lost.

5.15am Get lost again.

5.30am Completing the feeling that this is actually a giant mall and not a nightclub, there's a sizeable jewellery stall in one of the corridors. Beyond that - past a couple on a couch engaged in a marathon snogging session that seems to involve everything except coming up for air - the hardcore room is to be found. There, the music is loud, fast and furious, and, as a precaution, the pillars around the dancefloor are padded.

6am Woman Caballero is still going strong but there is talk of going to the beach where, apparently, there are some other clubs opening shortly. Opening? Does no one here sleep? Surely when the sun comes up they call it a day. But no, this is Barcelona, and tonight it seems as if every one of the city's 1.7m inhabitants is out on the town. Sadly, we've got a plane to catch.

6.30am "Basta ya de ruidos", says a sign outside the nearby station café, where we sit sipping café con leche and munching churros. "Enough of the noise," reads the translation underneath. It seems a pretty good idea. Our ears are ringing, our limbs are weary and our clothes are drenched with sweat. We look as if we've just been washed ashore.

7am The sun is coming up, casting a warm hue over the city. Out over the Mediterranean, purple clouds are heaping up on the horizon and, beneath them, the sky is like a strip of copper resting on the still blue sea. It's a staggering sight in a city of staggering sights. Resolving to stay longer next time, we hail a cab and head for the airport.

11am Arrive back home.

11.01am Sleep.

The practicals

Andrew Gilchrist flew to Barcelona with STA Travel (0870 1606070, www.statravel.co.uk), which offers return fares from Heathrow to Barcelona with British Midland starting from £117 (inc tax) and accommodation starting from £17pp per night. The fare is open to all and must be booked and paid for by January 31. STA Travel specialises in student and youth travel with 250 branches worldwide.

fields.headline: Playing the field
fields.standfirst: Paul McFarland gets active in Europe's biggest sports resort
fields.trailText: Paul McFarland gets active in La Manga, Europe's biggest sports resort.
fields.body:
It was raining when we left Gatwick, dousing the vestigial guilt we had been feeling as we abandoned the children to the care of a cousin and headed for sun, sand, sea and - exercise.

We were on our way to La Manga Club, an oasis in the southern Spanish desert - a valley of lemon groves surrounded by rich, red rock, where only 6-12 inches of rain fall each year and even in January the daytime temperature averages 18C.

The immediate countryside includes dramatic lunar landscapes, spectacular beaches and a huge inland sea. Within easy reach, the 2,500-year-old port of Cartagena offers shopping and sightseeing. But if you wish, you need never stray beyond the discreetly patrolled tree-lined streets that link tennis, golf and swimming to hotel, apartments and restaurants.

An American first opened a country club here in the 1970s, and went bust trying to make it work. Its success as a holiday centre dates from the late 1980s when P&O bought the resort and turned it into something between the opulence of Boca Raton in Florida and the domesticity of the Pierre et Vacances holiday villages of Brittany.

The main hotel is everything a five-star holiday hotel should be - spacious, beautifully decorated, yet relaxed enough that you don't feel self-conscious in your less than pristine shorts and with swimming-pool hair sticking out at all angles. Not so luxurious but very comfortable are the 60 Las Lomas self-catering apartments in a neat terraced village.

The rest of the resort is made up of some 1,600 privately-owned villas and apartments; some are time-shares, some are bolt-holes for owners, and some are semi-permanent residences. The vast majority of visitors are British, and the other cold bits of Europe - Germany and Scandinavia -are much in evidence, though a quarter of visitors are Spanish.

The Club has more than 20 places to eat. Within the hotel are serious gourmet dining at the Amapola restaurant and snacks and light meals in the lively bars. Elsewhere, cafés and restaurants are clustered at Las Lomas, at the tennis centre, and in the commercial square. You can choose from Spanish, Italian, Mexican, seafood and "Euromerican" - burgers and chips. Self-caterers can stock up at the resort's new supermarket.

The whole La Manga complex covers 1,400 acres - larger than Monaco. This gives it the scale to sustain an enormous range and quality of leisure facilities, restaurants and social activities, but the downside is that activities that would be five minutes' walk apart in a typical holiday village can take three of four times as long to reach. There are occasional small shuttle buses but, not surprisingly, many visitors rely on cars to get around the site. This might disappoint parents with small children looking for a relaxed, car-free and safe environment, though the parents we spoke to seemed perfectly happy.

The facilities, particularly golf and tennis, are hard to equal anywhere in Europe, and are designed not just for the holiday family but for the professionals. Some weeks, the club hosts major sporting events - five Spanish golf Opens, Federation Cup tennis, the Nordic Soccer Cup (national teams playing a winter tournament); and club and national squads use the eight-pitch football centre for training weeks.

Barwell Leisure (020-8786 3000, www.barwell.com) specialises in La Manga packages. The same packages at Las Lomas, based on six sharing a self-catering apartment, would cost £318, £338 and £398 respectively. Renting a Ford Ka costs about £25 a day from Centauro's in La Manga village. Green fees for 18 holes are £30 plus, extra for the hire of clubs, trolleys etc. Pitch-and-putt course is £5. Tennis costs £10 per hour, gym and spa £8 an hour, boules £1.40 an hour, bowling £4.50 an hour. Further information: www.lamangaclub.com and www.lamanga.com.

fields.headline: Website of the week
fields.standfirst: www.thomson.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.thomson.co.uk
fields.body:
That rings a bell.

No, you're thinking of Thomas Cook, which recently relaunched its site - I'll review that one next week. But it's not surprising that you're confused. Thomson may claim to be number one in the travel business ("Let No 1 look after you"), but it also owns Lunn Poly, Crystal, Budget Travel, Britannia Airways, the Holiday Cottages Group and Fritidsresor, a Stockholm-based operation.

But even the Thomson site has around a dozen sections.

Indeed. Thomson Weddings, Thomson Sports Resorts, Thomson Ski and Snowboarding, Thomson Young at Heart - the list goes on and on. The trouble is that these are all show sites - you can look, but you can't buy. To book, you'll have to go to a travel agent or ring the hotline.

I just want a very cheap holiday at the last minute.

The cheapest option listed was a self-catering week in "TLS" for £129 with accommodation allocated on arrival. I called the Thomson Direct line. "I'd really like to book this holiday," I lied. "But I wondered where TLS was?"

And the result?

"TLS? I'm afraid I don't know," came the reply. "It's maybe just an airfare to Tenerife. I've got one here for £99. But there's nothing coming up on the system for that date from Stansted at that price. Maybe it's already been sold."

Maybe it was Torremolinos?

Who knows? To be fair, I could have chosen the equally mysterious TRN for £139. Perhaps Thomson should start a Mystery Holidays site with the stag weekend market in mind.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Matt
fields.trailText: I am working in Melbourne at the moment. I have just spent six months in Sydney, but would seriously recomend getting down here. It's not as pretty but a lot more fun.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

I am currently on a little holiday myself and am working in Melbourne at the moment. I have just spent six months in Sydney, but would seriously recomend getting down here. It's not as pretty but a lot more fun.

The reason I was writing was to say that if you can time it right you should try and check out the total eclipse running through Africa (about the bottom of Madagascar and corresponding parts of the mainland) on June 21 this year. It won't be anything like the one in Cornwall! For more info see NASA's website.

Anyway, have fun and happy travels.

Matt

webTitle: Soccer scheme seeks to put reading on side

fields.headline: Soccer scheme seeks to put reading on side
fields.standfirst:
Football Unlimited
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: If it is Tottenham Hotspur, then it is books about the Wild West, but if it is Chelsea, then literary works about travelling are appropriate, given the west London club's contingent of foreign players.
fields.body:
If it is Tottenham Hotspur, then it is books about the Wild West, but if it is Chelsea, then literary works about travelling are appropriate, given the west London club's contingent of foreign players.

This is how the thinking goes as football and literature unite in a scheme to improve children's reading by getting them interested in books associated with the nicknames of the 20 Premiership clubs or topics the clubs are known for.

The scheme, Premiership Reading Challenge, which is backed by the Department for Education, will encourage youngsters to read 20 books in the football season, one for each club in the league.

The reading list covers subjects linked to the clubs. Tottenham Hotspur - the Spurs - have books about the Wild West such as The Horse Whisperer and The Virginian.

Sunderland - the Black Cats - are linked with books about superstition, while West Ham United - the Hammers - have a reading list on DIY, including Changing Rooms, based on the BBC TV programme.

Chelsea have books such as Around the World in 80 Days, by Michael Palin, and Far Side of the World, by Patricia O'Brien. Coventry City, associated with car manufacturing, have opted for cars, while Newcastle United, given the rich history in the north-east, have opted for historical books.

The scheme was launched in Walsall by the Aston Villa player Paul Merson and is to go nationwide this year. It was devised by a Walsall librarian, who found that linking books to football clubs increased interest in reading, particularly among young boys.

To join the scheme, a pre-season contract has to be signed with a local library, where members promise to fulfil 20 fixtures: that is, read 20 books during a season. Prizes are awarded to those who complete the assignment or get through the most books.

Some topics chosen by clubs speak volumes for how they perceive themselves. Bradford City - the Bantams - who are bottom of the Premiership and consider themselves lucky to be among English football's elite, have chosen books on folk tales and fantasy.

Liverpool - the Reds - have opted for books on humour, given the famous Scouse wit, while Ipswich, an unfashionable club riding high in the Premiership, have gone for books on the supernatural - perhaps seeing other forces at work in their good fortune.

The reading scheme is one of a number of initiatives to get young football fans interested in education. Learning centres at clubs around the country have proved hugely successful, increasing literacy and numeracy among boys in particular.

Dan Johnson, Premier League spokesman, said: "Learning is about motivation, and football certainly gets people motivated. It acts as a catalyst, and can make reading and education a lot more interesting."

webTitle: Wendy Holden: Earplugs | Perfume | Her husband

fields.headline: Wendy Holden never travels without...
fields.trailText: Earplugs | Perfume | Her husband
fields.body:
A necessity: Earplugs. I travel a lot on trains and get annoyed with people speaking loudly on their mobile phones while I am trying to read. It's a control-freak way of ensuring peace where ever I go.

A luxury: My Jo Malone amber and lavender perfume because it makes everywhere I go smell amazing.

A good luck charm: My husband because he makes everything go well, never loses his cool and is the perfect travelling companion.

If only: I could find the perfect mosquito repellent or even if mosquitoes suddenly found me repellent.

Pastures Nouveaux, by Wendy Holden, is published by Headline at £10

fields.headline: Go with the flow
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Steele warms up on a volcanic island
fields.trailText: Jonathan Steele warms up on a volcanic island
fields.body:
Guaranteed winter sunshine. No jetlag. Less than four hours of flight-time to get there. The magnet of the Canaries, so near and yet so sunny, was too much to resist in a cold, wet English December.

This is the European Union's southernmost tip. It has Spanish language and cuisine but a winter temperature that averages 21C, around four degrees warmer than southern Spain, and those few degrees make a big difference.

We chose Lanzarote, the most easterly island of the chain and according to the experts the most exotic. While all the Canary Islands have their extinct volcanoes, Lanzarote is dominated by them. Every hill is conical, and many have that sinister broken crater's edge where streams of lava once spilled over and poured across the landscape. The last eruption occurred in 1824.

The ground is mostly infertile, and with its minimal rainfall the island has the misfortune of not having a single river or stream. Fresh water has to be pumped from wells or wrung out of the sea via desalinisation plants.

In this wild environment ("moonscape", as no tourist brochure can avoid putting it) the few palm trees or flowering cacti that manage to take root have a special charm. But the attraction is the coast, and as it only takes an hour to drive from one end of the island to the other, and half that time to cross, you are never far from the sea. In most places, the sand is a respectable yellow, and only a few beaches have the tell-tale black sand of lava deposits.

The oldest resort, Puerto del Carmen, has several miles of yellow sand as well as a pleasant small cove, Playa Chica, near the yachting harbour. Most of the package tours concentrate here or at Playa Blanca on the south coast. But with a rented car you can get to the quieter beaches of El Papagayo along a dirt track to the east of Playa Blanca. This area was turned into a national park a few years ago to stop any risk of coastal ribbon development. Yet even before then, Lanzarote had managed to avoid the damage done by uncontrolled building.

The hero was a draconian figure called Cesar Manrique, who has left his stamp all over his native island. An internationally-acclaimed architect and artist, he was friendly with the island's political leadership and used his influence to ensure that development was strictly regulated and the island's character preserved.

High-rise building and advertising hoardings were banned. Every house, even in the remotest hamlet, had to be white-washed, its doors and window-frames painted green or blue.

We had intended to have a lazy week reading by the pool but found ourselves spending more time exploring the island. The volcano of Timanfaya is Lanzarote's main curiosity, and well worth a half-day excursion. At the El Diablo restaurant, those in quest for the ultimate culinary sensation can enjoy (besides the stunning view) chicken or beef grilled over the heat of the volcano.

Another fascinating volcanic excursion is to the Cueva de los Verdes, a tunnel-like cave formed by a prehistoric eruption. As it poured towards the sea, the river of lava cooled at the top and hardened, leaving a long tunnel underneath. But unlike caves in most other parts of the world, Lanzarote's minimal rainfall has left this one dry and a pleasant 18 degrees, and you can wander through in light clothes admiring the colours of the rocks.

One day, we drove to Lanzarote's most stunning beach, at Famara in the north-west. At the foot of beetling cliffs, this is a mile-long stretch of breakers on a wide curved bay, and a surfer's delight on days when the currents are not too strong.

Lanzarote is not "organised" for rambling and there are no officially marked trails, but by walking beyond the last house, we found a contour path about a third of the way up the cliffs. The breakers looked wonderful from above and in three hours we met only one other hiker.

Surrounded by the sea and with minimal opportunities for agriculture, Lanzarote's people mainly used to live off fish. Seafood is still the mainstay of the cuisine, although most of the shellfish that appears on every menu is flown in deep-frozen from elsewhere. The best local fish is cherne , which is unique to this part of the Atlantic and has a fine fleshy texture. Mero (grouper) and vieja are also local. To sample them at their best, head for one of the fishing villages rather than the larger tourist resorts.

At Orzola, at the northern tip of the island, we had an excellent meal at Os Gallegos. The fish is all freshly caught and came, as is common in most Lanzarote restaurants, accompanied by tiny potatoes which are cooked in their skins ( papas arrugadas ) and sprinkled with a red chilli sauce ( mojo rojo ). The three-course meal cost about £11 a head including wine.

In Puerto Calero, the quiet settlement of villas where we stayed, there is a choice of a dozen restaurants alongside the yachting marina. Most offer comfortable wicker-work armchairs at their alfresco tables. Our favourite was Don Quixote, which has a superb gazpacho starter and plenty of fish dishes. Here, too, a three-course meal cost little more than £11.

Tapas bars are everywhere. We liked La Lonja in the old port area of Puerto del Carmen, where locals also drop in and seem not to mind rubbing shoulders with tourists.

For a splurge, you cannot do better than the four-star Gran Melia Salinas in the resort of Costa Teguise. The building was conceived by the unavoidable Signor Manrique, and is centred on three courtyards filled with jungle trees, palms, lianas, and rustling streams. The style has since become a cliché elsewhere, but this early example is outstanding. The restaurant on the edge of Courtyard Three is first-class, and even here the price per person plus wine does not top £30.

Surprisingly, in view of its volcanic character, Lanzarote has its own wine. Nowhere in the world can vines be more lovingly tended. If you drive out to La Geria, you can marvel at the way the farmers dig a series of small round depressions in the volcanic black soil, and surround each one with a stone wall. The occasional rain is collected in the hole, the wind is kept at bay by the wall, and the year-round warmth and almost constant sunshine do the rest.

The resulting wine is more than passable, and had it not been for the insistent temptation to see as much of this unusual island as possible in the space of only seven days, we would have drunk a whole lot more of it.

The practicals

Meon Villas (01730-230370) has a range of four and five-star villas, starting from £344pp per week. Jonathan Steele stayed one week at the Villa Ramos, above Puerto Calero, which costs from £499pp, based on six sharing, including return flights, airport taxes, villa accommodation with private pool, welcome pack, weekly cleaning service, and car hire with unlimited mileage. For departures February 22 to April 4 the price is £585pp. In January and February, Meon Villas has special offers on selected four- and five-star villas in Lanzarote with savings of up to £247pp on one week bookings. For details, see Somewhere for now.

Seafood is still the mainstay of the cuisine, although most of the shellfish that appears on every menu is flown in deep-frozen from elsewhere. The best local fish is cherne , which is unique to this part of the Atlantic and has a fine fleshy texture. Mero (grouper) and vieja are also local. To sample them at their best, head for one of the fishing villages rather than the larger tourist resorts. At Orzola, at the northern tip of the island, we had an excellent meal at Os Gallegos. The fish is all freshly caught and came, as is common in most Lanzarote restaurants, accompanied by tiny potatoes which are cooked in their skins ( papas arrugadas ) and sprinkled with a red chilli sauce ( mojo rojo ). The three-course meal cost about £11 a head including wine. In Puerto Calero, the quiet settlement of villas where we stayed, there is a choice of a dozen restaurants alongside the yachting marina. Most offer comfortable wicker-work armchairs at their alfresco tables. Our favourite was Don Quixote, which has a superb gazpacho starter and plenty of fish dishes. Here, too, a three-course meal cost little more than £11. Tapas bars are everywhere. We liked La Lonja in the old port area of Puerto del Carmen, where locals also drop in and seem not to mind rubbing shoulders with tourists. For a splurge, you cannot do better than the four-star Gran Melia Salinas in the resort of Costa Teguise. The building was conceived by the unavoidable Signor Manrique, and is centred on three courtyards filled with jungle trees, palms, lianas, and rustling streams. The style has since become a cliché elsewhere, but this early example is outstanding. The restaurant on the edge of Courtyard Three is first-class, and even here the price per person plus wine does not top £30. Surprisingly, in view of its volcanic character, Lanzarote has its own wine. Nowhere in the world can vines be more lovingly tended. If you drive out to La Geria, you can marvel at the way the farmers dig a series of small round depressions in the volcanic black soil, and surround each one with a stone wall. The occasional rain is collected in the hole, the wind is kept at bay by the wall, and the year-round warmth and almost constant sunshine do the rest. The resulting wine is more than passable, and had it not been for the insistent temptation to see as much of this unusual island as possible in the space of only seven days, we would have drunk a whole lot more of it. The practicals Meon Villas (01730-230370) has a range of four and five-star villas, starting from £344pp per week. Jonathan Steele stayed one week at the Villa Ramos, above Puerto Calero, which costs from £499pp, based on six sharing, including return flights, airport taxes, villa accommodation with private pool, welcome pack, weekly cleaning service, and car hire with unlimited mileage. For departures February 22 to April 4 the price is £585pp. In January and February, Meon Villas has special offers on selected four- and five-star villas in Lanzarote with savings of up to £247pp on one week bookings. For details, see Somewhere for now.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.trailText: TP Cooper wants to know the easiest way to see the aurora borealis, preferably in Britain.
fields.body:
* TP Cooper wants to know the easiest way to see the aurora borealis, preferably in Britain.

Really good displays of the aurora borealis, the Northern Lights, are fairly uncommon in the UK, and are certainly better the further north you go. However, I would recommend that TP Cooper visits the website set up by physicists at York university who are studying the phenomenon. Not only is there a lot of information and some great photographs on www.aurorawatch.york.ac.uk but if you register with the site, they will e-mail you or send text messages to your mobile phone to alert you that the aurora are likely to occur and when and where will be the best time and place to see them.

Dave Taylor

If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: ask.a .fellow.traveller@theguardian.com.

I have seen spectacular aurora while staying on two campsites some 170 miles apart in Scotland. Both were on the edge of the clifftops, one at Applecross overlooking Skye and the Western Isles - the other at Thurso near John O'Groats. There are some good photographs at www.netreal.co.uk/aurora/index3 htm, taken from Fortrose near Inverness.

Norman Meyer

The best place to see the aurora borealis in Britain is in the Shetland Islands. Clear, frosty nights are the best time, so you need to look at the weather forecast beforehand, and even then you may not be guaranteed a sighting. Once there, you would have to keep watch, since the aurora can happen in a fleeting moment or last, on and off, for a whole night.Shetland is, however, a very expensive place to get to. You can fly from Aberdeen airport (one-hour flight, from £89 return, British Airways 0845 7733377) or take the overnight P&O ferry from Aberdeen (01224 572615), from £104 return. Once in Shetland, accommodation is relatively cheap. Since seeing the aurora is not guaranteed, it may be good to combine a winter visit with Up Helly Aa - the Viking fire festival held on the last Tuesday in January - a torch-lit procession casting an aurora-like glow across the night sky.

Janet Askew

This week's question

* My family and I would like to visit Cuba for a holiday. Will our passports be stamped on entry to/exit from Cuba; and, if so, will that make later visits to the USA difficult or impossible in view of the persisting US embargo?

Richard Davies QC

If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: ask.a .fellow.traveller@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Tapas dancing
fields.standfirst: Mark Mann enjoys northern hospitality in the bars of Logroño
fields.trailText: Mark Mann enjoys northern hospitality in the bars of Logroño.
fields.body:
There's a bar in Logroño's Calle Laurel that specialises in criadillas - fluffy meatballs, deep-fried in a light batter and served with a garlic and tomato sauce. When I say meatballs, I mean it in the most literal way, for criadillas are bull's testicles. Still, if that's not to your taste, there's always the Bar Soriano next door. It serves nothing but mushrooms; grilled, dripping with garlic and delicious.

That's the great thing about the tapas bars in Logroño. If you don't like what's served in one, you can always try the one next door. Or the one next to that. In fact, along the narrow, pedes trianised Calle Laurel in the town's old quarter, it's literally wall-to-wall tapas bars. Most specialise in one particular dish, such as the Soriano.

Along the main street there's everything on offer, from cured ham and pork chops to stuffed peppers and grilled aubergines, from Spanish omelettes to spicy mussels, and a local night out is something my Spanish friend Patricia calls chiquiteo , or "tapas-hopping" - a bar-crawl with food thrown in.

The tapas bars in Calle Laurel don't necessarily serve the best dishes in Logroño. For that, you need to look further afield, such as the Bar Tahiti in Avenida Republica Argentina, whose Spanish omelette was recently judged fourth best in Spain. What they have in spades is atmosphere - at 10pm on a Friday or Saturday night, the whole street is bursting with people, noise and garlicky aromas. The crowd is made up of revellers of all ages. There are constant shrieks and laughter as people bump into their friends. We begin as a threesome and end up with about a dozen of Patricia's friends - although after my 10th glass of wine it became increasingly difficult to work out exactly who was in our group.

Logroño is the capital of La Rioja, situated in northern Spain where the Castilian centre meets the Basque country. An hour and a half's drive south of Bilbao, the region is virtually unknown to British tourists. Guidebooks give it the most cursory of mentions, or often none at all. Admittedly, it lacks the celebrated history of, say, Toledo or Seville, or the buzz of Barcelona, but, if you want to explore an authentic slice of rural Spain, this is the place for you.

Not that the region is short of history. Logroño itself was devastated by El Cid in 1092, and the province is rich in monasteries, churches, castles and medieval walled towns.

However for me, the real treasures of La Rioja are the sierras. True, this isn't the Pyrenees, and the hills are more rolling than alpine, but it is high enough - over 2,000m in places - to have its own ski resort, at Valdezcaray near Ezcaray. There are lovely walks through mountain woodland, cycle rides along forest tracks and days to be spent exploring remote mountain villages. The day after our tapas hopping, we headed to one such village, Villoslada de Cameros, where Patricia's family owns a house.

Wool made Villoslada one of the richest villages in Europe before Australian imports flooded the market in the 1800s. In the 20th century, the inhabitants of Villoslada and other nearby villages abandoned the countryside for the cities. The rural exodus reached such a level that one village was left with only two inhabitants - a brother and sister who apparently didn't talk to each other.

Recently, though, the children of those who moved away started renovating the crumbling stone houses for use as summer homes. A fledgling tourist industry has developed, catering mainly to Spanish city-dwellers in search of fresh air and rural ambience.

La Rioja has much the same appeal as, say, Tuscany or inland Provence: sun, rolling hills, great food and wine, but it is not overrun with middle-class Brits. So at the moment you can have La Rioja's vineyards, forests and villages virtually to yourself. And as many bull's testicles as you can eat.

What to eat and where to find it

The word tapas literally means lid and derives from an old custom of serving wine in jugs topped with a piece of food that formed an edible lid. Tapas comes in four basic forms. The smallest and cheapest are nibbles such as stuffed olives or shrimps, eaten with your fingers. Pinchos are a little more substantial such as garlic mushrooms or grilled meat kebabs, served on skewers. Cazuelas are mini-stews such as patatas bravas (spicy potatoes) served in small clay dishes. Finally there are bocadillos - sandwiches - although most tapas come with a chunk of bread to soak up the oil and garlic.

House specialities are advertised on boards or incorporated in the name of the bar (El Jamonero, for instance). Alternatively, watch what the other customers order.

Rioja's cuisine is characterised by abundant fruit and vegetables (asparagus, artichokes, red peppers, peaches, pears) and meat - particularly pork in various forms, from chorizo and jamon de serrano (like Parma ham) to grilled chops and stews.

Regional specialities include cabrito (grilled baby goat), pimientos rellenos (grilled stuffed peppers), pochas (white bean stew), caparrones (another bean stew with chorizo) and fardelejos (pastry parcels with an almond-paste filling). As you might expect, olive oil, garlic and tomatoes feature prominently.

Wines are mainly red and range from the standard origen calificada to the superior crianza, reserva and gran reserva levels. Gran reserva (aged for two years in oak casks and three years in the bottle for reds, four in total for whites) is tops, although we're talking up to £30 or £40 a bottle. The outstanding recent vintages were 1994 and 1995.

One of La Rioja's best restaurants is the Hotel Echaurren (2 Héroes del Alcázar, 941 35 40 47), in Ezcaray. Plaza 6 in Fuenmayor (lunchtime only) is recommended for its menestra, a local vegetable stew. Other good restaurants include Meson Beethoven (Calle Santo Tomas) and Terefe (17 Lucrecia Arana) in Haro, and Sopitas in Arnedo. In Logroño, try Avenida 21 (21 Avenida de Portugal) and La Chatilla de San Augustin (6 Calle San Augustin), or En Ascus (22 Hermanos Moroy), which specialises in mixed pork grills.

Whether it's tapas or a restaurant, remember that the locals rarely eat before 9pm.

The practicals

Iberia (0845 6012854) flies London Heathrow to Bilbao from £100 return. P&O Portsmouth (02392 301000, www.poportsmouth.com) sails twice a week to Bilbao from Southampton. A five-day supersaver for a car and up to nine passengers costs from £99. Logroño is 90 minutes' by car from Bilbao on the A68 autopista. Logroño tourist office: Paseo del Espolon, 941 29 12 60 (www.larioja.com).

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Insider's information supplied by fellow readers
fields.body:
* Try to cross tricky borders on a weekday instead of a weekend in case you need to call the British Embassy for assistance.

Malika Browne

* If you want to do voluntary conservation work abroad, contact the country's National Parks office directly. For $7 a day (all in) I worked at several parks in Costa Rica alongside volunteers who had paid a fortune for the privilege.

Sue Coin

* To make yourself instantly popular with the locals, learn a football chant pertinent to the area. This causes great amusement and may get you free drinks. Be aware that if you choose the wrong chant, you may be lynched.

Alison Crane

* Norman Meyer is not impressed by Kevin Joynson's comment on December 30 that hand-tight wheel nuts are a recipe for disaster. "Yes they are," he writes, "but so also are the nuts done up by many compressed-air powered tools - you try and undo them on a motorway hard shoulder in the snow!" He suggests you buy a torque wrench and ensure that the hire company tightens the nuts to the manufacturers recommended torque-wrench settings.

If you have a tip you would like to share with your fellow readers please send your idea to: Travel Tip, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or e-mail us at: travel.tips @theguardian.com.Every reader whose tip we use receives a Rough Guide of their choice.

webTitle: Gilles and His Family, Jean-Antoine Watteau (c. 1716-18)

fields.headline: Gilles and His Family, Jean-Antoine Watteau (c. 1716-18)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Jean-Antoine Watteau (1684-1721) was born in Valenciennes, the son of a roofer. In 1702 he travelled to Paris, joined the studio of Claude Gillot, and then emerged as the supreme exponent of the hedonist and decorative rococo style.

Watteau never fitted into the world of the court: he rejected would-be patrons and at one stage lived in England, with its freer social codes. Here, it was said, he acquired a taste for reckless expenditure, while the sooty atmosphere worsened his tubercular condition. A friend warned him that he took too many risks. "If all else fails," he replied, "is there not the hospital? It doesn't refuse anyone." Watteau, as he seems to have expected, died young.

Subject: In theory, the central figure is Gilles or Pierrot, a stock character in the commedia dell'arte, popular at court in the early 18th century. The inclusion of his "family", however, suggests that instead of a scene on stage, this is a group portrait of itinerant players. Another possibility is that these are Watteau's friends dressing up.

Distinguishing features: This clown looks wanly at us. His fingers strumming his guitar are as tapered as those of an El Greco saint, and their boniness doesn't suggest the fun of the fair but a life of pain. His face is podgy and unshaven and, with its big-nosed clumsiness, definitely does not suggest the refined beauty of the court. He's a low character, a popular entertainer, and his family are equally ordinary: the sad girl on the left and the grey-haired, plump-faced woman to his right (his wife?) would never be accepted among the beautiful young things in the fêtes galantes - scenes of pastoral carousing that Watteau painted to huge acclaim. They are from the world from which the artist came and that he never quite seems to have left.

Watteau was friends with actors and clowns. He painted the figure of Gilles repeatedly; the famous full-length painting in the Louvre, in which the player stands alone in his white suit, may have been a signboard for a Paris cafe.

Watteau's paintings were collected by monarchs. Yet, in all, there are tense intrusions of the real, whether it is the violence of desire or the sadness of experience. The paintings that might help us to understand Gilles and His Family, though, are Watteau's little-known genre scenes of soldiers, such as The Gate of Valenciennes. Watteau's soldiers inhabit a brown-hued world of picturesque ruins but they are anything but picturesque: they are real, frightened, bored. Similarly, the masked caryatids carved in the arch behind Gilles denote the world of theatre and fantasy, of putting on false faces, becoming other, and of sexual abandon.

Yet Gilles, who stands directly under the sculpted face, forcing a comparison, is clearly nothing like that. His face is lumpenly his own. His family are his responsibility. His family, his community of players, is what matters to him; this is different from other paintings of Gilles because, instead of being set apart from the group, he is among them (he is also older). Reality undercuts the world of the rococo. Gilles is an ordinary man supporting his family, and he does this by dressing as a harlequin, wearing finery not for his pleasure but the crowd's, playing music to accompany games of desire that are not his own. This could ultimately be a self-portrait.

Inspirations and influences: Watteau was influenced by the carnival scenes of his teacher Claude Gillot (1673-1722). Watteau's paintings, in turn, fascinated not only 18th-century artists such as Gainsborough and Reynolds but modern artists too, as can be seen in Picasso's La Famille de Saltimbanques (1905).

Where is it? The Wallace Collection, London W1 (020-7935 0687).

Gilles is an ordinary man supporting his family, and he does this by dressing as a harlequin, wearing finery not for his pleasure but the crowd's, playing music to accompany games of desire that are not his own. This could ultimately be a self-portrait. Inspirations and influences: Watteau was influenced by the carnival scenes of his teacher Claude Gillot (1673-1722). Watteau's paintings, in turn, fascinated not only 18th-century artists such as Gainsborough and Reynolds but modern artists too, as can be seen in Picasso's La Famille de Saltimbanques (1905). Where is it? The Wallace Collection, London W1 (020-7935 0687).

fields.body:
The Memoir as Self-Destruction Aspect

This Aspect turned out to be much too prescient. I truly felt while writing the book that actually publishing it would be the end of me. I thought that a) the book would alienate me from my friends and relatives, even those who had read it well before publication and provided approval; and b) the book would enrage many readers for one reason or another, and would compel them to come and kill me. In October of 1998, when I started working in earnest on finishing the book's original text, and was poring through hundreds of journal entries, I called my brother Bill at about 4am one night and talked into his machine for a while about what should happen to these entries should I get hit by a train or blown up in an airplane or, most likely, killed by a man in an elevator, wearing a trenchcoat. (For years I feared the opening of every elevator, half-convinced that from the opened doors would come a bullet, for me, shot by a man in a tan trenchcoat. I have no idea why I feared this, expected it to happen. I even knew how I would react to this bullet coming from the elevator door, what word I would say. That word was: Finally.)

So I told Bill not to worry, that I was not suicidal, never that - when we leave such messages, we always have to render the boundaries immediately, so as not to provoke worry - but that, should anything happen, that under no circumstances was anyone to be allowed to see any of my journal entries, that even if behavioural scientists begged for them, that he was not to release them, and under no circumstances was he to compile any unfinished stuff, edit it without mercy and make it into a book about a safari-oriented ménage à trois.

The call to Bill reflected both my usual death-paranoia and also the fact that around that time the creation of the book began to seem eerily like a coming, self-induced death, probably a violent one. As if I'd been diagnosed with something horrible, something quick and unmerciful, ebola maybe, and that I was heading toward its inevitable result with no options other than to allow it to eat me from the inside out, liquefy my innards - or else take matters into my own hands and beat the ebola to the punch. I began to wonder why there are so many symptomatic similarities between the way I was thinking, and the way I'd read that suicidal people feel. I woke up late each day, I showered occasionally, I did not clean my house...

Yes, none of these things was new, but other things were. Chiefly, when I thought about suicide, it no longer seemed like such a foreign concept, such a remote possibility. The impulse toward suicide began to seem like something that could creep up on me, something that was more plausible than before, and something that might seem increasingly plausible in the future. I was tired, and my water-treading abilities seemed to be weakening. Then of course there was the likelihood, more glamorous and self-serving for someone begotten by a Catholic martyr, that someone would kill me, as I kept picturing. And oddly enough, when not picturing it happening from the cavity of a closing elevator, I envisioned it occurring, fittingly enough, at a reading.

In one of my many such daydreams, there was a recurring image of a man in a raincoat pushing through the assembled with a snub-nosed pistol and, once close enough, shooting me square in the chest. In the scenario, which was for some reason always set in the back portion of Rose Records, a music-purveying shop on Green Street in Champaign, Illinois, I always vacillate between a) jumping under the desk and avoiding the shots long enough for him to be wrestled to the ground by... by bookstore security, I guess; and b) the reaction that seems to make more sense: I sit up straight and offer my chest to him, take the bullet, and am killed.

So because I knew that many people would be saddened by the appearance of this book - those who cared about my father, for instance, and feel I was unfair - I figured that, after its publication, I'd be in hiding somewhere, that I would disappear - to safety! Right. So, the visions and their increased dream-to-life probability brought to mind what I used to tell Toph, when he would come to me when he couldn't sleep, when he was terrified, as I was, at age nine, of death, not of imminent death but any death at all, eventual death, the fact of death somehow more tangible at nine than at 30 or 50 - he, like I did at his age, saw the door of life closing already, however distantly and slowly, and couldn't bring himself to sleep, and so, sitting on the couch in our place in Berkeley, we had to talk about the afterlife, and my explanation to him at that point was this: "Well, Toph, I do believe in some sort of afterlife, I suppose because it just seems more logical that there is one than there is not. I mean, if we can so clearly conceive of it, if so many disparate (no I didn't use that word at the time) peoples can conceive of it, then it almost means that there must be..." Etc.

And that's how I had come to think about imminent and violent death, the shot from the man in the elevator or at the reading: because I saw it so often, and it was beginning to make more and more sense, to seem less and less fantastical, then it almost followed that it was more likely than before, that it had been pre-ordained, mapped out more or less, given a time frame, scheduled, and I had been simply watching previews of something coming, without equivocation, soon.

There is, intrinsic to the process of a memoir, the resulting destruction of one's former self. Writing about those years, and being as cruel to who I was as I could be, implicitly means that you are killing that person. Yes, you are sometimes celebrating that person's better moments, and relating with sympathy that person's better thoughts, but overall you are saying: This was me then, and I can look at that person, from the distance I now have, and throw water balloons on his stupid fat head. But even as good an idea as that seems to be, an idea attractive to the intellectually violent, it is also a very painful plan to carry out, and one that is rebelled against, by various self-preservative internal forces. Which is not to say anything of what happens once those thoughts are read and processed by the public at large. However much I tried to make happen the things I wanted to happen, and however much I tried to prevent things from happening that I hoped would not, they happened anyway.

It was, for the most part, very entertaining. Were parts of the process incredibly painful? They were. I wrote a book in large part about the deaths of my parents, and living with my brother thereafter, and this, inexplicably, brought out in a very few people a kind of malice that I have rarely seen. Very strange. But it was not entirely unexpected. The weird thing is that while writing the original text, I had in my head not the usual Writer's Ideal Reader, but instead my own potential reading person, the Mean/Jaded/Skimming Reader - the person I had been for many years. Thus I expected the worst from the book's readers, I expected claws and blood and teeth. The book ends with a plea for those who would tear into me to just go ahead and do it, because I wanted it to happen, finally.

But then a weird thing happened: People were kind. It was almost impossible to find people who were as vicious and small as I had for many years been. Not completely impossible, but still: I expected crucifixion and instead got something more like its opposite.

Where is your brother?

This happened: At a reading in Portland, I read the passage involving the being-annoyed-at-being-asked this question part, and, immediately afterward, a middle-aged woman in the third row raised her hand and asked, in English but with what sounded like a German accent: So where iz ya brotdha now? And she was not kidding. This sort of thing still happens. For fun, Toph and I actually did one reading together, in Austin, which turned out to be sort of a mistake, given the pleasure he takes in dismantling his brother's tendencies toward the precious. Sitting next to me, pen in hand, every page I would sign, he would turn over and, on its underside, go to work on a deconstruction or outright parody of whatever I had written in whomever's book.

Irony and its malcontents

This section should be skipped by most, for it is annoying and pedantic, and directed to a very few. They know who they are. Here we go: You can't know how much it pains me to even have that word, the one beginning with i and ending in y, in this book. It is not a word I like to see, anywhere, much less type on to my own pages. It is beyond a doubt the most overused and under-understood word we currently have. I have that i-word here only to make clear what was clear to, by my estimations, about 99.9% of original hardcover readers of this book: that there is almost no irony, whatsoever, within its covers.

But to hear a few people tell it, this entire book, or most of it, was/is ironic. Well. Well. Ahem. Well. Let's define irony as the dictionary does: the use of words to express something different from and often opposite to their literal meaning. Now, where, keeping that definition in mind, do we find that herein? We do find some things that might have confused the reader prone to presuming this irony, so let's address them one at a time:

1. When someone kids around, it does not necessarily mean he or she is being ironic. That is, when one tells a joke, in any context, it can mean, simply, that a joke is being told. Further, satire is not inherently ironic. Nor is parody. Or any kind of comedy. Irony is a very specific and not all that interesting thing, and to use the word/concept to blanket half of all contemporary cultural production - which some aged arbiters seem to be doing (particularly with regard to work made by those under a certain age) - is akin to the too-common citing of "the Midwest" as the regional impediment to all national social progress (when we all know the "Midwest" is 10 miles outside of any city). In other words, to refer to everything odd, coincidental, eerie, absurd or strangely funny as ironic is, frankly, an abomination upon the Lord. (Re that last clause: not irony, but a simple, wholesome, American-born exaggeration.)

To illustrate the many more things that are not ironic but are often referred to as such, let's look at some sample sentences, starring a wee wayward pup known as Benji, and see if we can illuminate some distinctions.

Sample: Benji was run over by a bus. Isn't that ironic?

No: That is not ironic. That is unfortunate, but it is not ironic.

Sample: It was a bright and sunny day when Benji was run over by a bus. Ironic, no?

Again, no: That is not irony. It is an instance of dissonance between weather and tragedy.

Sample: It is ironic that Benji was on his way to the vet when he was run over by a bus.

Still: That is not irony. That is a coincidence that might be called eerie.

Sample: It is ironic that Benji was run over on the same day he misused the word ironic.

But see: This is, again, a coincidence. It is wonderfully appropriate that he was run over on this day, deserving as he was of punishment, but it is not ironic.

2. Now, on a related subject: simply because humour is found in a context of pain, does not make that humour ironic. I have heard people claim that there is irony in the first chapter of this book, a chapter that is excruciatingly serious and straightforward. Are there even a few funny moments in this section? Absolutely not. But what confuses some people is the use of a device here or there, a formal trick or innovation that this sort of reader finds bothersome in the same way that a certain king of lore is said to have told a certain court composer that his music had too many notes.

3. If we dismiss the idea that all formal fun - and we must be allowed it - constitutes irony, then we must agree that:

5. Prefaces are not ironic.

6. Notations are not ironic.

7. Diagrams are not ironic.

8. Funny titles are not ironic.

9. Numbered points are not ironic.

10. Footnotes are not ironic*.

11. Small type is not ironic.

11a. Appendices are not ironic.

12. Having characters break out of character is not ironic.

Wait, back to humour for a second: Generally, if a joke is told, or a humorous anecdote relayed, and by chance you do not understand that joke or humorous anecdote, it does not mean it is ironic. Or "neo-ironic". It simply means that you do not understand that joke. And that is okay. There have been a few readers who have taken the long, messy run-on of the book's end, even that passage, as ironic. Which is so disturbing. A parody of Ulysses? What is wrong with you people?

But such interpretations, in the end, aren't really my problem. When I was done, I was ashamed, because I had written what I saw as a much too revealing and maudlin thing, overflowing with blood and sentiment and a simple bare longing for people who are gone. The book was seen by its author as a stupid risk, and an ugly thing, and a betrayal, and overall, as a mistake he would regret for the rest of his life but a mistake which nevertheless he could not refrain from making and, worse, as a mistake he would encourage everyone to make, because everyone should make big, huge mistakes, because

a) They don't want you to;

b) Because they haven't the balls themselves and your doing it reminds them of their status as havers-of-no-balls;

c) Because your life is worth documenting;

d) Because if you do not believe your life is worth documenting then why are you wasting your time/our time? Our air?

e) Because if you do it right and go straight toward them, you, like me, will write to them and will look straight into their eyes when writing, will look straight into their fucking eyes, like a person sometimes can do with another person, and tell them something, even though you might not know them well, or at all, and even if you wrote in their books or hugged them or put your hand on their arm, you still would scarcely know them, but even so wrote a book that was really a letter to them, a messy fucking letter that you could barely keep a grip on, but a letter you meant, and a letter you sometimes wish you had not mailed, but a letter you are happy that made it from you to them.

* What the fuck is ironic about this?

In one of my many such daydreams, there was a recurring image of a man in a raincoat pushing through the assembled with a snub-nosed pistol and, once close enough, shooting me square in the chest. In the scenario, which was for some reason always set in the back portion of Rose Records, a music-purveying shop on Green Street in Champaign, Illinois, I always vacillate between a) jumping under the desk and avoiding the shots long enough for him to be wrestled to the ground by... by bookstore security, I guess; and b) the reaction that seems to make more sense: I sit up straight and offer my chest to him, take the bullet, and am killed.

So because I knew that many people would be saddened by the appearance of this book - those who cared about my father, for instance, and feel I was unfair - I figured that, after its publication, I'd be in hiding somewhere, that I would disappear - to safety! Right. I mean, if we can so clearly conceive of it, if so many disparate (no I didn't use that word at the time) peoples can conceive of it, then it almost means that there must be..." Etc.

There is, intrinsic to the process of a memoir, the resulting destruction of one's former self. Writing about those years, and being as cruel to who I was as I could be, implicitly means that you are killing that person. Yes, you are sometimes celebrating that person's better moments, and relating with sympathy that person's better thoughts, but overall you are saying: This was me then, and I can look at that person, from the distance I now have, and throw water balloons on his stupid fat head. But even as good an idea as that seems to be, an idea attractive to the intellectually violent, it is also a very painful plan to carry out, and one that is rebelled against, by various self-preservative internal forces. Which is not to say anything of what happens once those thoughts are read and processed by the public at large. However much I tried to make happen the things I wanted to happen, and however much I tried to prevent things from happening that I hoped would not, they happened anyway.

It was, for the most part, very entertaining. Were parts of the process incredibly painful? They were. I wrote a book in large part about the deaths of my parents, and living with my brother thereafter, and this, inexplicably, brought out in a very few people a kind of malice that I have rarely seen. Very strange. But it was not entirely unexpected. The weird thing is that while writing the original text, I had in my head not the usual Writer's Ideal Reader, but instead my own potential reading person, the Mean/Jaded/Skimming Reader - the person I had been for many years. Thus I expected the worst from the book's readers, I expected claws and blood and teeth. The book ends with a plea for those who would tear into me to just go ahead and do it, because I wanted it to happen, finally.

But then a weird thing happened: People were kind. It was almost impossible to find people who were as vicious and small as I had for many years been. Not completely impossible, but still: I expected crucifixion and instead got something more like its opposite.

This happened: At a reading in Portland, I read the passage involving the being-annoyed-at-being-asked this question part, and, immediately afterward, a middle-aged woman in the third row raised her hand and asked, in English but with what sounded like a German accent: So where iz ya brotdha now? And she was not kidding. This sort of thing still happens. For fun, Toph and I actually did one reading together, in Austin, which turned out to be sort of a mistake, given the pleasure he takes in dismantling his brother's tendencies toward the precious. Sitting next to me, pen in hand, every page I would sign, he would turn over and, on its underside, go to work on a deconstruction or outright parody of whatever I had written in whomever's book.

Irony and its malcontents

This section should be skipped by most, for it is annoying and pedantic, and directed to a very few. They know who they are. Here we go: You can't know how much it pains me to even have that word, the one beginning with i and ending in y, in this book. It is not a word I like to see, anywhere, much less type on to my own pages. It is beyond a doubt the most overused and under-understood word we currently have. I have that i-word here only to make clear what was clear to, by my estimations, about 99.9% of original hardcover readers of this book: that there is almost no irony, whatsoever, within its covers.

But to hear a few people tell it, this entire book, or most of it, was/is ironic. Well. Well. Ahem. Well. Let's define irony as the dictionary does: the use of words to express something different from and often opposite to their literal meaning. Now, where, keeping that definition in mind, do we find that herein? We do find some things that might have confused the reader prone to presuming this irony, so let's address them one at a time:

1. When someone kids around, it does not necessarily mean he or she is being ironic. That is, when one tells a joke, in any context, it can mean, simply, that a joke is being told. Further, satire is not inherently ironic. Nor is parody. Or any kind of comedy. Irony is a very specific and not all that interesting thing, and to use the word/concept to blanket half of all contemporary cultural production - which some aged arbiters seem to be doing (particularly with regard to work made by those under a certain age) - is akin to the too-common citing of "the Midwest" as the regional impediment to all national social progress (when we all know the "Midwest" is 10 miles outside of any city). In other words, to refer to everything odd, coincidental, eerie, absurd or strangely funny as ironic is, frankly, an abomination upon the Lord. (Re that last clause: not irony, but a simple, wholesome, American-born exaggeration.)

To illustrate the many more things that are not ironic but are often referred to as such, let's look at some sample sentences, starring a wee wayward pup known as Benji, and see if we can illuminate some distinctions.

Sample: Benji was run over by a bus. Isn't that ironic?

No: That is not ironic. That is unfortunate, but it is not ironic.

Sample: It was a bright and sunny day when Benji was run over by a bus. Ironic, no?

Again, no: That is not irony. It is an instance of dissonance between weather and tragedy.

Sample: It is ironic that Benji was on his way to the vet when he was run over by a bus.

Still: That is not irony. That is a coincidence that might be called eerie.

Sample: It is ironic that Benji was run over on the same day he misused the word ironic.

But see: This is, again, a coincidence. It is wonderfully appropriate that he was run over on this day, deserving as he was of punishment, but it is not ironic.

2. Now, on a related subject: simply because humour is found in a context of pain, does not make that humour ironic. I have heard people claim that there is irony in the first chapter of this book, a chapter that is excruciatingly serious and straightforward. Are there even a few funny moments in this section? Absolutely not. But what confuses some people is the use of a device here or there, a formal trick or innovation that this sort of reader finds bothersome in the same way that a certain king of lore is said to have told a certain court composer that his music had too many notes.

3. If we dismiss the idea that all formal fun - and we must be allowed it - constitutes irony, then we must agree that:

5. Prefaces are not ironic.

6. Notations are not ironic.

7. Diagrams are not ironic.

8. Funny titles are not ironic.

9. Numbered points are not ironic.

10. Footnotes are not ironic*.

11. Small type is not ironic.

11a. Appendices are not ironic.

12. Having characters break out of character is not ironic.

Wait, back to humour for a second: Generally, if a joke is told, or a humorous anecdote relayed, and by chance you do not understand that joke or humorous anecdote, it does not mean it is ironic. Or "neo-ironic". It simply means that you do not understand that joke. And that is okay. There have been a few readers who have taken the long, messy run-on of the book's end, even that passage, as ironic. Which is so disturbing. A parody of Ulysses? What is wrong with you people?

But such interpretations, in the end, aren't really my problem. When I was done, I was ashamed, because I had written what I saw as a much too revealing and maudlin thing, overflowing with blood and sentiment and a simple bare longing for people who are gone. The book was seen by its author as a stupid risk, and an ugly thing, and a betrayal, and overall, as a mistake he would regret for the rest of his life but a mistake which nevertheless he could not refrain from making and, worse, as a mistake he would encourage everyone to make, because everyone should make big, huge mistakes, because

a) They don't want you to;

b) Because they haven't the balls themselves and your doing it reminds them of their status as havers-of-no-balls;

c) Because your life is worth documenting;

d) Because if you do not believe your life is worth documenting then why are you wasting your time/our time? Our air?

e) Because if you do it right and go straight toward them, you, like me, will write to them and will look straight into their eyes when writing, will look straight into their fucking eyes, like a person sometimes can do with another person, and tell them something, even though you might not know them well, or at all, and even if you wrote in their books or hugged them or put your hand on their arm, you still would scarcely know them, but even so wrote a book that was really a letter to them, a messy fucking letter that you could barely keep a grip on, but a letter you meant, and a letter you sometimes wish you had not mailed, but a letter you are happy that made it from you to them.

* What the fuck is ironic about this?
