webTitle: Review:  The Adversary by Emmanuel Carrère

fields.headline: Doctor death
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit on a French tragedy too bizarre for fiction, Emmanuel Carrère's The Adversary: A True Story of Murder and Deception
fields.trailText: Chris Petit on a French tragedy too bizarre for fiction, Emmanuel Carrère's The Adversary: A True Story of Murder and Deception
fields.body:
The Adversary: A True Story of Murder and Deception

Emmanuel Carrère

183pp, Bloomsbury, £14.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The initial facts are extraordinary enough, like something out of a Claude Chabrol movie, via Georges Simenon or Ruth Rendell. It's a true life story of French bourgeois implosion - respectable doctor living near the Swiss border goes berserk, kills wife and two children, having previously shot his mother and father and attempted to strangle his mistress, sets fire to the family home and takes an overdose, only to be rescued, revived and charged with murder, much to the consternation of the local community, which had always regarded him as a solicitous, conscientious and caring husband, father and son.

So far, so Chabrol. Then, with a twist worthy of Nabokov, a further level is revealed. In spite of everything he had claimed, the killer, Jean-Claude Romand, turns out never to have been a doctor at the World Health Organisation, nor to have any medical qualifications. The whole professional edifice of his life was an elaborate fabrication. This scandalous revelation was followed by local rumours of a romantic surrogate life in drug-running, and so on, but the truth was more desperate.

Days when Romand had said he had been teaching in Dijon, or working at the WHO's Geneva headquarters, had been spent mooching about alone. Romand, the ostensibly successful professional and happy family man, had in fact done nothing with his life, except make it up.

Herein, presumably, lies his appeal to Carrère: a case of fiction intruding into reality, as well as that peculiar sense of wasted days and hanging around with which Carrère, as a writer, could easily identify. It hardly seems worth pointing out that writers spend their lives making things up too.

The perpetrator of all these lies was of course a mild man on the surface, in many ways unnoticeable, well used to avoiding drawing attention to himself, except occasionally, when he concocted elaborate ruses to both gain sympathy and distract - pretending while a student to have been set upon; claiming, when things got more desperate, that he had cancer.

Romand's exceptional passivity and fear of confrontation seem to have been the products of a combination of geographical and family elements: rural isolation in a grandiose but oppressive landscape - the Jura forests of eastern France - in which he grew up a sensitive only child with a stoical, undemonstrative father and a sickly, fretting mother, on whom no demands could be made. Romand's neurosis manifested itself in an inability to take exams, and his initial break with his family - to study medicine instead of following his father into forestry management - faltered because of this. From that failure of nerve developed his forged life.

What followed was a bizarre combination of upward mobility and stasis, funded initially by a parental allowance, then through embezzling the savings of relatives and friends. Here Romand was able to capitalise on two things: the traditional mistrust of the French paysan and petit bourgeois towards banks; and the proximity of the Swiss border.

Romand was entrusted to make miraculous-sounding high-interest investments with this money, which was really used to fund an increasingly affluent middle-class lifestyle. Indeed, until the moment of implosion, Romand could be said to have lived an extreme version of the kind of compartmentalised life that countless middle-class men lead: the loving family man juggling with his hypocrisies, spending beyond his means, with a mistress on the side, a bit of porn at home, and fortnightly trips to the Only You Club massage parlour.

After the trial, the shrinks would have a field day. So too would Romand, centre of attention at last, flattered by the (rather creepy) attendance of a famous author and having made the apparently effortless transition from being trapped in life's equivalent to a Chabrol or Fassbinder movie (Why Does Herr R Run Amok?) to the transcendentalism of one of Bresson's spiritual studies, in which the sinner achieves forgiveness and clarity.

The major irony of Romand's life of lies was that what he secretly craved was exposure and testing, which were achieved with his trial. The complex psychological mechanisms of evasion and deferral produced in him a bizarre variation of a death wish. What he seemed to desire most was existence as a posthumous figure. This desire was realised - after his token suicide attempt following the murders - through the spectacle of trial as funeral, resulting in formal punishment and escape into religious serenity, with the help of Christian do-gooders.

Given such great material, what is wrong with The Adversary? It asks too many rhetorical questions for a start, many of them the sort that sound better in, well, French. It also evokes too many superior fictions, including those authors and film-makers mentioned above, as well as Agnes Varda's Le Bonheur and the Swiss film Alpine Fire (family massacre in postcard landscape). Carrère, to talk up his subject, probably makes more of a mystery of Romand than is deserved - the outcome of his wretched life seems both perfectly logical and transparent.

What is really wanted is more speculation on the prosaic complicities and collusions that grew up around his fabrications - not simply with the author, who limits himself to a few "mon semblable, mon frère" riffs, but between Romand and his wife, who never called him at his office, and whom, one guesses, suspected but chose not to know.

In translation, The Adversary too often reads like bad Primo Levi: a too slim, quasi-lucid (and quasi-bogus) philosophical and psychological inquiry into the nature of evil, verging on the lazy when it comes to the big imponderables and well summarised by its cop-out last sentence: "I thought that writing this story could only be a crime or a prayer"; to which the appropriate Anglo-Saxon retort is "Pull the other one". It also, given the singularity of its material, lacks narrative drive, and suffers from too much literal translation into duff English: "How fragile life is! Only yesterday, there was a close, happy family, people who loved one another, and today - a boiler accident, charred bodies being taken to the morgue..." Sacré bleu!

fields.headline: Not to be sneezed at
fields.trailText: Many thanks to the Bookseller for our first item, a glimpse into the bizarre in-tray of Larry Ashmead, editor-in-chief of HarperCollins US
fields.body:
 Many thanks to the Bookseller for our first item, a glimpse into the bizarre in-tray of Larry Ashmead, editor-in-chief of HarperCollins US. Ashmead's speciality is the oddball submission letter, whether fanciful (a picture-book about "a nose from an Easter Island statue who travels to New York City..."), brash ("It took me several years to write this... when I finished finally, it was as magnificent and beautiful as the Taj Mahal") or simply tragic. My favourite in the last category is as follows: "I am trying to write a book based on successful living... Unfortunately suffering from unlimited setbacks that included financial deficits, several relocations and a divorce, I have yet to complete my goal..." But as any successful writer knows, these are just the events from which the greatest work proceeds.

 Still in the States, we hear that Playboy magazine has dispensed with the services of its fiction editor, rather loftily dismissing the post as "a luxury". At the same time, they are keen to reassure bookish subscribers that the mag is as committed to the world of literature as ever. Sounds like it.

 And now proof that there's a book to be written about everything. Scheduled by OUP for publication on March 1, World Book Day, Jenny Hartley's Reading Groups does exactly what it says on the tin. "How do they choose and use books? What kinds of social protocols and rituals do they observe and what do they mean? Why are men less likely to be members?" Pressing questions for all those huddles who've exhausted Captain Corelli and Possession and are looking for fresh horizons.

 The Loafer's ascetic January evenings have been much enlivened by an early copy of A Writer's Notebook by the late Anthony Powell, a collection of gnomic phrases the novelist jotted down for inspiration. Among the ideas for book titles (At Lady Molly's appears, but then so does Purged Not In Lethe) are some wonderfully inconsequential fragments. "General and porridge," muses Powell one day, and, "A pretty Wednesday side" (covert football fan?). In among the incomprehensible are some gems of good sense - as in "People usually do what they want" - and a hint of poignancy. "It's too late now to die young," he remarked mournfully.

 The advent of anti-hype provides a welcome diversion for all those wearied by a surfeit of "magisterials" and "stunnings". Canongate are billing new discovery Sylvia Smith as "Bridget Jones with the fun taken out", adding that Misadventures, her episodic part-novel part-memoir, which consists of "achingly tedious anecdotes", is "relentlessly drab and wearingly depressing". Evidently their attempt at reverse psychology is designed to pique the interest of jaded hacks. A crazy idea, but it might just work.

What kinds of social protocols and rituals do they observe and what do they mean? Why are men less likely to be members?" Pressing questions for all those huddles who've exhausted Captain Corelli and Possession and are looking for fresh horizons.  The Loafer's ascetic January evenings have been much enlivened by an early copy of A Writer's Notebook by the late Anthony Powell, a collection of gnomic phrases the novelist jotted down for inspiration. Among the ideas for book titles (At Lady Molly's appears, but then so does Purged Not In Lethe) are some wonderfully inconsequential fragments. "General and porridge," muses Powell one day, and, "A pretty Wednesday side" (covert football fan?). In among the incomprehensible are some gems of good sense - as in "People usually do what they want" - and a hint of poignancy. "It's too late now to die young," he remarked mournfully.  The advent of anti-hype provides a welcome diversion for all those wearied by a surfeit of "magisterials" and "stunnings". Canongate are billing new discovery Sylvia Smith as "Bridget Jones with the fun taken out", adding that Misadventures, her episodic part-novel part-memoir, which consists of "achingly tedious anecdotes", is "relentlessly drab and wearingly depressing". Evidently their attempt at reverse psychology is designed to pique the interest of jaded hacks. A crazy idea, but it might just work.

webTitle: Review: Big Bangs by Howard Goodall

fields.headline: Pitched perfect
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard admires a strong popularisation of classical music
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard admires Big Bangs: The Story of Five Discoveries that Changed Musical History, a strong popularisation of classical music by Howard Goodall
fields.body:
Big Bangs: The Story of Five Discoveries that Changed Musical History
Howard Goodall
(Vintage, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Did you know that the do-re-mi scale (originally ut-re-mi) comes from the first lines of the hymn for the feast of John the Baptist, composed by Guido of Arezzo in the 13th century? ("Ut queant laxis/ Resonare fibris/ Mira gestorum," etc.) And that until Guido, there had been no system of musical notation that dealt both with pitch and rhythm?

Or did you know that Pope Urban VIII was so impressed by the spiritual power of Allegri's "Miserere Mei, Deus" that he not only forbade its publication, he only allowed it to be performed once a year? And that Mozart, on hearing it once at the age of 14, was able to transcribe it and so give the rest of the world a chance to hear it without having to travel to the Vatican in Holy Week in order to do so? And did you know that shellac was made of crushed Malaysian beetles?

Okay, you probably knew all these things. But they were new to me until I read this book. I had missed the TV series, fronted by the relatively ubiquitous Goodall, on which this book is based, and from which it takes its embarrassing title. The book-of-the-series flavour might sometimes come over very strongly, but then it is purposefully middlebrow, on a mission to explain musical arcana to a wide audience. It does not do to be snobbish about such things. (I had noticed that the book wasn't that badly written at all, considering this and that; a note at the end thanks the superb Jenny Uglow for her editing skills, which goes some way to explaining matters.)

Besides, while Goodall sometimes sounds all happy-clappy about the process of musical composition and influence himself, he has his reservations about the drive towards greater "comprehensibility" in modern church music. He makes his point very well when comparing Brian A Wren's "Life is Great" (no 149 in Hymns for Today ) unfavourably with "Lead, Kindly Light". The lyrics of the former go like this: "Life is great! So sing about it/ As we can and as we should,/ Shops and buses, towns and people,/ Village, farmland, field and wood." (It would appear that Mr Wren supposes shops, buses and towns capable of tuneful vocal utterance.) As Goodall says: "I'm not on my own with this one, am I?" No, he's not.

It's not all easy stuff, which is good. I have always been perplexed about the difference between D flat and C sharp, with explanations about dominant cycles and the like causing the eyes to glaze over faster than a puddle in a cold snap; here Goodall does his best to explain the business of temperament, the Pythagorean comma, and why it took so long to invent the piano. I am not sure I have got all the details straight, and the eyes did glaze over a tiny bit, the brain reel in confusion - but this is my fault, not Goodall's.

The strength and value of the book lie in the way it manages to approach music as a technical problem as well as a matter of mystery. (A chapter on how he composed his own "Missa Aedis Christi" shows, besides the fact that Goodall is not seriously plagued by a wish to avoid the limelight, that the creative process still has a core of inexplicability.) The very mechanics of sound reproduction have had an effect on music throughout the ages, which sounds like an obvious point to make; but then obvious points often don't get made.

fields.headline: The real thing
fields.standfirst: Isobel Montgomery on a portrayal of frail self-delusion, The Pretender by Mary Morissey, plus The Dud Avocado, Eros Island and  Tales of Old Japan
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery on a portrayal of frail self-delusion, The Pretender by Mary Morissey, plus The Dud Avocado, Eros Island and Tales of Old Japan
fields.body:
The Pretender

Mary Morissey

(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Onion domes and a sepia tint of the doomed Empress Alexandra may well mislead, but Morissey's imagined biography of Anna Anderson, the woman who believed she was Grand Duchess Anastasia, is not the historical hogwash the cover suggests. Morissey's Anastasia is a Polish munitions worker, Franziska Schanzkowska, fished from a Berlin canal and placed in an asylum where, unless she can remember a past, she will stay. Anastasia/ Franziska's own desperation to recover a previous life and the need of those around her to make her the improbable, romantic explanation of a tragedy are quietly revealed in this portrayal of frail self-delusion.

The Dud Avocado

Elaine Dundy

(Virago, £7.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

I still have the frayed, cream-and-orange Penguin original of this comically wise novel. I found it on my mother's bookcase when I was a taciturn teenager who longed, like the heroine Sally Jay Gorce, truly to live life and make all the mistakes I could as fast as I could. Sally, an American in Paris, wanders through cafés and bars, beds and friendships. On the way she learns that dyed-pink hair doesn't make for an instant personality change, and that champagne can be as dull as Seven-Up. One of the best novels about growing up fast, it can serve as an aide-memoire to abandoned dreams or as a peace-offering to sulky teenage girls.

Eros Island

Tony Hanania

(Bloomsbury, £6.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Hanania, Lebanese by birth, educated at an English public school by accident of war, has already written two books, opulent with adjectives, about this curious mixture of cultures. This covers similar ground. The narrator picks his way back through an adolescence and early adulthood divided between Spain where his father lives and the England of upper-class boys slumming it in style (Hampshire, York and Notting Hill). Anna and Sylvie are his icons, beacons of early 1980s post-punk style (amphetamines, leather jackets and the Stranglers). Eros Island has an unquestionable nostalgic power, but it reads like a good first novel. Hanania is still exorcising childish demons.

Tales of Old Japan

A B Mitford

(Wordsworth Editions, £3.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Mitford, Victoria's man in Japan and, incidentally, grandfather of those girls, travelled east picking up languages as he went. He apologised for this collection of "little children's tales" when it was first published in 1871, but later Japanophiles and folklorists see his translations as a priceless introduction to Japanese culture, gathered at the very point when the country had thrown off isolationism and the shogun for an Emperor and engagement with the wider world. Mitford's notes and exquisite line drawings pepper these enchanting tales of kettles that become badgers, goblin dogs and Samurai chivalry.

fields.headline: Against the West
fields.standfirst: John Dugdale looks at corporations' branding compulsions in No Logo, by Naomi Klein and an impressive biography, Saddam Hussein by Said K Aburish
fields.trailText: John Dugdale looks at corporations' branding compulsions in No Logo, by Naomi Klein and an impressive biography, Saddam Hussein by Said K Aburish
fields.body:
No Logo

Naomi Klein

(Flamingo, £8.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Like Susan Faludi's Stiffed, Klein's debut has been lazily treated as a manifesto, although it's primarily an exhilaratingly wide-ranging descriptive study. Only the concluding section looks directly (and not unsceptically) at the anti-corporate movement, with earlier chapters dealing with the developments that led to its emergence: the compulsion of global corporations to imprint their brand on every part of culture; their systematic suppression of diversity and dissidence; and their exploitation of Third World labour. Cogently structured, this counter-history of the 1990s is written with a winning mixture of academic synthetic intelligence and snarky journalistic pizzazz.

Saddam Hussein

Said K Aburish

(Bloomsbury, £7.99)
Buy it at a discount at BOL

An impressive biography portraying Saddam as an Arab Stalin, who modelled his rise before and after the Ba'athist coup of 1968 on the Soviet dictator and has continued to employ tactics learnt from him (such as inventing foreign-backed conspiracies) to hang on to power. Aburish analyses incisively how the masterly organiser and adroit diplomat who modernised his country and charmed the west in the 1970s became today's megalomaniac at bay, ruling a devastated outlaw state. But his book, dedicated to "the suffering children of Iraq", is no less acute in excoriating the hypocritical blunderings of US policy from the Iran-Iraq war onwards.

fields.trailText: The author vainly attempts to flout the basic rule that merchant banking cannot throw up good fiction. That is the trade-off that real-life Trixies make when they plump for obscene City salaries
fields.body: This is cobbled from a fluffy column on the Telegraph money pages. Trixie is a City banker with a faith in cosmetics and clothing brand names who is depressingly vacuous even by chick-fiction conventions. She is given six weeks to net a good deal or be sacked. The author vainly attempts to flout the basic rule that merchant banking cannot throw up good fiction. That is the trade-off that real-life Trixies make when they plump for obscene City salaries. Their university contemporaries in social work, the police or teaching earn crap money yet their jobs can produce passable telly series, but this makes Bridget Jones sound like George Eliot. If you really must exercise your Switch card, get one of those 50th-anniversary Archers reissues.

webTitle: Review: Smashing People  by Michael Fishwick

fields.headline: A pain in the arts
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on Michael Fishwick's  pricking of pomposity, Smashing People
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on Michael Fishwick's pricking of pomposity, Smashing People
fields.body:
Smashing People

Michael Fishwick

250pp, Jonathan Cape, £15.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Anybody who stumbled out of university in the 1980s, slept through the milk round and fell blearily into a job in telesales might find this novel a touch dismaying. Despite the comfortingly accidental hero, Wilf Wellingborough, its characters exude an air of confidence and accomplishment that might, had the novel been set in a later period, be termed the culture of entitlement. With an outward semblance of bumbling raffishness, they become publishers, magazine editors, gossip columnists, literary agents, and tycoons, without appearing to languish too long in the dreary doldrums of less glamorous occupations.

These mysterious and irritating transformations are, to some extent, Fishwick's point. Against the backdrop of a decade of rapid expansion, cut-throat careerism and insubstantial stylishness, he deploys fast-buck reputations and apparently effortless success to create a well-oiled farce. At its centre is Wilf, catapulted into the editorship of the small-circulation journal Arts Unlimited by childhood friend and aspiring press baron Jimmy Spalding, the on-the-make proprietor of a magazine empire who most resembles "a whale chasing plankton". Wilf, although clearly signposted as a fairly decent bloke, discovers that he is not immune to the allures of the gravy train: "I found myself wondering quite how sycophantic I was going to be, and the answer was, to my surprise, very."

As a comic villain, Spalding is reassuringly wicked - thrashing his wife and waving his pistol around to indicate displeasure -and Wilf, like a lamb to the slaughter, is properly dim and clueless. Blind to Spalding's stratospheric manoeuvrings, he makes a hash of Arts Unlimited and fails miserably at his relationship with the unworldly Grace. Having unexpectedly fluttered into the spotlight, he finds himself more smashed than smashing and, when intimacy with Spalding's wife offers itself as a consoling option, imagines that he has little else to lose. Actually, he has.

If Fishwick's characterisation often teeters uncomfortably on the verge of caricature - women who are either ballbreaking sexpots or naively trusting nurturers, men who adopt the persona of fop or shark - then his eventual conceit is ingenious. In a feverish atmosphere that polarises victors and victims, it is not always immediately possible to tell one from the other or to be sure that they will stay the same. Falling prey to the vicious fallacy that my enemy's enemy is my friend, Wilf discovers that even his half-hearted attempts at revenge are open to manipulation and that his trust in ancient friendships and loyalties is fatally misplaced.

As a comic caper - one that, rather charmingly, ends in rooftop escapes, murky conspiracies and ringing gunshots - Smashing People is a rollicking read. Fishwick has a fine ear for the absurdities and pomposity of in-crowd chatter - "Marvin's just been published by Chatto. He is our premier rap poet" - and a nicely ambiguous sense of its worth. When Wilf reminisces on the power of a high-flying journalist "whose editorials made Whitehall quiver, whose reviews closed shows overnight", he ironises beautifully the self-importance of those who manage rather than contribute to cultural production.

There is, however, a lingering sense that Fishwick has his eye on more weighty topics than period satire and could, in further novels, explore them to greater effect. Where his evocation of the 1980s can seem mildly laboured and unconvincing, his underlying interest in the exchanges of power between lovers and friends remains intriguing. In Wilf, he demonstrates a talent for conveying a meditative intelligence, a searching sadness, but never quite allows it to develop. And his exploration of charisma, ruthlessness and betrayal need not have been tethered quite so firmly to their setting. After all, power never goes out of fashion.

webTitle: Review: As Meat Loves Salt by Maria McCann

fields.headline: Of maggots and bread
fields.standfirst: Douglas Galbraith  discovers how research can go too far in Maria McCann's As Meat Loves Salt
fields.trailText: Douglas Galbraith discovers how research can go too far in Maria McCann's As Meat Loves Salt
fields.body:
As Meat Loves Salt

Maria McCann

532pp, Flamingo, £13.99

Maria McCann's début novel is the story of Jacob Cullen, one of three brothers once of some substance but now reduced to serving in a minor aristocratic household. The historical setting is the English Civil War, and we absorb some of the radical ideas of the time from the servants' reading of contraband pamphlets that must be carefully concealed from their royalist masters.

This is a mere undertone, however, to the two opening events that will drive the novel - Jacob's marriage to his beloved Caro, and the recent discovery of the gruesome murder of a young boy from a neighbouring household. These three constituents are the gunpowder that sets off a violent picaresque taking us through action with the New Model Army, a torridly erotic period of recovery in London and finally participation in an idealistic Diggers' commune before its brutal dissolution by the local lord of the manor. We end with that well-established device, the protagonist standing on the quay waiting for embarkation to the New World.

McCann has opted for the intimacies of an internalizing, first-person style which must, in this case, shoulder the double burden of creating a convincing sense of historical period as well as character. The result avoids all the worst disasters that can befall such a project, but is by no means entirely free of genre-fiction blight. The sprinkling of "liefs", "fains" and even the occasional "methinks" often appears self-conscious. Period locutions set in the middle of an otherwise admirably plain and readable English can come across as translations from a less than fully mastered foreign language - when one of Jacob's brothers cannot understand something, he admits "I cannot come at it". At other times the target is missed in terms of tone - when the Diggers' colony becomes troublesome, Jacob looks back to a time "when the colony was but a maggot in my friend's head".'

With respect to period detail we have a solid, if occasionally over-eager performance. Work has been done on domestic crafts, and this has resulted in details on the cleaning of pewter and the restoration of cloth which the real literature of the mid-17th century never found sufficiently interesting to mention. A command of military drill techniques is displayed, perhaps to excess. Most striking of all is the author's evident satisfaction in knowing the meaning of the words "manchet" and "cheat" (types of bread). These are used to the exclusion of the dreaded "b" word throughout the book, despite the fact that they were already antique in the mid-17th century and had caused the recent translators of the Bible no anxiety at all - "And when they were eating, Jesus took b***d and blessed it . . ." (only one of several scabrous references). No doubt the likes of us will appear in a novel 400 years hence routinely discussing multi-seeded organic bloomer.

A graver difficulty is that to read As Meat Loves Salt is to spend 532 pages in the company of an unusually baffling psychopath. We know from the start that Jacob himself is responsible for the sadistic murder of young Christopher Walshe (Christopher had been cheeky to him). He has to flee justice on his wedding day, persuading his new wife in the space of a few lines to commit the capital offence of stealing her mistress's jewels and coming with him. Within hours he beats and rapes her. He has an intense desire to strangle a young boy he encounters in the New Model Army. He pulls a knife on the man who will become his lover in London, where he nearly succeeds in raping him too. He looks down on him after love-making and reflects how easy it would be to break his back. He betrays the Digger colony and passively observes its destruction while on the way back from having stolen its money. There is an assault, possibly murderous, on an infant that might be his. An inner voice tells him it his brother's child, and that seems to make it all right. Thence to Southampton and the New World - where, presumably, he adds the serial-killer gene to the population of the future United States.

Clearly Jacob is not a well man, but the causes or indeed the aesthetic significance of his behaviour elude us. The justifying context of higher meaning that always surrounds the portrayal of violence in true art is absent here. The gestures at remorse are as fleeting and shallow as the interspersing episodes of violence.

This is a mere undertone, however, to the two opening events that will drive the novel - Jacob's marriage to his beloved Caro, and the recent discovery of the gruesome murder of a young boy from a neighbouring household. These three constituents are the gunpowder that sets off a violent picaresque taking us through action with the New Model Army, a torridly erotic period of recovery in London and finally participation in an idealistic Diggers' commune before its brutal dissolution by the local lord of the manor. We end with that well-established device, the protagonist standing on the quay waiting for embarkation to the New World. The result avoids all the worst disasters that can befall such a project, but is by no means entirely free of genre-fiction blight. The sprinkling of "liefs", "fains" and even the occasional "methinks" often appears self-conscious. Period locutions set in the middle of an otherwise admirably plain and readable English can come across as translations from a less than fully mastered foreign language - when one of Jacob's brothers cannot understand something, he admits "I cannot come at it". At other times the target is missed in terms of tone - when the Diggers' colony becomes troublesome, Jacob looks back to a time "when the colony was but a maggot in my friend's head".' A command of military drill techniques is displayed, perhaps to excess. Most striking of all is the author's evident satisfaction in knowing the meaning of the words "manchet" and "cheat" (types of bread). These are used to the exclusion of the dreaded "b" word throughout the book, despite the fact that they were already antique in the mid-17th century and had caused the recent translators of the Bible no anxiety at all - "And when they were eating, Jesus took b***d and blessed it . . ." (only one of several scabrous references). No doubt the likes of us will appear in a novel 400 years hence routinely discussing multi-seeded organic bloomer. A graver difficulty is that to read As Meat Loves Salt is to spend 532 pages in the company of an unusually baffling psychopath. We know from the start that Jacob himself is responsible for the sadistic murder of young Christopher Walshe (Christopher had been cheeky to him). He has to flee justice on his wedding day, persuading his new wife in the space of a few lines to commit the capital offence of stealing her mistress's jewels and coming with him. Within hours he beats and rapes her. He has an intense desire to strangle a young boy he encounters in the New Model Army. He pulls a knife on the man who will become his lover in London, where he nearly succeeds in raping him too. He looks down on him after love-making and reflects how easy it would be to break his back. He betrays the Digger colony and passively observes its destruction while on the way back from having stolen its money. There is an assault, possibly murderous, on an infant that might be his. An inner voice tells him it his brother's child, and that seems to make it all right. Thence to Southampton and the New World - where, presumably, he adds the serial-killer gene to the population of the future United States. Clearly Jacob is not a well man, but the causes or indeed the aesthetic significance of his behaviour elude us. webTitle: Review: Tournament of Shadows by Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac

fields.headline: Spies like us
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Moorhouse  on the scramble for Asia in Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac's Tournament of Shadows
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Moorhouse on the scramble for Asia in Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac's Tournament of Shadows
fields.body:
Tournament of Shadows: The Great Game and the Race for Empire in Asia

Karl Meyer and Shareen Brysac

644pp, Little, Brown, £25
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This book is a salutary corrective for anyone with a taste for British Indian history, who imagines that the long Anglo-Russian rivalry in Central Asia was a bit like the Roses cricket match: a Great Game that had nothing at all to do with anyone else. In fact, this was a very serious and often deadly antagonism, with the British anxious to create a sympathetic buffer region that would protect their Indian holdings, and the Russians avid to expand their own lands into an empire. But the whole thrust of Tournament of Shadows is to demonstrate that so many others were eager for influence in the area over a much longer time-span than the 19th century that the Great Game may justifiably be regarded as "a Victorian prologue to the Cold War".

Appropriately, the authors are Americans, Meyer a distinguished journalist with an historian's qualification (Princeton PhD), Brysac "a prize-winning producer of prime-time documentaries for CBS... a contributing editor to Archaeology magazine". And theirs is a very American (and slightly exhausting) approach to the writing of narrative history, including everything remotely relevant to their theme, in which no tidbit is left unturned.

A great deal is familiar, of course, from many treatments on this side of the Atlantic, notably by Peter Hopkirk and John Keay. They start with William Moorcroft, the Lancashire horse doctor who was rescued from obscurity by Garry Alder's brilliant biography in 1985: he was probably the greatest of all the explorers in the region, primarily on the look-out for breeding stock that would improve the East India Company's stud, but also a meticulous observer of all that he encountered in then-unknown lands, which he relayed in copious despatches to his masters in Calcutta. In this sense, he was the first British spy, forerunner of dozens (some of the bravest and best were Indians) who endured great hardship and danger in order to secure alliances with local chieftains, lend an ear to useful gossip in the bazaar, map the ground and, increasingly, keep an eye open for signs of Russian influence.

We have long known, too, all that can be valuably said about two soldiers, Charles Stoddart and Arthur Conolly (who coined the phrase "the Great Game"), who were executed by the Emir of Bokhara for noseying around his realm. And about Capt Montgomerie, Royal Engineers, and his Indian pundits, who disguised themselves as pilgrims and logged the miles they trod on their prayer wheels. Also those who pulled strings in Calcutta, like Charles Metcalfe, who was Moorcroft's boss, and Lord Curzon, who is treated more generously than usual here, being seen (quite rightly) as something more than an arrogant imperialist. The traditional adversaries of these Brits are in turn carefully reviewed: Capt Vitkevitch, whose "life history was Dostoyevskian", first of the Czar's men to head for Afghanistan; Nikolai Przhevalsky, the Russophile Pole who discovered a new breed of horse on one of his four expeditions into Central Asia, all fired by his huge contempt for its inhabitants. There are several others.

The real value of Tournament of Shadows for anyone who already knows about these participants comes in the last third of the book, where Meyer and Brysac turn to the also-rans in this territorial competition. And here the atmosphere of the main text (not the source notes) becomes heavy with disclosure, with some information "scarcely known even now to specialists", other revelations made possible "thanks to the opening of long-closed archives", and something hitherto buried in "a revealing Yale doctoral dissertation by the Canadian scholar David Schimmelpenninck van der Oye": I don't think this is a leg-pull.

The authors have thus thrown into relief William Woodville Rockhill, "the original China Hand", formerly of the French Foreign Legion, friend of Sara Chandra Das, the first pundit, and Theodore Roosevelt's envoy in Peking, great scholar and extensive traveller in the region, who left 6,000 volumes of Orientalia to the Library of Congress and "initiated a century of American emotional and political involvement with Tibet": and here's a photograph, in which he looks uncommonly like Sir Henry Irving playing Macbeth. Another illustration pictures what could be a Flying Fortress pilot on a mule, who is Captain Brooke Dolan II, explorer and socialite in uniform, who embarked on a secret mission to Lhasa in 1942, which ultimately led to the CIA training Tibetan guerrillas in Colorado before sending them into China in 40 air drops, which only a quarter of them survived.

Dolan may also have been the dupe of the Nazi SS, the sponsor of an expedition to Tibet ordered by Heinrich Himmler in 1939, which resulted in a cordial dinner party of Germans and local nobles, with a swastika and SS flashes hanging in pennants on the wall. The American had befriended the expedition's leader, Ernst Schäfer, and may have contributed several thousand dollars to his funds. Much, much worse was the involvement of the odious Sven Hedin, an extraordinary mapmaker in Central Asia and an unrepentant racist wherever he went, whose admiration for Hitler was rewarded when the Swede was invited to make the opening speech at the 1936 Berlin Olympics.

It is possible to nitpick at certain things in this book: at the occasional lapse into Time -speak ("With his cascading sable beard, glowering brow, and strong Roman nose..."), at the urge to update instantly the remoter facts of history (the murder of Sir John Macnaghten at Kabul in 1841 is pursued by a parenthetic reminder that "the scene was repeated in 1997, when Taliban militants seized and executed Najibullah..."), and one or two errors of understanding (the authors are a bit muddled about the theory of Indo-European languages), but this is a scrupulously balanced and extremely readable chronicle of a very top-heavy subject. It is a book about cartography, archaeology, anthropology and several other things, as well as exploration and imperial lust. It is overview with nobs on. Whoever would have thought that Virginia Woolf could have had even a walk-on part in an account of the Great Game? Or Steven Spielberg?

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole on The Elizabethan Boy Player,  The Great Hedge of India and High Stakes, No Prisoners
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on The Elizabethan Boy Player, The Great Hedge of India and High Stakes, No Prisoners
fields.body:
Squeaking Cleopatras: The Elizabethan Boy Player

Joy Leslie Gibson

(Sutton Publishing, £20)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

This book's tone is one of rather odd defiance against a shadowy cadre of scholars who don't believe that boys could have played the parts of Shakespeare's women owing to their emotional complexity - but does anyone hold that opinion any more? Gibson attempts to prove by textual means that Shakespeare's female roles were written to accommodate the limitations of boy actors, specifically in breath control. I wasn't convinced that the speeches can be split into such boyish morsels as she recommends without doing some violence to the sense. Isabella's "To whom should I complain?" speech in Measure for Measure, for example, seems to demand a non-stop 59 syllables from "Though he hath fall'n", but Gibson breaks it into three. Meanwhile she argues that sex-chat in the plays is couched metaphorically so as not to embarrass the boys, which seems to misunderstand the differing possibilities of lyric poetry and drama. Yet her intelligent curiosity is appealing, and the research on grammar schools and apprenticeships paints a vividly detailed, warts'n'all picture of Elizabethan playhouse life.

The Great Hedge of India

Roy Moxham

(Constable, £14.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

"I will but look upon the hedge," insists Shakespeare's Autolycus, and our author is similarly determined. He learns about a 1,500-mile hedge that divided northern India in two in the 19th century, and sets off to try to find it. The hedge was invented by the British as a customs barrier, to protect revenues from the cruel and much-loathed Salt Tax. Fourteen feet wide and up to 20 feet high, the impenetrable thorny wall was manned by 12,000 guards. Moxham narrates a lovely travelogue of his increasingly desperate attempts to find any thorny remnants of this eldritch triumph of botanical engineering.

High Stakes, No Prisoners

Charles H Ferguson

(Texere, £12.99)

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Fabulous wealth loosens tongues. In 1994, Ferguson founded Vermeer Technologies to produce website-authoring package FrontPage. Within two years he sold up to the devil - sorry, to Microsoft - for a cool $133 million. His share of that payday means that he can be deliciously bitchy about everyone involved - the arrogant fools at Netscape, even the oily CEO of his own company. Michael Lewis's The New New Thing got all the hype last year, but this is much better: a real insider's portrait of Silicon Valley greed and loathing.

webTitle: Review: The Queen Is Dead by Mark Simpson and Steven Zeeland

fields.headline: Love is all around
fields.standfirst: Peter Tatchell  finds Mark Simpson and Steven Zeeland's The Queen Is Dead a compelling argument against the existence of  gay identity
fields.trailText: Peter Tatchell finds Mark Simpson and Steven Zeeland's The Queen Is Dead a compelling argument against the existence of gay identity
fields.body:
The Queen Is Dead: A Story of Jarheads, Eggheads, Serial Killers and Bad Sex

Mark Simpson and Steven Zeeland

283pp, Arcadia Books, £11.99
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Five years ago, I contributed to a feisty little anthology called Anti-Gay . My chapter, "It's Just a Phase: Why Homosexuality is Doomed", suggested that gay identity is a historically transient phenomenon destined for oblivion. This identity evolved, I argued, as a psychological and political defence against homophobia. Once we get rid of bigotry, gay identity will become redundant, as will its heterosexual counterpart.

For most homosexuals, such ideas are rank heresy. They regard gay identity as a sacred cow that cannot be questioned. It is unchanging and beyond challenge. Full stop. This is the suffocating gay orthodoxy that Mark Simpson and Steven Zeeland debunk in The Queen Is Dead . They illuminate the inadequacies of gay and straight identities, highlighting the frequent disjunction between how people define their sexuality and what they actually do in bed (or in public restrooms, in Zeeland's case). Although the narrative has a gay theme, the message is universal: "Behaviour," concludes Zeeland, "is an unreliable basis for sexual categories. Desire is messy. Identity is a joke."

The Queen Is Dead takes the form of an exchange of letters between two gay writers: Simpson, based in Britain, and Zeeland in the US. They share a passion for military men. Both have Marine lovers, Alex and Jason, who give them grief. The sex is irregular and the emotional commitment blows hot and cold. They hang around with army and navy guys who have sex with men, but who don't identify as gay and don't conform to the standard-issue gay lifestyle. This is both a blessing and a curse. As Simpson observes: "The problem with straight men is they're repressed; the problem with gay men is they're not."

A hedonistic, anything-goes attitude dominates gay culture, making most gay-identified men slaves to their cocks, trapped in the "jism prison". Conversely, precisely because they are repressed, men who have sex with men but don't see themselves as gay tend to be emotional iceblocks.

Simpson and Zeeland are caught between a rock and a hard place - and it shows. Slipping into a pessimism that borders on misanthropy, they sometimes present an unjustifiably dark, dystopian view of gay life. Their trans-Atlantic correspondence - 39 letters written from 1995 to 1998 - charts the illusions, frustrations, masquerades and disappointments that so often accompany love and desire. But out of this literary exchange evolves a friendship that proves to be more honest, profound and lasting than any of their military amours.

What makes this book so appealing is that you can read it on three levels. As a tale of bawdy exploits with enlisted men, it skirts the fringes of highbrow gay porn. It can also be read as a thoughtful critique of masculinity and the urban gay lifestyle, scattered with witty epigrams that are pure entertainment. Equally engagingly, it is a story about the relationship between the writers who, encountering misfortune in love, come to realise the value of friendship.

The literary intercourse of the correspondents mirrors the sexual unions they describe. Zeeland plays literary bottom to Simpson's top, telling most of the dirty stories. Many of these originate from his encounters with military men while gathering material for his books, The Masculine Marine and Barrack Buddies.

Revisiting the themes of Simpson's earlier works, It's a Queer World and Male Impersonators, this volume suggests that the boundaries between gay and straight are more blurred and ambiguous than homophobes and homosexualists dare admit. This is why notions of gay and straight identity are so problematic, and why moralists have such great difficulty in policing same-sex desire. Queer is everywhere, although often repressed.

Simpson quotes one serviceman as saying: "We don't like taking showers with men who like to take showers with men." To which he responds tartly: "So why join the Army in the first place?" Touché.

fields.headline: Death becomes her
fields.standfirst: Jad Adams on our fascination with the Victorians:  The Victorian Celebration of Death,  A Victorian Marriage, Last Days of Glory and Farewell in Splendour
fields.trailText: Jad Adams on our fascination with the Victorians: The Victorian Celebration of Death, A Victorian Marriage, Last Days of Glory and Farewell in Splendour
fields.body:
The Victorian Celebration of Death

James Stevens

Curl 330pp, Sutton Publishing, £20

Buy it at a discount at BOL

A Victorian Marriage: Mandell and Louise Creighton

James Covert

412pp, Hambledon & London, £19.95

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Last Days of Glory: The Death of Queen Victoria

Tony Rennell

326pp, Viking, £12.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

Farewell in Splendour: The Death of Queen Victoria and Her Age

Jerrold M Packard

294pp, Sutton, £19.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the early decades of her rule, Victoria would sometimes be jeered during public appearances, while the Teutonic character of the royal house was derided in print. Republicanism was a gathering storm at a time when the monarchy seemed an expensive irrelevance to the questions of the day. Yet by the time of Victoria's death, on January 22, 1901, the editors of the Dictionary of National Biography felt they had to extend the remit of their work past the end of the 19th century to include her entry, so completely did she embody national life.

Part of the reason is mere longevity: Victoria enjoyed the longest reign in the history of the monarchy, a period which coincided with an unparalleled growth in national wealth and Britain's leap to world dominance. The other reason, paradoxically, was death: Albert had done the British monarchy a favour by dying young, both removing himself, a minor German prince, from interference in the public scene, and stimulating Victoria's extended period of mourning, which kept her from excessive meddling while sharper minds applied themselves to the business of Britain.

By the time she returned to effective public life, the turbulent years of mass riot and discontent on the mainland were past. Disraeli's 1867 Reform Act had made Britain something very close to a democracy, and the nation was enjoying a better distribution of its prosperity than ever before. The monarchy could still be described (and sometimes was) as an expensive irrelevance, but in Victoria's last 30 years the institution that had been a focus for growing discontent was representative of the nation's lush self-satisfaction. Victoria's own death resonated through the lives of her subjects, most of whom had known no other monarch.

webTitle: Review: The Truth About Dogs by Stephen Budiansky

fields.headline: Cunning canines
fields.standfirst: Andrew Brown  discovers  why dog owners are slaves in  Stephen Budiansky's  The Truth About Dogs
fields.trailText: Andrew Brown discovers why dog owners are slaves in Stephen Budiansky's The Truth About Dogs
fields.body:
The Truth About Dogs
Stephen Budiansky
263pp, Weidenfeld, £20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A martian biologist could understand dogs at once: they are parasites, who have developed to exploit Homo sapiens. But it takes a brave human to realise this. Stephen Budiansky is only intermittently brave. The first chapter of his book, The Truth about Dogs, lays out very clearly the case that dogs are, biologically speaking, parasites on humanity, degenerate wolves who lost 25 per cent of their brain mass after they discovered it was easier to scavenge around primitive man than to hunt for a living. The rest of it argues what lovable, friendly, and rewarding parasites they are. Well, I suppose, he doesn't want to be torn to pieces by a pack of slavering dog-lovers; indeed, he goes out of his way to pose with a dog on his back cover and to point out what a true dog-lover and owner he himself is.

Budiansky is an excellent science writer whose book on horses is a classic of its kind. He is also the author of How Animals Think, whose subtitle should have been "Not at all". It is a thread running through all his work that animals should only be understood on their own terms, and that the intelligence they need to survive is very different from the quality that we prize in humans.

Normally, this is a rather comforting thought. He has explained how we have been able to domesticate horses by subverting their instincts for herd life - and even, to some extent, to domesticate dogs by appealing to their social instincts. But the inescapable conclusion is that dogs have been much more successful at subverting our instincts to their purposes than the other way round. Unhappy and lonely people find that dogs are what humans should have been. When the scientist points out that dogs are only what dogs should have been, they can expect attacks.

A few hard statistics show the extent to which dogs have benefited from us. The dogs of America produce two million tons of turds every year; they eat, for their body weight, twice as much as American humans. Think of the size of the average American human being, and you will realise what a tribute this is. What is really revealing, though, is that while Americans spend $5bn a year on dog food, they spend nearly half as much again on dog medicine.

This cannot possibly be justified on grounds of utility. When you look at the genetics, it turns out that dogs were parasites long before they were ever useful. According to DNA evidence, dogs diverged from wolves 100,000 years before there was anything useful for them to do for human beings - before we had animals to herd, or property to defend. As Budiansky points out: "No one has done an actual study of this, but there is every reason to be very suspicious of even the most common rationalisation of dogs' utility to man, as guardians of property or intruder alarms; for every tale of a dog successfully frightening off burglars, there are thousands of dogs who bark incessantly at every goddamned thing that moves and then sleep blissfully through a crime in progress."

There speaks the true voice of exasperated love, and in it you hear the final triumph of the dog. For, as various devoted students of dogs have discovered, the idea of loving them is very new and very western. Most of the dogs of Africa survive by being despised. They are too filthy to touch or to attack. Wolves, which are clean and beautiful, have been hunted almost to extinction because they are seen as dangerous. Dogs have survived and prospered because they are seen as disgusting. The first adaptation that seems to have been made by the proto-dog to human society was to lose its predatory instincts towards non-dogs and to replace them with aggression.

The difference is important: the predator wants to kill you as unobtrusively as possible; the aggressor wants to bully you as visibly as possible. Dogs, in their triumph over humans, so well described by Budiansky, have shown that aggression pays better than predation in this world. It's a striking example of the explanatory power of modern biology - but of course dogs understand this quite instinctively. That is why they can get away with putting a million people in casualty wards every year, and killing 12 Americans, while wolves are hunted just for killing sheep.

webTitle: Review: The Collected Stories  by Arthur C Clarke

fields.headline: Magic among the stars
fields.standfirst: Andrew Rissik asks whether  Arthur C Clarke's  The Collected Stories shows him to be a  hard-nosed technologist or philosophical mystic and takes a look through Piers Bizony's lens in  2001: Filming the Future
fields.trailText: Andrew Rissik asks whether Arthur C Clarke's The Collected Stories shows him to be a hard-nosed technologist or philosophical mystic and takes a look through Piers Bizony's lens in 2001: Filming the Future
fields.body:
The Collected Stories

Arthur C Clarke

966pp, Gollancz, £20

Buy it at a discount at BOL

2001: Filming the Future

Piers Bizony

168pp, Aurum, £14.99

Buy it at a discount at BOL

For more than 50 years, and in cleverly coded form, Arthur C Clarke has been rewriting the Book of Revelation. Under the cover of his sometimes astonishingly prescient scientific speculation, he has brought us fables of imagined futuristic worlds where, at the story's close, we are shown that "the former things are passed away". As his Collected Stories helps to demonstrate, there has been no popular writer since the days of C S Lewis and Charles Williams whose disposition is more nakedly apocalyptic, who takes greater pleasure in cradling eternity in the palm of his hand.

At its ambitious best, Clarke's grave and lucidly written fiction vaults metaphysically across millennia and contracts the near-infinite arc of astronomical time. It gives us not the usual picturesque bric-a-brac of sci-fi - the invading aliens, dogfighting spaceships and feuding interstellar empires - but the long, immortalising perspective within which humanity's brief lifespan looks either newly irrelevant, or newly purposeful and complete. All his finest books share the same, dwarfing John Martin-ish visual perspective, the sense of tiny human figures suspended against visionary galactic immensities, transfigured at the supreme moment by the ages and the stars. Again and again, in Against the Fall of Night or 2001: A Space Odyssey or the Rendezvous with Rama novels or his last-days-of-the-human race classic Childhood's End, we seem to hear in our heads, as we read the final pages, the age-old biblical testimony: "And I saw a new heaven and new earth, for the first heaven and the first earth were passed away."

To describe Clarke as a mystical fabulist may sound perverse when there is so much in his work that appears hostile to the religious view, or at least unsentimentally agnostic. But beneath its progressive science, its apparent faith in the rational calm of the technological mind, his writing has always been disturbed by that ancient, bedevilling sorcerer's itch: the hunger for mysticism and metamorphosis. Long before magic realism, Clarke's science fiction found ways to make the outwardly miraculous an expression of an inner emotional need without violating the literal, technical integrity of the accepted external world.

In a factual essay, "The Obsolescence of Man", written in the early 1960s, Clarke had speculated: "Although intelligence can only arise from life, it may then discard it. Perhaps, as the mystics have suggested, it may also discard matter..." Essentially, this evolutionary sea-change, its imminence and dreadful beauty, became the theme of all his mature novels. Something of the precocious child, eager but unhappy in the world, still clings to his fiction. It's as if, from the start, the rooted intractability of human affairs distressed him, and he turned instead to a new dispensation, far in the future, when the tarnished experiment of "civilisation" - with all its congen ital warfare and wearying psychic division - is approaching its end, about to make the quantum jump to a realm of pure intelligence, something closer to the Buddhist ideal of integrated spiritual creation that I suspect Clarke at least half-believes.

"It might seem a risky notion to drive sci-fi into magic," wrote Penelope Gilliatt in the New Yorker in the spring of 1968, when the film of 2001: A Space Odyssey was first released, before concluding, in a shrewdly far-sighted review (which is quoted in full by Piers Bizony in his judicious and well-informed account of the film's production, 2001: Filming the Future ), that director Stanley Kubrick and Clarke had nevertheless "made it the poetically just place to go". Probably, at the same time, a shade too much of the conceptual credit for the film's half-luminous, half-baffling structure went to Kubrick, too little to Clarke, who had in fact selectively plundered a number of his earlier works in order to bring to the screenplay a narrative and philosophical audacity unheard of in mainstream commercial cinema.

As those early, appreciatively tuned-in college-student audiences instinctively understood, the film's shape was poetic and metaphorical, not straightforwardly dramatic. The transition from the shrieking, war-hungry man-apes brandishing their bone-clubs, agog at the sense of infinite possibility that strategic murder creates for their species, to the effortless technological super-sophistication of a half-empty Pan-Am space cruiser, waltzing the heavens with insolent imperial grace, gave us, in a single provocative jump-cut, a taste of Clarke and Kubrick's scepticism and restlessness. It demonstrated their fascination with the umbilical cord connecting the barbarous past and the far-seeking, ambitious future, their urge to make their audiences think philosophically.

It's interesting to see how the seeds of virtually all his major novels are scattered across Clarke's Collected Stories , in tightly wrought tales of serendipity or suspense that, while they contain seductive pre-echoes of the metaphysical breadth Clarke would achieve in the longer form, reveal him also as a twist-in-the-tail, punchline-addicted contributor to sci-fi periodicals such as Thrilling Wonder Stories and Science-Fantasy. The central ideas of 2001 originate in a series of small-scale but ingeniously plotted anecdotes of discovery or confrontation - the alien pyramid, unearthed from the lunar surface, signalling to its maker the news of the human race's first giant leap beyond the earth in "The Sentinel"; the visiting star-voyager benignly steering prehistoric man towards the uses of technology in "Encounter at Dawn". As Bizony describes, Kubrick was nervous of Clarke's sometimes too-neat facility for exposition, and continually pared back the detail of the screenplay, to concentrate on what was allusive and poetic and visual.

In the event, the film proved one of the most dazzling artefacts of the late 1960s. It scrutinised a solemnly immaculate future as coolly as if it were the domesticated present, putting sequences on the screen that seemed initially to have nothing to do with the traditional wham-bang excitements of B-movie sci-fi.

Clarke's skill, in his prose, was to draw moments of epiphany with an engineer's precision. Kubrick matched this with breathtakingly well-realised images of spaceflight and weightlessness, of eerily silent docking procedures and bleached lunar surfaces, of the velvet-deep, star-scattered infinity of immeasurable interstellar distances. In a succession of coldly disturbing and forensically lit flight-deck scenes he created the banal, unforgiving ritualised remoteness of space travel, its chilling existential far-offness from home.

Like those other rare, defining interior cinematic journeys - The Seventh Seal in the 1950s, Apocalypse Now on the cusp of the 1980s - 2001, with its idea of human strain washed clean by the infinite, seemed to express a whole culture's underlying fears, dreams, collective neuroses.

Probably it is unwise to praise Clarke without also confessing that his work remains riven with contradictions. His characters are brightly drawn but psychologically flat and undifferentiated, yet enduring human values are nevertheless the most important element in his imaginary universe. He writes like a man adapting the tools of fiction to the exhilarating long-range intellectual excitements and discoveries of the essayist, and the conceptual ideas that flow most freely and profoundly through the skein of his work. Yet one of his strengths is that his prodigious gift for scientific and technical invention never really gets the better of him.

His stories don't claim to be "great literature", but they stand sensible comparision with the work of talents like Arthur Conan Doyle, H G Wells and John Wyndham. They throng with memorable images, situations that have the power to cast their own disconcertingly long emotional shadow into the reader's mind. The least of them are mere clever doodles, playful but Roald Dahl-ishly glib. The best are like fairytales - wise, light-hearted but emotionally compelling, calmly luminous in their descriptions of terrible or miraculous events vivid with a sense of sadness and loss, and, like all profound stories of magic, essentially improbable, essentially convincing.

Like those other rare, defining interior cinematic journeys - The Seventh Seal in the 1950s, Apocalypse Now on the cusp of the 1980s - 2001, with its idea of human strain washed clean by the infinite, seemed to express a whole culture's underlying fears, dreams, collective neuroses. Probably it is unwise to praise Clarke without also confessing that his work remains riven with contradictions. His characters are brightly drawn but psychologically flat and undifferentiated, yet enduring human values are nevertheless the most important element in his imaginary universe. He writes like a man adapting the tools of fiction to the exhilarating long-range intellectual excitements and discoveries of the essayist, and the conceptual ideas that flow most freely and profoundly through the skein of his work. Yet one of his strengths is that his prodigious gift for scientific and technical invention never really gets the better of him. His stories don't claim to be "great literature", but they stand sensible comparision with the work of talents like Arthur Conan Doyle, H G Wells and John Wyndham. They throng with memorable images, situations that have the power to cast their own disconcertingly long emotional shadow into the reader's mind. The least of them are mere clever doodles, playful but Roald Dahl-ishly glib. The best are like fairytales - wise, light-hearted but emotionally compelling, calmly luminous in their descriptions of terrible or miraculous events vivid with a sense of sadness and loss, and, like all profound stories of magic, essentially improbable, essentially convincing.

fields.headline: Conscience of a nation
fields.standfirst: The child of working-class immigrants to America, he has become one of the 10 most quoted sources in the humanities - along with Shakespeare and the Bible.  Maya Jaggi on the founding father of linguistic philosophy and tireless scourge of US imperialism
