fields.headline: Narratives of life caught on the wind
fields.standfirst: Adam Thorpe tells Nicholas Wroe of the poetic influences on his novels
fields.trailText: Adam Thorpe tells Nicholas Wroe of the poetic influences on his novels
fields.body:
Soon after the publication of his first collection of poetry in 1988, Mornings in the Baltic, Adam Thorpe was asked by a perceptive editor whether he had considered writing a novel. Thorpe conceded that he had, dug out a few stories he had been working on for the previous six or seven years and began work on what was to become Ulverton, his virtuoso and highly praised account of the lives of 12 generations of inhabitants of a single English village. The publication in paperback this month of his sequence of stories based around the world of work, Shifts, indicates that long gestation periods seem to suit him.

"I started Shifts pretty much at the same time as Ulverton ," he says. But getting the three elements necessary for each story - the person telling it, the story itself and the work - has taken me all this time." Thorpe has used material from jobs he did, "when times were hard or when I was a student; eg neon-bulb factory machine operator, dustman, airline dish washer," but listening to him talk about his literary life it is clear that his real occupation has always been as a writer. "I started my first novel when I was 11. I sat in the back room of the optician's where my mother worked and wrote about a man chasing his hat on a windy day through Chesham. But, as usually happens when writing a novel, the doldrums set in and I gave up at about page 13. But it was an absolutely serious attempt to write this novel."

Thorpe says he remembers his early reading as being, "rather old fashioned". He was born in Paris and as a child moved to Beirut and then Calcutta before his family went to the Congo and Cameroon and Thorpe went to boarding school in England.

"We had a beautiful Everyman edition of the Just So stories. I was absolutely haunted by them, particularly Kipling's pictures. They were very weird and highly designed but I did like stuff that faintly frightened me. There was also an abridged edition of Dickens's A Christmas Carol with a picture of Marley's ghost on it that absolutely petrified me. Kidnapped and Treasure Island with Blind Pew were also central."

In his mid teens he became interested in poetry and, because of his unhappiness at school, would spend long periods of time on his own in the library making anthologies for his younger sister. "I remember doing an animal anthology with Lawrence's The Snake and Ted Hughes's The Horses," he says. "I'd re-write them out in fountain pen and find pictures to go with them. It was a great way of learning them."

When he was 17 he "stumbled across" Mercian Hymns, Geoffrey Hill's influential poetry sequence. It was the decisive literary moment. "Here was someone who was expressing something about England that seemed to me very important," Thorpe explains. "He mingled the past and the present and talked about history and tyranny and suffering. As a schoolboy trying to understand my own personal past as well as that of the country I was part of, it was a revelation."

While at this stage Thorpe couldn't conceive of writing as a career, he also couldn't see himself sitting behind a desk or teaching. "I was in love with the romantic idea of being a poet, but I was also attracted by the theatre."

After university Thorpe did become a teacher of theatre and mime as well as touring villages in Berkshire and Wiltshire as a sort of "wandering minstrel." He says he, "burrowed round looking for folk tales. The idea was to keep local and relate to the local community. I was concerned to put down roots as I had had a fairly rootless childhood in many ways. That's where most of the inspiration for Ulverton came from and three of the tales ended up in Ulverton."

Despite its apparent quintessential Englishness, Ulverton has travelled well and has been much translated. Thorpe, who now lives in France, says in fact the reaction of French readers is very similar to that of English readers. "The Englishness doesn't seem to feature. The French relate to it because the themes are universal and not particularly English at all; the concentration on rural issues and so on."

He has gone on to publish two more collections of poetry, a play and two more novels - Still and Pieces of Light - with a third due this summer. He has also recently written a radio play, Something Memorable, based on Thomas Hardy's "The Darkling Thrush". Working on the play has made him think he must go back to try his hand at a another full-length play. An impulse made stronger by his experience of writing the stories in Shifts.

"There is a compression and an intensity to a short story which is closer to poetry or drama than the novel. But one has to be careful not to stifle the story by over-compressing it. There is an illusion of something more relaxed, that this is a fragment of somebody's life or narrative. There must be a sense that these are things caught on the wind, something overheard. It was Doris Lessing who said that writers are like magpies who pick up glittery things to line their nests and that is exactly what I have been doing. I've been going round with my eyes and ears open for anything that would feed into Shifts. The soil had been ready to be seeded for nine years and has been seeded by anything that happened to drift into my view."

 Something Memorable will be broadcast on Radio 4 on Friday at 2.15pm.

Working on the play has made him think he must go back to try his hand at a another full-length play. An impulse made stronger by his experience of writing the stories in Shifts. "There is a compression and an intensity to a short story which is closer to poetry or drama than the novel. But one has to be careful not to stifle the story by over-compressing it. There is an illusion of something more relaxed, that this is a fragment of somebody's life or narrative. There must be a sense that these are things caught on the wind, something overheard. It was Doris Lessing who said that writers are like magpies who pick up glittery things to line their nests and that is exactly what I have been doing. I've been going round with my eyes and ears open for anything that would feed into Shifts. The soil had been ready to be seeded for nine years and has been seeded by anything that happened to drift into my view."  Something Memorable will be broadcast on Radio 4 on Friday at 2.15pm.

fields.headline: Dead good
fields.standfirst: Returning from Hollywood to star in British movies would be a step back for most, but Sixth Sense star Olivia Williams was tempted by sex, drugs and cruelty
fields.trailText: Returning from Hollywood to star in British movies would be a step back for most, but Sixth Sense star Olivia Williams was tempted by sex, drugs and cruelty
fields.body:
There's something reassuring about Olivia Williams. This Royal Shakespeare Company actor brought a very English voice of reason to Hollywood movies The Sixth Sense and The Postman, and was the stabilising influence to Jason Schwartzman's lovestruck schoolboy in the 1998 comedy Rushmore. Now she's refusing to get carried away in an adaptation of Martin Amis's Dead Babies, in which she plays a bored young woman barely putting up with her hedonistic friends on a weekend break that turns very nasty indeed.

Dead Babies is a pretty gruesome film. What qualities attracted you to the project?

I was attracted to the uncompromising bleakness of it. After reading seven or eight scripts that have the prescribed happy ending or redeemed characters, it was almost a relief to read something nihilistic.

Did the violence ever bother you?

Yes, and so did the sex and the drugs and the cruelty to people and animals, but I had never been asked to test my own limits before, and decided that if I was going to break my own rules, Martin Amis was worth breaking them for. Most of the time it is a question of breaking my rules for the sake of titillation or derivative writing, the answer to which is no.

Do you think Amis's novel is a witty parody of empty lifestyles, or just plain cynical?

It is pretty clear that he was writing from experience, and this was borne out when we met him - many of the characters were based on contemporaries. Having read Experience [Amis's memoir] I think it is clear that the vacuity and waste in these lives bothers him... not to say there isn't an unforgivable pleasure in describing the most excessive aspects of it.

Your character is the only one who emerges with any kind of dignity. Did you relate to how she felt?

My favourite line is, "I want a drug that makes me feel nothing - that is, if this evening is as stupid and nasty as it looks like being." I can relate to that.

How did you get involved in the project?

I auditioned first about three years ago, then the project disappeared. I was called in again, with low expectations and was amazed to be cast.

You've done stage with the Royal Shakespeare Company, big-budget Hollywood, small-budget Hollywood and independent British. Which is the most satisfying?

Each has its own very different rewards - almost not comparable. The rehearsal process for stage is hugely rewarding, and the extraordinary high of three hours' concentrated performance culminating in applause and a large drink is very addictive. Film acting is more zen; you take pleasure in the three-minute take in which you feel your feet may have just left the ground rather than the space travel of theatre. But then galloping across the high deserts of Oregon on a beautiful horse with Kevin Costner by your side has its compensations too... My most sublime filming day was in Rushmore watching Bill Murray eat a carrot. Does this answer qualify for Pseuds Corner yet?

Finally, what's next on the agenda?

As I write, I am on the horns of a dilemma. Right on the horns. Ouch. I'll tell you when I make up my mind.

fields.headline: 'Duvet day' protest by Vauxhall workers
fields.trailText: Luton is facing a flu epidemic next Thursday when thousands of Vauxhall workers stage a "duvet day" protest over the car factory's proposed closure.
fields.body:
Luton is facing a flu epidemic next Thursday when thousands of Vauxhall workers stage a "duvet day" protest over the car factory's proposed closure.

The 2,200-strong workforce is planning to ring in sick to get round employment laws that would prevent them legally joining a Europe-wide day of inaction.

So when German, Belgian and Spanish employees go on strike, Britons will catch colds, suffer stomach bugs and wake up with splitting headaches.

An organiser of the protest said: "Employment laws leave us with no alternative. General Motors did not consult us before they decided to shut the plant."

General Motors is to shut Luton with the loss of 2,200 jobs in 15 months. A similar number of jobs are due to go in Germany. The unions accuse the company of breaking past commitments to invest in Luton and failing properly to consult the corporation's European works council. A strike ballot is to start in Britain next Friday but will take two weeks, and a further seven days' notice is required before industrial action can start.

The idea of "sickies" as a form of industrial protest was pioneered by British Airways staff in a dispute during the mid-1990s. Union leaders, if pressed, would be forced to disown the action to protect their funds from court sequestration if they were proved to have backed it.

A march and rally are planned today in Luton town centre. Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union, said: "Vauxhall cannot be allowed to close a profitable plant and dump thousands of loyal workers on the dole."

The Manufacturing, Science and Finance union calculates that Vauxhall has made about £100,000 profit per employee over the past decade.

A spokesman for Vauxhall said: "We are not speculating about the future. We look forward to a full week's production next week."

fields.headline: Ashdown Park, Sussex
fields.trailText: With a neighbouring chapel, this former convent is in grounds with 186 acres of lakes, lawns, trails and gardens. Stunning.
fields.body:
Address: Wych Cross, Forest Row, East Sussex RH18 5JR.

Reservations: Small Luxury Hotels of the World, tel: 00 800 525 48000

Web address: www.slh.com

First impressions:

Huge country-house estate. The kind of place that Elizabeth Bennett and Mr Darcy set up home in together. With a neighbouring chapel, this former convent is in grounds with 186 acres of lakes, lawns, trails and gardens. Stunning.

What are the rooms like?

Our Fairway suite opened out on to the golf course. Extremely spacious with large double bed, sofa and two arm-chairs, satellite TV, bottles of still and sparkling water plus tea- and coffee-making.

The bed test:

Some rooms have four-poster beds. Ours didn't, but it was still large and comfy.

Bathroom luxury:

Outstanding. Huge with (height of luxury) two sinks, a walk-in shower and a large whirlpool bath. Generous quantities of smellies by Molton Brown plus fluffy bathrobe, slippers, the works.

The restaurant:

Award-winning and delicious range of modern and traditional food. Three-course table d'hote very reasonable (lunch for two without wine came to less than £50) and dinner is a suitably pampered occasion, with cocktails and canapes served in the lounge. Light meals can be served in your room.

The lounge:

Oak panelled and real log fires. Better yet is the basement games room with two full-size snooker tables and bar billiards.

What is there to see within walking distance?

You'd be hard pushed to walk to the end of the driveway.

What is there to see nearby?

Visit Ann Boleyn's ghost at Hever Castle or play pooh sticks at Pooh Corner.

How much a night?

Singles from £120 to £175, suites from £230 to £330. Includes dinner, full English breakfast and membership of the country club for your stay. Various weekend break deals available.

fields.headline: Back to a job on the line
fields.standfirst: Interview: Kevin Howe, chief executive, MG Rover
fields.trailText: A tall, burly man with goatee beard and moustache, Kevin Howe, chief executive of MG Rover, strides around the Longbridge complex exuding a deep-seated air of control. He enjoys a surprisingly warm relationship with employees, given the fearsome reputation he carries from his time as manufacturing director in the old, pre-BMW regime.
fields.body:
A tall, burly man with goatee beard and moustache, Kevin Howe, chief executive of MG Rover, strides around the Longbridge complex exuding a deep-seated air of control. He enjoys a surprisingly warm relationship with employees, given the fearsome reputation he carries from his time as manufacturing director in the old, pre-BMW regime.

"Hi, Terry," he says to an assembly line worker scarred by two decades of despair and doubt at Rover. "What's the mood?" Terry replies: "Best I've known. We've had the Japanese [Honda], the Germans [BMW] and now we're back in English control so if we can't make it now, it's our fault. But it's down to you - I'm just a small cog and you're the big cog." Howe disabuses him: "We're all in this together, you, me and the rest of us."

Walking on, he points to a multistorey car park for storing vehicles before they go to dealers. "Built in the 1960s and ugly: it's got to go. I'm getting rid of it this year. We'll landscape it and open up a vista."

Mr Howe, who holds a master's degree in business administration, was part of the turnaround team under BMW which left managerial control in British hands - much to the German company's subsequent chagrin after it invested £3bn and lost almost as much.

He is "totally besotted with" turning the company around. Part of his task is to persuade a sceptical media that Rover has a future as an independent company, and to be more transparent about its finances, production programmes and sales.

Back in the Red Room - a refurbished executive dining suite more reminiscent of negotiating tables in communist eastern Europe - he lays a transparency in the overhead projection and tries, unsuccessfully, to manipulate a chart showing the "profits bridge", a plan to transform Rover's financial fortunes from the £840m lost by BMW in 1999 to the small profit pledged for 2002.

But the point is clear. Strip out Land Rover's losses of more than £100m, now Ford's responsibility, and BMW's £550m one-off losses, and he's well on the way.

Take away the share of overheads under BMW that included Oxford, now home to the new Mini, the Gaydon research centre down the M42 and the Warwick headquarters, and bring the entire Rover business under one roof by the summer - and lo, there's a performance gap of around £100m to be filled by better trading.

Mr Howe is adamant that free of BMW's shackles the group will no longer have to perform to a corporate strategy - a "game" devised in Munich - but will survive by balancing output and sales. "We'll only sell cars that make a profit," he says, adding that for a limited period he'll sustain a few loss-making sales areas until the new MGs expand the group's overseas presence.

For the time being he is stuck with the R25 and R45 models, which have only a few more years life in them, and the new R75 executive car designed under the aegis of BMW.

Mr Howe is proud that the R75 production line was transferred from the BMW-owned Oxford plant to Longbridge in just 12 weeks, and that every one of the 600 cars that come off the line each week is already sold. Production is to be doubled by September to meet demand.

Last Monday, the first body shells of a dozen prototype R75 estates rolled down the line, a week ahead of schedule. They've been given spot welds by 140 robots - part of a £400m investment bequeathed by BMW. The gleaming new line, lit by halogen lamps, contrasts starkly with the dark corners of the hall opened in 1980 for the ill-fated Metro, and scene of sullen exchanges between workers and management which often turned into stoppages that brought the UK car industry to its knees.

The will to survive

In Longbridge the talk is of turnaround, optimism, self-belief, independence; even of hiring new staff. Mr Howe says he's constantly struck by the openness of contact: "They look you straight in the eye; they want to talk; they're engaged."

This buoyant mood may prove to be short-lived, and certainly does not reflect the overall ambience of the UK car industry which, faced with yet more global change, is riven with uncertainties and self-doubt. General Motors is adamant it will end Vauxhall production at Luton, and the fate of Nissan's Sunderland plant is still unclear despite EU officials approving £40m of government aid.

Mr Howe, who has spent most of his working life in the motor industry, did not expect to be back at the sharp end of all this. His 11 years on the management fast track at Rover covered jobs in systems, planning, logistics and manufacturing. When he left Rover at the end of 1999 to join Rolls-Royce, the aerospace group, as managing director of the fan systems division, he thought he was embarking on a new career. Then came a call from his old boss, former Rover chief executive John Towers, asking whether he would return as chief executive.

There was no guarantee that Mr Towers would be in a position to offer him the job. Jon Moulton and his Alchemy venture capital firm were favourites to buy Rover from BMW, and Mr Towers' Phoenix consortium looked like an also ran.

But all changed when the Alchemy deal fell through. Rover was losing up to £840m a year, and BMW could not get rid of it quickly enough. Phoenix bought the business for £10, and collected a £500m interest free 50-year loan from BMW in the process.

Mr Howe is encouraged by newspaper stories about the loan being repayable from group profits. "At least they think we are going to make profits," he says.

So, is there a sustained future for MG Rover and the rest of the UK motor industry? Professor Garel Rhys at Cardiff business school says last year's talk of a meltdown was always overblown, and that many of the problems, especially in pre-war plants such as Luton and Dagenham, had been around for years.

The key to the future, he adds, is making cars people want to buy - for quality, price and brand value.

The public's response to three new MG saloons, derived from the 25, 45 and 75 series and on offer from the summer, will be critical to Rover's success. Mr Howe's five-year business plan envisages trading in the black next year, with 190,000 cars sold this year and over 210,000 in 2002.

He is determined to escape the ignominy of 20 years ago, when BL slapped the MG badge on Metros and Maestros, to public disdain. The new MGs will not be derivatives but "significantly differentiated", priced from around £10,000 to £35,000 for the "outrageously performing" model with a V8 engine producing 300hp. MG, already booked for Le Mans, is also set to enter rallies and tours.

But very soon decisions must be made about the design, building and financing of the new medium range car, due to enter production in 2004 after development costs of more than £250m.

It's assumed that Rover is talking to Malaysia's Proton - hardly a byword for brand value - about a collaboration that could lead to a merger or takeover. This assumption is false. Rover would much rather talk to VW or Peugeot, and Mr Howe indicated this week he strongly favoured going it alone by shortening the R75 "platform" as the basis for the new car - provided unit costs are kept down.

"By 2004, all our models will be replaced and it will be self-financed," he says confidently. His confidence will be tested by the public's response to the new MGs.

webTitle: 'Promising' tests on car speed limiters extended

fields.headline: 'Promising' tests on car speed limiters extended
fields.trailText: The government has commissioned a trial of speed limiters in cars, which could lead to computer-controlled overrides as a standard fitting within five years.
fields.body:
The government has commissioned a trial of speed limiters in cars, which could lead to computer-controlled overrides as a standard fitting within five years.

Twenty trial vehicles will be fitted with a system which has won praise on a prototype Ford Escort driven over thousands of rigidly monitored miles in the past three years.

The tests, which prevented the car from topping 30mph, 40mph and other limits, were "highly reliable" according to the Institute of Transport Studies at Leeds University, which has won funding for the expanded trials from the Department of Transport, Environment and the Regions.

"We've had two dozen people driving along a 40 mile route, including the A1M motorway," said Oliver Carsten, head of the project, which has also been demonstrated on the north circular road in London.

The system uses a computerised navigator linked to the car's electronic controls and a positioning satellite. Areas with speed restrictions are fed into the system to trigger action as soon as a limit is breached.

webTitle: Sleepy resort where developers might dispel the gloom

fields.headline: Sleepy resort where developers might dispel the gloom
fields.trailText: The sleepy seaside town of Bridlington, nestled in a sweeping Yorkshire bay between Whitby and Scarborough, is hell bent on becoming the new Brighton, Bournemouth or Blackpool.
fields.body:
The sleepy seaside town of Bridlington, nestled in a sweeping Yorkshire bay between Whitby and Scarborough, is hell bent on becoming the new Brighton, Bournemouth or Blackpool.

It has come up with an ambitious £60m regeneration plan to wake from its slumbers and become England's premier conference venue.

If the project - spearheaded by East Riding county council - goes ahead, it will be the single largest development of its kind on the east coast of England.

Plans include a shimmering new conference centre which could attract thousands of delegates to meet, talk and gaze over the breezy North sea.

A 500-berth marina would pull in big-spending boat owners, and new commercial, leisure and residential developments would also help to revive the resort's fortunes.

Bridlington is typical of an English seaside town in winter with its closed cafes and vacant, tacky, amusement arcades. A third of the town's population is over 60 - a higher proportion than anywhere else in England. Pensioners shuffle up and down the otherwise empty promenades and the dull drizzle that hangs over the bare beaches creates an overwhelming aura of a place whose best days have long since passed. It is begging for a facelift.

The Bridlington regeneration partnership, which is managing the plan, includes local interests ranging from the Royal Yorkshire Yacht Club to the Humber Chamber of Commerce.

A total of £14m has been set aside from the council's capital budget, and the remainder of the funds are expected to come from European grants and private sector investment. Plans have been drawn up, business proposals assessed, and the local population consulted.

However, the Bridlington Protection Group is challenging the viability of the development, and warns of the negative impact on the make-up of the local community, the marine environment and existing businesses.

The group claims a survey conducted on its behalf found only 4.3% of local people in favour of the project. The planned marina development is, it says, out of proportion to the size of the town. New properties would change the face of the harbour, ruin views and destroy the town's character. There is a danger of Bridlington's heritage being lost and preservation being sacrificed in the name of progress.

Opponents also fear that the social make-up of the area will be altered as the affluent, upwardly mobile, move in. Property prices will rise and the citizens of Leeds and Bradford, who traditionally retire to "Brid", will have to look for their bungalows elsewhere.

John Hunter, 29, has lived in the town all his life. The family restaurant he runs has a panoramic view of the stretch of harbour targeted for redevelopment, and he recognises that his business could be changed for ever if the plans go ahead.

"Some local businesses will be affected, including my own, but at some point you have to put your own selfish interests aside in the interests of the town."

His restaurant is empty but his enthusiasm for the future fills the room. "I'm all for it. It will bring money in and a lot of investment. So what if the place changes?

"I love it here but that doesn't mean things must always stay the same. It's visitors mainly, and old people who are afraid of change, who are objecting. I just can't see why they are so sceptical. We will be the envy of other resorts if this goes ahead."

The council claims the development can only be good for the town and that it will be a catalyst for wider regeneration, bringing jobs and increasing property values.

Simon Taylor, of the Yorkshire Marina partnership, said: "There are a small number of people with concerns and we are taking these on board. But this project is about reversing a decline."

With government approval, the development could be completed by 2004.

fields.headline: Tabla, London
fields.standfirst: The soulless wasteland that is Canary Wharf really needs spicing up. And Tabla, in its own way, is doing just that, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: The soulless wasteland that is Canary Wharf really needs spicing up. And Tabla, in its own way, is doing just that, says Matthew Fort.
fields.body:
You're going to have dry urad lentils," said Persimmon.

"How do you know?" I said, slightly miffed, because I was, it so happened.

"Because it's the most obscure dish on the menu," she said.

Am I so predictable?

There's something of the Cities of the Plains about Canary Wharf. It may be that plodding around the place in the driving rain did not improve my mood, but it always seems to me that the buildings here have been erected as a set for a disaster movie by some designer who manages to encompass the vast and the vulgar with unswerving vision. Any moment the whole thing will be swept away by some cataclysmic act of God.

Yet, tucked away in a corner of this monument to Mammon is a rather handsome Georgian house that has taken on new life as a rather handsome Indian restaurant. (For anyone who has read the diaries of the original William Hickey, there is a rather pleasing frisson about the conversion of a specifically Georgian building for these purposes, for when the old boy's family had had enough of him frolicking and philandering his way through London in the time of George III, he was packed off to India for a spot of soul-saving.

The change of address, however, did nothing to diminish his appetites, and the diaries in India are full of details of eating and drinking on a scale that makes the adventures of modern-day trencherfolk look like visits to a health farm. But that's all by the bye.)

Tabla is the first restaurant adventure of Iqbal Wahab - who, as editor of Tandoori magazine, once caused something of a fuss by saying that not all the waiters in Indian restaurants had been to the Pierce Brosnan school of charm - and of Albert Ray - once of The Ivy, Alastair Little and St John. It marks another step in the gentrification of Indian restaurants, away from the cheap and frequently not very cheerful curry house of yore.

The outside of Tabla is gracious Georgian. The inside is pleasantly airy and handsomely nondescript. In an era of obsessive design, such forbearance is really rather soothing.

I slightly wish the forbearance had extended to the form of the menu, which is about the size of a crusader's shield. As the list of dishes is relatively limited by the standards of other Indian restaurants, this means that there is a lot of creamy space around the margins.

Contrary to the Brobdingnagian scale of the menu card, I found the restrained number of dishes something of a relief, as I did not experience the sense of helpless inadequacy that I tend to feel when confronted with a massive choice. The menu ranges pretty freely all over the subcontinent, with representatives from Kerala, Goa and Rajasthan, to name but a few, that I could spot.

In the event, Persimmon zeroed in on pea and coriander soup and then spring vegetable biryani and then coconut sorbet. I followed a different route by way of crab cakes flavoured with coconut and chilli, ox tongue and chickpea soup (off the dishes of the day), lamb cooked in a karahi with Indian bitter gourd karella and, yes, the dry urad lentils, and carrot halva with vanilla ice cream to finish off.

I must point out that the restaurant was (undeservedly) virtually empty on this particular lunchtime. It may have been the unspeakable weather, or the toilers in the Canary Wharf vineyards may have been giving their livers and lites time off for good behaviour following the festive season, but, whatever the reason, Persimmon and I were among six people all told. Such a situation is a serious test of a kitchen's resolve - most restaurants like to work flat out, and find it difficult to concentrate when they aren't. The kitchen at Tabla showed no such weakness, however: each dish was exemplary in its attention to detail, in its finish and, above all, in its spicing.

I've said it before, and I'll say it again: the genius of Indian cooking lies in the spicing. When the spices are freshly ground and the dishes freshly cooked, then you get a sensation of savour and perfume and pleasure that hums in the mouth and lingers around the tonsils. When the food has been sitting around for a few hours and the spices for a lot longer, then the dishes taste brown and flat.

So it was all the more impressive that, as the dishes rolled out, you could pick out the scents and tastes of cardamom, clove, cumin, cinnamon, chilli, fenugreek and a whole lot more that I couldn't identify. The coconut and chilli breathed lightly through the crab cakes, which were fluffy and light as thistledown. Fresh chilli cut the richness of the potent ox tongue and chickpea soup.

The lamb cooked in karahi had not been braised so long that it had lost its texture entirely, but it was easy to cut with a fork alone. Persimmon was cheered by the winter-warming nature of her pea and coriander soup and perked up by the vegetable biryani as it emerged from beneath its pastry cap, softly steaming and vivacious with spice. Then she attacked my dry urad lentils with such vigour that I had difficulty in rescuing any for myself; and they were well worth rescuing. The puddings, too, were distinctly superior, the vanilla ice cream with the fragrant carrot halva among the best I have had for some time.

Now, the really nice thing about all this was that, while the food at Tabla was just as good, if not better, than that in the more ambitious London restaurants, the bill was not - £67.70 is more than you would expect to spend in Southall or Brick Lane, sure, but certainly less than you would at most of the other establishments in Canary Wharf, particularly if the bill included £22 for a bottle of splendid Crozes Hermitage 1997 off a short, sharp wine list. Take away the water, too, and we ended up with £42.75 for the food, some of which, to our shame, we were unable to finish.

All in all, when the terminal tidal wave finally engulfs Canary Wharf, I rather hope that it spares Tabla.

webTitle: The art of good design is never to forget the simple pleasures in life

fields.headline: The art of good design is never to forget the simple pleasures in life
fields.trailText: Whenever designers start to discourse on garden spaces, it seems to me that they become virtually incomprehensible. Perhaps the difficulty lies in defining a void - something that isn't there, or that is there only by virtue of what surrounds it.
fields.body:
Whenever designers start to discourse on garden spaces, it seems to me that they become virtually incomprehensible. Perhaps the difficulty lies in defining a void - something that isn't there, or that is there only by virtue of what surrounds it.

It is perfectly true that we should not become too engrossed by detail - after all, if our vision can never rest from checking for aphids on the roses or spotting weeds (both more likely in our own gardens than in those we are visiting, where we can take a detached view), we shall never appreciate the scene as a whole: the way the shadows slant, the translucence of backlit foliage, the silhouette of trees against an evening sky. Those are the sort of impressions that make a garden worth being in.

But how much uncluttered space we should allow around us is largely a question of balance. The jungle effect - that sense of enclosure by beautiful flower and foliage shapes, and by colours through which you almost seem to be swimming - can be very stimulating. But you also want to emerge from all that excitement to somewhere you can sit and contemplate or chat, yet still have something nice to look at.

Some of the more intellectual designers fancy a hedged-in space with a pool at its centre, perhaps the tinkle of a water spout, with a weeping silver-leaved pear at one end and a bench. I think that is plain boring. Even if I just want to read, it is important, when I raise my eyes, that there should be a pleasing scene before me. As I like plants, this will probably include plants. Water is fine for reflections, but you need something good to reflect; and the water must be still, not in a constant fidget from that water spout. Anyway, a blackbird's song is sound enough.

A garden is for companionship as well as for peace and quiet, so you want to be sure you have the right sort of seating. In two parts of our garden, Lutyens designed us a long oak bench with right-angled returns at each end, which make for easier conversation. They are in an embrasure, enclosed by hedging on three sides and wide open on the fourth, which presents a good view. That is where the value of space comes in.

The great thing in gardening is to avoid clutter. There is often a lot of ongoing fuss, perhaps from colourful coils of hose pipe or rubbish that you have left as witness to your industry, hoping that someone else will clear it away. But there is even more from having too many plants unrelated to their neighbours.

The collector's garden is not to be despised. It may be packed with interesting detail of which good use could be made if only it were more restfully disposed. And that would, admittedly, entail throwing out a lot. I could, in fact, tell you what to throw out, but then I am amazingly good at throwing out other people's clutter (don't you dare touch mine, however).

Nearly half the plants being grown are there for some stupid, sentimental reason. "Dear old Mrs Gregory gave it to me only months before she died." But wouldn't it be better to remember her without the plant? "No; it makes me picture her, somehow, usually with a drip on the end of her nose. That even makes me reach for my own tissue." Yes, but... "And I brought that one back from the Mont Cenis pass. It was quite forbidden to dig up anything, but somehow that makes it the more precious." Aren't you setting a bad example? Big sigh. No further explanation or defence forthcoming.

Surely you don't need to keep that ? It's no better than a weed."That's the trouble. Our neighbours gave it to us on our arrival, when we needed to stock the garden, and now we don't know how to get rid of it and it's into everything." Glyphosate works wonders in a tight corner. "Harold doesn't believe that weedkillers are right, and I can't hold out against him."

Your forsythia is enormous. Think of all the space it's occupying where you could grow something that did more for you through the year. "I know, I know, but it is an area I never have to worry about. Besides, there's the labour of getting it out. I expect we shall get around to it some day." Well, the yucca is well placed. It really does something for that corner. "We're going to get rid of it. It was there when we came. Jacko, our old terrier, is blind and I'm afraid of his walking into those vicious points." (If he's blind already, perhaps that wouldn't be too serious?)

Advice is easily given (whether free or charged for) but is less readily taken. What it boils down to is whether you are getting maximum enjoyment from your garden. If you can think of ways by which to enjoy it more, seize on them. Giving yourself more space, even with the little you have at your disposal, is one way. But its being restful is not synonymous with its being agreeable. We need to nourish our senses, but not to cram them with a pile of flotsam.

webTitle: Review: Late Victorian Holocausts by Mike Davis

fields.headline: Hunger strike
fields.standfirst: Sukhdev Sandhu  on Late Victorian Holocausts - the famines that fed the empire -  by Mike Davis
fields.trailText: Sukhdev Sandhu on Late Victorian Holocausts - the famines that fed the empire - by Mike Davis
fields.body:
Late Victorian Holocausts: El Nino Famines and the Making of the Third World

Mike Davis

464pp, Verso, £20
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Recording the past can be a tricky business for historians. Prophesying the future is even more hazardous. In 1901, shortly before the death of Queen Victoria, the radical writer William Digby looked back to the 1876 Madras famine and confidently asserted: "When the part played by the British Empire in the 19th century is regarded by the historian 50 years hence, the unnecessary deaths of millions of Indians would be its principal and most notorious monument." Who now remembers the Madrasis?

In Late Victorian Holocausts, Mike Davis charts the unprecedented human suffering caused by a series of extreme climactic conditions in the final quarter of the 19th century. Drought and monsoons afflicted much of China, southern Africa, Brazil, Egypt and India. The death tolls were staggering: around 12m Chinese and over 6m Indians in 1876-1878 alone. The chief culprit, according to Davis, was not the weather, but European empires, with Japan and the US. Their imposition of free-market economics on the colonial world was tantamount to a "cultural genocide".

These are strong words. Yet it's hard to disagree with them after reading Davis's harrowing book. Development economists have long argued that drought need not lead to famine; well-stocked inventories and effective distribution can limit the damage. In the 19th century, however, drought was treated, particularly by the English in India, as an opportunity for reasserting sovereignty.

A particular villain was Lord Lytton, son of the Victorian novelist Edward Bulwer-Lytton ("It was a dark and stormy night...") after whom, today, a well-known bad writing prize is named. During 1876 Lytton, widely suspected to be insane, ignored all efforts to alleviate the suffering of millions of peasants in the Madras region and concentrated on preparing for Queen Victoria's investiture as Empress of India. The highlight of the celebrations was a week-long feast of lucullan excess at which 68,000 dignitaries heard her promise the nation "happiness, prosperity and welfare".

Lytton believed in free trade. He did nothing to check the huge hikes in grain prices, Economic "modernization" led household and village reserves to be transferred to central depots using recently built railroads. Much was exported to England, where there had been poor harvests. Telegraph technology allowed prices to be centrally co-ordinated and, inevitably, raised in thousands of small towns. Relief funds were scanty because Lytton was eager to finance military campaigns in Afghanistan. Conditions in emergency camps were so terrible that some peasants preferred to go to jail. A few, starved and senseless, resorted to cannibalism. This was all of little consequence to many English administrators who, as believers in Malthusianism, thought that famine was nature's response to Indian over-breeding.

It used to be that the late 19th century was celebrated in every school as the golden period of imperialism. While few of us today would defend empire in moral terms, we've long been encouraged to acknowledge its economic benefits. Yet, as Davis points out, "there was no increase in India's per capita income from 1757 to 1947". In Egypt, too, the financial difficulties caused to peasants by famine encouraged European creditors to override the millennia-old tradition that tenancy was guaranteed for life. What little relief aid reached Brazil, meanwhile, ended up profiting British merchant houses and the reactionary sugar-planter classes.

The European "locusts" did not go unchallenged. Rioting became common. Banditry increased. In China, drought-famine helped to spark the Boxer uprising. In Europe, the fin de siècle was largely an opportunity for pale-faced men to wear purple cummerbunds and spout rotten symbolist poetry; for colonized peoples it genuinely seemed to presage mass extinction. It was, says Davis, "a new dark age of colonial war, indentured labour, concentration camps, genocide, forced migration, famine and disease."

Davis's attention to the importance of environment may recall the work of the Annales school of historians, but he is far more radical than any of them. His writing, both here and in such classic books as City of Quartz and Ecology of Fear, is closer to that of Latin American intellectuals such as Ariel Dorfman and the Urguayan, Eduardo Galaeno, who for decades have spotlighted capitalism's casual abuse of the third world and who have sought to champion the poor and dispossessed. Such commitment, forcefully and lucidly expressed, is unfashionable these days.

"Class" may be passé in academic circles, yet the catalogue of cruelty Davis has unearthed is jaw-dropping. A friend to whom I lent the book was reduced to tears by it. Late Victorian Holocausts is as ugly as it is compelling. But, as Conrad's Marlow said in Heart of Darkness : "The conquest of the earth, which means the taking away from those who have a different complexion and slightly flatter noses than ourselves, is not a pretty thing when you look at it too much."
fields.bodyText: Late Victorian Holocausts: El Nino Famines and the Making of the Third World Mike Davis 464pp, Verso, £20 Buy it at a discount at BOL Recording the past can be a tricky business for historians. Prophesying the future is even more hazardous. In 1901, shortly before the death of Queen Victoria, the radical writer William Digby looked back to the 1876 Madras famine and confidently asserted: "When the part played by the British Empire in the 19th century is regarded by the historian 50 years hence, the unnecessary deaths of millions of Indians would be its principal and most notorious monument." Who now remembers the Madrasis? In Late Victorian Holocausts, Mike Davis charts the unprecedented human suffering caused by a series of extreme climactic conditions in the final quarter of the 19th century. Drought and monsoons afflicted much of China, southern Africa, Brazil, Egypt and India. The death tolls were staggering: around 12m Chinese and over 6m Indians in 1876-1878 alone. The chief culprit, according to Davis, was not the weather, but European empires, with Japan and the US. Their imposition of free-market economics on the colonial world was tantamount to a "cultural genocide". These are strong words. Yet it's hard to disagree with them after reading Davis's harrowing book. Development economists have long argued that drought need not lead to famine; well-stocked inventories and effective distribution can limit the damage. In the 19th century, however, drought was treated, particularly by the English in India, as an opportunity for reasserting sovereignty. A particular villain was Lord Lytton, son of the Victorian novelist Edward Bulwer-Lytton ("It was a dark and stormy night...") after whom, today, a well-known bad writing prize is named. During 1876 Lytton, widely suspected to be insane, ignored all efforts to alleviate the suffering of millions of peasants in the Madras region and concentrated on preparing for Queen Victoria's investiture as Empress of India. The highlight of the celebrations was a week-long feast of lucullan excess at which 68,000 dignitaries heard her promise the nation "happiness, prosperity and welfare". Lytton believed in free trade. He did nothing to check the huge hikes in grain prices, Economic "modernization" led household and village reserves to be transferred to central depots using recently built railroads. Much was exported to England, where there had been poor harvests. Telegraph technology allowed prices to be centrally co-ordinated and, inevitably, raised in thousands of small towns. Relief funds were scanty because Lytton was eager to finance military campaigns in Afghanistan. Conditions in emergency camps were so terrible that some peasants preferred to go to jail. A few, starved and senseless, resorted to cannibalism. This was all of little consequence to many English administrators who, as believers in Malthusianism, thought that famine was nature's response to Indian over-breeding. It used to be that the late 19th century was celebrated in every school as the golden period of imperialism. While few of us today would defend empire in moral terms, we've long been encouraged to acknowledge its economic benefits. Yet, as Davis points out, "there was no increase in India's per capita income from 1757 to 1947". In Egypt, too, the financial difficulties caused to peasants by famine encouraged European creditors to override the millennia-old tradition that tenancy was guaranteed for life. What little relief aid reached Brazil, meanwhile, ended up profiting British merchant houses and the reactionary sugar-planter classes. The European "locusts" did not go unchallenged. Rioting became common. Banditry increased. In China, drought-famine helped to spark the Boxer uprising. In Europe, the fin de siècle was largely an opportunity for pale-faced men to wear purple cummerbunds and spout rotten symbolist poetry; for colonized peoples it genuinely seemed to presage mass extinction. It was, says Davis, "a new dark age of colonial war, indentured labour, concentration camps, genocide, forced migration, famine and disease." Davis's attention to the importance of environment may recall the work of the Annales school of historians, but he is far more radical than any of them. His writing, both here and in such classic books as City of Quartz and Ecology of Fear, is closer to that of Latin American intellectuals such as Ariel Dorfman and the Urguayan, Eduardo Galaeno, who for decades have spotlighted capitalism's casual abuse of the third world and who have sought to champion the poor and dispossessed. Such commitment, forcefully and lucidly expressed, is unfashionable these days. "Class" may be passé in academic circles, yet the catalogue of cruelty Davis has unearthed is jaw-dropping. A friend to whom I lent the book was reduced to tears by it. Late Victorian Holocausts is as ugly as it is compelling. webTitle: Local gulf between rich and the poor

fields.headline: Local gulf between rich and the poor
fields.standfirst: Household survey highlights area disparity in wealth to rival traditional north-south divide. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Household survey highlights area disparity in wealth to rival traditional north-south divide. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
What is the poorest part of Britain, where average household income barely scrapes over £9,000 a year? What is the sixth richest part of Britain, where average incomes top £46,000 a year? The surprise answer is that both are districts of Merseyside: Vauxhall in central Liverpool and Heswall on the Wirral.

The figures, compiled in the Wealth of the Nation report by income data specialists CACI, cast a new light on the north/south divide. They reveal that although the income gap between north and south is wide and growing, it masks the huge disparities within each region of Britain.

For example, the residents of Manchester have an average household income of £19,800 a year, a long way behind the £33,400 average in Surrey, Britain's richest county. But a large number of northern towns and cities outstrip the household incomes of towns in the so-called prosperous south.

Stockport's postcode, for example, is on a par with Tunbridge Wells, while incomes in Harrogate, Crewe, Warrington, Preston and Huddersfield postcodes all outstrip prosperous southern postal areas such as Bath, Bournemouth and Colchester.

CACI chief executive Greg Bradford says: "The average levels of household income in the north are biased by the pockets of extremely low income levels which mark large northern towns."

An analysis of the richest and poorest areas in Britain on a region-by-region basis, prepared exclusively for Jobs & Money by CACI, reveals that poor north/rich south is a gross oversimplification. In the north-east, the TS15 postcode in central Middlesbrough has an average household income of £9,870 but in nearby Stockton on Tees, residents in the TS175 postal district enjoy incomes averaging £37,776, placing them amongst the richest in Britain. The south-east figures are distorted by huge variations in London. While Portsmouth P014 is listed as the lowest income areas in the region, pockets of south-east London are lower and among the lowest in the UK.

The CACI figures, based on 4m households, claim to be the largest and most comprehensive survey of household income in the UK. It also believes they are a better indicator of the financial health of Britain than traditional indicators such as the unemployment figures and movements in house prices. It shows that average household income in the UK has risen strongly in the past four years and now stands at £23,200, up 19.6% on 1996 and up 8.6% on 1998.

Average incomes by county

The ten richest counties are all in the south, although Cheshire comes in at eleventh. The lowest is not in the north, but the far south - Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly, at £17,700. Surrey enjoyed a 12.5% increase in average incomes in the last two years, while the Western Isles saw average income fall.

Average incomes by postcode area

London and its surrounds dominate the top ten ranking. Residents of London with the W postcode have average household incomes of £34,200 (up 13.4% since 1998), followed by Kingston upon Thames, SW London, Slough and Guildford. Lowest were Sunderland, Truro, the Outer Hebrides, Plymouth and Sheffield, all with average incomes below £19,000. The area with the fastest rise in in comes over the past two years was Harrow - up 19%.

Where the wealthiest live

The CACI figures also identify the areas which have the highest proportion of households earning over £100,000 and the areas with a high proportion of households earning less than £10,000. Top is the London EC2Y 5 postcode, which contains the high-rise Barbican development, where 10.6% of the residents earn more than £100,000 a year. Second is NW6 3 (South Hampstead) and SW1 H9 (St James's Park). Outside of London, Chalfont St Peter in Buckinghamshire and Igtham, near Sevenoaks in Kent, also have nearly a tenth of residents earning £100,000 a year.

Where the poorest live

The biggest concentration of poverty is Liverpool. The L16 postcode area in central Liverpool has 65.8% of households earning less than £10,000 a year. There are two more Liverpool postcodes in the bottom-ten table, which it shares with two districts in Bradford where two-thirds of the population earn total household income below £10,000. Newtown in Birmingham B19 also falls into the bottom ten.

webTitle: Voluntary sector opens itself to scrutiny

fields.headline: Voluntary sector opens itself to scrutiny
fields.standfirst: How do we know non-governmental organisations do the right thing?
fields.trailText: How do we know non-governmental organisations do the right thing, asks John Elkington
fields.body:
The Romans had a phrase for it: "Quis custodiet ipsos custodes?" - "Who guards the guardians?" The question implies a lack of confidence in those appointed to positions of trust - looking after public funds, for example. The question, long applied to politicians, police forces and judges, could also be applied to campaigning groups.

The proliferation of non-governmental organisations or NGOs, has been a striking trend in recent decades. And the evidence suggests that the public invests a great deal more trust in NGOs like Amnesty and Greenpeace than in politicians or business people. Research by Edelman Public Relations found almost one-third of Europeans trusting NGOs to do the right thing, with just one-fifth trusting national governments, 15% business and 11% the media. Strikingly, three-quarters of all respondents said they thought NGO influence had grown.

Fine, but how do we know that such groups do the right thing? There are various answers. One is that not-for-profit groups often have trustees with responsibility to keep things above board. But, at a time when growing numbers of companies have been responding to NGO demands for greater corporate accountability and transparency, what are NGOs doing to ensure they operate in the same goldfish bowl?

This is a question increasingly raised by business people. Where they once demanded to know who NGOs represented, now they want to know whether NGOs practise what they preach. We are not an NGO, but this is an issue to which SustainAbility became sensitive five years ago. As a founder-signatory of the International Chamber of Commerce's Business Charter for Sustainable Development in 1991, we encouraged the business world to begin environmental reporting. It took five years to realise that this also applied to us.

In 1996 we published a self-assessment report called Environmentalism Is Not Enough, reviewing our performance against the 16 ICC principles. One of these requires companies to evaluate the impact of their products and services. Products are not too difficult to deal with, but what about services? What do you measure if you are dedicated to changing people's hearts and minds?

There are few answers as yet, but a number of NGOs have produced useful environmental reports. Forum for the Future published one recently and the UK end of World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) has just launched its first externally verified environmental report. This covers such things as emissions of greenhouse gases, but deputy chief executive Leslie Jones notes that thorny issues still to be addressed include the "service effects" and social impacts of WWF's work.

The service effects are direct environmental impacts linked with WWF's core conservation activities. But there are other issues NGOs must address. In our report we stressed the need to evolve new ways of measuring the impact of our work on the thinking and priorities of the public and client companies. The questions are on our website. But a key issue for mainstream NGOs, and increasingly for companies, relates to lobbying. Who are they lobbying, on what issues, with what outcomes in mind? In this sense, reports like WWF's are still eco-efficiency, rather than eco-effectiveness reports. Progress, certainly, but recall the case of Caesar's wife. Like NGOs, she wielded huge influence, but knew she had to be seen to be whiter than white.

 John Elkington is chairman of SustainAbility and co-author of The Global Reporters: The First International Survey of Corporate Sustainability Reporting.

webTitle: Lord of the Rings brings riches to city

fields.headline: Lord of the Rings brings riches to city
fields.standfirst: The filming of JRR Tolkien's fantasy epic has brought a multimillion-dollar boom to New Zealand's capital
fields.trailText: The filming of JRR Tolkien's fantasy epic has brought a multimillion-dollar boom to New Zealand's capital
fields.body:
The cafe chatter in Wellington may be dominated by talk of the new film version of JRR Tolkien's Lord of the Rings, but New Zealanders are feeling a more tangible benefit from the shooting of the epic fantasy trilogy - a boost to their economy.

The three films - The Fellowship of the Ring, The Two Towers and The Return of the King - were shot back to back over 15 months in locations around New Zealand, one of the biggest ever projects of its type.

Principal shooting finished in late December but by the time post-production work on special effects for the last film is finished in 2003, New Line Cinema will have spent an estimated £300m on the trilogy.

That has translated into an economic boom for Wellington, a city of only 150,000 inhabitants. While property prices in New Zealand as a whole have declined by up to 12% in the last few years, the cost of property around Wellington has gone up by about the same margin.

In parts of Miramar, the tranquil suburb of tearooms and sea views where Mr Jackson works, rents have quadrupled.

And apart from the 300-strong crew and the 15,000 extras who will appear on screen alongside stars such as Elijah Wood (Frodo), Ian McKellen (Gandalf), Ian Holm (Bilbo Baggins) and Liv Tyler (Arwen), more than 7,000 new jobs have been created in the New Zealand film industry in the last year.

New Zealand was chosen for location shooting because of the beauty of its landscape and because it is the home of the director, Peter Jackson, 39, previously best known for directing Kate Winslet's first film, Heavenly Creatures.

"It has taken 45 years for film-making technology to fi nally catch up with Tolkien's imagination," he said. "We are fortunate down here to have both the computer technology and the natural landscape to bring the unique world of Middle Earth to life."

The project has come as sweet relief to a domestic film business whose highly limited output to date has been described as adventurously low-budget or, alternatively, direly underfinanced.

The New Zealand Screen Producers and Directors Association has predicted that, on the strength of the ongoing work associated with The Lord of the Rings and other productions, national revenues from film production could again top NZ$1bn (£300m) next year.

Mr Jackson's custom-built studio, WETA, will create some 1,200 computer-generated and model shots for the films at a fraction of the cost that Hollywood special effects houses charge.

While companies such as George Lucas's Industrial Light & Magic sometimes charge up to £67,000 per special effects shot, Mr Jackson's studio can sever a goblin's head or conjure a jabbering hobbit for as little as £5,500.

Wellington's mayor, Mark Blumsky, plans to lead a contingent of New Zealand businessmen and film industry bosses to the US next month to promote his city as "the home of The Lord of the Rings".

He said that he hopes to persuade New Line Cinema to hold at least one of its world premieres for the trilogy in the New Zealand capital.

The first installment of the completed trilogy, The Fellowship of the Ring, is scheduled for British release next December, although teaser trailers have already been shown.

Mr Jackson promises that the work will be crafted for British audiences "with honour. I do want to make the kind of movie that Tolkien would have enjoyed.

"But to do it with integrity, for me, means making a Peter Jackson movie, my own very personal version of a passionate, classic British work."

For the citizens of Wellington, though, the financial benefits have already been felt.

webTitle: Filipinos rally to oust the president

fields.headline: Filipinos rally to oust the president
fields.standfirst:
C U @ the revolution: text messages summon millions on to streets of Manila, forcing government's collapse

Rising tide of proest in Manila
fields.trailText: C U @ the revolution: text messages summon millions on to streets of Manila, forcing government's collapse
fields.body:
Thousands of protesters marched to the presidential palace in Manila in the early hours of this morning after the collapse of the government of President Joseph Estrada in the Philippines.

Television reported that police fired warning shots near the palace to keep protesters away and to make sure demonstrators did not clash with a small number of Estrada supporters.

The powerful Roman Catholic church in the Philippines had earlier announced that it would swear in the vice-president, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, as the country's new president by midday local time today (4am British time), although it was later reported that the ceremony might be put back.

The opposition had set noon as the new deadline for the resignation of Mr Estrada after he ignored an earlier deadline. According to an Estrada adviser, the president was still at the palace and wanted to stay in the Philippines.

Ms Arroyo has already declared herself commander in chief of the army.

Mr Estrada's government had been besieged by a people power movement utilising modern technology and voicing outrage at the former movie star's blatant attempts to sabotage his impeachment trial.

Millions of ordinary Filipinos, communicating with each other via mobile phone text messages, swarmed on to the streets of the capital, Manila, in scenes reminiscent of the 1986 uprising which ousted the former dictator Ferdinand Marcos.

The country's most senior generals and most of the cabinet deserted their beleaguered leader as more than 250,000 people demonstrated.

Most people heard about the planned swearing-in of Ms Arroyo via the text messages, the same means that galvanised a spontaneous uprising on Tuesday evening, when Mr Estrada's impeachment trial collapsed after he bullied and bribed senators to block the admission of vital evidence.

Within minutes "Trial collapsed" was whizzing round the phone networks, followed by messages abusing the senators as "elements of evil". All the messages ended with the same three words: "Pass this on."

Then the first genesis of a protest movement emerged: "Be angry _ Come outside at 11 [pm] and make noise."

"Come to EDSA" hit people's screens, referring to the shrine built on the site of the 1986 demonstrations. "Wear black because we're mourning the death of truth and justice," was the next command.

"No one knew where these messages originated," said Narzalina Lim, a civil society leader and minister under former president Corazon Acquino, who replaced Marcos in 1986. "They just appeared and within an hour or two tens of thousands of people had gathered. It really was people power in action as there was no obvious leader to make the calls."

The tone of the messages changed on Wednesday as people feared retaliation and retribution from Mr Estrada and his cronies. Bomb scares, fake assassination attempts and warnings about coups were the most common alarms.

By yesterday the crowd at the shrine had swollen to more than a quarter of a million, while the pro-Estrada rally numbered about 3,000.

The first development yesterday was news that several thousand pro-Estrada supporters had descended on the business district and had clashed briefly with anti-Estrada office workers there.

The impeachment affair, which broke last October when a provincial governor, Luis Singson, went public with accusations that Mr Estrada had siphoned off millions of pounds from illegal gambling scams, almost brought the economy to its knees.

On the news that the government had collapsed, the Philippine currency rallied from almost 56 pesos to the US dollar to almost 47. Then came news that the country's military chief, General Angelo Reyes, had withdrawn his support for Mr Estrada, followed by a slew of other generals, police chiefs and ministers. Only a tiny hardcore of fanatical loyalists remained at the president's side.

The text message doing the rounds late last night said it all: "I guess we've won again."

"They just appeared and within an hour or two tens of thousands of people had gathered. It really was people power in action as there was no obvious leader to make the calls." The tone of the messages changed on Wednesday as people feared retaliation and retribution from Mr Estrada and his cronies. Bomb scares, fake assassination attempts and warnings about coups were the most common alarms. By yesterday the crowd at the shrine had swollen to more than a quarter of a million, while the pro-Estrada rally numbered about 3,000. The first development yesterday was news that several thousand pro-Estrada supporters had descended on the business district and had clashed briefly with anti-Estrada office workers there. The impeachment affair, which broke last October when a provincial governor, Luis Singson, went public with accusations that Mr Estrada had siphoned off millions of pounds from illegal gambling scams, almost brought the economy to its knees. On the news that the government had collapsed, the Philippine currency rallied from almost 56 pesos to the US dollar to almost 47. Then came news that the country's military chief, General Angelo Reyes, had withdrawn his support for Mr Estrada, followed by a slew of other generals, police chiefs and ministers. Only a tiny hardcore of fanatical loyalists remained at the president's side. The text message doing the rounds late last night said it all: "I guess we've won again."

webTitle: Rising tide of protest sweeps in on Estrada

fields.headline: Rising tide of protest sweeps in on Estrada
fields.standfirst: The military withdraws its support for the president as huge protests hit Manila
fields.trailText: The military withdraws its support for the president as huge protests hit Manila.
fields.body:
The beginning of the end for the Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, came yesterday when the country's two previous presidents, Fidel Ramos and Corazon Acquino, called on the head of the armed forces just before lunch.

Their message to General Angelo Reyes was simple: The president's position is untenable and the size of the opposition's demonstrations, which at that time had swollen from 20,000 people to a quarter of a million in the three days since his impeachment hearing had collapsed, were ballooning by the hour.

With a reputation as a professional soldier rather than a political yes-man, Gen Reyes wanted to avoid violence at all costs. He realised his guests were telling the truth and told them he would withdraw his support for his supreme commander.

"That was undoubtedly the precipitating factor," Edicio Dela Torre, the director general of a government education agency, said. "That sent a chill shudder round the rest of us [senior members of government]."

During the next 10 hours events accelerated at such breakneck speed that the country could barely keep pace with the developments.

The general sought an audience with Mr Estrada to inform him of his decision to withdraw support.

At the same time Mr Torre, a close associate of Mr Estrada's, and some colleagues drafted a letter suggesting that both the president and the vice-president, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, should resign. They felt Mr Estrada, 63, had been irrevocably damaged by his involvement in the collapse of his impeachment trial on Tuesday; he allegedly paid enough senators to win an 11-10 vote against admitting potentially damning new evidence.

Meanwhile, organisers of the opposition demonstrations were planning how to coordinate a three-day general strike to start on Monday morning. Across town, an unexpected gathering of pro-Estrada supporters marched into the capital's business district.

The opposition's strike plans were shelved in favour of more immediate action. "We realised we were scenting victory and so we went for it," said Karina David, a former Estrada minister who resigned 15 months ago after a falling out with the president.

Within six hours more than three-quarters of the government had also resigned and joined the hundreds of thousands of demonstrators now on the streets of the capital.

When Mr Estrada announced an hour later that he was calling a snap presidential election in May, in which he would not stand, the end was nigh.

The opposition rally grew at such a pace that the commander of the presidential guard, fearing the palace would be stormed, ordered in reinforcements. The sight of armoured personnel carriers arriving at the palace only heightened the tension.

But the force's passive intentions soon became clear and the focus turned to the office of the senate president, Aquilino Pimentel, where negotiations for Mr Estrada's climbdown were taking place.

The president was asking for five days and a pardon; the opposition threatened to move its now 500,000 followers to the palace if he did not leave at once.

In the face of this growing protest, Mr Estrada's supporters on the streets gave way quickly. Not a bullet was fired, and not one protester reached the presidential palace.

Since Tuesday night, when tens of thousands of people first took to the streets in anger, the atmosphere had been reminiscent of a festive party rather than a desperate political struggle.

But such is often the shape of political protest in the Philippines. Its people go out of their way to avoid confrontation. They insist on enjoying themselves and actions are often spontaneous, unlike in neighbouring countries such as Indonesia where noth ing happens without leaders.

For example, when the pro-Estrada supporters snaked their way into the business district the opposition supporters came out of their offices, not to throw missiles or punches, but to castigate; the verbal abuse they heaped on their opponents would have been considered mild at football match inBritain.

"I think it's a realisation of the people that each of them is a leader on his own," Katrina Legarda, a lawyer, shouted over the din at the confrontation. "They do not need anyone to follow. They just have to make up their own mind if he [Mr Estrada] is fit to govern this country. It is clear they have decided the answer is no."

This spontaneous collective decision-making was again on show when Mr Estrada offered to hold a snap presidential poll. With one voice the hundreds of thousands of demonstrators immediately shouted: "Snap election no! Snap resignation yes!"

"It's just a delaying tactic," said one man, who had brought his two children along to the rally. "He'll just look for a way out if we accept this. He can't be trusted, so we have to get rid of him now."

This latest version of Philippine people power was also kept alive by their faith; Filipinos have a near-fanatical devotion to Roman Catholicism. One of the highlights of each day's protests was the early evening mass where religious leaders kept morale high by repeatedly telling the masses that God is on their side.

The Filipinos built a chapel and a shrine of the Virgin Mary to commemorate the spot where they gathered in 1986 to topple President Ferdinand Marcos. It is at this location, known as the EDSA shrine after the road on which it is located, where they gathered again this week.

No one at EDSA was going anywhere last night.

"We've come so far, we have to finish it off now," said Ms David, the former minister, as she swayed to the music blaring out of dozens of loudspeakers. She then settled down for a long night of protesting Filipino-style.

New leader, old tricks

How President Estrada compares to the former dictator Ferdinand Marcos:

Education

Marcos
Honours graduate in law at the University of the Philippines

Estrada
Dropout from its civil engineering department

Career

Marcos
Lawyer/professional politician, seen as the Philippines' answer to Kennedy when he took office

Estrada
B movie action star who rode to political success on the back of his cult fame

Private life

Marcos
One wife, Imelda, has three children by her. Several mistresses

Estrada
One wife, at least eight mistresses and up to 20 children

Fall from grace

Marcos
Took more than four years before people realised how corrupt he was. Kept control by introducing popular reforms then later declared martial law

Estrada
Took less than two months before people realised how corrupt he was

Most famous for

Marcos
His wife Imelda's collection of thousands of pairs of haute couture shoes

Estrada
All-night drinking, gambling and policy-making sessions with cronies. Also notorious for giving his mistresses large mansions

 Hear John Aglionby reporting from Manila on the Guardian website at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/audio
