fields.headline: And the winner is...
fields.standfirst: The Baftas are raising their glamour by leapfrogging the Oscars on the calendar. But are movie folk already overloaded with awards, asks David Eimer
fields.trailText: The Baftas are raising their glamour by leapfrogging the Oscars on the calendar. But are movie folk already overloaded with awards, asks David Eimer
fields.body:
The beginning of the year in Los Angeles signals the start of a three-month orgy of self-congratulation and back-slapping that's better known as the awards season. By the time it all comes to a head on March 25 with the Oscars, there will have been close on 30 different ceremonies honouring Hollywood, and mantelpieces in Beverly Hills will be groaning under the weight of the accumulated statuettes.

In the past, it was easy to scoff at this very American cycle but now it seems that we Brits feel the need to muscle in on the action. This year, in a transparent attempt to boost the profile of the British Academy Of Film And Television Arts, the BAFTA awards will for the first time be held before the Oscars. The idea is that the Baftas will come to be seen as the natural stepping stone to the Academy Awards, as well as an indicator of who will carry off the ultimate prize of an Oscar.

But by moving their shindig to February 25, the BAFTA film committee, headed up by former Palace Pictures supremo Steve Woolley, has thrown down a direct challenge to the Golden Globes, the awards that the Hollywood Foreign Press Association will hand out tomorrow. The Globes have long been regarded as the traditional precursor to the Oscars, while the Baftas have a reputation as a consolation prize for the mostly British talent who failed to win anything in LA.

It's easy to understand, though, why Woolley is so keen on the move. After all, BAFTA has close on 4,000 members, a significant minority of whom are also eligible to vote for the Oscars, who all work in the industry. In contrast, the HFPA has a mere 90 hacks on its books and many of those have questionable qualifications as both journalists and experts on the movies.

On the face of it then, BAFTA is in a strong position to establish itself as the number two ceremony behind the Oscars. The Hollywood studios have certainly responded to its overtures, because potential winners like Michael Douglas and Geoffrey Rush have been turning up to introduce BAFTA screenings of their movies in London. Then there are the packages of CDs and DVDs that have been dropping through the letterboxes of BAFTA members for the last couple of months; the American Academy may regard blatant campaigning for votes as bad form, but its British counterpart positively encourages it and the studios haven't been slow to take advantage.

The Golden Globes, though, are the awards that are most susceptible to studio pressure and that's down to a simple matter of numbers. With only 90 people voting, it's easy for the studios to get to them and they do it by flattering them to death. It starts at their now notorious press conferences where each person who turns up gets to ask one whole question to the assembled talent. Far more important, though, is the photo opportunity at the end when each HFPA member gets to pose with Brad Pitt or whoever.

Spend any time in LA as an entertainment journalist and you'll hear the stories: how one Australian member got a phone call from Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman congratulating her on her upcoming wedding, or the messages from Harvey Weinstein asking the HFPA member what he or she really thought of the latest Miramax movie. But the biggest carrot of all is the night of the Globes itself, when the studios send out prized invitations to the post-ceremony parties and star-struck journos from central Europe get to hob-nob with the elite of Hollywood.

All of which is a long way from the idea of rewarding excellence in film.

But then, for the studios, the awards season serves only two purposes: it's a highly visible way of scoring points over the opposition and it's a convenient device for refuting accusations that they're dumbing down the world's population by putting out total tat. Never mind Adam Sandler's movies, just look at that Best Picture Oscar.

Of course the stars can be expected to collude in this: awards are a way for them to validate themselves and to prove that it really is about art and not multi-million dollar salaries, private jets and designer togs. In fact, these days most of them will happily pick up any old gong. When Jennifer Aniston received her People's Choice award as Most Popular Woman On TV in LA on January 8, she reacted like she'd won a Nobel Prize, rather than something that's decided by a random Gallup poll.

There's no sign that the awards frenzy will go away anytime soon. On the contrary, there seem to be more of them every year, and that's because we can't get enough of watching the stars sashay down the red carpet in the latest haute couture creations. Last year, 250m people in 122 countries tuned in to the Golden Globes, which made it the third most popular awards show in the world after the Oscars and the Grammys.

A captive audience like that is the reason why NBC pays millions of dollars a year to the HFPA for the TV rights to the Globes. But it's not wasted, because the HFPA has handed out over $2m of that money over the last six years to various film-related charities. Only last August, the ubiquitous Michael Douglas accepted a cheque for $100,000 for film preservation and, of course, a photographer was there to ensure that the HFPA members got a picture to show the relatives back home.

In fact, a cynic might think that the real reason for moving the Baftas is because the British Academy wouldn't mind a global TV deal that would ensure the ceremony is shown live on US television. That would boost the coffers and ensure that they really could challenge the Globes for number two in the awards pecking order. But until that happens, the Americans will continue to regard the Baftas as little more than an excuse for a free trip to London.

webTitle: Jonathan Romney on recent French films

fields.headline: New Gauls, please
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney  is far from impressed by the latest French movies
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney is far from impressed by the latest French movies
fields.body:
I've been trying for ages to put my finger on the difference between the French and British film worlds, and now I think I've got it. The difference is that, over there, the stars turn up to the works disco. This week, the French cinema industry threw a closing-night party for a delegation of visiting foreign buyers and journalists in a no-frills disco off the Champs-Elysées. Nothing remotely flashy - just assorted distributors, hacks and movie business office workers making the most of the free drinks. But, look - isn't that Sophie Marceau on the dance floor, just north of Sergi Lopez? And, over there, Emmanuelle Béart? And not a press photographer to be seen. In London, of course, anyone who ever turned up halfway down the EastEnders cast list is unlikely to grace an event unless there's a guaranteed full contingent from the OK! photo desk.

For the past three years, Unifrance, a body that promotes French cinema abroad, has been organising an annual "European rendezvous" - a big junket at which foreign delegates can watch new films and journalists can bag a few interviews. My own film-nerd instinct on arrival is to scan the pages of listings mag Pariscope and the fabulously unpronounceable arts weekly Les Inrockuptibles to see what's new on release. As always, there's at least one French comedy with an unfeasibly unwieldy title - this season's is People Who Wear Swimming Suits Are Not (Necessarily) Superficial (love those brackets).

There's also usually an event film the critics love to hate. This season, it's the first feature in eight years by Jean-Jacques Beineix, director of Diva and Betty Blue. Mortel Transfert (Deadly Transference) is a deliriously convoluted psychoanalytical thriller about a shrink (the perennially droopy Jean-Hugues Anglade), who nods off in a session with a femme fatale patient and wakes to find her strangled. The film is an expensively ghoulish goulash of flashy interiors, necrophilia, S&M and slapstick, with the odd Lacan reference thrown in. It's dreadful, but compulsively watchable, and you won't be missing much if it never comes here.

Most of the screenings Unifrance has on offer are commercial rather than art-house fare. An unidentified French filmgoer is quoted in Variety this week as saying that French films are more intelligent, "except those with Gérard Depardieu", and Le Placard (The Closet), this week's big opener, bears that out. It's directed by mainstream comedy stalwart Francis Veber (Le Dner de Cons), and the appropriate response is: shrug, bof!, harmless if you like that sort of thing. Daniel Auteuil plays a shy accountant who pretends to be gay to keep his job. Depardieu, on amiable good-sport form, is his macho personnel manager. It's a well-intentioned, old-fashioned, drab film that only works if you imagine a world in which no one had ever met a gay man before, or your idea of comedy is a poker-faced Auteuil wearing an outsize condom on his head.

Then there's the debut feature by British TV's favourite professional Frenchman, Antoine de Caunes. Les Morsures de l'Aube (Love Bites) is a would-be hip vampire thriller about a satanic brother-sister duo who haunt the Paris club scene. It's slick, dated Goth tack. Eurotrash indeed. But it boasts what may prove the strangest dialogue-bite of the year, in a sex scene featuring hyper-trendy vamp Asia Argento: "I won't take my bra off, as I have huge breasts. But perhaps you recognise it - it's an exact replica of the one worn by Janet Leigh in Psycho."

But the real knockout was La Ville Est Tranquille by Marseilles-based Robert Guédiguian, who made A la Place du Coeur. A hit in Venice last year, it's an ensemble piece - rather like Magnolia in a hard realist vein. Its main characters are a docker-turned-taxi driver and a middle-aged woman trying to keep her junkie daughter alive. It has the smack of reality, you might say, with brilliant performances by the director's usual rep players, including Ariane Ascaride. Sometimes the arguments about the downfall of the labour movement are a little on-the-nose, but Guédiguian spins his tragedy with a grace and complexity that finally leave you shaking. And so, to quote a leading French vampirologist: "Allez, salut maintenant."

Les Morsures de l'Aube (Love Bites) is a would-be hip vampire thriller about a satanic brother-sister duo who haunt the Paris club scene. It's slick, dated Goth tack. Eurotrash indeed. But it boasts what may prove the strangest dialogue-bite of the year, in a sex scene featuring hyper-trendy vamp Asia Argento: "I won't take my bra off, as I have huge breasts. But perhaps you recognise it - it's an exact replica of the one worn by Janet Leigh in Psycho." But the real knockout was La Ville Est Tranquille by Marseilles-based Robert Guédiguian, who made A la Place du Coeur. A hit in Venice last year, it's an ensemble piece - rather like Magnolia in a hard realist vein. Its main characters are a docker-turned-taxi driver and a middle-aged woman trying to keep her junkie daughter alive. It has the smack of reality, you might say, with brilliant performances by the director's usual rep players, including Ariane Ascaride. Sometimes the arguments about the downfall of the labour movement are a little on-the-nose, but Guédiguian spins his tragedy with a grace and complexity that finally leave you shaking. And so, to quote a leading French vampirologist: "Allez, salut maintenant."

fields.headline: Coke and the reel thing
fields.standfirst: Steven Soderbergh steers an evasive path through the drug debate in Traffic. The result? He's won over both the law enforcers and legalisation lobby, reports Mark Honigsbaum
fields.trailText: Steven Soderbergh steers an evasive path through the drug debate in Traffic. The result? He's won over both the law enforcers and legalisation lobby, reports Mark Honigsbaum
fields.body:
Does Steven Soderbergh have a crystal ball or is he just uncannily prescient? No sooner did his new film Traffic, about the pointlessness of America's increasingly costly war on drugs, set on the Mexican border, open in Los Angeles than California voters approved new legislation permitting the medicinal use of marijuana and allowing non-violent drug offenders to opt for treatment over punitive prison sentences.

The next thing you know, the Supreme Court gifted the presidency to Bush - a candidate who had spent much of his campaign fudging the question of whether or not he "inhaled" cocaine in the early 70s during what his father's former chief-of-staff infamously referred to as Dubya's "lost weekends in Mexico".

Finally, in another example of life imitating art (or is it the other way round?), two weeks ago Clinton's outgoing drug tsar General Barry McCaffrey began a round of interviews in which he expressed sentiments not a million miles away from those uttered by judge Robert Wakefield (Michael Douglas) in his resignation speech at the end of Traffic.

No wonder Soderbergh's film, already nominated for multiple Golden Globes and a best director Oscar contender, has been hailed by American critics as the most "timely" and "resonant" film of the year. In an industry that usually comes down on the side of Nancy Reagan and "just say no", Traffic cuts through the vacuous political rhetoric surrounding drugs and dares to say "just say know".

The trouble is, that's all it says. Just when you think Douglas - the veils removed from his eyes by the discovery that his Mexican counterpart is working for the cartels and that his daughter is a crack addict - is going to tell it like it is, Soderbergh and screenwriter Stephen Gaghan duck the issue, leaving the audience, in the words of Time's critic, "feeling restless and dissatisfied".

Indeed, the irony is that in recent interviews Clinton's real-life drug tsar has gone much further than Douglas - for all his recent pot-smoking in Wonderboys - is allowed to in Traffic. While Douglas slopes off at the end of Soderbergh's film muttering "I don't know how you wage war on your own family", McCaffrey, who refuses to use the phrase "war on drugs", has come up with concrete proposals, including the repeal of New York's mandatory prison sentences for drug offences and more federal funds for treatment.

Meanwhile, now he's a lame duck, Clinton has been making similarly progressive noises in an interview with Jann Wenner of Rolling Stone. Too little, too late, cry critics like the Lindesmith Center, the drugs policy reform foundation set up by the financier George Soros and Progessive Corporation's Peter Lewis. The Clinton administration, they point out, spent $19bn last year on drug interdiction - more than six times what it spent on treatment - and that's not including the $1.3bn Clinton has just pledged to Colombia to stamp out its cocaine trade.

In the best sequences of Traffic - the yellow-tinted sections set in Tijuana following Benicio Del Toro's bear-like cop as he is drawn ever closer to the heart of the corruption - Soderbergh's film at least shows how futile the outgoing administration's Colombian strategy is likely to be. The mystery is why he didn't take the argument further and turn the camera, for instance, on the widespread drug abuse in his own industry.

When he optioned Simon Moore's C4 series, Traffik, in which multiple storylines tracked drug dealers from Pakistan to Great Britain, Soderbergh said his goal was to recreate the same documentary feel and not to "come off like we had the answers." Unfortunately, in his concern to be even-handed and, presumably, to keep in Oscar contention too, Soderbergh ends up censoring himself. The result is a film that appears to be all things to all people.

After a special screening in Washington for Drug Enforcement Administration officials, for instance, Soderbergh was congratulated for making a pro-law enforcement movie. Meanwhile, his hip liberal friends think he's turned in an ode to legalisation. As he told the Village Voice: "The funny thing is, everybody who sees it thinks it puts their point of view across." Duh. Isn't that what he intended?

At least there is no confusing where Darren Aronofsky is coming from in Requiem For A Dream. Adapted from the book by Hubert Selby Jr with Selby's help, Requiem looks the way drug movies used to look: all urban angst and whizzed-up junkies. Like Panic In Needle Park, Drugstore Cowboy and even Boogie Nights - set in the porn industry but as much to do with cocaine abuse - it starts on a high and ends on a cautionary low. Indeed, so graphic are Aronofsky's rapid-edit images of Harry (Jared Leto) and his girlfriend Marion (Jennifer Connelly) shooting up, you almost get high watching them - the camera takes you literally inside the syringe and then puts you eyeball-to-eyeball with the couple's dilating pupils.

But it would be a mistake to see Requiem simply as another in a long line of gritty drug movies. Despite the inevitable, unhappy ending, Requiem is no Christiane F. Uli Edel's 1981 portrait of the decline of a young Berlin heroin addict was the film equivalent of lithium; Requiem, in contrast, is as much about the double standards of our postmodern drug-phobic society as it is about addiction and, unlike Traffic, Aronofsky's message is absolutely clear.

Indeed, of the two, Requiem is the more subversive. Harry and Marion, for instance, may be junkies but they yearn to go legit. What stops them is the war on the streets and the fact that, owing to the small matter of their habit being illegal, their fix is hard to come by. In contrast, Harry's mother Sara Goldfarb's addiction - television - is piped straight into her living room via the networks. Invited on to her favourite gameshow, she becomes desperate to lose weight and scores a brace of diet pills (read: uppers) from her doctor. But as we watch her waste away it is hard not to see heroin as the lesser of two evils - especially as Harry's inability to score means he isn't around to check up on Mom when she most needs him.

If Benicio del Toro's sloe-eyed Mexican cop is the coolest character you'll see in a drug movie this year, Ellen Burstyn's home-alone mom is the scariest. However, neither is likely to move the "nondebate" over drugs forward as much as an interview in the recent issue of Playboy given by New Mexico's Republican governor, Gary Johnson. A lame duck like Clinton, Johnson has pushed for the decriminalisation of marijuana and non-custodial sentences for other drug offences. But in Playboy he went further, arguing that there is little point decriminalising possession if you do not also put a stop to the hugely profitable trade in dope that lies behind it. His solution? Legalisation.

Now that's a position that so far no filmmaker has been willing to dramatise.

 Requiem For A Dream is out now. Traffic opens on Friday

webTitle: Joining the continental drift to a European school

fields.headline: Joining the continental drift to a European school
fields.standfirst: Study in a multi-cultural setting to enhance your credentials
fields.trailText: Study in a multi-cultural setting to enhance your credentials
fields.body:
Whether you are a recent graduate or someone with solid experience behind you, an MBA from a top business school is a wise investment in your future.

And as the world becomes a smaller place and as global businesses become the norm, completing an MBA course abroad can greatly enhance your educational and professional knowledge.

Moreover, an ability to thrive in a multi-cultural environment could at a later date help to advance your career and boost your earning power.

Top level international MBA courses are designed to train future international business leaders who can operate with vision, innovation, and collaboration in a dynamic and changing global environment.

The only problem is choosing from the plethora of overseas programmes which are available. You could spin the globe and go where your finger lands, or be guided by executive colleague who brags about his time in a big-name school like Harvard in the United States.

However, by relying purely on someone else's recommendation, you run the risk of overlooking some very important factors. Perhaps your colleague took a gap year out to travel in the US and welcomed the challenges of living in an unfamiliar culture. You, on the other hand, might be a graduate who has never travelled outside Europe. You might very well like America, but chances are another location would be a better option for you.

The decision to study abroad requires some serious self- examination. If you know why you want to study abroad, why you're at a certain school and why you've chosen a certain lifestyle, you'll be much better prepared when the going gets a little bumpy. Why do you want to study abroad? Without answers to these question, finding the right programme will be a hit-or-miss affair.

William H Cox, in his Guide to the Best European Business Schools, (McGraw Hill) outlines some of the main differences between US and European MBA programmes. European programmes, he says, have a more international student body and teaching faculty than US programmes. European schools still lack the historically-rooted and accepted accreditation norm that exists in the United States, but because they are less developed, can also afford to be more dynamic, often employing a greater diversity and originality of teaching and learning methods.

On a more practical level, the courses at European business schools tend to be shorter-ranging from one to one-and-a-half years compared with the standard two-year courses run by most US schools. European MBA students also tend to be slightly older than their US counterparts. Ten or 20 years ago, US students tended to take MBAs in their early twenties; now the average age in the US is 26, compared with an average age of 27 in Europe.

European students, therefore, begin MBAs with greater work experience, and to take two years out of a career in order to study may be a good deal less practicable than choosing a one-year course. Critics of shorter courses say a year is not always sufficient to digest the volume of work covered; graduates of two-year MBA courses also tend to have higher starting salaries than those from one-year courses.

If you are thinking of France, you are in good company. Business schools in France have long been a mecca for aspiring European managers. French companies are employing increasing numbers of foreigners in senior management as they try to internationalise their management ranks.

In France, the MBA student body is drawn from a very diverse and talented group of professionals which span a wide range of ages, disciplines, and cultures.

If you want to pursue an MBA course in France, there are several English-speaking programmes which aim to fold French culture into a multicultural environment.

France's most famous school, Fontainbleau-based INSEAD, has grown from a modest European educational institute to one of the world's most internationally-renowned business schools and more than 650 MBA graduates, 5,500 executives and 40 PhD students from more than 75 countries passthrough it each year.

These participants are taught by a faculty of 124 professors from 26 countries. The institute's extensive alumni network, which includes Conservative leader William Hague, is present in 122 countries.

INSEAD, which was the first business school to offer a one-year MBA, continues to expand. For example it recently opened an Asian campus in Singapore. Its "one school, two campuses" concept allows participants to study in Europe, Asia or both. "The emphasis at Insead is on gaining leading-edge knowledge that can be put to use immediately for competitive advantage," says Yves Doz, associate dean and professor of global technology and innovation.

Lausanne-based IMD in Switzerland is more industry- focused. Every year, more than 4,000 executives from around 70 countries attend one of the IMD executive programs. Some 130 of the world's leading companies, maintain close business links with IMD through participation in its 'learning network'.

IMD's MBA graduates benefit from classroom-based learning and opportunities to meet with the school's business partners throughout the year.

The Belgian Vlerick Leuven Ghent Management School targets younger managers from different cultural, academic and professional backgrounds.

Significantly, the Belgium government subsidies the typical

£20,000 course fees by up to 75%, leaving the individual student to find around £5,000.

The financial support makes MBAs at the school at a very affordable proposition. For example, Paddy Creedon, a Dublin-based businessman running his own firm, has enrolled on the part-time MBA at Vlerick Leuven Ghent. Each week he jumps on an overnight Ryan Air flight from Dublin to Brussels, which costs him around £30 return, attends his lectures and seminars, then flies back the following day to continue running his business without a prolonged absence.

Vlerick Leuven Ghent's is accredited by the Association of MBAs, an increasingly important international standard. Getting accreditation is neither easy nor quick. A business school starting to teach MBAs cannot apply until the MBA programme has run for three years. When it does apply, there is first an informal visit, probably from the association's accreditation manager, before the school makes a written submission. Once over that hurdle, the school is visited by (usually) a five-strong team of senior academics. The curriculum, faculty, teaching methods, assessment procedures, the standing and finances of the business school are all inspected, as are the students. Are the entry criteria for students high enough? Have past students done well in their careers, and do they think the course was a life-changing experience?

The association's scope now runs through western Europe and into Russia, Malaysia, Singapore, South Africa, and most recently Argentina.

For more information about AMBA, visit www.mba.org.uk

webTitle: A qualification that adds weight to your CV and pay slip

fields.headline: A qualification that adds weight to your CV and pay slip
fields.standfirst: Surveys suggest graduated can double their money
fields.trailText: Surveys suggest graduated can double their money
fields.body:
Sometimes what you hear about MBAs can sound more like the back-of-a- lamp post adverts from the other end of the employment market. But what is really known about the sort of salaries that MBA graduates can command?

According to the Financial Times ranking of the top 75 full-time international MBA courses, alumni of the highest place UK institution (London Business School) can expect salary increases of 146%, with alumni of the other nine UK schools on the list receiving an average rise of 95% in the three years since graduating in 1996.

The FT's figures are the most comprehensive available, but it should be remembered they have been converted into dollars to facilitate comparison with US schools and then adjusted to take into account salary variation between sectors. The figures are also, of course, a snapshot of only the very top of the market.

The second set of figures available is from the Association of MBAs (AMBA). According to its report for 1999-2000, which is based on a sample of alumni from UK and non-UK schools, salaries rise by 40% on average at graduation.

This figure drops to 25% when adjusted for wage inflation, but it remains impressive given that it is based on salary levels immediately after completion of the course.

Finally, there are figures available from organisations such as MBA Direct, an executive recruitment service which holds details on alumni from leading business schools. Statistics from this source show that a UK-based MBA can expect a more realistic 36% salary rise on graduating.

"Figures like these are extremely difficult to come by," says Rod Younger, a Cranfield MBA graduate, and the founder and chief executive of MBA Direct, "and not many organisations hold data across all sectors and internationally as we do. Our data is actually a by-product of our service rather than something that has been produced for report or ranking purposes, so it may therefore have greater validity."

Younger highlights one of the most important difficulties with obtaining reliable information about MBA salaries. As a category, they are almost by definition generalists, so transcending sector and industry salary surveys.

Secondly, although there are a lot of them (the current estimate is more than 50,000 with 9,000 new MBA graduates leaving business schools each year), no single organisation oversees the whole sector. AMBA only accredits 35 of the 118 institutions offering MBAs in the UK (although its figures do account for 65% of all UK graduates).

The third difficulty is that the people who respond to questionnaires, whether from the FT or AMBA, are of necessity self- selecting, and while both organisations have a response rate of more than 1 in 5, MBA graduates have a vested interest in talking up themselves and their schools.

These caveats aside, what information is there available on actual salaries? AMBA's figures show that the average salary an MBA graduate can currently command is now £63,950 (this is the mean figure - the median is £50,000).

This figure should be fairly robust given that it is based on a sample of more than 1,300 graduates, and it compares well with the average extrapolated from MBA Direct's statistics which are in the range between £50,000 and £65,000. (Unfortunately, although MBA Direct's sample size is similar, its figures have been converted into euros making direct comparisons difficult.)

When it comes to looking at salaries by sector, only MBA graduates working in finance can expect mean salaries of more than £80,000. Graduates working in telecommunications and consulting should expect more than £70,000, while those in energy and IT can command salaries of more than £60,000. All other sectors show a base salary of between £50,000 and £60,000, except for public services and education, where the figures are £40,100 and £36,600 respectively.

All these averages are from AMBA's report, but unfortunately, because of differences in sector definition, only a handful of them can be compared with figures supplied by MBA Direct. Those that are comparable do fall within the broad range of salaries indicated by MBA Direct's statistics except in two areas: consulting and telecommunications.

In these sectors, MBA Direct's data suggests salaries should be at the top end of the £50,000 to £65,000 range.

Other points to note from AMBA's report, which may be of interest to prospective MBA students, include the fact that the highest percentage increase in salary on graduation goes to those who have done a two-year full-time qualification (67% when adjusted for salary inflation).

One year courses are the next most profitable (at 30%), while modular, part-time and distance learning bring up the rear (all around 20%). Prospective MBA students should also note, as should their bosses, that the increases in salary for those who changed employer were also particularly high.

Don't expect it to transform you, says Sara Hadlow, a 34-year old MBA graduate of Aston Business School who now works as commercial strategy manager for Brintons Carpets. "An MBA is a tool through which to learn. It is hard work and applying the knowledge that gets you where you want to go.

"From a base in manufacturing, I took a fairly conventional route from product management through to marketing. But by my late 20s I felt my career was beginning to stall. I wasn't moving towards strategic management, and I realised that an MBA was the only springboard that would get me where I wanted to go.

"I decided to do it full-time because I wanted to change the way I thought, rather than being side-tracked by one organisation's issues. With a mortgage and without sponsorship, it was a high-risk strategy, but it turned out to be the best career investment I have ever made.

"The goals I had when I started the course have easily been exceeded. My salary has increased by 95% over the last four years; I have moved from marketing to strategic management, and it has transformed the way I think. I would temper all that by saying that when you finish the MBA the course is only half-way through. There will still be a lot to learn about putting the theory into practice."
fields.bodyText: Sometimes what you hear about MBAs can sound more like the back-of-a- lamp post adverts from the other end of the employment market. But what is really known about the sort of salaries that MBA graduates can command? According to the Financial Times ranking of the top 75 full-time international MBA courses, alumni of the highest place UK institution (London Business School) can expect salary increases of 146%, with alumni of the other nine UK schools on the list receiving an average rise of 95% in the three years since graduating in 1996. The FT's figures are the most comprehensive available, but it should be remembered they have been converted into dollars to facilitate comparison with US schools and then adjusted to take into account salary variation between sectors. The figures are also, of course, a snapshot of only the very top of the market. The second set of figures available is from the Association of MBAs (AMBA). According to its report for 1999-2000, which is based on a sample of alumni from UK and non-UK schools, salaries rise by 40% on average at graduation. This figure drops to 25% when adjusted for wage inflation, but it remains impressive given that it is based on salary levels immediately after completion of the course. Finally, there are figures available from organisations such as MBA Direct, an executive recruitment service which holds details on alumni from leading business schools. Statistics from this source show that a UK-based MBA can expect a more realistic 36% salary rise on graduating. "Figures like these are extremely difficult to come by," says Rod Younger, a Cranfield MBA graduate, and the founder and chief executive of MBA Direct, "and not many organisations hold data across all sectors and internationally as we do. Our data is actually a by-product of our service rather than something that has been produced for report or ranking purposes, so it may therefore have greater validity." Younger highlights one of the most important difficulties with obtaining reliable information about MBA salaries. As a category, they are almost by definition generalists, so transcending sector and industry salary surveys. Secondly, although there are a lot of them (the current estimate is more than 50,000 with 9,000 new MBA graduates leaving business schools each year), no single organisation oversees the whole sector. AMBA only accredits 35 of the 118 institutions offering MBAs in the UK (although its figures do account for 65% of all UK graduates). The third difficulty is that the people who respond to questionnaires, whether from the FT or AMBA, are of necessity self- selecting, and while both organisations have a response rate of more than 1 in 5, MBA graduates have a vested interest in talking up themselves and their schools. These caveats aside, what information is there available on actual salaries? AMBA's figures show that the average salary an MBA graduate can currently command is now £63,950 (this is the mean figure - the median is £50,000). This figure should be fairly robust given that it is based on a sample of more than 1,300 graduates, and it compares well with the average extrapolated from MBA Direct's statistics which are in the range between £50,000 and £65,000. (Unfortunately, although MBA Direct's sample size is similar, its figures have been converted into euros making direct comparisons difficult.) When it comes to looking at salaries by sector, only MBA graduates working in finance can expect mean salaries of more than £80,000. Graduates working in telecommunications and consulting should expect more than £70,000, while those in energy and IT can command salaries of more than £60,000. webTitle: Games designer adds leadership to experience

fields.headline: Games designer adds leadership to experience
fields.standfirst: Plus anunexpected bonus
fields.trailText: Plus anunexpected bonus
fields.body:
The so-called 'long boom' has meant a boom in business for schools and universities that offer MBAs. And not only are there more and more educational institutions offerings MBAs, the choice of flavours of MBA is increasing too with the last decade seeing a new beast on the block in the form of the specialist MBA.

Not everyone would agree that such a beast should exist. The Association of Business Schools, for example has taken a look at this new development and decided that the MBA in itself is good enough.

"It is a good generalist qualification which is internationally recognised and covers everything that a student needs," says chief executive Jonathan Slack. European business schools associations take the same view, he adds.

In an ideal world you would take an MBA followed by a masters in their specialist area. But given the cost of higher education and the length of time it takes to study for qualification, the specialist MBA has a role to play, especially for people already on their career path who want some bolt-on business skills.

For them, an MBA tailored to their particular line of business is the obvious option.

Nottingham Business School has specialist MBAs covering finance and also public services. "Our strength is in finance," says Scott Goddard, director of MBAs, "and we have been running a specialist MBA for a number of years. All our MBAs have a part that is the general management core with seven modules that everybody will have to take."

There are 30 elective courses, some of them for specialist finance students, some for general MBA students and others which are open to both.

"This gives them flexibility," explains Goddard. "The finance MBA is for people with aspirations to go further in the financial sector and the industry has responded well. Blue chip companies are very pleased. The market seems to like the extra dimension."

Nottingham also offers a public services MBA which has proved popular with NHS professionals like hospital managers, GP fund-holders and consultants who need business expertise. It has also attracted professionals from the education sector, dentists, and even a vet.

Nottingham's local government MBA has trained senior officers from councils and at least two people with political aspirations.

Henley Management College has two specialist MBAs, one in telecommunications and the other in project management which has been going since the early 1990s.

Richard McBain, director of studies for distance learning, explains: "We launched the telecommunications MBA with Cable and Wireless four years ago. We have now taken the programme over and will relaunch it in May this year. We have been impressed by the interest in the market place for an MBA in telecommunications."

There are some things in common between the two MBAs and some of the subjects are also part of the general MBA.

"Assignments are tailored to the industry," explains McBain and tutors are experienced in specific areas in that industry.

"As the market matures MBAs will tend to become more specialist, but there will always be a place for the general MBA. There will be a growth in the specialist MBA and the type will change. It is how students see their career path - if you are in project management obviously it makes sense to do an MBA with this speciality and the same is true of telecommunications."

Director of full-time MBAs at Edinburgh University, Dr James Hine, agrees that specialist MBAs are ideal for people committed to a certain career path.

"But a specialist MBA can limit career options," he says. "If you have a generalist MBA you are qualified in the major business areas."

Edinburgh offers a specilaist MBA in international business but, as with other larger business schools, offers such a wide range of elective subjects that students can tailor their studies to one area of interest if they want.

Liverpool John Moores University offers an e-commerce specialist MBA and an unusual joint with the Institute of Chartered Secretaries and Administrators (ICSA).

The e-commerce MBA draws in the best from other schools in the university - the arts school for web design, the maths and computing school for the technical aspects of the MBA.

The partnership with the ICSA, says MBA admissions officer John Vaughan, gives students a company secretaries qualification as well as a business studies degree.

Liverpool John Moores is also developing two new specialist MBAs for next year - facilities management and envrionmental management.

Students will do four modules on contract, management, intellectual property law and international trade law as well as a dissertation.

"It is useful for law graduates who want to go into business rather than the legal profession and those already in business who come into contact with legal issues," says spokesman Colin Perkin.

Other specialist MBAs include agribusiness at Aberystwyth, church management at Bishop Grosseteste College in Lincoln, , tourism and hospitality at Luton and leadership at Strathclyde.

As design studio manager with Games Workshop, Robin Dews has years of business under his belt, but no formal qualifications to support his experience.

"I wanted to improve my level of technical skill in some areas of the business - for example finance, strategic planning and operational methods," he explains. "I also wanted to place my work for Games Workshop within a broader business context."

He chose to take Glasgow Stratchlyde's specialist MBA in leadership which is run in conjunction with the Leadership Trust, because of historical links with his company.

"Many, if not all, of our senior managers have attended the Leadership Trust's Leadership in Management residential course. We hold this in great store for the emphasis it puts on self- knowledge and self-perception.

"The MBA had the core curriculum plus the additional bonus - delivering results through the hearts and minds of people," says Dews.

As a psychology graduate who started his career with London local authorities in youth and community work, Robin, now 45, ran a busy youth centre in south east London.

The psychology aspect of the Leadership MBA was therefore an obvious attraction plus the core curriculum of general and strategic management, international business environment, management functions, finance, marketing and operations.

The course is taken by distance learning and Robin studies for 10 to 15 hours a week in addition to his job where he is responsible for 80 staff and a £2.5m budget.

"Each student has access to the tutors by email and there are also intensive study weeks each term when the distance learners travel to Glasgow, spend the week in seminars and lectures and swap notes with other students," says Robin.

fields.headline: A whole uni-verse of choice
fields.standfirst: What is the best mode for you?
fields.trailText: What is the best mode for you?
fields.body:
Full-time for one year, part-time over two. One evening a week, a fortnight every two months, distance learning - anyone choosing an MBA has never had more options in how to study.

Over the next academic year it is estimated that around 12,000 people will be studying for an MBA in Britain and for many the most difficult decision - apart from how to finance it - will be what mode of study best suits them.

In essence, graduates can choose one of three options. A full-time, usually residential course that generally lasts a year. A part-time course, usually one or two evenings a week which generally takes two years or the distance learning option made famous by the Open University. That said, there are literally hundreds of permutations within this structure - particularly among the part-time courses - and it's fair to say that however weird your work patterns, there will be a course out there for you.

Full or part-time?

Certainly, if you talk to those offering full and part-time courses they'll tell you that ultimately the student has to decide which best suits their personal circumstances as there are benefits to going down either route.

"Some people need and enjoy the discipline of attending a college on a full-time basis. For others giving up a full-time job may not be an option if they have a family or other commitments," says Ken Russell, director of the MBA programme at Bristol Business School, part of the University of the West of England.

He says the obvious benefit of attending full-time is that you are able to focus all your energies on the course and you get to meet like-minded people from all over Europe.

"We get a lot of graduates from France, Spain and Germany on our courses - particularly on the European MBA, and many become friends for life," he says.

But while you are not likely to be attending weddings all over Europe, there are benefits to attending part-time - besides the huge saving in the cost.

"Being part of a working environment as you do the course allows you to go back to try out what you've been learning and it can make some of the more abstract ideas a bit more real. Also a good number of students going down this route are being sponsored by their employer," says Russell.

Ask him which course wins the higher number of distinctions and he will tell you the full-timers just win out, but he points out that they aren't also juggling a job as well.

Ask the managing director of Cranfield's University's MBA programme, Professor Leo Murray, whether he would go full or part-time and, again, he'll tell you there are benefits to both routes.

"There's no doubt that those on full-time courses get a huge amount out of what can be an amazing, quite intense experience. I think those doing it part-time miss out on what I call the jollies - the trips abroad and some of the moments that make it a life-changing year."

Again he suggests that those working have a different and no less worthwhile experience and is "full of admiration for anyone doing an MBA while doing a full-time job".

However, press Murray to say which he would choose, and he says he would opt for the part-time course - assuming he found an employer to sponsor him. Maybe it's his Scots background, he suggests.

Distance learning?

But quiz both Murray and Russell about distance learning MBAs and you get a different response. While Murray is against them on the basis that much of the MBA experience comes from the interaction of ideas between the lecturers and students and among the students themselves, Russell accepts that for those unable to attend a college in person, an MBA gained remotely is worthwhile.

Certainly one of the colleges at the forefront of MBA distance learning, the Open University Business School (OUBS) has seen student numbers increase by 10% year-on- year since it launched its MBA a decade ago.

Today around 85% of OUBS students go on to get their MBA so it's clear that it has to be taken seriously.

One of the great advantages it has over the full and part-time courses is its flexibility. Courses may take longer, but students can go as fast or as slowly as they wish.

One way around the lack of organised contact for students working at home is through the use of technology. Chat rooms on the web are one way around this problem; another is the forming of self-help groups.

Tomas Pallas Aparisi, a Spaniard who did the OUBS MBA while working for the European Commission in Brussels, has just completed his MBA.

While he found studying in isolation hard at times, a Brussels-based self-help group formed four years ago that met twice a month played a large part in his success.

Interestingly, distance learning is considered the next growth area for MBAs with a number of colleges, particularly in the United States starting to offer web-based programmes available to anyone with internet access.

fields.headline: Green light for Alzheimer drugs
fields.standfirst: Ruling to end postcode lottery may help thousands.
fields.trailText: Health authorities were told yesterday to end the postcode lottery on new drugs that can help to slow Alzheimer's disease and raise the quality of life for those suffering the most common form of dementia.
fields.body:
Health authorities were told yesterday to end the postcode lottery on new drugs that can help to slow Alzheimer's disease and raise the quality of life for those suffering the most common form of dementia.

Three medicines were approved for treating the debilitating condition in its mild to moderate stages by the national institute of clinical excellence (Nice), the NHS body that advises on clinical effectiveness and value for money.

The Alzheimer's Society welcomed the decision, which could benefit about 30,000 new patients a year in England and Wales. It should also help carers, it said.

Specialists, while also welcoming the ruling, warned that the drugs were not cures.

About half of all health authorities are thought to allow the drugs to be prescribed at present, although some limit such spending. It is not known how many patients have access to them, through the NHS or privately.

The drugs are thought to help those who do benefit for up to three years, leading the Department of Health to estimate that 75,000 sufferers each year could eventually see real differences in their lives.

Nice said the wider use of the drugs, Aricept, Exelon and Reminyl, could cost £42m a year, and some authorities would need to spend more on specialists to assess which patients should be treated with them and to check regularly on whether they were still working. But there would be savings elsewhere, including on care in nursing homes.

Andrew Dillon, Nice's chief executive, said: "It is important to remind patients and their carers that these products will not benefit all patients and that they should only be used as long as they are having a worthwhile effect."

Alistair Burns, professor of old age psychiatry at Manchester University, said the drugs represented "a significant advance on what professionals are able to offer patients".

David Wilkinson, a consultant at Southampton University, said: "More experience is needed to find the best time to start treatment and for how long it is necessary, but we do at last have a rational treatment and must ensure we provide the resources to make the best use of it."

About 400,000 people are thought to have Alzheimer's in England and Wales, 250,000 of them in mild to moderate form. The illness progresses from forgetfulness, confusion, mood swings and difficulty with reading and writing to loss of inhibitions, disintegrating personality and being bedbound or dependent on carers, often elderly themselves.

Nice also approved the use of Rilutek for the most common form of motor neurone disease, after being satisfied that the drug could delay its progress. MND usually leads to death two to five years after onset of symptoms. The NHS's annual bill for the drug could rise from £2m to £7.5m.

About 2,000 patients with the muscle wasting disease will benefit from the drug, which is judged to be effective in treating the form affecting about eight out of 10 cases.

Nice advised that the treatment should be started only by specialists, but GPs could supervise its progress under shared protocols.

Mr Dillon said: "The additional months of life which this medicine offers makes it a worthwhile treatment."

George Levy, chief executive of the MND Association, said the advice was "a significant endorsement of the only drug treatment available... the extra time gained can mean so much to people."

The association would continue to fight for those with other forms of the disease to be eligible for the treatment.

webTitle: Payouts for asbestos victims put at risk

fields.headline: Payouts for asbestos victims put at risk
fields.trailText: Thousands of asbestos victims, many of them dying from their illnesses, could each lose hundreds of thousands of pounds in compensation after an insurance company called in the liquidators.
fields.body:
Thousands of asbestos victims, many of them dying from their illnesses, could each lose hundreds of thousands of pounds in compensation after an insurance company called in the liquidators.

Lawyers acting for former industrial workers across the UK say the situation caused by the actions of Chester Street Insurance Holdings Ltd is scandalous. They have called on the government to step in.

The company called in provisional liquidators earlier this month, claiming it would be unable to meet the growing number of claims from asbestos sufferers suing their employers.

The uncertainty affects workers whose employers were insured by the old Iron Trades Employers Association Ltd, which was a market leader in industrial liability insurance and was responsible for between a half and two-thirds of UK asbestos litigation.

It stopped taking on new employers' liability business in 1990 and much of its continuing business was sold to another company, QBE International, in February last year. But the pre-1990 employer liability business was transferred to Chester Street.

The firm has drawn up a scheme to be put before creditors next month under which the insurer would pay part of a claim and the rest, in some cases, would be topped up from an industry protection fund.

But lawyers say that protection applies only to claims dating from 1972, and most cases came about before this date.

The provisional liquidator, Dan Schwarzman, of PricewaterhouseCoopers, said if the scheme to be put to creditors next month was not accepted, the company would go into liquidation, leading to even more uncertainty and delay. He said, however, he was confident the proposals would be accepted.

Frank Maguire, of the employment lawyers Thompsons, who are currently representing 2,500 asbestos victims, said victims could now be looking at payments of as little as £10,000 instead of the six-figure sum they could have expected.

"You can imagine someone dying from an asbestos-related disease, who has gone through all the pain and suffering of that, and the stress of court action, to be told in the middle of that that they are not going to get much compensation," he said. "They are devastated."

Mr Maguire said the situation could also have serious repercussions for Scotland's shipbuilding industry.

"If the insurance company is not going to pay the damages we will be seeking the bulk of the damages against the company. If that shipbuilding company is trying to survive and maintain its workforce then this is a major problem for them."

Mr Maguire estimates that 5,000 shipyard workers in Scotland will die in the next 10 years because of their previous exposure to asbestos. He also said he was seeking a meeting with the Scottish secretary, John Reid, to inquire about the Department of Trade and Industry's role as regulator of the industry.

Death from asbestos-related diseases can take between 20 and 50 years and thousands of workers have already won cases against their employers for exposure to the deadly dust.

Phyllis Craig of the campaign group Clydeside Action on Asbestosis said it had been inundated with calls from worried clients.

"They have had to deal with one hurdle after another," she said. "And now they are hit with this. These are people who are ill, or dying, through no fault of their own."

A spokesman for the financial services authority denied that thousands of workers could receive no compensation.

"It is planned that Chester Street will introduce a scheme of arrangements, hopefully next month. Employers will receive a certain amount, and where the claim is a protected claim, as most claims are, the Policyholders' Protection Board will top up the claim to 100%."

'I feel very bitter. I want to make sure my family is taken care of'

At the age of 62, time is running out for Joseph Murray, a former pipe fitter who has mesothelioma - a devastating and fatal disease. In the 1950s he did a five-year apprenticeship at Greenock dockyard on the Clyde. Asbestos was everywhere. He did not wear protective clothing - no one did, since no one knew about the material.

Sometimes, he says, they would ball up the stuff and throw it at each other for fun, like snowballs. After work their wives would shake the dust off their husbands' overalls without a second thought.

A year ago, Joe started getting chest pains and becoming breathless. Tests found mesothelioma, and he began a claim for compensation. He had been confident of enough money to see his family secure, until the news broke that the insurance firm had called in provisional liquidators.

"I feel very bitter. It's not just for me. There's an awful lot of people affected by this. And I want to make sure my family is taken care of."

fields.headline: Limits eased on foreign teachers
fields.trailText: The government took further steps to lift recruitment problems in schools yesterday by making it easier for foreign teachers to work in England.
fields.body:
The government took further steps to lift recruitment problems in schools yesterday by making it easier for foreign teachers to work in England.

Until now teachers from countries outside the European economic area, including South Africa, Australia and New Zealand, could work in English schools for a maximum of two years.

Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, extended the time limit to four years. She also removed a rule which meant those teachers could work in the same school for only four months.

"Our proposals will cut through bureaucracy to ensure that where schools have recruited overseas teachers they benefit from the skills and experience they have to offer," Ms Morris said.

Several hundred, possibly thousands, of teachers from Commonwealth countries are teaching in the UK - though no figures are held centrally.

If teachers from those countries want to teach in England for longer than four years they need to obtain an English teaching qualification. But Ms Morris said the teacher training agency was considering making the process quicker.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "It's a small step which could help in the short term but this over-reliance on foreign supply teachers is dangerous. It is more reminiscent of a developing country than the world's fourth largest economy."

It emerged yesterday that Ofsted, the school inspection service, took the unprecedented step of failing a school - Heber primary, in Dulwich, south London - because of staff shortages. At one point three classes did not have a permanent teacher and only one of them had a supply teacher. The school is now fully staffed.

The chief inspector of schools, Mike Tomlinson, is expected to warn in his annual report, published next month, of the threat to standards from staff shortages.

Meanwhile, the Conservatives pledged yesterday to privatise the student loan scheme and save graduates an average of £1,000.

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said a Tory government would raise the earnings threshold at which graduates would have to start paying back student loans from £10,000 to £20,000. They would also introduce tax relief on the repayments worth around £3,500 a year. The loans would be sold on to banks and made available at market rates of interest - double the current levels.

The student loans scheme could be sold as an asset for £3.5bn, with another £1.6bn a year from the sale of the loans to banks and insurance companies, the Tories said. Universities would then compete for endowment funding. But Baroness Blackstone, the higher education minister, attacked the plan, saying it was uncosted and unworkable.

fields.headline: Fans buy into United
fields.trailText: A group of Manchester United fans hoping to head off any future takeover have unveiled ambitious plans to buy a 10% stake in the club.
fields.body:
A group of Manchester United fans hoping to head off any future takeover have unveiled ambitious plans to buy a 10% stake in the club.

Shareholders United, a pressure group set up two years ago to fight Sky's controversial plans to take over the club, claims to have the backing of the manager Sir Alex Ferguson and wants fans to team up to buy the shares as a way of ensuring United remain independent. "A 10% stake would make us the biggest single shareholder and act as an automatic block to future threats of hostile takeover," said Oliver Houston, a spokesman for Shareholders United.

Houston conceded that the scheme was hugely ambitious given that a 10% stake in United would cost £57m. Even if 10,000 fans committed to spend £10 a month each on shares it would take them more than 47 years to reach their target.

The real significance of the scheme is that it is being launched with the blessing of the club and is an indication of how relations between the United board and rebel fan groups are improving.

The chief executive Peter Kenyon has been keen to build bridges with supporters since taking over from the unpopular Martin Edwards in the autumn. Shareholders United (SU) has been awarded a place in United's new Supporters' Consultative Forum and Kenyon has committed to meeting supporters regularly.

A £10,000 cheque, which SU hopes will be the first of regular monthly payments, will be presented to United's stockbrokers Wise Speak before today's home game against Aston Villa. The money will be spent on shares and held in a special account by Wise Speak.

Fans will be charged £10 to join the scheme and automatically become shareholders, gaining a say in how the club are run.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Sun-burnt Grobbelaar stranger than fiction
fields.trailText: • If Grobbelgate is ever turned into a film (Ten Angry Men?), the transcripts of the former keeper's secretly taped talks with Chris Vincent will make the scriptwriter's work a lot easier. For would-be Tarantinos we can recommend item 178, among many others, of the court of appeal's judgment (wood.ccta.gov.uk/courtser/ judgements.nsf) where Mr Red refers to the dangers of crossing the mysterious "short man" (not believed to be a reference to Sammy Lee): "You better get a bullet proof f***ing vest, then ... That's how f***ing big it is ... This is how f***ing dangerous it is ... When you're playing with f***ing dangerous men, it's f***ing dangerous." Expect to see Samuel L Jackson provocatively cast as the former South African Defence Force stalwart.

For would-be Tarantinos we can recommend item 178, among many others, of the court of appeal's judgment (wood.ccta.gov.uk/courtser/ judgements.nsf) where Mr Red refers to the dangers of crossing the mysterious "short man" (not believed to be a reference to Sammy Lee): "You better get a bullet proof f***ing vest, then ... That's how f***ing big it is ... This is how f***ing dangerous it is ... When you're playing with f***ing dangerous men, it's f***ing dangerous." Expect to see Samuel L Jackson provocatively cast as the former South African Defence Force stalwart.

 A League of Wales club is taking the BBC to court over its refusal to read out the Welsh results on Final Score. Greg Dyke's comments on racial imbalance within the BBC have "added new impetus" to their case apparently, based as it is on alleged discrimination. It might be easier to sympathise with this quest for publicity (sorry, bid for justice) if the club in question were not being flagrantly used as an advertising vehicle for the owner's company.

 Espen Baardsen's Scandinavian instincts seem to have been well and truly subverted by his upbringing in the US. Writing on his website this week, Watford's reserve keeper comments on the Duncan Ferguson have-a-go-hero case, noting an alleged lack of similar crimes in America: "The only logical explanation for this is the protection offered by the Second Amendment to the Constitution, the one that defends the right to bear arms." We hope to see him campaigning in the general election under the slogan "Give Dunc a gun".

 Further to last week's story on Cardiff City's unorthodox media policy (dousing the local journalist Grahame Lloyd with buckets of water), the two parties have issued a statement. "Cardiff City is a unique and independent club that will preserve and express itself in any way it wishes in the future and this will include further 'baptisms'," it says. Unique, certainly.

 It's an appalling job, but it seems someone in the warped world of football ghostwriting has to do it. Yes, George Best's dog now has its own column on the Ulsterman's imminent official website. "I've always been interested in a career in journalism," Red Best the Red Setter begins, before unforgivably missing the chance to discuss chasing stories and biting satire.

 Signing players used to be a matter of managers slipping into terrace houses after dark to sweet-talk parents over a pot of strong tea. No longer. This week Southampton secured an Australian, Jay Lucas, by faxing best wishes for his 16th birthday - and a contract, of course - to his hotel room in Papua New Guinea, where his club are taking part in the World Club championship qualifiers. You can run from the Premier League, but you can't hide.

 Sadly, there were more than a few big names missing from the prestigious World Sports Awards event in London this week. One footballer who might have been there but for the strict dress code was Marcel Desailly. He turned up in jeans and trainers and could be seen hanging around the entrance wondering whether or not to risk ridicule inside.

 Party problems of a different sort for Gheorghe Hagi, who is staging a farewell match, Romania v A World XI, in Bucharest on March 24. Two famous guests who don't get on. Bitchy spat at a previous do. Tricky decision for the Maradona of the Carpathians, who resolved it elegantly. "I decided to drop Diego from the list of my guests," Hagi said. "I want my retirement to be a happy celebration."

 Arsenal are said to be interested in Bari's young goalkeeper, Generoso Rossi. Generoso? What kind of twisted parents name their kid Generoso and encourage him to become a 'keeper?

webTitle: Carling pulls out in black day for league

fields.headline: Carling pulls out in black day for league
fields.trailText: The Premiership will have an unfamiliar taste to it next season after Carling pulled out of negotiations to renew its sponsorship deal last night.
fields.body:
The Premiership will have an unfamiliar taste to it next season after Carling pulled out of negotiations to renew its sponsorship deal last night.

The move ends an eight-year association between the Premier League and Carling, whose parent company Bass blamed "indecision" among the league's chairmen for the split. Although Carling is understood to have offered £39m over three years, Budweiser is thought to have topped that with £45m. Budweiser is now the favourite to take over, although other companies have expressed interest and may look to negotiate with the Premier League.

A decision on the identity of next season's sponsors is due to be made at an extraordinary meeting of the Premier League chairmen in the first week of February.

It was the refusal of the chairmen to back Carling's offer at their meeting on Thursday which prompted Bass to turn its attention elsewhere. The company had set Thursday as a deadline for a decision and feels its bid was not being dealt with properly.

"We first presented a bid back in September and understood that it would finally be tabled at yesterday's meeting so that club chairmen could make a decision," said Bass's marketing director Mark Hunter.

"This didn't happen, so we can't let this indecision affect other plans for Carling. This is why we are moving forward with other initiatives."

Yet in being a broadly British brand Carling seems to have suffered in these latest sponsorship talks. With a huge worldwide audience for its own product, the Premier League is thought to be keen to secure the backing of a global brand, which is likely to be more lucrative.

The Premier League's chief executive Richard Scudamore expressed regret at Carling's withdrawal, though he stressed he respected the business decision made.

"They have been an excellent partner and we would have liked that relationship to continue," he said. "That has not proved possible. In the meantime we will continue our work in securing a sponsor."

Bass refused to close the door for good last night but a renewal of its deal is highly unlikely. "Never say never but I would be very surprised if it's the Carling Premiership next season," said Stuart Cain, head of sponsorship at Bass. "If the Premier League come back in one month and want to look again we will sit with them, but by that time we may well have committed our sponsorship budget elsewhere."

Carling is expected to pour more resources into music, having already become involved with the Reading and Leeds festivals. But Bass stressed that it hoped to maintain its relationship with English football and Scudamore insisted there was still scope for future deals.

"Both brands have benefited from this association and remain proud of their achievements," he said. "The door therefore is still very much open for future opportunities."

The decision does not affect Carling's plans for the remainder of this season, which include end-of-season celebrations and initiatives such as the manager and player of the month awards.

webTitle: Taylor snags Sturridge as Foxes bolster attack

fields.headline: Taylor snags Sturridge as Foxes bolster attack
fields.trailText: Leicester City's manager Peter Taylor yesterday completed the signing of Derby's reserve striker Dean Sturridge in a £350,000 deal. It follows the arrival of the Italian veteran Roberto Mancini, who on Thursday joined from Lazio until the end of the season.
fields.body:
Leicester City's manager Peter Taylor yesterday completed the signing of Derby's reserve striker Dean Sturridge in a £350,000 deal. It follows the arrival of the Italian veteran Roberto Mancini, who on Thursday joined from Lazio until the end of the season.

Taylor made his move after Sturridge scored twice for Derby against Leicester in a reserve fixture on Tuesday. The manager confirmed: "We have agreed a fee, he has passed a medical and we have sorted out personal terms. I am delighted to sign Dean."

Leicester will be relieved to have added another striker to their squad to supplement the inexperienced pairing of Ade Akinbiyi and Trevor Benjamin. Like Mancini, Sturridge may go straight into the squad for today's Premiership visit of Arsenal. He will also be eligible for the FA Cup fourth-round tie at Aston Villa next Saturday.

The Leeds and South Africa central defender Lucas Radebe says he will retire from the international game after next week's World Cup qualifier.

The 31-year-old has been involved in another tug-of-war over the past few days between his club and the South African FA - he has been called up for the qualifier with Burkina Faso next Saturday, so ruling him out of Leeds's FA Cup fourth-round tie at home to Liverpool that day - and he has had enough. But he has not ruled out a compromise, given his desire to captain his country to the next World Cup in 2002.

West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp is contemplating signing the 22-year-old Bulgarian striker Svetoslav Todorov, who has impressed him in training this week.

fields.headline: Hoddle the hovering Hotspur
fields.standfirst: Spurs fans see their old hero as the manager to bring back the style but he is all Saints at White Hart Lane today, writes  Roy Collins
fields.trailText: Spurs fans see their old hero as the manager to bring back the style but he is all Saints at White Hart Lane today, writes Roy Collins
fields.body:
The return of Glenn Hoddle to Tottenham today as Southampton manager will do nothing to lift the heads of home supporters from the nostalgic fog in which they appear as morbidly enshrouded as The Likely Lads. Like Bob and Terry, Spurs fans seem convinced that the only thing they have to look forward to is the past.

In that case the Tottenham manager George Graham has trodden on their future as well as their past by claiming that their memories have been playing tricks on them and that the concept of a Spurs Way of playing is as nebulous as Tony Blair's Third Way.

Yet Hoddle, as a player, embodied the Spurs style: he could be both breathtakingly brilliant and infuriatingly inconsistent.

"From the moment I went to the club as a young kid to the day I left as a player," he says, "we were taught to play through the pitch from the back of the team to the front. That was always the way."

That does not mean that Hoddle, who tops Spurs fans' wish list of managers and is apparently fancied by the prospective owner Enic too, would instantly transform Spurs into a team of ball-juggling entertainers. As a manager he shares Graham's pragmatic belief that supporters, not to mention chairmen and sponsors, put success a long way ahead of aesthetics.

Hoddle, who has not always chosen his words as carefully as he might, is naturally diplomatic when discussing a possible return to a club with an under-pressure incumbent. But he would not be a Spurs man if he did not sometimes imagine swinging his car through those famous gates on Tottenham High Road and parking in the manager's spot.

He says: "People will always speculate about X, Y and Z and of course I've got an affinity with Tottenham. I went there at 11 and left when I was 29, so there are lots of memories you just can't wipe away. Maybe in 10 years' time I might find myself back there as manager, but then again it might never happen.

"As I've found out in football, things change and you can't guess what is going to happen. There's a job to be done here and I'm enjoying it but, if results go badly, I might be sacked in a year's time. Or I might do well and feel I want to move on."

In any case, when Hoddle steps off the team coach today his thoughts will not be of his many glory days on the White Hart Lane pitch but of the humiliating 7-2 defeat inflicted on his Southampton team last March. With the one-eyed revisionism exclusive to managers and supporters he says: "It was a freak result. Mark Hughes had to come off to have a split head treated and we gave them three goals with schoolboy errors. We beat them 2-0 at the Dell in December, so we're going with a lot of optimism and we won't be going to shut the door."

Having started the foreign policy at Chelsea before getting his pick of home-grown talent as England coach, he surprised many by climbing back into the management saddle on such a lowly nag as Southampton. But he insists: "The quality of player here is much better than when I took over at Chelsea. And people forget what I did at Swindon with no money at all.

"It's a great challenge to work with the cream of the country and it's a massive challenge to try to improve players and get a team structure. This is a different kind of challenge, a different kind of pressure. I've been at both ends of the Richter scale and I've enjoyed both."

Hoddle's frustration is not in his modest working environment but in the failure of his team to rise above their status as perennial relegation fodder. His predecessor Dave Jones joked that he had always thought the club's official name was Struggling Southampton.

Having saved them from relegation last season, Hoddle had anticipated finally detaching the noun from the adjective and says he cannot fathom why his side have won only once away this term. "I am frustrated we are not higher up the table because we have played well. I know we are a small club but Leicester and Ipswich are an example of where Southampton can go and what can be achieved."

Managing Southampton has been recuperative for Hoddle after his sacking by England over those injudicious remarks about disabled people but, when he talks about how things in football can change in an instant - "You never know what's around the corner" - the words resonate with poignancy.

Despite that, he generously offers an invitation to Sven-Goran Eriksson to follow through his promise to pick the brains of England's former coaches; he also takes pride that his influence and ideas live on at the FA in the form of Peter Taylor. "I got slagged off by three quarters of the press when I appointed Peter as Under-21 manager," he says, "so it made me smile when quite a lot of them said recently he should be the next England manager. That is a credit to Peter, and myself if you like, and the people we worked with. I knew he would be perfect for that job and now he's gone on to manage England. It would be nice if one day he could manage England permanently."

And one day, of course, Hoddle might manage Tottenham. He has heard the rumours that Enic might fancy him but says: "It's all hearsay and out of my control. In any case I've got a job to do here and, if we beat Spurs 1-0, I'm not sure the fans will be singing my name."
