webTitle: Going in over the top in transfer battle

fields.headline: Going in over the top in transfer battle
fields.trailText: The tangle in which football has got itself trying to bring the transfer system into line with European labour laws can best be summed up by the American acronym Snafu, which in its polite form stands for Situation Normal, All Fouled Up.
fields.body:
The tangle in which football has got itself trying to bring the transfer system into line with European labour laws can best be summed up by the American acronym Snafu, which in its polite form stands for Situation Normal, All Fouled Up.

Except that the European football union might prefer Fatheaded Idiocy For All (Fifa) and the game's world governing body could respond with Usual Excess of Flatulent Air (Uefa).

Either way, the grey and largely legal suits running Fifa and Uefa have been so much at odds over how to give footballers the basic right to change jobs when they like, while retaining some sort of fee for their services, that a seismic split between the game's two biggest governing bodies has been predicted.

By the time the parties met in Zurich yesterday things had cooled down, yet Uefa may see no harm in having reminded Fifa of how enfeebled it would be without the leading European nations. And should south America join any confederacy then Nyon, where Fifa lives, would look like the Roman empire without Rome.

For the moment Uefa has merely threatened to do its own deal with the European Commission on marrying players' contracts with the rights enjoyed by workers employed in EU countries. In fact it seems a pity that Fifa became involved at all, given its president Sepp Blatter's unfortunate habit of upsetting the European body almost at every turn.

When, as Fifa secretary, he conducted the draw in Las Vegas for the 1994 World Cup, Blatter was addressed by the American comic Robin Williams as "Mr Bladder". Since then he has managed to do a fair imitation of a blimp with a leak, that is to say blowing raspberries while pursuing a wildly erratic course.

For example, who but Mr Bladder could furnish the EU with the idea of allowing players to leave clubs in mid-contract if they did not agree with a coach's tactics? When the Europeans erupted, Fifa hrrumphed and said this was merely a working paper, not an official document, and yesterday it withdrew the paper altogether, describing it as "invalid". Either way the notion is plain daft.

To a casual observer - and here the average fan is more likely to be a bored, bewildered onlooker - the crisis might have seemed unnecessary. After all, what is at stake? The EU says that only players moving between countries would be affected and everybody seems to agree there should be a set contract for footballers, with clubs getting compensation for those footballers who break it.

The problem is that, like the Bosman ruling, any new system will quickly be applied universally, making it even more likely that the wealthiest clubs will still pay the highest salaries to the best players and that the smaller clubs will lose much of the income from transfer fees that keeps them alive.

In addition, and before anything can be agreed between Fifa, Uefa and the EU, the players' international federation, Fipro, led by the Professional Footballers' Association's Gordon Taylor, will insist on an agreement which honours the spirit of European law and ends the principle of a footballer being unable to change jobs until his employers have received a transfer fee. That, remember, was the right established by George Eastham in the high court nearly 40 years ago.

The trouble is that even though the EU feels justified in rationalising, though not wholly abolishing, a transfer system spiralling towards the first £100m player, football's inequalities will surely make the application of any such scheme impracticable.

There is nothing the EU can do which will prevent the continued concentration of the world's leading footballers among a handful of mega-rich clubs or the huge sums involved when they move. If fees were ended, more money would simply go to the players and their agents.

The Spanish idea, employed by Luis Figo when he left Barcelona for Real Madrid, might satisfy the EU. Figo (ie Real) bought out his own contract at Nou Camp. It was the £37m fee which persuaded the EU to light a bonfire under Fifa, which had failed to respond to Europe's original objection to transfer fees two years earlier.

Yet whatever the system of compensation for clubs turns out to be, there will remain the fundamental problem of trying to impose order on a game which thrives on anarchy. Players dispute referees' decisions on the field and contracts off it. Managers are either sacked or walk out when a better offer comes along. Chairmen abide by Football Association rules until their clubs are punished for breaking them; then they take the FA to court.

The big clubs regularly use the threat of a breakaway league, whether European or domestic, to frighten football bodies into meeting their demands for ever greater exclusivity - ie more cash. Similarly, Uefa has been attempting to use its considerable clout to bring Fifa to heel.

A logical mind might think that nobody would want a footballer who made a habit of changing clubs because he disagreed with the team's tactics or anything else of equal triviality. But only when clubs stop signing the game's Stan Collymores will anything approaching logic come into the argument.

The EU, meantime, awaits another Snafu - in this case Some Nonsense About a Footballing Utopia.

fields.headline: Kirch's EM.TV bid in jeopardy
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: An alliance of companies including venture capital firm Morgan Grenfell Private Equity is considering a counter offer for EM.TV, the embattled German group which owns a 50% share of the lucrative media rights to formula one racing.
fields.body:
An alliance of companies including venture capital firm Morgan Grenfell Private Equity is considering a counter offer for EM.TV, the embattled German group which owns a 50% share of the lucrative media rights to formula one racing.

The bid could scupper the continuing talks between EM and German media group Kirch, which had hoped to inject needed cash into the business in return for a stake and part of the formula one rights.

Shares in EM - a former star of Germany's Neuer Markt - had a volatile day. They rose in early trading to an intraday high of €10.20 (£6.51), an increase of 60%, before settling back at €6.40.

The consortium considering a counter-bid is headed by Tele München Group, a media outfit 45% owned by EM. It also includes Morgan, the UK-based venture capital arm of Deutsche Bank, and Hellman & Friedman, the American private equity house.

The deal is expected to be structured with TMG offering to take a stake in EM and the private equity firms supplying the cash for EM's 50% stake in Slec, the holding company that owns the formula one rights.

Morgan Grenfell and Hellman & Friedman had both previously been shareholders in Slec and the deal is understood to have the backing of motor racing tycoon Bernie Ecclestone, who owns the other half.

The discussions with Kirsch were announced at the beginning of December, but have recently stalled amid reported friction between the two companies.

EM paid DM3.5bn (£1.1bn) for the formula one media rights stake from Mr Ecclestone last year. The deal was part of an ambitious programme of acquisitions that also included the Jim Henson company, creator of the Muppets.

EM declined to comment, but noted that it had agreed not to solicit any other offers for the company or its assets until the end of January, although that does not prevent buyers making an approach.

webTitle: Straw ups the stakes on crime

fields.headline: Straw ups the stakes on crime
fields.standfirst: Home secretary rejects civil liberty fears
fields.trailText: The most sweeping extension of police powers since Michael Howard's infamous 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act was yesterday unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, under the banner of tackling "drunken yobs" and "modernising law enforcement".
fields.body:
The most sweeping extension of police powers since Michael Howard's infamous 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act was yesterday unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, under the banner of tackling "drunken yobs" and "modernising law enforcement".

More than 20 new powers for the police are contained in the legislation, including: taking and storing DNA samples and fingerprints from people who have never been found guilty of a crime; issuing fixed penalty fines to those who make hoax 999 calls and those who throw fireworks in public places; and measures to revive Labour's failed child curfew and anti-social behaviour initiatives.

The bill also pledges that the same levels of witness protection given to those in criminal cases will be granted to people who come forward to give evidence in civil cases. The measure is designed to reduce witness intimidation in cases such as anti-social behaviour orders which, the Home Office said in today's documents, has been far less successful than hoped with applications running at 100 a year rather than the expected 5,000.

Mr Straw's criminal justice and police bill will be introduced into the Commons in about a fortnight and the political battle to get it on to the statute book is expected to form a centrepiece of the run-up to a general election.

Mr Straw last night dismissed any civil liberties objections to his new package, insisting the public would welcome the extra police powers because they were "more interested in the arrest, prosecution and conviction of persistent offenders such as burglars through the use of the new powers".

But the home secretary has already been forced into retreat over the crackdown on teenage yob culture promised by Tony Blair at last year's Labour party conference. Home Office civil servants confirmed last night that the much-trumpeted fixed penalty fines for louts would only apply to adults over 18, with plans for them to include 16- and 17-year-olds dropped.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, raised concerns about the human rights implications of some of the proposed new measures. She predicted that the bill would not reach the statute book before the election.

"There is little chance of this bill becoming law. It is little more than an attempt to grab headlines with spot-fine and curfew powers that will overburden police forces even more when they are already at breaking point," she said.

"Some parts of the bill also have serious civil liberties implications which will require detailed scrutiny - such as new powers to disclose inland revenue records and the retention of DNA samples by the police even after a person has been found not guilty."

The DNA proposal goes against a recent House of Lords ruling banning the retention of samples of people who are acquitted by the courts.

Mary Cunneen, associate director of Liberty, the civil rights organisation, said the powers in the bill amounted to "the most serious erosion of rights in the criminal justice system that we have seen for years. It is a series of apparently small and mainly technical changes that show a lack of respect of the criminal justice system and the rights of people within it."

The Liberal Democrats' Simon Hughes predicted that the new system of fixed penalty notices would turn into a bureaucratic mess with many fines being challenged in court. "Labour is still placing too much emphasis on short-term solutions to crime, rather than dealing with the root causes of the problems," he said.

The scale of the 132-clause bill reawakened memories of Michael Howard's shorter 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act, which restricted the right to silence and gave police the power to take DNA samples and act against trespassers, squatters and rave parties which featured music "characterised by the emission of a succession of repetitive beats".

On the spot penalties for disorderly behaviour

Instant closure of violent clubs and pubs

Bans on drinking in public places

Crackdown on protests by animal rights activists

Sweeping powers to take and keep DNA samples

New police powers of seizure

New police power of arrest, including for kerb crawlers and hit and run drivers

Extension of child curfew schemes to 15-year-olds

Extension of police powers under 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act without parliamentary approval

Disclosure of confidential tax records to police
fields.bodyText: The most sweeping extension of police powers since Michael Howard's infamous 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act was yesterday unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, under the banner of tackling "drunken yobs" and "modernising law enforcement". More than 20 new powers for the police are contained in the legislation, including: taking and storing DNA samples and fingerprints from people who have never been found guilty of a crime; issuing fixed penalty fines to those who make hoax 999 calls and those who throw fireworks in public places; and measures to revive Labour's failed child curfew and anti-social behaviour initiatives. The bill also pledges that the same levels of witness protection given to those in criminal cases will be granted to people who come forward to give evidence in civil cases. The measure is designed to reduce witness intimidation in cases such as anti-social behaviour orders which, the Home Office said in today's documents, has been far less successful than hoped with applications running at 100 a year rather than the expected 5,000. Mr Straw's criminal justice and police bill will be introduced into the Commons in about a fortnight and the political battle to get it on to the statute book is expected to form a centrepiece of the run-up to a general election. Mr Straw last night dismissed any civil liberties objections to his new package, insisting the public would welcome the extra police powers because they were "more interested in the arrest, prosecution and conviction of persistent offenders such as burglars through the use of the new powers". But the home secretary has already been forced into retreat over the crackdown on teenage yob culture promised by Tony Blair at last year's Labour party conference. Home Office civil servants confirmed last night that the much-trumpeted fixed penalty fines for louts would only apply to adults over 18, with plans for them to include 16- and 17-year-olds dropped. The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, raised concerns about the human rights implications of some of the proposed new measures. She predicted that the bill would not reach the statute book before the election. "There is little chance of this bill becoming law. It is little more than an attempt to grab headlines with spot-fine and curfew powers that will overburden police forces even more when they are already at breaking point," she said. "Some parts of the bill also have serious civil liberties implications which will require detailed scrutiny - such as new powers to disclose inland revenue records and the retention of DNA samples by the police even after a person has been found not guilty." The DNA proposal goes against a recent House of Lords ruling banning the retention of samples of people who are acquitted by the courts. Mary Cunneen, associate director of Liberty, the civil rights organisation, said the powers in the bill amounted to "the most serious erosion of rights in the criminal justice system that we have seen for years. It is a series of apparently small and mainly technical changes that show a lack of respect of the criminal justice system and the rights of people within it." The Liberal Democrats' Simon Hughes predicted that the new system of fixed penalty notices would turn into a bureaucratic mess with many fines being challenged in court. "Labour is still placing too much emphasis on short-term solutions to crime, rather than dealing with the root causes of the problems," he said. The scale of the 132-clause bill reawakened memories of Michael Howard's shorter 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act, which restricted the right to silence and gave police the power to take DNA samples and act against trespassers, squatters and rave parties which featured music "characterised by the emission of a succession of repetitive beats". On the spot penalties for disorderly behaviour Instant closure of violent clubs and pubs Bans on drinking in public places Crackdown on protests by animal rights activists Sweeping powers to take and keep DNA samples New police powers of seizure New police power of arrest, including for kerb crawlers and hit and run drivers Extension of child curfew schemes to 15-year-olds Extension of police powers under 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act without parliamentary approval Disclosure of confidential tax records to police

fields.headline: Meacher owner of nine homes
fields.standfirst: Meacher's many homes
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has built up a property portfolio of at least nine and up to 12 homes with his second wife, Lucianne, worth a minimum of £2m, a joint investigation by the Guardian and the Mark Thomas Product TV programme reveals today.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has built up a property portfolio of at least nine and up to 12 homes with his second wife, Lucianne, worth a minimum of £2m, a joint investigation by the Guardian and the Mark Thomas Product TV programme reveals today.

The leftwing minister, who nearly 20 years ago condemned posh homes as "status symbols" and part of the Thatcherite divide, has built up most of the portfolio in the 1990s, with his latest purchases coming after taking up his government post.

Mr Meacher and his wife own a house in Wimbledon; a country retreat in Gloucestershire and a terraced property in his Oldham constituency. Between them they are building up a portfolio of flats in Wimbledon, Balham and Putney in south London which are being let. His wife is a director of three property companies.

Mr Meacher, who two years ago condemned second home owners for preventing young people in rural areas from getting a foot on the property ladder, has a Cotswold house worth more than £500,000 according to local estate agents.

Andrew Lansley, the Conservative spokesman on the Cabinet Office, said: "I intend to write to Mr Meacher asking him to explain how this fits in with the ministerial code of conduct and whether he has informed his colleagues of his financial interests if he participates in discussions on housing matters."

fields.headline: How the zebra got its stripes
fields.standfirst: Lisa Milroy's paintings painstakingly depict the surface of things: their                                                                            textures, the patterns they make, how light reflects off them. Adrian Searle                                                                            is intrigued
fields.trailText: Lisa Milroy's paintings painstakingly depict the surface of things: their textures, the patterns they make, how light reflects off them. Adrian Searle is intrigued
fields.body:
Wake up, shake off the night, go to the loo, have a coffee and take a bath. Dress, then cycle to the studio, via that sandwich shop you always use. Fiddle with the padlock and walk into the studio. Put on that old misshapen jumper, the one with the paint stains. It is cold here.

The day's ritual goes on, till you find yourself caught up in the optimistic tempo of late morning, looking at what you accomplished yesterday. Time to get going. You stand, you sit, you get up again and pick up a brush. There goes the phone. Put on some music, then finally lose yourself in painting. Hours pass.

At the end of the day you clean the slab you mix your paints on, throw the brushes in the turps and wash up. Then, buttoned up in your coat, you take a last look at what you did in the fading light. This is an abbreviated description of A Day in the Studio, a new painting by Lisa Milroy. The images are laid out like a strip cartoon, the cells presented as though they were a grid of drawings on sheets of paper, re-presented on the big canvas. Her day is so familiar to me, especially that one last look in the darkening room.

What was she painting that day? We never quite get to see. Maybe one of those paintings of rows of shoes, or piles of neatly folded shirts, or shiny black gramophone records or sailors' caps that made her career in the 1980s. As much as they were still lifes of objects, those paintings were also stealthy comments on consumerism and fetishisation, about the way we devour images and paintings as well as an endless variety of things - frocks, shoes, hats, light bulbs, door handles. Things we need and things we don't.

As the images in her paintings multiplied, so Milroy presented us with insatiable wants. Car tyres slanted away in a vast painted emptiness, obeying laws of capitalist overproduction as much as of perspective. Milroy rummaged in collectors' cabinets for exotic butterflies, rare stamps, Roman coins, pot shards and decorated Greek vases, Japanese mugs and bowls with their heavily pitted glazes, stacks of willow-pattern and dishwasher-safe plates. The things she painted provided her with a painter's problems and opportunities - how to render a slick of light reflected on a Grecian urn, the grooves on an LP, how to paint not just the pot or the plate, but the decoration on its surface, the zebra and its stripes.

How far to go into texture, sheen, the details and the decoration. She went on to paint singular images: a profile of a girl with perfect skin and well-brushed hair and kids in skiing gear. Paintings that look like job-lot canvases for hotel bedrooms, and paintings of the hotel rooms themselves. Pictures of Japanese rooms and streets and London's windswept corners - Embankment tube station and a Soho newsagent's where I go to buy Spanish papers, the New York Review of Books, my favourite angling magazines. Milroy prompts you to list things: places, painting styles and idioms.

She detoured at one point into what we might see as abstraction - but were these patterned paintings, or paintings of patterns, wallpapers and wrapping papers? Her early painterly shorthand took a lot from Manet and Sargent. Later it shifted to a kind of anonymous suppressed descriptiveness reminiscent of Hopper. Her paintings of Japanese ceramics were photorealist, while her paintings of fast food gleamed with cholesterol and the backlit fakery of the burger joint menu.

She has always been interested in how things and their descriptions collide, how painting works, how perilous is its autonomy. The artist herself hung Tate Liverpool's excellent survey of her work, juxtaposing newer works with old, style against style, subject against subject. Her newest works - almost alarming at first sight - are painted in a style reminiscent of the drawings of Posy Simmonds (who is giving a talk at the Tate on Milroy's work). It seems that Milroy has had to re-jig her practice once again in order to focus on the social and on the autobiographical rather than on the surfaces of things (though even her earlier work was in part about the things she liked, her shopping habits, the places she has been and the art she looked at).

It has enabled her to be funnier, faster, maybe less self-censoring about what she can put in a painting. Yet the demands of execution - how to paint a crowd, a woman trying lipstick in a shop, how to do jars of cosmetics, speech bubbles and lettering, a shorthand for a thought or feeling - demand just as much rigour, inventiveness, graphic abbreviation as any still life object. She is putting into painting what artists usually leave to their notebooks or their prints (think of the difference between Turner's landscapes and his erotic drawings, Goya's court portraits and his Caprichos).

Milroy still has an omnivorous eye, for art as much as for the world of things and places, but she's turning it towards what she used to leave out. If she's painting differently now, and moving away from the manners of what might pass for a latter-day high style, then it is to let more of the world in, to deliberate on different feelings, things more essential and closer to home.

webTitle: Fate of internet twins rests on international court battle

fields.headline: Fate of internet twins rests on international court battle
fields.standfirst:
Twins' fate rests on court battle

Special report: Babies For Sale
fields.trailText: The case of the internet twins, Belinda and Kimberley, was last night heading for weeks of courtroom argument on both sides of the Atlantic as the complex inter-country adoption case entered uncharted legal territory.
fields.body:
The case of the internet twins, Belinda and Kimberley, was last night heading for weeks of courtroom argument on both sides of the Atlantic as the complex inter-country adoption case entered uncharted legal territory.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the would-be adoptive parents who found the girls through a website run by a Californian child broker, challenged the decision of Flintshire social services to remove the children from their care.

The twins - still American citizens - were placed with temporary foster parents in Wales after the council secured an emergency protection order late on Thursday evening.

Flintshire county council said the six-month-old twins were "safe and well" and it would bring a case to the high court before the end of next week.

Philip McGreevy, chief exec utive, said the seizure of the children on Thursday was "a careful, considered and proportionate response to the emerging circumstances".

But the Kilshaws and their solicitor said they had not yet been given any reasons for an action that conflicted with the adoption order from the US court in Arkansas.

Mrs Kilshaw added a further international dimension to the case when she suggested that the family might go abroad rather than return to their seven-bedroom farmhouse in Buckley.

"I'm not going home. I see my future now abroad because I'm the most hated figure in England. I can't live a normal life," she said.

Mr Kilshaw said he had intended immediate legal action against the emergency protection order, but now thought a delay before high court proceedings next week would give the family breathing space.

"I believe that social services have definitely got it in for us. We have not done anything to give them a major reason to take this course of action. I rather suspect that someone is behind this, beyond social services, in a political context, but we will have to wait and see," he said.

A director of social services from another authority said emergency protection orders were normally used when social workers thought a child was suffering or likely to suffer significant harm from abuse or neglect.

A possible justification for the Flintshire authorities was that the Kilshaws were regarded as private fosterers, pending settlement of doubts about the legitimacy of the adoption in the US. In that event the children could have been removed if social workers were not getting sufficient access to check their health and well-being.

The emergency protection order will lapse after eight days unless it is renewed or, as Flintshire council intends in this case, replaced by more permanent protec tion for the children.

The standard procedure would be for the council to apply for an interim care order. This could be done before magistrates who would hear representations from the parents and from a guardian ad litem - an independent person appointed to represent the interests of the child.

Given the complexity of this case, the hearing would almost certainly be referred up to a judge in the high court. Dianne Miller, the parents' solicitor, said she favoured moving the case to the high court.

Proceedings could also take the form of an application by the parents, the local authority or another person to make the children wards of court.

Ms Miller said: "The only argument is where are the children between now and the case being settled. I want the children home with the parents. My argument is why is temporary foster care better than being with my clients?

She said she would be talking to Heather Swindells, a leading counsel specialising in children's law. "She will be going to the high court in Birmingham on Tuesday. Tuesday is the beginning - the end is some way off."

The case will be more complicated if the American courts invalidate the adoption and order the children to be returned to US jurisdiction.

Although Mr Kilshaw said he would abide by decisions of the courts in Arkansas or the US supreme court, the British courts would need to be satisfied that the children were going back to a safe place.

Judge Ellen Brantley, one of six Arkansas judges dealing with adoption, said it was likely that there would be legal action over the babies in the state's courts that could render the adoption invalid.

She suggested that the babies' birth mother might be prosecuted for perjury if she returned to Arkansas to seek the return of her children.

Rhodri Morgan, first minister of the Welsh assembly, which is reponsible for overseeing social workers in Wales, welcomed the move to take the girls into temporary care.

fields.headline: Virgin furious at 'hijacking' of route
fields.standfirst:
Branson considers legal action against rail authority

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Branson considers legal action against rail authority.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson was last night said to be considering legal action against the strategic rail authority for allegedly hijacking his plans to build a new 225mph high speed rail line along the east coast.

Senior SRA board members said that they backed the recommendation of Sir Alastair Morton, their chairman, to reject Sir Richard's plan in favour of a more cautious idea of upgrading the existing line, even though Sir Richard's plan is cheaper and would save the Treasury £1.5bn.

Sir Alastair's colleagues said that they would oppose any move by the government to force Sir Alastair to change his mind. Ministers have already let it be known that they approve of the plan - although the Treasury has still to decide whether it gives "value for money".

Virgin said yesterday that it was writing to the SRA for an explanation for the delay but was still confident its plan for a purpose built railway, capable of running trains at up to 225mph, would be built.

Following reports yesterday that it had rejected the Virgin plan, the SRA hurriedly issued a statement saying that it backed the idea of high speed railway and would be inviting consultants to work on a feasibility study.

The statement enraged Virgin executives, who said that Sir Alastair was trying to hi-jack its plan in an attempt to save face and present it as his own.

Sir Richard could seek a judicial review against the SRA if the government decides to go ahead with an alternative plan by Great North Eastern Railway. GNER holds the current franchise. It would operate tilting trains on the upgraded existing track at speeds of 140mph.

The SRA would make no comment about the row with one of the largest rail operators in Britain. Industry sources said that it was already seeking legal advice on a possible challenge by Sir Richard.

Mike Grant, the SRA's chief executive, said that the high speed line would reduce journeys from Manchester or Leeds to less than 90 minutes, to Newcastle to around two hours and to Scotland to less than three hours.

He said that preliminary work had already been carried out by the SRA with the aim of providing "the best concept" by the end of 2002.

Mr Grant omitted to say that such plan would take at least 10 years from drawing board to realisation, and that GNER has been offered a 20-year extension of its franchise.

Virgin has already carried out preliminary work on its plan. The route would go through mainly farm land, displacing few houses.

webTitle: Harare sheds no tears for its puppet

fields.headline: Harare sheds no tears for its puppet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: For two days, Laurent Kabila's cronies hid his corpse away in a Zimbabwean morgue and pretended that the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo was still of this world. But having finally admitted the reality, they put his body on display amid tight security.
fields.body:
For two days, Laurent Kabila's cronies hid his corpse away in a Zimbabwean morgue and pretended that the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo was still of this world. But having finally admitted the reality, they put his body on display amid tight security.

Kabila, wearing a black suit and showing no sign of bullet wounds, was ensconced in an elaborate white and gold coffin, draped with the Congolese flag. It lay in the chapel of a Zimbabwean army commando unit barracks, for diplomats and others who looked suitably respectful to view. A man in a leather motorcycle jacket decided who fitted this bill. He brusquely refused entrance to all journalists save for Zimbabwe's state news media.

This time Congo's president had the kind of security that was clearly lacking when one of his own soldiers shot him in the back on Tuesday.

It is fitting that Kabila's corpse should be put on display in Zimbabwe before Congo. He was certainly more welcome there, at least among its leadership, than he was in his own country.

Kabila's ally, Robert Mugabe, arrived to acknowledge the death of a man who was a puppet and yet frustratingly unmanageable despite his reliance on Zimbabwe.

Wailing

At a service attended by about 300 people, including Kabila's wife and six of their children, two senior vice-presidents and diplomats from several African countries, mourners were greeted by 40 wailing Congolese women in T-shirts with Kabila's face emblazoned on the front and "Adieu mon president" on the back.

But one of the women uttered what her compatriots believe - Kabila's death is no bad thing. "We hope that with Kabila's departure we will be able to sit down and find a way to peace and we will be able to live like other countries," she said.

Mr Mugabe said nothing. He had looked badly shaken on state television as the Zimbabwean government finally confirmed the Congolese leader's death.

Both governments had claimed that Kabila had been airlifted to Harare for emergency medical treatment but Moven Mahachi, the Zimbabwean defence minster, admitted yesterday that he died in Kinshasa of his wounds.

Mr Mugabe ordered that Kabila's corpse be flown to Harare to create the fiction that he was still alive in order to buy time to entrench the new regime headed by the late president's son, Joseph.

Zimbabwe's president may mourn but on the streets of Harare there was no great sorrow. It is not that Kabila was particularly despised in Zimbabwe, although there was resentment that its soldiers should be dying to keep a despot in power.

fields.headline: Couple's four-day journey to notoriety
fields.standfirst:
Sale of adoption story to newspaper led to Kilshaws becoming media villains.

Special report: Babies For Sale
fields.trailText: In four short days, Judith and Alan Kilshaw have gone from being an anonymous middle-aged couple bringing up their young sons in rural north Wales to media villains holding court from their hotel base.
fields.body:
In four short days, Judith and Alan Kilshaw have gone from being an anonymous middle-aged couple bringing up their young sons in rural north Wales to media villains holding court from their hotel base.

Their journey to notoriety began when the Sun published their story on Tuesday about how they had bought twin six-month-old babies Belinda and Kimberley on the internet.

The newspaper told the extraordinary story of how the couple had driven 2,000 miles across America with the babies as they sought a quick adoption.

Another couple, Richard and Vickie Allen, from California, who had earlier paid £4,000 for the babies from adoption broker Tina Johnson of the Caring Heart Agency, claimed the Kilshaws had kidnapped the girls. After caring for the babies for two months the Allens were tricked into handing them back to their natural mother, Tranda Wecker, and then after a 2,000-mile road trip and transatlantic flight, into the hands of the Kilshaws.

Only three weeks after they had returned to their seven-bedroom farmhouse in Buckley with the children, the Kilshaws embarked on a series of interviews to publicise their story. They happily posed with the babies for the cameras.

On breakfast television on Tuesday what was supposed to be a live sofa-bound link with the Allens quickly sunk into the spectacle of a transatlantic slanging match, with the interviewer aghast as the Kilshaws traded verbal blows with the Allens.

At all times, Judith and Alan Kilshaw were more than willing to speak and eager to explain and defend their actions. Brushing aside any criticism, they vociferously maintained they had done nothing wrong. Mr Kilshaw, a 45-year-old solicitor, encouraged other couples who were thinking of adopting children using the internet to contact them so they could advise other prospective parents of the the pitfalls.

But their attempt at openness appears to have been badly misjudged. It fanned the flames of public and political opinion, which were virtually unanimous in criticism of the pair. Both Jack Straw, the home secretary, and Tony Blair expressed disgust about the adoption arrangement.

Social services from Flintshire county council attempted, but failed, to contact the couple on Tuesday, when they were holed up in a suite at a luxury hotel near Chester, talking to journalists. By Wednesday, two senior social workers had visited the family and vowed to keep in regular contact with them.

'Milky Man'

The following day the Kilshaws' credibility took another knock, when it was reported that they were exploring the possibility of turning their story into a movie.

Another US couple stepped into the row and claimed they had been promised the girls by adoption broker Tina Johnson. Amy and Eddie White, from New York State, agreed a deal with Ms Johnson for the twins, but it collapsed when they failed to produce the money quickly enough.

Further scorn was heaped on the Kilshaws when it emerged that they had called in paranormal investigators after they and their children thought they saw, heard or felt unexplained phenomena in their farmhouse. One of the couple's two young sons talked of "the Milky Man", a ghostly apparition of an old man in a white milkman's coat.

Events took a dramatic turn on Thursday night when social services intervened and took the baby girls, by this time staying at the Beaufort Park Hotel in Mold, from their adoptive parents. As cameras flashed, the sleeping babies were removed in their car seats after a tense three-hour confrontation with the Kilshaws. They were then taken to a temporary foster family - their fourth set of carers in only six months of life - after an emergency protection order was granted under the 1989 Children Act.

Friends and relatives of the Kilshaws fled the hotel in tears, claiming the babies' removal was unjustified.

At the same time in America, Ms Wecker told CBS News that she really wanted the babies back. She claimed that she did not think the Kilshaws were fit parents.

Yesterday as Mrs Kilshaw, 47, sought to come to terms with the babies being seized by social workers, the couple indicated that they would appeal against the social services' decision.

She said: "Wherever we go in Britain we are going to be known as the baby snatchers - the internet people. I am going to have to live with this for the rest of my life. I feel as if I can't go home to Buckley because of finger pointing and name calling. With friends like that, who needs enemies? I wish I had never come back. I wish I had stayed in America. I could have sent for the boys."

Mr Kilshaw said it was "very regrettable" that the six-month-old sisters were now living with a fourth family, but blamed social workers for their latest upheaval. "That has increased by 25% thanks to the actions of social services. Social services have admitted they have been placed with temporary foster carers, which I presume means they will soon have another home."

But Mrs Kilshaw made it plain that they were going to fight the case all the way and added uncompromisingly: "If I don't win, I am going back to America to adopt two other children, and stick my fingers up to Britain."

fields.headline: Those Victorian values
fields.trailText: What is the legacy of the Victorian age to British church life and Christian belief? They  continue to make Christianity a townscape presence of soaring spires and stained glass windows.
fields.body:
What is the legacy of the Victorian age to British church life and Christian belief? Physically, Victorian Christianity is all around us. Many churches and chapels were either built or substantially re-ordered in the latter part of the 19th century. That gothic revival may be a nightmare in terms of crippling fabric costs, but even after being turned into second-hand furniture workshops and night clubs, Victorian churches continue to make Christianity a townscape presence of soaring spires and stained glass windows.

And we sing hymns, a practice virtually unheard of outside the established churches of England and Scotland until Queen Victoria's reign, and enjoy late 19th-century inventions like harvest festivals and the service of nine lessons and carols. In Anglican churches especially, robed choirs, clergy in vestments and candles on the altar are legacies of the Oxford movement, which restored medieval Catholicism's colour and ritual to the national church in the 1840s and 50s.

Ironically, Victoria herself opposed ritual and ornamentation in worship. Brought up a strict Evangelical and influenced by her husband's Lutheranism, she preferred the Church of Scotland's Presbyterian simplicity to the Church of England, which she complained was not a properly reformed and Protestant church. She insisted that clergy preaching before her should wear a plain black gown and vetoed candles or processions in services.

She almost certainly influenced the 1874 Public Worship Act, which curbed excesses of Anglican ritual and led to the trial of clergy indulging in "Romish practices".

The tendency to view the church in terms of organisation and bricks and mortar, rather than as a movement or tendency, owes much to Victorian values. So too does our obsession with head-counting and judging Christ- ianity by the numbers in church, a trend begun with the 1851 census of attendance.

That census found that roughly half the English population went to church on Sunday, with the Church of England making up half of the churchgoers. This is often taken to support the idea that the age was one of strong faith, but although Victorian churchgoing held steady and perhaps even in creased during her reign, late 19th-century Britain was assailed by a crisis of faith, the impact of which is still felt.

Three intellectual movements produced that crisis. Scientific discoveries, particularly around evolutionary biology, cast doubts on the literal- ness of the Genesis creation story, and the special role of humans as uniquely created in the image of God. The German-originated biblical criticism movement stripped away the Bible's infallibility, inspiring a liberal theology which replaced certainty with questions and ambiguities.

Finally, and perhaps most damaging, were the feelings by a growing number of earnest Victorians about a religion predicated on God's goodness in the face of so much manifest cruelty and suffering in the world.

In many ways, the Victorians wrestled with these questions more seriously than we do. It was only after agonised soul-searching that Darwin, George Eliot, and JS Mill gave up their childhood faith. A good many erstwhile Christians immersed themselves in esoteric cults. Others threw themselves into high-minded ethical secularism and humanism, often tied to socialism, though both these streams have dwindled to a trickle now.

Other creations of Victorian Christianity also seem to have largely evaporated. The nonconformist conscience has lost most of its moral and radical political force, and the liberal, muscular Christianity of Charles Kingsley and Thomas Hughes is also in pretty short supply in these days of feminist theology and post-Holocaust pessimism.

Perhaps the legacy of Victorian Christianity remains strongest in the ranks of the unchurched majority. There, its consolations and comforts still appeal, while its acknowledgement of doubts and difficulties has been largely forgotten. John Henry Newman's Lead Kindly Light, which, with its doubt-filled ambiguity, was Queen Victoria's favourite hymn, is hardly sung now. Yet the imperial echoes of, "The day, thou gavest, Lord is ended" remain at the top of the hymnological hit parade.

 Ian Bradley is senior lecturer in practical theology at St Andrews University. His books include Abide With Me: The World Of Victorian Hymns, and he will preach the sermon on Radio 4's Sunday worship at 8.10am tomorrow.

fields.headline: When 'crackdown' becomes climbdown
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The anti-crime bill published yesterday provides the most sweeping range of police powers since the then Tory home secretary Michael Howard's 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act that sought to outlaw rave music and ban convoys of new age travellers.
fields.body:
The anti-crime bill published yesterday provides the most sweeping range of police powers since the then Tory home secretary Michael Howard's 1994 Criminal Justice and Public Order Act that sought to outlaw rave music and ban convoys of new age travellers.

While no single measure alone sounds particularly draconian, taken together the accretion of more than 20 extra police powers adds up to a package that looks as much to do with the politics of the coming election as it does with "yob culture".

Mr Howard tried to pull this trick ahead of the 1997 general election. He published a crime (sentences) bill in 1996 in which he proposed to lock up all third-time burglars for a minimum of three years, and challenged Labour to vote against it to expose them as "soft on crime".

Jack Straw is trying similar tactics. The extra twist is that with a May election so close, if the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, chooses to oppose it, she could prevent it reaching the statute book in the time available. Labour could then go into the election claiming that it was the Tories that had voted down the very measures the police had asked for.

The problem for Mr Straw and Tony Blair is that they have forgotten the iron law of such initiatives: promised "crackdowns" soon turn into "climbdowns".

The process was visible yesterday. Labour complained that the Tories' 1996 legislation was different to what had been originally promised and "significantly flawed".

The same could be said of yesterday's bill. Its main measure, fixed penalty fines to tackle teenage "yob culture", had been promised by the prime minister on September 26. "There will be zero tolerance of yob culture," he announced to the Labour party conference, as a consultation document published that day made clear that 16- and 17-year-olds - the Euan Blairs of this world - would be fined £100 if found drunk in the street.

The small print of the legislation confirmed that this will not happen. Fixed penalty tickets are only going to apply to over 18s, and rather than £100 the fine is more likely to be nearer the current average fine for drunkeness, £37.

Last year the Home Office published another of its consultation documents - proposing to sweep away Victorian laws that criminalise gay sex and instead strengthening the law against child sex abuse. But there is no sign of those kind of measures in Mr Straw's bill.

fields.headline: Redstone curbs broadband plans
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Redstone Telecom yesterday scaled back its plans for the deployment of broadband services, reflecting the new pragmatism taking hold of the hi-tech sector.
fields.body:
Redstone Telecom yesterday scaled back its plans for the deployment of broadband services, reflecting the new pragmatism taking hold of the hi-tech sector.

The change in strategy was forced upon the business due to the effective closure of the debt markets to telecoms companies, many of which have borrowed heavily in the past two years. But investors welcomed the shift in gear and marked the company's shares almost 23% higher at 155p.

Redstone, which provides services to small and medium sized businesses, said it expected to move into profitability ahead of the 2002-3 financial year forecast by analysts.

The firm's revised plans will focus on rolling out DSL technology, which upgrades the old copper wire telephone network for broadband use, in a handful of cities including Nottingham and Cambridge. Its earlier plans for DSL had covered large parts of the country.

Rivals to Redstone have also dramatically scaled back their investment plans in broadband technologies because of the worsening climate, sending worrying signals to the government's plan for widespread high-speed internet access.

Telecoms regulator Oftel called an emergency meeting earlier this week to address the lack of interest in the first 25 BT local exchanges opened to competition.

Business development director Bob Cushing said Redstone had originally hoped to raise up to £150m to finance its plans for a national DSL service. As conditions worsened, however, Redstone's advisers warned the company against taking the debt on.

"The terms just aren't attractive, and as we don't urgently need the cash it didn't make sense," Mr Cushing said. "Investment decisions are very different to a year ago. We have a pretty good relationship with our major investors, who have told us we are doing the sensible thing."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Independent financial advisers on the net

fields.headline: Online deals to halt death of salesmen
fields.standfirst:
Independent financial advisers should seize the opportunities now available to reach potential clients via the net, believes Mark Loosmore

More net news
fields.trailText: Independent financial advisers should seize the opportunities now available to reach potential clients via the net, believes Mark Loosmore.
fields.body:
Despite ups and downs of the share prices of dot.com stocks consumer purchases via the net are on the increase, according to new data from the retail sector.

Booking holidays and cheap flights through the world wide web is commonplace and many cash-rich but time-poor shoppers delegate grocery buying to the supermarkets' websites and home delivery service.

So how is the traditional financial services sector responding. More than 53% of sales of life, pensions and investment products are sold by Independent Financial Advisers (IFAs). IFAs remain the main channel to market despite numerous threats and predictions of their imminent demise, based on the fear that technically literate, young professional people will turn to the internet in droves to buy investment products. This scenario has made some doom merchants predict that as many as 40% of all IFAs may go out of business in the next few years.

Yet fears for the demise of these salesmen are exaggerated. A survey commissioned by Focus Solutions reveals that only 10% of 25-35 year olds would avoid seeking financial advice face to face. Moreover, most of the people in this age group are high-earning professionals, of whom fewer than half have made any personal provision for retirement.

More than half have not prepared for any loss of income should they contract a serious illness which prevents them from working. Two thirds (65%) claim to have no life assurance policies while nearly 60% have no private medical insurance.

Significantly, the research identified that the majority of young professional people have mobile phones and internet access - what Focus terms "wuppies" (Young Wired Urban Professionals). Wuppies should be easy targets for those financial product providers and advisers who are prepared to invest time and effort to take advantage of the new virtual distribution channels such as the internet, digital TV and the new generation of mobile phones.

More than three-quarters of 25-35 year olds surveyed (76%) said that they would be more interested in taking out financial products on-line if it were quicker, easier and safer.

So the internet is the perfect solution for those too busy to spend time sitting down periodically with an IFA.It is clear that there is a place for financial advice which can be communicated to clients over the internet which serves to supplement the core activity. Our survey indicates that, like the majority of UK consumers, this target group of young, high-earning, professionals have reservations about buying financial products on-line without proper advice delivered in user-friendly language.

webTitle: The many homes of Michael Meacher

fields.headline: The many homes of Michael Meacher
fields.standfirst: Two years ago he condemned owners of second homes, now he has nine himself
fields.trailText: Two years ago he condemned owners of second homes, now he has nine himself
fields.body:
If he was a leading Tory it would be a wonderful rags-to-riches tale - from sitting on a freezing loo in a terraced cottage to a millionaire lifestyle garnered from shrewd property investments. But the man in question is an ardent Old Labour socialist - once described as Tony Benn's "vicar on earth"- who in the past condemned posh homes as status symbols.

He even lost a libel action against a journalist who said he wasn't quite the horny-handed son of toil he had claimed to be and branded him middle class. But Michael Meacher has come a long way from the days of that chilly toilet in Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, when his mother had to take in lodgers.

He and his second wife, Lucianne, are already well-known for owning a large £400,000 home in Wimbledon, south London; a £500,000 Cotswold stone retreat, complete with swimming pool, in Gloucestershire and the normal MP's pied-a-terre - worth around £150,000 - in Chadderton, part of his Oldham constituency.

But documents seen by the Guardian - and used as the basis for the Mark Thomas Comedy Product TV programme this week - reveal that the Meachers are embarking on a small but burgeoning property empire that has taken home ownership to a level that would cause many old socialists to turn in their graves.

Five tenants

According to documents deposited in the Land Registry and Companies House, the Meachers are the owners of at least nine properties - from third-floor luxury flats to more modest ground floor properties - many acquired after Mr Meacher became environment minister in Tony Blair's government. He has told friends that he now owns 12 properties, and he now takes rent from five tenants.

The family property portfolio is worth around £2m in total.

After the furore over "Two Jags"' Prescott, the epithet "12 homes Meacher" could become a fresh embarrassment for Labour - not helped by the fact that Mr Meacher does not want to come clean on exactly how many homes he owns. His entry in the register of members' interests says tersely "Flats let in London."

He declined to tell the Guardian how many properties he had acquired since he became environment minister in Tony Blair's government in 1997 but does admit to putting his surplus cash since his second marriage to Lucianne Sawyer into property investment.

His move neither breaks parliamentary rules - he is said to have consulted Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, to ensure he need not disclose more information - nor the ministerial code of conduct. His permanent secretary, Richard Mottram, is said to have "cleared him" of any"conflict of interest" in buying property while holding a job in a ministry that regulates housing.

But some might say Mr Meacher does appear to have a conflict of interest with himself. Less than 20 years ago he wrote a savage indictment of the huge Thatcherite divide in the property market in his book Socialism with a Human Face: the Political Economy in the 80s. He then railed against "elitism and materialism" which "are all too often gross and excessive." On housing, in particular, he condemned its use as "a status symbol and an object of conspicuous consumption."

Only two years ago at a Labour party conference fringe meeting he condemned second home owners for "robbing people of a home which is a basic right."

Now in a household that owns at least nine homes and runs three property companies, one from his home address, he was not keen to tell the Guardian where he stands now on the issue.

But many people would consider that some of his properties are examples of what he once called "conspicuous wealth."

His main home in Kingscliffe Gardens, south Wimbledon, is a very large, imposing and impressive property with a large garden and at least four bedrooms. His country retreat, Hilcot House in Ampney Crucis, near Cirencester, is three cottages knocked into one home with a large garden, swimming pool, spacious living room, kitchen and four bedrooms. He recently became embroiled in a row when he tried to buy some disused land near the home to build a tennis court. Neighbours objected because it meant felling some trees.

His Labour constituency home is a much more modest terraced house but he does not spend too much time there because of his ministerial engagements.

His property acquisitions started after he split up with his first wife, Molly, in 1987. He bought a modest flat in Quadrangle Court, Wimbledon,close to the town centre. This is now let by him.

His most controversial acquisition is in Cascades Court, Wimbledon, a new development of luxury flats worth around £300,000 each in the present market. This was purchased in 1998, a year after he became a minister. Flats in the block, which are mostly owned by Hong Kong expatriates and many registered abroad in offshore trusts, are said by local estate agents to be easily let at £700 a week.

Socialist roots

The development was at the centre of a row with Labour-controlled Merton council - who agreed to accept a £600,000 payment from the developers to relieve them of having to provide cheap, affordable housing, which is official Labour party policy. Mr Meacher said he was unaware of the deal when he bought the property, a deal which goes against government plans to try to provide more cheap homes for nurses and police officers in the capital.

His wife, Lucianne , lets out three flats in Putney, Balham and Wimbledon Common. They are all owned by companies where she holds directorships.

Mr Meacher may not, however, have lost entirely his touch with his socialist roots. He has recently become a director of a charity set up by his wife to help house the homeless. But it is unlikely that any of the applicants will be housed in Cascades Court.

webTitle: We don't like to be beside the seaside

fields.headline: We don't like to be beside the seaside
fields.standfirst: Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: Tourism and travel are at record levels, but domestic tourism is still losing out to foreign destinations, and coastal resorts are failing to grab their share of the bonanza, according to a survey by the English tourism council.
fields.body:
Tourism and travel are at record levels, but domestic tourism is still losing out to foreign destinations, and coastal resorts are failing to grab their share of the bonanza, according to a survey by the English tourism council.

In the last decade, tourism in England grew by 59% and visitors spent a fifth more than in the previous 10 years. However, an increase of 108% in the number of people travelling abroad dwarfs the number who took their holidays in the UK - as does their spending, which leapt by almost 100% in the same period.

The report, Perspectives on English Tourism, concluded that a strong economy, higher disposable incomes, social mobility and changing attitudes to travel were all factors contributing to the upward trend.

It said: "England's overseas competitors are clearly receiving more of the extra discretionary money now available to consumers."

A spokesman for the tourism council said: "A lot of this is about increasing discretionary income. But we are a more mobile population, and short breaks, in particular to cities, are proving popular."

The report also said: "In the past 10 years, locations favoured for domestic trips have changed, with trips to cities and towns overtaking the seaside and countryside as most popular destinations."

The tourism council voiced concerns yesterday at trends showing that despite cashing in on a proportion of the new money, the more traditional holiday destinations, such as seaside resorts, were continuing to lose out.

"The idea that everyone is flocking abroad isn't quite right, and more money is going into coastal resorts, but they should be taking a bigger slice of the cake," the spokesman said.

The survey found that stays of eight or more nights had fallen from 6.4m in 1990 to 5.5m in 1999 - a fall of 14%. As more and more people chose to take their annual holiday at resorts abroad, the long-stay holidaymakers at England's resorts were fast declining.

At the same time, the number of domestic short breaks has been growing - but visitors are not being drawn to the coast. Stays of between one and three nights grew by 61% to just under 35m between 1990 and 1999, generating just under £35m.

A big increase in the number of people taking day trips has also failed to bolster seaside resorts, historically a first choice for day trippers.

fields.headline: Loose connections as top ISPs fail to deliver
fields.standfirst:
The drive to sign up new customers may be taking preference over providing the necessary technical hardware, reports John Crace

More net news
fields.trailText: The drive to sign up new customers may be taking preference over providing the necessary technical hardware, reports John Crace.
fields.body:
Since the beginning of the year a growing number of people have reported difficulties connecting to the internet and sending and receiving email. And time and again, it was the same three internet service providers (ISPs) - BTinternet, AOL and Freeserve - that were the problem.

In itself, this may not be a surprise; these three ISPs are the market leaders, according to the most recent figures released by industry analysts MMXI. Freeserve has a media reach of 30% of the total UK internet population, BTinternet 15.4% and AOL 15.3%, so you could argue that the most complaints would come from these companies.

But the more cynical might wonder whether the problems might also have something to do with the fact that these three companies might be spending more time and effort signing up new customers than in ensuring they had the technical hardware to deliver the service. After all, the ISPs that often offer the best availability and connection speed are those that are the least successful in attracting new business.

Only last week BT announced that it had signed up more than 1m customers to its Together packages since December. Angus Porter, managing director of BT's consumer division, said: "Take-up of the BT Together packages has far exceeded our expectations." Which could be taken to mean, "we have been slightly caught on the hop". Not so, says Stephen Brown, BT's head of marketing. "We have a brand to protect and we try to ensure that we have the capacity to deliver before we launch a service. That is why we have taken our time before announcing our own unmetered internet service in response to AOL's which launched in November."

BT's new internet package, which will be identical to AOL's in offering unlimited surftime for a fixed subscription of £14.99 per month, will be launched towards the end of this month - at about the same time that Freeserve launches its unmetered AnyTime service which iwill cost £12.99 a month. At present, BT offers unmetered access at weekends and weekdays after 6pm for £9.99 per month, while Freeserve has recently upped its charges for a similar package from £6.99 to £8.99. Both packages will be available after the introduction of the unlimited surftime deals.

Even so, Mr Brown admits there were problems with BT's internet service for a couple of weeks in October. "We had just launched a major subscription drive and at the same time many of our customers were switching from BT Click to BTinternet," he says. On the subject of the more recent problems he is less forthcoming, other than to point to the fact that BT was the only major ISP to be awarded a five-star rating by Net-Basics, an independent research group, and to acknowledge that every ISP has problems at times.

But the reader who complained that he had been unable to connect to BTinternet for a 24-hour stretch won't be surprised by the latest listings in Internet Magazine. Each month the magazine's technical editor, David Wildy, tests each dial-up ISP for availability and speed of connection and in the space of two months BT has fallen from 12th to 97th. In the same period Freeserve has fallen from 16th to 101st. AOL has declined to take part in the independent monthly tests.

"There are problems with demand outstripping supply," says Mr Wildy, "Especially when ISPs launch new offers. The problem is that the telephone system was designed for analog; no one ever imagined that the copper wires would be used to carry digital data. There isn't the bandwidth in the pipes to cope at peak times and until the system is upgraded the service will be less than perfect."

This is a theme close to the heart of Matt Peacock, AOL's UK director of corporate communications. He claims that AOL had to fight BT tooth and nail through the regulators in order to be allowed to use its Friaco (Flat Rate Internet Access Call Origination) on the BT system. "Some 85% of all households are connected to BT copper," he says, "And BT was reluctant to make Friaco available to its customers as it was making a great deal of money out of its current pricing structure."

He adds: "We have investigated all customer complaints about connectivity and very few relate to problems with our servers. Until BT replaces the wiring in local and regional exchanges, there's not much more we can do."

BT is upgrading the exchanges, but predictably is unwilling to carry the can for AOL. "I don't want to get into a slanging match," says Mr Brown, "But the cabling isn't the main issue. The fact is that all ISPs have problems delivering a perfect service from time to time." And this is the crux of it. Despite all the hype about connectivity, it is still a less than perfect service. Even the top-ranking ISPs only tend to get an availability of just over 95% throughout the year. Or put another way, for every 20 times you log on you are likely to fail to get connected once. If you had these problems with your phone line - or any other appliance for that matter - you'd go berserk. But with the internet you just have to put up with it. For now at least.

So what's the answer? If you don't mind constantly changing your email address you can register with the ISP that tops Internet Magazine's monthly ratings. But beware. If too many of you switch at the same time you will overload the system and end up with a service as bad as the one you've currently got.

This week RedHotAnt.com shut down its unmetered internet access service. So many people signed up for its £130-a-year deal it couldn't cope with demand. This leaves users an estimated £30,000 to £60,000 out of pocket as they are unlikely to get refunds.

webTitle: Diana butler bailed in royal wedding gift theft inquiry

fields.headline: Diana butler bailed in royal wedding gift theft inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The late Princess of Wales's butler, Paul Burrell, was held for more than 16 hours by police investigating the disappearance of a wedding present.
fields.body:
The late Princess of Wales's butler, Paul Burrell, was held for more than 16 hours by police investigating the disappearance of a wedding present.

The jewel-encrusted replica of an Arabian sailing dhow, given to the prince and princess by the Emir of Bahrain in 1981, is alleged to have been put up for sale at a London art dealer's showroom.

Mr Burrell, 42, who worked for the princess for 10 years until her death in 1997, is the second royal employee to have been questioned in the three-month Metropolitan police inquiry. He was released on bail.

In November Princess Margaret's butler, Harold Brown, who also worked for a time for the Prince and Princess of Wales during their marriage, was arrested and later released on bail.

In 1981 the item was said to be valued at £500,000 but recently it has been estimated at twice that amount. A similar object was removed from display by the jewellers Spink and Son last autumn.

Police conducted a 12-hour search on Wednesday of Mr Burrell's cottage near Chester, where he lives with his wife, Maria, the princess's former dresser, and two sons. He was subsequently taken to Runcorn police station for questioning. He was released yesterday lunchtime.

webTitle: Equitable clients quit at four times pre-crisis levels

fields.headline: Equitable clients quit at four times pre-crisis levels
fields.trailText: Equitable Life, the stricken mutual insurer, yesterday revealed that the number of customers cashing in their policies has jumped to four times pre-crisis levels.
fields.body:
Equitable Life, the stricken mutual insurer, yesterday revealed that the number of customers cashing in their policies has jumped to four times pre-crisis levels.

The level of surrender requests has risen to £50m a week, Equitable admitted, compared with an average of £12m a week during the first 11 months of 2000 - even though any members who exit are hit by a 10% penalty.

Equitable, however, said the £240m outflow so far is less than 1% of its funds under management. It added that only 3,558 of its 450,000 individual policyholders had cashed in their policies, while only two of its 6,000 company schemes had transferred their money. "Policy surrenders are not significant in relation to the total £26bn with-profits fund," it said.

Equitable refused to disclose the number of policyholders who have stopped making contributions but left their policies on ice at the insurer. These are believed to include most company schemes and a significant proportion of individual policyholders.

The prospect of further payout reductions also grew yesterday after Equitable revealed that its with-profits fund achieved a total return last year of just 2.7%, compared to 16% in 1999.

It said the performance compared well with the 8% fall in the FTSE 100 index during the year. However, Standard Life, which has a financial year-end of November 15, said its with-profits fund had achieved a total return of 7.1% over the year, while Scottish Life said it achieved around 3% to the December 31 year's end.

Chief executive Chris Headdon rejected criticism of the £8m due to be paid out in bonuses to Equitable staff this year. "The value of the businesses being sold is in the staff working in those businesses. We must continue to retain and motivate our staff... and believe a bonus is appropriate."

Equitable Life confirmed its continuing talks with a handful of buyers for parts of the business - thought to include GE Capital and Aegon, with a deal believed to be imminent. It is also discussing ways to cap its liabilities to guaranteed policyholders, which could result in the 10% penalty being reduced or abandoned.

A BBC Radio 4 investigation into the Equitable affair, to be broadcast tomorrow, will reveal that emergency talks between the Treasury, the Bank of England and the financial services authority were held days before the shock closure of Equitable. The talks were called by the tri-partite standing committee, which is only called to discuss events which could threaten the financial stability of Britain.

The report also reveals that the number of policyholders with guarantees, who are behind the current crisis, is far higher than first thought.

fields.headline: M&S sales in tatters
fields.standfirst: Now men desert the clothing racks to wreck chairman's prediction of a 'wonderful Christmas'
fields.trailText: Now men desert the clothing racks to wreck chairman's prediction of a 'wonderful Christmas'.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is set to unveil a dismal set of Christmas trading figures which will mark it out as the worst performing high street chain for the third year running.

Tuesday's sales figures are expected to show a substantial decline in clothing sales and will be a severe embarrassment to the chairman, Luc Vandevelde, two months after he predicted M&S would have a "wonderful Christmas".

Analysts believe the group's total sales will be down around 3% on a like-for-like basis, which excludes the impact of new store space.

But the performance of individual departments has varied widely. M&S's foodhalls and homeware departments are understood to have performed well, but their advances have been more than wiped out by a further deterioration in the vital fashion departments.

Menswear sales are believed to have performed worst, and there is speculation that sales in the 16 weeks to mid-January could be down by up to 15%. Women's and children's wear are said to be 5-10% lower.

The group's performance will be in sharp contrast to its nearest rivals. Next's sales climbed 6% in the 19 weeks to December 24, while House of Fraser reported a 6% increase in like-for-like sales in the 23 weeks to January 6.

Even Arcadia - which operates mid-market brands such as Wallis, Burton and Dorothy Perkins and has also done miserably in the last couple of years - posted a better performance. This week it said sales had risen 4.3% in the 20 weeks to January 13.

The only good news expected next week is an indication that margins improved because it did not discount goods before Christmas.

The M&S figures are likely to prompt renewed criticism of senior management and questions about whether the new brooms drafted in to turn around the company are up to the job.

Two of the key appointees - Mr Vandevelde and marketing director Alan McWalter - have now been in their jobs for a year, and the City had expected to see real signs of improvement by now.

Mr Vandevelde, who spent last week checking out the company's Spanish operation, said a year ago that he needed two years to return M&S to growth. He is now halfway through that term with no sign of a recovery.

Analysts are also unsure of the credentials of Roger Holmes, the former Comet executive who has just joined as chief operating officer.

Yesterday the shares added 0.5p to 199.5p, but analysts regard them as highly vulnerable. Merrill Lynch recently picked M&S as its "bear" stock in the general retail sector for this year. "The company is failing to offer price, style or quality in clothing," the broker said in a recent note.

Analysts at Goldman Sachs downgraded earnings forecasts to £473m ahead of next week's statement, saying it was "unnecessary to wait".

The current consensus is profits of £485m - up from £417m last year, but still less than half 1998 levels, when the group made £1.2bn.

fields.headline: Baird buyout in danger
fields.trailText: The management buyout of the William Baird textile group is close to collapse after new concerns about the cost of losing Marks & Spencer's business.
fields.body:
The management buyout of the William Baird textile group is close to collapse after new concerns about the cost of losing Marks & Spencer's business.

M&S ditched Baird in 1999 after a 30-year relationship. Baird, which also owns brands such as Windsmoor and Planet, was forced to set aside £103m to cover resulting costs and is pursuing M&S through the courts in a £54m compensation claim.

Now it is understood the provision may not be enough, and Alchemy, the venture capital group backing the buyout, seem to have taken fright.

The deal, based on an offer of 75p a share, was due to go unconditional yesterday. Barid - the vehicle set up to buy Baird - had only 88% shareholder acceptance and was expected to ask for an extension.

Instead, Barid said it was prepared to pull out of the deal on the basis of "certain information" which it said entitled it to lapse the offer. Baird's advisers appealed to Barid to reconsider. The Takeover Panel was called in and gave permission for an extra fortnight's grace to iron out the problems.

Neither side has detailed Barid's concerns, but Baird rushed out a trading statement yesterday to show there were no financial black holes in the group. It said sales of some brands were ahead 18% in December and that the firm's debts of £19m were likely to be reduced by disposals.

It also said the £103m M&S provision was being "reviewed", but that only a "modest increase was expected". The increase is understood to be below £10m.

Barid has bought 29% of Baird's shares and would be left nursing a substantial loss on its investment if it pulled out of the deal.
