webTitle: Sleepy resort where developers might dispel the gloom

fields.headline: Sleepy resort where developers might dispel the gloom
fields.standfirst: Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: The sleepy seaside town of Bridlington, nestled in a sweeping Yorkshire bay between Whitby and Scarborough, is hell bent on becoming the new Brighton, Bournemouth or Blackpool.
fields.body:
The sleepy seaside town of Bridlington, nestled in a sweeping Yorkshire bay between Whitby and Scarborough, is hell bent on becoming the new Brighton, Bournemouth or Blackpool.

It has come up with an ambitious £60m regeneration plan to wake from its slumbers and become England's premier conference venue.

If the project - spearheaded by East Riding county council - goes ahead, it will be the single largest development of its kind on the east coast of England.

Plans include a shimmering new conference centre which could attract thousands of delegates to meet, talk and gaze over the breezy North sea.

A 500-berth marina would pull in big-spending boat owners, and new commercial, leisure and residential developments would also help to revive the resort's fortunes.

Bridlington is typical of an English seaside town in winter with its closed cafes and vacant, tacky, amusement arcades. A third of the town's population is over 60 - a higher proportion than anywhere else in England. Pensioners shuffle up and down the otherwise empty promenades and the dull drizzle that hangs over the bare beaches creates an overwhelming aura of a place whose best days have long since passed. It is begging for a facelift.

The Bridlington regeneration partnership, which is managing the plan, includes local interests ranging from the Royal Yorkshire Yacht Club to the Humber Chamber of Commerce.

A total of £14m has been set aside from the council's capital budget, and the remainder of the funds are expected to come from European grants and private sector investment. Plans have been drawn up, business proposals assessed, and the local population consulted.

However, the Bridlington Protection Group is challenging the viability of the development, and warns of the negative impact on the make-up of the local community, the marine environment and existing businesses.

The group claims a survey conducted on its behalf found only 4.3% of local people in favour of the project. The planned marina development is, it says, out of proportion to the size of the town. New properties would change the face of the harbour, ruin views and destroy the town's character. There is a danger of Bridlington's heritage being lost and preservation being sacrificed in the name of progress.

Opponents also fear that the social make-up of the area will be altered as the affluent, upwardly mobile, move in. Property prices will rise and the citizens of Leeds and Bradford, who traditionally retire to "Brid", will have to look for their bungalows elsewhere.

John Hunter, 29, has lived in the town all his life. The family restaurant he runs has a panoramic view of the stretch of harbour targeted for redevelopment, and he recognises that his business could be changed for ever if the plans go ahead.

"Some local businesses will be affected, including my own, but at some point you have to put your own selfish interests aside in the interests of the town."

His restaurant is empty but his enthusiasm for the future fills the room. "I'm all for it. It will bring money in and a lot of investment. So what if the place changes?

"I love it here but that doesn't mean things must always stay the same. It's visitors mainly, and old people who are afraid of change, who are objecting. I just can't see why they are so sceptical. We will be the envy of other resorts if this goes ahead."

The council claims the development can only be good for the town and that it will be a catalyst for wider regeneration, bringing jobs and increasing property values.

Simon Taylor, of the Yorkshire Marina partnership, said: "There are a small number of people with concerns and we are taking these on board. But this project is about reversing a decline."

With government approval, the development could be completed by 2004.

webTitle: Top people for top jobs in £800m float

fields.headline: Top people for top jobs in £800m float
fields.trailText: Michael Page, the professional recruitment company, is planning a return to the London Stock Exchange this spring through an £800m flotation.
fields.body:
Michael Page, the professional recruitment company, is planning a return to the London Stock Exchange this spring through an £800m flotation.

Spherion Corporation, a Florida-based temporary-staffing specialist which acquired Page for £330m four years ago, announced the sale yesterday as it warned of its own trading problems in the US and its need to cut debts.

Terry Benson, who has been chief executive of Page since 1990 and watched the company's client list grow to include every FTSE 100 company, believes investors will be comforted by the fact that the senior management team remains unchanged from its former days as a quoted British firm,

"All the top people here have been in the [recruitment] business for a dozen years," he said. "They have seen the good and bad times and I think we coped with the recession pretty well."

Investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston, which was brought in by Spherion last year to explore options for the British business, will begin marketing the new issue to institutions at the end of January. It remains unclear whether retail investors will be invited to participate in the offer.

Last night analysts welcomed the company's return to the London market. "Those people with memories will remember it fondly as a strong business with a very good record," Mark Shepperd, support services analyst with UBS Warburg, said.

Spherion is said to have largely failed to integrate Page, preferring instead to focus on areas such as training and temporary workers in the US rather than professional recruitment.

Page was founded in 1976 and now employs 2,600 in 90 offices worldwide.

Its principle market is the UK, followed by France, Australia and the Netherlands.

It recruits for sectors including accountancy, financial services, banking, sales, legal and marketing. The company, which first joined the stock market in 1988, recorded operating profits of £80m in the last financial year, on the back of £400m turnover. Both profits and turnover are understood to have doubled over the past three years.

This year Page expects to open an office in Tokyo and there are early plans to have a presence in Scandinavia, although the US market remains largely untapped by the company.

In the US, Spherion said it would use the cash raised by the flotation of Page to buy back stock and reduce its debts.

The group said that its earnings were likely to come in below forecasts, due to lower-than-expected revenues and weaker operating margins during the last three months of the year.

webTitle: Notebook: Intervene - or kiss goodbye to industry

fields.headline: Intervene - or kiss goodbye to industry
fields.standfirst: Steel imports force the issue
fields.trailText: Steel imports force the issue.
fields.body:
Sir Brian Moffat, chairman and acting chief executive of Corus, is unlikely to have a restful weekend. Perhaps as early as next week, he will tell us how he plans to stop the Anglo-Dutch steel group haemorrhaging losses that, in Britain alone, have probably grown to £500m over the last year.

Treading a political, as well as financial, tightrope, he faces two ineluctable variables: the future course of sterling against both the euro and dollar; and UK demand for steel as our domestic manufacturing base continues to shrink. Both are completely out of his control, not least because none of us knows if or when Britain might join the single currency.

It is commonly understood that a good portion of Corus's recent losses stem from the strength of the pound against the euro. So why, the unions are frantically asking, is Sir Brian considering the closure of Llanwern, the steel mill near Newport, Gwent, and perhaps also large chunks of Lackenby on Tees-side, when the predicted recovery of the euro should reverse the trend in profitability. Why not close IJmuiden, the group's main Dutch plant on the North Sea coast, instead - especially when productivity in Britain has risen so remarkably over the past decade: from 348 tonnes per employee per year in 1989 to 571?

But that, Sir Brian will argue, misses a crucial point, namely that over the same period steel consumption in Britain has fallen 10%, while US demand has risen 28% and Germany's is up 10%. What is more, in Britain much of the demand has been satisfied by intermediate or finished goods imported from overseas. Recent figures show that steel imports made up 49% of the British market in 2000 compared with 44% in 1999 and 29% in 1989.

In the same period, the old British Steel has seen exports increase as a share of production from 30% to 50% - a rise that testifies to the shrinkage of its home market and, given sterling's strength, the impact on its margins.

With UK-based car groups planning to cut the British content of their output from 80% to 50% at best, Sir Brian's graphs on future demand from UK manufacturing must look very bleak.

Politically, the fallout will be enormous, especially in Wales where a campaign to save Llanwern and 4500 jobs has been launched by Team Wales - politicians, industry, including the WDA development agency, and unions. Manufacturing in Britain accounts for 15% of GDP; in Wales it is nearly twice as high. If Llanwern goes it is assumed Labour will pay the electoral price through heavy losses to Plaid Cymru, the nationalist party, in May.

So will the government intervene? Certainly the Welsh lobbying has been enormous compared with hardly a shout from the north-east of England. Stephen Byers, industry secretary, and Rhodri Morgan, first minister of the national assembly for Wales, are trying to put together a package of measures worth at most £20m to stay Sir Brian's hand on the axe. The outcome remains unclear but he is bound to cut out large swaths of Corus's British operations, especially in Wales, to bring production and sales back into kilter and reboot shareholder value.

The real question for the government is not whether it can jig together a package that will get Brussels' approval, but the role it foresees for manufacturing in Britain. It has to decide whether the country that began the industrial revolution is the first to kiss it goodbye. Sir Brian's plan will help ministers focus on that emotive issue.

Muppetry

There was a small prick to the traditional Friday afternoon torpor in the Square Mile yesterday when news spread that a "small British investment bank" is ready to buy the 50% stake in formula one held by Germany's EM.TV, thus scuppering the rescue of EM which media group Kirch is desperately trying to hold together.

Word had it that a representative of the unnamed British bank met EM's supervisory board chief, Nickolaus Becker, in Geneva on Thursday, offering to pay around £400m for the stake - an offer EM was minded to accept, despite having paid the racy Bernie Ecclestone almost £1.2bn for the holding last year.

This particular business of sport makes the head spin. As one banker who has worked on formula one's fiendishly complicated finances, commented yesterday: "Anyone who thinks they can buy it and rip off Ecclestone in the process is a complete muppet."

webTitle: Profits leap as plans for Cardiff pubs advance

fields.headline: Profits leap as plans for Cardiff pubs advance
fields.trailText: The Old Monk Company is accelerating plans to develop two huge pubs in Cardiff aimed at quenching the thirst of thousands of football fans visiting the city's Millennium Stadium.
fields.body:
The Old Monk Company is accelerating plans to develop two huge pubs in Cardiff aimed at quenching the thirst of thousands of football fans visiting the city's Millennium Stadium.

The two units will cost a total of £2.6m to build, and will have a combined capacity of 2,300.

They are due to open next month - in time to benefit from the Worthington Cup final, the FA Cup final, divisional promotion play-offs and the Six Nations rugby matches.

Chairman Gerry Martin said the new outlets would be popular even when few football fans were in town: "Friday and Saturday nights will be massively busy - we've got 2am licences and the Walkabout, which will be our main rival nearby, shuts at 11pm."

Mr Martin is the brother of Tim Martin, the founder of the pub chain JD Wetherspoon.

The company yesterday announced a 20% jump in half-year pretax profits to £391,000. Shares edged up 1.5p to 75p.

fields.headline: Threat of Clinton charges lifted
fields.standfirst: Clean slate President strikes immunity deal
fields.trailText: The dark legal shadow that hung over the eight years of the Clinton administration finally lifted on his last day in office yesterday when the outgoing president struck an immunity deal with the special investigator examining his conduct in the White House.
fields.body:
The dark legal shadow that hung over the eight years of the Clinton administration finally lifted on his last day in office yesterday when the outgoing president struck an immunity deal with the special investigator examining his conduct in the White House.

In return for Mr Clinton's admission that he lied under oath about his affair with Monica Lewinsky, the independent counsel, Robert Ray, agreed to end his investigation and not bring charges against Mr Clinton after he leaves office today. Mr Clinton, however, had his law licence suspended for five years by the Arkansas Bar Association and was fined $25,000.

In his statement, Mr Clinton said: "I tried to walk a fine line between acting lawfully and testifying falsely but I now recognise that I did not fully accomplish this goal and that certain of my responses to questions about Ms Lewinsky were false."

Moments later, Mr Ray told journalists: "The nation's interests have been served and therefore I decline prosecution. This matter is now concluded. May history and the American people judge that it has been concluded justly."

However, the Lewinsky affair had one more twist in store yesterday, when it emerged that Linda Tripp had been fired from her public relations job at the Pentagon. Ms Tripp's tape-recordings of conversations with Ms Lewinsky helped corner Mr Clinton, leading to his impeachment. Her lawyers called her dismissal "vindictive and mean-spirited", but Jake Siewert, the White House spokesman, said all political appointees who had not resigned by the change of administration had had their employment terminated.

Mr Siewert said that Mr Clinton was "upbeat about his future and looking forward to putting this behind him, returning to New York and resuming his duties as a citizen of the United States".

In his statement, Mr Clinton attempted to close the door once and for all on the scandal. "I have apologised for my conduct and I have done my best to atone for it with my family, my administration and the American people," the president said, in a written text read by Mr Siewert.

"I have paid a high price for it which I accept because it caused so much pain to so many people. I hope my actions today will help bring closure and finality to these matters."

Yesterday's deal means Mr Clinton will be able to enjoy his last few hours in the White House today without the threat of imminent prosecution, after eight years of almost constant scrutiny. The $60m rolling investigation of the president by the office of the independent counsel began soon after his 1993 inauguration with an inquiry into an Arkansas real estate deal known as Whitewater, which dated back to Mr Clinton's days as state governor. Hillary Clinton was also involved in the Whitewater affair, and the deal allows her to begin her career as senator for New York with a clean slate.

The independent counsel investigation into Whitewater mutated into an inquiry into the Clintons' handling of the White House travel office, of FBI files on political opponents, and finally - under Kenneth Starr - it became an inquisition into Mr Clinton's affair with Ms Lewinsky, which led to his impeachment in 1998.

The president survived a trial in the Senate and spent the final two years of his tenure trying to salvage his place in history.

webTitle: 4m acres of countryside still forbidden to ramblers

fields.headline: Landowners still have time on their side
fields.standfirst:
70 years on and 4m acres are still forbidden

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: 70 years on and 4m acres are still forbidden.
fields.body:
High in the snow-topped hills of northern England, where the grouse are cackling amid the knee-deep heather, a 5ft fence abruptly divides open moorland from the thicker vegetation of the sporting estate. Down the valley from the Trough of Bowland, a designated area of outstanding natural beauty, walkers loiter by a stream in the midday sun near prominent "private" signs which protect the preserve of the rich and powerful beyond the wire. They could venture across at their peril.

Nearby, in the village at the heart of the Duke of Westminster's 19,500-acre Abbeystead estate, in north Lancashire, the tweeded set are carrying the feathered pickings from the morning's shoot. Pheasants, dead and alive, seem to be everywhere - darting over hedges and swooping uneasily over the road, when they are not being blasted by the shotgun. But on a fine winter's day, the ramblers are outnumbering the shooters, although the former have learned to keep a safe distance from the latter.

Soon these competing interests could collide. In a few days' time new legislation will, in theory, open up 4m previously forbidden acres of mountain, moor, heath, down and common land in England and Wales - finally completing the unfinished business of the 1949 National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act. While underpinning 140,000 miles of footpaths, it left a huge question mark hanging over access to the country's spectacular wilderness areas. Under pressure from the aristos and the country lobby, postwar ministers shied away from a blanket "right to roam" in favour of voluntary agreements with landowners like the Duke of Westminster, one of Britain's richest men. In practice, this has meant much of England and Wales remains out of bounds - leaving dedicated walkers, like former teacher Ian Brodie, with a bitterness about promises never fulfilled.

As a leading campaigner for more access to Abbeystead and the surrounding Forest of Bowland since the 60s, he has seen small parts of the estate opened to ramblers while huge tracts remain forbidden. Walking up to the boundary fence by the Trough, past the odd "private" sign, Mr Brodie marvels at the wildlife on offer alongside the red grouse - hen harriers, merlins, peregrine falcons - before lamenting the restrictions. "Everything you are looking at is barred to the public," he fumes before turning to a landowner who could be public enemy number one. Remarkably, he is not. "In some ways it is unfair to focus on the duke because the problem is much wider. It's just that he's got more, but there's no doubt this is a well-kept and well-managed estate."

But while Mr Brodie is waiting for the "private" signs to disappear and the fences to come down, Rod Banks, who oversees Abbeystead and its 30 staff as the duke's agent, is proceeding with caution. While the Countryside and Rights of Way Act officially comes into force on January 30, the government's countryside agency has to re-map much of the 4m acres showing strictly defined "right to roam" areas - because parts of the countryside, such as farmland, will still be barred. The task could take over three years - prompting Mr Brodie, the Ramblers' Association and the Open Spaces Society, to complain of delaying tactics.

They would like to see the government grant "fast track access" to common land and places over 600 sq metres - areas already shown on existing maps. In addition, they see no reason why the countryside cannot be opened up on a region-by-region basis, once particular zones have been mapped.

The Duke of Westminster's Grosvenor company insisted yesterday it could not implement the legislation "until the appropriate infrastructure is in place  the present situation is confused and not ideal."

Rod Banks takes pride in the 11 miles of "concessionary" paths on Abbeystead, introduced after an access agreement with the county council, as well as 28 miles of statutory rights of way. "We are offering quality fell walking already," he says.

Preparing Abbeystead for the new legislation could prove onerous, nevertheless, and take three to five years. While the "private" signs would come down, notices would have to be erected pointing out restrictions in the new act - no fires, camping, organised games, for instance. Most of the fencing would remain to indicate the estate boundary.

Knowing he probably has time on his side, Mr Banks is philosophical, echoing the views of a senior Grosvenor director that his lord and master is "a lot more giving than people make out  he wants to do right." He adds: "Our line has always been  that as long as we know where people are [on the estate] - purely for safety reasons - we can undertake our day-to-day activity and we are happy."

This strikes at the heart of the right to roam movement, which held "mass trespasses" in the 30s in the battle to open up land for the workers; almost 70 years' ago, six people were jailed for leading a trespass on Kinder Scout, in the Peak District, provoking a national outcry. Passions still run high today. Mr Brodie, and the earlier activists, portray responsible roaming across God's open countryside as an inalienable human right.

A few miles across the Pennines, Alan Gaskell, a veteran activist with the Ramblers' Association, is waiting to see a life's ambition fulfilled. "Just after the war I attended these [access] rallies and thought 'this is one of the main freedoms we all want'," he says. "I am 78 and time is running out and all I want to do is walk responsibly through the countryside." With luck, time might be on his side. Ministers are planning to reinforce their "freedom to roam" commitment over the next few days with a promise that delays over mapping will be kept to a minimum.

Sooner, rather than later, Ian Brodie, Alan Gaskell, and other veterans could be plodding over those forbidden acres from Abbeystead to the out-of-bounds Bronte moors of West Yorkshire and the prohibited South Downs of Sussex, where 80% of land is not legally accessible.

webTitle: More clout for police in tackling murderers and drunken yobs

fields.headline: More clout for police in tackling murderers and drunken yobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday described his flagship criminal justice and police bill as a package of measures to increase police powers to tackle crime and disorder - from yobbish behaviour to rape and murder.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday described his flagship criminal justice and police bill as a package of measures to increase police powers to tackle crime and disorder - from yobbish behaviour to rape and murder.

The bill is expected to be introduced in the Commons at the end of the month, and parts could make it to the statute book before a May general election.

Its main provisions include:

'Yob culture'

Fixed penalty fines: to deal with "drunken and anti-social yobs". Implements Tony Blair's promise that it is "time to end yob culture" made in his party conference speech last September. But the Home Office has been forced to drop its plans to issue the fines to 16- and 17-year- olds, and they will now apply only to over 18s.

The range of offences includes, as expected, drunk and disorderly behaviour, being drunk and incapable, using threatening words, and buying alcohol for someone under age.

But plans to issue them for littering and dog fouling have been dropped. Instead they cover damaging property, throwing fireworks, making hoax 999 calls and throwing missiles on a railway. The bill includes fines for wasting police time.

No figure is in the bill as to how much the fixed penalty fine will be: £100 was floated last September. Offenders will be given the choice of paying the fine or going to court.

The amount will be no more than "half the amount of the maximum fine for the offence", says the bill.

Disorderly pubs and clubs: can be closed for up to 24 hours by police order. Expected to apply to 800-1,000 premises a year.

Unlicensed "drinking dens": more powers to close them, particularly those that are a focus for city centre crime at night.

Underage drinkers: Tougher clampdown, including legalising the use of children for undercover "sting" operations by off licenses and publicans. Legal duty on bar staff to ask for proof of age.

Drinking in public places: Banned in declared "dry zones". Police will have power of arrest and can confiscate alcohol. Family picnic sites exempted.

Drunks at the bar: All bar staff get legal power to refuse to serve drunks.

Anti-social antics

Child curfews: power to raise the age limit from 10 to 15 years for those banned from being out in specific area after 9pm. This power appeared in 1998 act but has not been used.

New legislation will enable police, in addition to the local authority, to apply to the court for a curfew order. The curfew can last up to 90 days.

Anti-social behaviour orders: explanatory notes with the bill disclose the extent of official dismay at the failure of this initiative, introduced in the 1998 legislation. The Home Office had hoped that 5,000 orders a year would be issued, but applications are running at only 100 a year.

Bill extends police power to provide witness protection from intimidation and fear of violence, to encourage more applications. For the first time such powers are to be used in civil cases.

Police powers

Seizure: power to overturn the "Bramley judgment", which ruled that Derbyshire police had wrongly seized a computer hard disk containing confidential correspondence between a suspect and his solicitor. The bill allows police to seize such "inextricably linked" material.

Kerb crawlers: police given new power of arrest to take suspect to police station and to obtain DNA sample. At present he can only be summonsed by post and is free to go after giving name and address.

Hit and run: police get new power to arrest a driver suspected of failing to stop or, having stopped, of leaving the scene in cases where someone has been injured.

DNA and fingerprints: the bill overturns a House of Lords ruling banning retention of DNA samples and fingerprints in cases where charges are dropped or the accused is acquitted. About 50,000 such samples were held last year and will now have to be destroyed, as legislation is not retrospective.

The bill gives the police power to retain and use DNA samples given voluntarily, eg by village residents after series of rapes. Police Federation opposes this measure for its members, saying constables should not be forced to give DNA samples, on human rights grounds.

Nurses as well as doctors are allowed to take intimate samples for DNA profiling.

Ministers hope to expand DNA database from 1m to 3m samples within three years.

Pilot schemes: schemes to test changes to police powers to stop and search and detain suspects are allowed without par liamentary approval.

Suspects' rights: right to object to videotaping of interviews scrapped.

Granting bail: courts to give reasons if they grant bail against prosecution and police advice.

Passports: convicted drug traffickers' passports to be confiscated.

Importing child pornography: an arrestable offence.

Records: confidentiality of Inland Revenue records removed for all criminal investigations, and much greater powers given to Department of Trade and Industry inspectors.

Police training

Right to silence: removed in police disciplinary hearings.

New ranks: ranks of deputy chief constable and chief superintendent reintroduced. These were abolished in 1995, but half the forces retained them, even though there was no legal basis for them.

Colleges: new independent central training college.

Funding: for national criminal intelligence service and national crime squad.

Age ban lifted: people over 70 can serve on police authorities.

Anti-social behaviour orders: explanatory notes with the bill disclose the extent of official dismay at the failure of this initiative, introduced in the 1998 legislation. The Home Office had hoped that 5,000 orders a year would be issued, but applications are running at only 100 a year. Bill extends police power to provide witness protection from intimidation and fear of violence, to encourage more applications. For the first time such powers are to be used in civil cases. Police powers Seizure: power to overturn the "Bramley judgment", which ruled that Derbyshire police had wrongly seized a computer hard disk containing confidential correspondence between a suspect and his solicitor. The bill allows police to seize such "inextricably linked" material. Kerb crawlers: police given new power of arrest to take suspect to police station and to obtain DNA sample. At present he can only be summonsed by post and is free to go after giving name and address. Hit and run: police get new power to arrest a driver suspected of failing to stop or, having stopped, of leaving the scene in cases where someone has been injured. DNA and fingerprints: the bill overturns a House of Lords ruling banning retention of DNA samples and fingerprints in cases where charges are dropped or the accused is acquitted. About 50,000 such samples were held last year and will now have to be destroyed, as legislation is not retrospective. The bill gives the police power to retain and use DNA samples given voluntarily, eg by village residents after series of rapes. Police Federation opposes this measure for its members, saying constables should not be forced to give DNA samples, on human rights grounds. Nurses as well as doctors are allowed to take intimate samples for DNA profiling. Ministers hope to expand DNA database from 1m to 3m samples within three years. Pilot schemes: schemes to test changes to police powers to stop and search and detain suspects are allowed without par liamentary approval. Suspects' rights: right to object to videotaping of interviews scrapped. Granting bail: courts to give reasons if they grant bail against prosecution and police advice. Passports: convicted drug traffickers' passports to be confiscated. Importing child pornography: an arrestable offence. Records: confidentiality of Inland Revenue records removed for all criminal investigations, and much greater powers given to Department of Trade and Industry inspectors. Police training Right to silence: removed in police disciplinary hearings. New ranks: ranks of deputy chief constable and chief superintendent reintroduced. These were abolished in 1995, but half the forces retained them, even though there was no legal basis for them. Colleges: new independent central training college. Funding: for national criminal intelligence service and national crime squad. Age ban lifted: people over 70 can serve on police authorities.

webTitle: Plea to keep Belfast's 'Hannibal' in jail

fields.headline: Plea to keep Belfast's 'Hannibal' in jail
fields.trailText: Prison officers yesterday made an unprecedented attempt to convince the attorney general to keep a man they have dubbed Northern Ireland's answer to Hannibal Lecter behind bars.
fields.body:
Prison officers yesterday made an unprecedented attempt to convince the attorney general to keep a man they have dubbed Northern Ireland's answer to Hannibal Lecter behind bars.

Charles Conlon, 34, from north Belfast, was given a six-month sentence this week for beating a warder around the head with the arm of a chair and fracturing his skull in Maghaberry prison, Co Antrim, last January.

But prison staff said Conlon, who has been blamed for 200 incidents in jail over the past 10 years, including one particularly vicious attack last November when he allegedly bit an officer's cheek, should be locked up for much longer.

Like the fictional serial killer, burly 6ft Conlon is kept in isolation in a special cell. He is allowed out for an hour's exercise every day but is accompanied at all times by a four-man team in riot gear to prevent him attacking or biting them.

Prison sources said he had no visitors, and his mother - he was jailed for threatening to kill her - was too scared to come to see him.

"This man is an out-and-out animal," said Finlay Spratt of the Prison Officers' Association. "In my 24 years' experience, including all the paramilitaries, he is the worst, most evil prisoner our men have had to deal with.

"He seems to have a total hatred of the system and has assaulted 32 prison officers in the past 2 years alone. Even now he's gloating and taunting staff. He's made up a song which he sings to them: 'Six months for doing a screw, wee buns to me, I've got the screws on the run and I'm having fun.'

"The man he beat with the chair arm was so badly hurt he'll probably never work again. This is the first time we've petitioned the attorney general over a case like this but we feel it's absolutely necessary. If the courts aren't going to dish out appropriate sentences, then it leaves us very vulnerable."

Conlon, whose father was a US Vietnam veteran, has been in and out of young offenders' centres and prison since he was a teenager. His offences include 25 assaults on police, 27 other assaults, two arson attacks, 18 burglaries, four robberies, 12 convictions for criminal damage, and one for threatening to kill.

"This guy has a list as long as your arm. There's no doubt he's dangerous," said one source. Conlon is currently in solitary confinement for the second lengthy stretch since being put back into jail in October 1999.

Kevin Winters, of the Madden and Finucane firm of solicitors which represents Conlon, confirmed that his client was seeking a judicial review against the prison service because of the conditions in which he was kept.

"He has been in solitary confinement for at least six months and denied basic prison privileges," Mr Winters said. "I cannot deny there have been incidents of violence but our client, who is black, has instructed us he has been subjected to racist abuse.

"He says he has been taunted and provoked and has reacted and one view is that he has overreacted."

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor on a new attitudes survey

fields.headline: Poll reveals Britons are 'inspired' by materialism
fields.standfirst: Mother Teresa just made it into a popular poll  of 'the most inspirational' figures in history, but she was well behind Britney Spears, the pop singer
fields.trailText: Mother Teresa just made it into a popular poll of 'most inspirational' figures in history, but she was well behind Britney Spears, the pop singer.
fields.body:
It beats me why the British are feeling so pleased with themselves. An opinion poll conducted in eight European countries, and published by the Guardian last Monday, shows that the "feel-good factor" in Britain is much stronger than in France, Germany, Italy or Spain. Only the citizens of Luxembourg and the Netherlands, among the countries polled, are more cheerful than we are about their prospects, and more confident in the ability of government to improve their lot. But I expect that this is just because smallness in nations has a tendency to breed smugness. Why should the British be more delighted with their condition than countries with excellent hospitals, efficient train services, good schools, fewer single mothers, fewer drug addicts and less crime? That's what I want to know.

The British are the continent's greatest newspaper readers, and I would have thought that the perusal of any newspaper any day of the week would crush any optimism they might be tempted to feel. The Sunday newspapers are usually the most depressing. Last Sunday's not only dwelt at length on the callousness and incompetence of the police, medical and social services in the horrific case of Anna Climbie, the poor little girl from the Ivory Coast who was tortured to death before their eyes. One paper had a front-page picture of seven dead bodies, casually wrapped in sheets, that had been dumped without ceremony in a carpeted, unrefrigerated room in a NHS hospital in Bedford. Others were full of the usual tales of betrayal, perfidy and moral turpitude. The copy of the Evening Standard I have just bought says that muggings in London have risen by 27%.

I was feeling quite depressed anyway on Sunday as I waited at Taunton station for a delayed train to take me to London; and I was not cheered up by a recorded voice repeatedly announcing that it would be 14 minutes late, long after the 14 minutes had passed. Buying a sandwich and some newspapers in the station buffet to while away the time, I chanced on an article in the Sunday Telegraph that depressed me even more. This reported another opinion poll finding that Sir Richard Branson was chosen from a slightly bizarre list of characters as the second most "inspirational" figure in history (Nelson Mandela came first).

What makes Branson so inspiring - that he goes up in balloons, that he wants to run the National Lottery, that his train from Taunton on Sunday was 45 minutes delayed? It is probably just the fact that he has made lots of money that put him streets ahead of the Pope, Sir Winston Churchill, Mahatma Gandhi and Martin Luther King in the inspirational stakes. Mother Teresa just made it on to the list, but she was well behind Britney Spears, the teenage American singing siren. An even more surprising nominee was Earl Spencer, presumably for his anti-royal address at his sister's funeral a few years back.

The same poll asked people which publications "have had the most positive influence on life in Britain today". Newspapers were top choice, followed by the Bible, and in third place - can you believe it? - The Highway Code. Even more amazing is that Hello! came sixth, just behind the Koran and above The Little Book Of Calm. The Highway Code may be prized for encouraging people to drive carefully and to avoid the frightening explosions of road rage that I seem inexplicably to provoke in other drivers, but it is extremely hard to understand in what way Hello! can be thought to exert a positive influence on British society.

The main conclusion I draw from the poll is that the two things that are most "inspirational" and "positive" to the people of Britain are money and the celebrity culture, for newspapers promote the latter almost as much as Hello!. The notion that Mandela is a sort of god has been so drummed into people's minds that his status as most inspirational person ever to 65% of respondents, probably doesn't mean much. Jesus Christ got only 1%, as did the royal family. So, if my conclusion is correct, it is hardly surprising that the British people are so contented. They have never been more prosperous, and the celebrity culture has never been so strong.

It may be that my current debt to the Inland Revenue would in any event reduce my potential to feel good, but the Sunday Telegraph poll certainly makes me feel worse. One doesn't even have to be a Christian to find Jesus Christ more inspirational than Branson, for whom 51% voted. By any decent standard, the country is in a hell of a mess. What is the matter with us all?

webTitle: Huntingdon lab on brink of winning backing from US

fields.headline: Huntingdon lab on brink of winning backing from US
fields.trailText: Huntington Life Sciences was last night on the brink of securing alternative financial backing from the US to keep its animal testing laboratories open for business.
fields.body:
Huntington Life Sciences was last night on the brink of securing alternative financial backing from the US to keep its animal testing laboratories open for business.

As animal rights protesters stepped up their demonstrations outside the Cambridgeshire laboratory and in the financial district of London, it became increasingly evident that the company had found a way to repay a £22m loan which fell due yesterday.

Huntingdon executives, who have been fighting to restore the laboratory's reputation since evidence of cruelty to animals was uncovered in 1997, spent most of yesterday locked in talks with US bankers to come up with a long-term solution to the company's financial problems.

The laboratory had faced closure last night unless it could persuade Royal Bank of Scotland to extend its portion of the £22m loan while it continued talks with a number of potential backers in the US.

The bank, which inherited the loan when it bought NatWest last year, has been extending the repayment period since August when it ran out. The bank is thought to have found a way to extricate itself from the loss-making company even though it has faced mounting pressure from the government, the pharmaceutical industry and its trades unions to maintain support.

It has also faced protests outside its branches and the homes of its directors. Yesterday activists demonstrated outside its office in London. The office of the investment bank Merrill Lynch, which does not own Huntingdon shares directly but on behalf of clients, were also picketed.

In the past, City firms which bought shares in the company have sold them off in the face of protests, incurring heavy losses. The shares, which traded at more than 300p 10 years ago, crept towards 8.25p yesterday, an improvement on the 1p level to which they sunk earlier in the week.

As it began to look increasingly likely that the laboratory would secure financing from the US, protesters warned they would maintain their demonstrations against the company if it was thrown a financial lifeline.

Huntingdon Life Sciences
Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty
UK Bioindustry Association

fields.headline: Gender bending
fields.standfirst: The NHS was never designed to be a sort of state-run Jim'll Fix It, so I don't understand why gender should be the one exception
fields.trailText: The NHS was never designed to be a sort of state-run Jim'll Fix It, so I don't understand why gender should be the one exception.
fields.body:
Maybe it says something sad about my life, but the best night out I've had so far this year was at the Theatre Royal's pantomime of Cinderella. How we swooned at the doe-eyed beauty of Julian Clary as Dandini, at the hands-on stroppiness and tiny ankles of Joanne Good's Fairy Godmother and at the remarkable voice of Dave Benson Phillips, who may have made his name running around like a madman on children's TV but who actually has a pair of pipes to shame Levi Stubbs.

But a special welcome is always reserved for the Ugly Sisters. Ugly Sisters are, of course, always played by men and, though conventional feminism might look at them askance, I find them oddly appealing and sound; the very fact that no woman, however unattractive, is ever thought to be ugly enough to be an Ugly Sister is a testament to the superior beauty of women. In recent years, we have seen the decline of the Principal Boy, traditionally played by an attractive, athletic girl with extremely good gams; how much of this can be put down to a growing awareness of designer dykery, and our inability to see two pretty girls snogging without putting the worst possible interpretation on it? But you never think of sex when you see the Ugly Sisters.

The best reason for their continuing existence is that they demonstrate how very stupid men look, in fact, when they dress up as women. In the context of panto, this is perfectly appropriate. But for the rest of them, I see no difference between transvestite entertainers and the late Black and White Minstrels. They're both extremely offensive, and I don't understand why one is beyond the pale and the other totally acceptable in enlightened circles.

And, yes, I know that they're not the same, but may I say that I feel even less patience with transsexuals. Male to female transsexuals are Michael Jackson to the transvestites Ali G; not content even to dress up temporarily as the Other, they presume that its authenticity can be theirs through a few cosmetic adjustments. We laugh at people who want to change colour; we are shocked that millions of Japanese women each year have their eyes permanently occidentalised; we ban skin-lightening preparations, and would never dream of letting black people have Jackson-type whitening operations on the NHS.

Yet we pay for thousands of men every year to "become" women; around 7,000 at £8,000 a pop, and rising every year. You do the maths. "Oh, but I'm a woman trapped in a man's body!" So? What about all the white people who feel black, black people who feel white, poor people with rich people's tastes and short people who are dying to be tall? They're all welcome to go off and seek to make their dreams a reality, but I don't see the NHS spending money that could be better spent on hip operations, cancer treatments and simply cleaning up our filthy hospitals. The NHS was never designed to be a sort of state-run Jim'll Fix It, and I don't understand why gender must be the one exception.

The Daily Mail seems to have a special, not quite wholesome interest in male-to-female transsexuals, featuring at least one a month in extensive Before and After poses, with a headline typically saying something like THE PUBLIC SCHOOL SIR WHO WANTS TO BE A MISS; Nicholas/Nicola the Charterhouse teacher, Ian/Isabelle the Oxford tutor, Bill/Dian the Welsh preacher and Simon/Carol the C of E vicar. Its attitude used to be that these people were dangerous sexual radicals; now, it seeks to portray them as tragic victims.

My objection to trannies, though, is that they are woefully conventional souls (typical Mail readers, in fact) who seem unable to exist alongside any sort of ambiguity, which as we all know is one of the things that makes life so interesting. I wouldn't have the least problem leaving a young girl child in the care of any of them - I'd fear sexual molestation far less than from a "straight" man - but I would be worried that, by the time I came home, the child would be dressed from head to toe in pink and being danced round the room to the saccharine strains of Thank Heaven For Little Girls.

It is the literal-mindedness, the clunky logic of transsexuals, that is so appalling (that, and their taste in blouses), not their sexual depravity. They are frilly, docile smilers who always wear make-up and never the trousers. Their idea of womanhood seems to have survived intact from 1953. Despite their sticky lipstick rictuses, they are the ultimate example of a particularly middle-class, middle-aged male arrogance that cannot see why anything it desires shouldn't be so.

Such men invariably report that they were aware of feeling "trapped" in the wrong body since boyhood. Yet, thoughtfully, they go ahead and marry blissfully ignorant women and father children. Then, in middle age, with the kids off their hands, and when their wives are looking forward to kicking back and relaxing à deux, she comes home one day from Marks & Spencer to find hubby prancing about in her second-best Frank Usher frock and committing GBH on her new Carvela kitten heels. These poor stunned women - talk about feeling you've been sold a pup! - are then told by the caring professionals and counsellors to accept their husbands as "sisters". Just switch it for a moment and imagine that thousands of women decided they wanted penises. Would their husbands be expected to stay with them and live as brothers? Somehow, I doubt it. But it seems that whatever men choose to do - be it buy pornography from sweetshops, masturbate at impoverished single mothers on "chatlines", walk naked in the street (as Vincent Bethell was given the right to do last week) or demand to be called Daphne - must at all costs be normalised, whereas, for women, the rules are all but unshifting.

Transsexualism is, basically, just another, more drastic twist on the male menopause, which in turn is just another excuse for men to do as they please. And before the geek chorus - hi fans! - start up, yes, I know I've been pretty damned selfish during my long and squalid marital career. The difference is, of course, that I've never sought to dress up my own egoism in poor-me-trapped-in-the-wrong-life claptrap, and I've certainly never expected the taxpayer to hand over more than £8,000 in order to set me up in a love nest with my new squeeze. No - at the end of the day, changing sex is no more noble than changing your wife for a new woman. Only, this time, the woman is you.

And before the geek chorus - hi fans! - start up, yes, I know I've been pretty damned selfish during my long and squalid marital career. The difference is, of course, that I've never sought to dress up my own egoism in poor-me-trapped-in-the-wrong-life claptrap, and I've certainly never expected the taxpayer to hand over more than £8,000 in order to set me up in a love nest with my new squeeze. No - at the end of the day, changing sex is no more noble than changing your wife for a new woman. Only, this time, the woman is you.

fields.headline: We are the people of England. And we can't be bothered to speak
fields.trailText: My patience is severely tried.
fields.body:
They say that "have a nice day" is on its way out, while "how may I help you?" at least expresses a desire to cooperate. But there's no such defence for a line which seems increasingly to crop up on the posters and handbills of people whose services just keep on letting you down, whose trains run late or don't run at all, whose escalators are constantly out of service, whose lifts are suspended, or whose 94 bus has gone missing. "Thank you for your patience," they say. "What patience?" I screech in return. "Just look at me! Your persistent and shameless inadequacy has reduced me to a great steaming, smoking Etna of filthy impatience. How dare you insult my intelligence by suggesting anything else?"

Still, you can see why the railway companies (they are the worst offenders, of course) still dare to impute such patience to suffering customers. They do it because it's true. How docile they are, the people of Britain, as they stand on the station concourses listening to announcements of further delays - delays we're expected to think are the aftermath of Hatfield, though some of them (absence of train crew, signal failure, a defect on your incoming train) have nothing to do with Hatfield at all.

Why has no politician been hanged - or at least, let's be decent about it, impeached - for complicity in that conspiracy against the travelling public which is rail privatisation? "We are the people of England," Chesterton wrote "that have never spoken yet." Nor ever will, I suspect.

Something odd and rather nasty has happened to horse racing. Long ago, when I sometimes attended a racetrack, the races had harmless names like the St Mildred's handicap, the Hampton-in-Arden selling plate, or the Cesarewitch. But today a naked commercialism is stalking the paddocks, even in sweet little places like Chepstow. Tuesday's meeting there, having opened with the Faucets for Groheart Available Next Day novice hurdle, proceeded through the Faucets for Grohe Chiara Basin Mixers Novice Hurdle to the Real Radio Race Night July 27 Handicap Chase (run at 2.10 pm on January 16: where is the logic in that?)

After that we were back to the Faucets for Grohe Euroeco Hospital Fittings hurdle, the FfG (I'm sorry; I cannot give it in full every time) Avensys Shower Valves novice chase, and the FfG Grohemaster 3000 standard open NH/flat divisions 1 and 2.

At Wolverhampton, meanwhile, they were staging the Bet Direct From Littlewoods apprentice handicap and, still worse, the Bet Direct on 0800 211 222 handicap. It is good that the BBC when handing out tips on Today still refers to the 2.30pm at Wincanton, rather than the 2.30 Bet Direct on a Faucetmaster 0800 999 999 999 Ask For Charlie Or If Charlie's Out On The Razzle, Try Giving Dear Old Eric A Tinkle selling stakes. No doubt that will come in time.

Wit and wisdom on horseback - an occasional Smallweed series, number 322: "Everyone now agrees that there is no case for a ban" - some ermined twerp on the Today programme on the morning of the hunting debate.

All these recent altercations* about Acton have led Smallweed to neglect a number of pithy letters about an earlier columnar controversy: my contention that England cricket selectors are always unwise to choose players whose names coincide with those of cathedral cities. The one exception to that, I asserted at first, was a batsman called Arthur Shrewsbury, who was highly rated by WG Grace. Having been rebuked by a reader who said that Shrewsbury was not a cathedral city, I then declared that my so-called exception did not apply. I am now rebuked, however, for believing what I was told. For Shrewsbury is a cathedral city; it's just that the cathedral is Roman Catholic** rather than Anglican.

Terence Hall of Pendlebury, Manchester, prefers to be positive. ("Pendlebury people prefer to be positive", as the local saw has it.) He thinks the safest course the selectors can take is to pick players whose names coincide with places in Lancashire, such as Atherton, Denton, Hutton, Leyland, Rhodes, Tyldesley and Wardle. There are 17 names on his list, though unhappily all but three are dead. Should a player called Blackburn or Lancaster come to the fore, the selectorate will be in a bit of a pickle, since these names belong to towns which are in Lancashire (good), but have a cathedral (bad, unless it is Shrewsbury). The same applies to players called Manchester, Salford or Liverpool, but I don't suppose there are many of them.

Wit and wisdom on horseback - an occcasional Smallweed series, no 323: "We are not cruel, and I am quite sure if the fox had a vote between nature and hunting he would vote for hunting."- Vet Professor "Twink" Allen from the Equine Fertility Unit in Newmarket, taking to the Press Association*** at a rally on Wednesday

Next week in Smallweed: Why I'd like to vote for Christmas, by a turkey.

A final, absolutely ultimate, last-ever (probably) footnote on Acton. I have news of the whereabouts of the elusive 94 bus. Roger Newport, of Bitton near Bristol, has seen one! In full London Transport livery, too, and displaying the destination "Piccadilly Circus"; but outside Katoomba railway station, in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, which is not much use if you're stuck at a bus stop at Turnham Green station.

Mr Newport's technical notes - not sponsored by Faucets for Grohe, I am happy to say:
(1) The bus carried the garage code "A" which, in Mr Newport's day, referred to the output of Sutton garage. Yet Acton buses do not run out of Sutton! (2) The type of vehicle (a Bristol make) and the UK registration still visible (HHL 139L) show that the bus never ran in London anyway. (Some of my correspondents complain, of course, that the real 94 does not do so either.) In other words, he explains,it's merely a tourist attraction**** which has borrowed the hallowed name of route 94.

*As alert readers will notice, this word is an anagram of "Acton is alert". **An anagram of "Acton charm oil." ***An anagram of "Acton Oasis's spire." ****An anagram of "Acton tart? I?"

webTitle: Thousands at risk as air pollution reaches danger mark

fields.headline: Thousands at risk as air pollution reaches danger mark
fields.trailText: Britain is suffering the worst air pollution episode since 1991 and thousands of elderly people and asthmatics are at risk over the weekend, the Department of Environment warned last night.
fields.body:
Britain is suffering the worst air pollution episode since 1991 and thousands of elderly people and asthmatics are at risk over the weekend, the Department of Environment warned last night.

The high pressure of the past week has allowed traffic and power station pollutants to concentrate to dangerous levels - conditions which are expected to increase hospital admissions, and bring the premature deaths of hundreds of people suffering heart and lung problems.

Last time conditions were as bad, in December 1991, deaths rose 10% in London during four days.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, appealed last night for people to use their cars as little as possible and when they did drive to avoid revving engines and causing unnecessary exhaust fumes.

Worst affected areas today are expected to be Northern Ireland, central Scotland, central England and London. Yesterday east Belfast and Derry were already in the "very high" category of air pollution for the number one killer particulates (PM10s) - the tiny aerosols from vehicle exhausts and power stations that inflame the lungs.

Northern Ireland is particularly vulnerable to air pollution because it has two large coal burning power stations which are surrounded by hills which naturally trap the fumes if there is no wind.

London had high levels of particulates yesterday from traffic, and all large urban areas are at risk today, the department warned.

The government has been gradually reducing air pollution by measures to encourage cleaner engines and the fitting of particulate traps to commercial vehicles. Clean diesel is also reducing the danger.

However, government scientists estimate that despite these measures, 10,000 deaths are brought forward each year in Britain by air pollution, because the peaks in death rates coincide with higher air pollution. The Europe-wide figure is 40,000.

Advice to vulnerable people is to stay indoors whenever possible. Joggers and outdoor sports enthusiasts are also advised to cut down on activity.

Mr Meacher said: "The prolonged cold, still weather has caused pollution levels to rise throughout the week. I have therefore taken the precautionary step of making sure vulnerable people, such as those with heart and lung disease, are aware and can take appropriate measures to reduce their exposure."

He said people with asthma and others affected might need to consider modifying their treatment, and consulting their doctor as necessary.

The weather is expected to change tomorrow, when a spell of wet and windy conditions should clear the air.

webTitle: Billionaire brothers made to stay in India

fields.headline: Billionaire brothers made to stay in India
fields.trailText: An Indian judge yesterday prevented Britain's wealthiest Asian family, the Hinduja brothers, from leaving the country after they turned up in court to answer allegations of taking bribes in India's biggest corruption scandal.
fields.body:
An Indian judge yesterday prevented Britain's wealthiest Asian family, the Hinduja brothers, from leaving the country after they turned up in court to answer allegations of taking bribes in India's biggest corruption scandal.

The brothers - Srichand, Gopichand and Prakesh - flew into Delhi on Thursday and were supposed to leave for the US last night, but were ordered to remain in India until further notice. The judge, Ajit Bharihoke, said the Hindujas could return to Britain only with his permission.

Their lawyers had earlier argued that the Hindujas' global business empire would suffer if they were compelled to stay in India. But the judge said the Hindujas had to be treated like everyone else, and ordered them to pay £6,000 each in sureties and bonds.

The billionaire industrialists remain in Delhi while their lawyers prepare a fresh application for later today.

Last night Srichand Hinduja said he "welcomed" the judge's decision. "I take things as they come. That is how I have lived my life," he said. "We have nothing to hide. We are relaxed because we are innocent, otherwise we would not have come to India."

The Hindujas, who sponsored the Millennium Dome's spirit zone, are accused of accepting $10m (£7.1m) in bribes from the Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors.

They were allegedly given the money after using their influence with the late Indian prime minister, Rajiv Gandhi, to secure the firm a massive defence contract in 1986. The bribes, it is claimed, were hidden in a series of secret Swiss bank accounts.

The Hindujas are likely to have to reappear in court on January 30.

webTitle: Powell calls for climate talks delay

fields.headline: Powell calls for climate talks delay
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George W Bush's America
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Colin Powell, the incoming US secretary of state, has asked for climate change negotiations to be postponed because Bush administration appointees will not be briefed in time.
fields.body:
Colin Powell, the incoming US secretary of state, has asked for climate change negotiations to be postponed because Bush administration appointees will not be briefed in time.

The talks, which collapsed in December in the Hague, failed to restart during the last month of the Clinton administration despite meetings between the EU, US, Japan, Canada and Australia to try to find common ground.

The next scheduled meeting was to be May in Bonn but Mr Powell has said he fears that the new under-secretary for global affairs, who will replace Frank Loy, will not have time to "read himself in".

The new president has expressed doubts that climate change is a problem. But Mr Powell, who has overall responsibility for the issue, has indicated that the US takes its responsibilities seriously and has told EU officials that he wants the Bonn talks delayed for at least a month so that the administration can make a "constructive contribution".

webTitle: John O'Farrell on George W Bush

fields.headline: The misunderestimated president
fields.standfirst:
Our best hope is that Bush will trip over his words today and fail to be inaugurated

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Our best hope is that Bush will trip over his words today and fail to be inaugurated.
fields.body:
Today will see the inauguration of George Bush. Today he'll start trying to shake off the jibe that he will represent only the very rich. Tickets for the event start at £2,500.

Thousands of demonstrators are expected to converge on Washington, though George will be lucky to get all of them to pay that much. The protesters are angry that Al Gore has been cheated out of the presidency but instead of joining them Al will have to stand there applauding the man who got less votes than him. He's spent all week in front of the bathroom mirror practising his "dignified statesman" look.

If I were Bill Clinton I would have resigned yesterday, just to give his deputy a whole 24 hours as president. This would have been just enough time for Bill to take him round the Oval Office and show him the ropes. "Al, here's your desk. Look, I had them make up a little nameplate saying 'Al Gore, President'. Take a seat Al, how does it feel?" Then "President Gore" could have sat down and opened up his diary to see what his duties were for the day. "Let's see, Saturday, Saturday. Ah yes, here we are; 4pm - hand over the presidency to George Bush."

Throughout his campaign George W Bush told us that the "W" stood for "win", although when you hear him speak it is not the first "W" that springs to mind. It is typical of "Dubya" that he won the election by losing it, since his entire career has been built upon a succession of failures from which he emerged better placed on each occasion.

He likes to make out that he had a typical American background, no different to any other wholesome American family in which Dad was head of the CIA. No doubt when they were kids George and his brother could be heard playing in the backyard. "Come on Jeb, let's play destabilising third world governments."

After an expensive education which resulted only in mediocre grades, George Jr took the traditional route for future American politicians and jumped the queue for the National Guard to avoid going to Vietnam. It's a shame for the US that he never took part in the war, because after the North Vietnamese had overrun Saigon and occupied the entire country, Bush could have declared America the winner.

In 1981 Dad became vice-president, which seemed to coincide with the time that George Jr found it easier to get backers for his oil company. Despite his connections his various oil businesses all foundered, and though his investors lost millions, George somehow always managed to emerge with his personal wealth increased. Who needs oil when Dad can oil the wheels for you?

Even more murky are his financial dealings with the Texas Rangers baseball team. Bush put together a consortium of millionaires to buy the club, and got himself made managing director even though he put up less than 1% of the money himself.

A brand new stadium was built with public money. This greatly increased the value of the club but of course none of this cash was returned to the taxpayer when it was sold again. George pocketed a cool $14.9m and became the man who put the "base" into baseball.

The association with the Texas Rangers made him a local celebrity and against expectations he was elected governor. He worked very hard in Texas, signing more death warrants than all the other state governors put together. He broke a few other records as well; Texas now has the worst water pollution and air quality of any of the major states.

Bush consistently took the side of big business against the interests of ordinary Texans and what he did for the Lone Star state, he now hopes to do for all 50. It couldn't be better for the multinationals if Ronald McDonald himself had got the presidency. In fact Ronald probably would have got the Republican nomination if it wasn't so obvious that he wore make-up.

The only hope is that at today's inauguration, George will trip over his words again and fail to be sworn in as president. Because some of his recent statements suggest he might not be quite up to the world's top job.

"I was raised in the west. The west of Texas. It's pretty close to California. In more ways than Washington DC is close to California." He's even stronger on economics: "It's clearly a budget; it's got a lot of numbers in it." And on the environment: "Natural gas is hemispheric. I like to call it hemispheric in nature because it is a product that we can find in our neighbourhoods."

We knew that American voters had an anti-intellectual streak but they didn't have to go that far. But as George said himself "they misunderestimated me". Today, at the dawn of the 21st century, the global village is finally complete. At last it has a global village idiot.

fields.standfirst:
Community unites as parents return to Mediterranean island to bury the baby they lost in operation

More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: Community unites as parents return to Mediterranean island to bury the baby they lost in operation.
fields.body:
In late spring last year an expectant mother and her husband left their remote Mediterranean home hoping and praying that within a few weeks they would return nursing lovely twins. But yesterday Mikelangelo and Rina Attard - parents of the conjoined twins known to the world as Jodie and Mary - arrived home to bury one of their daughters.

As night fell over the Maltese island of Gozo, Mary, the twin who had to die to save her sister, was laid to rest in a cemetery on a peaceful hillside overlooking farmers' fields and the sea. The simple grave is to be adorned in marble and will become a melancholy shrine for would-be mothers and their families.

In time, perhaps in the next couple of months, the Attards will be making a happier journey when they carry Jodie, now a bright and lively girl aged five months, back to their home village of Xaghra.

But yesterday was about Mary and a close-knit, devout community finally closing a tragic chapter.

When the Attards' white taxi, which followed the hearse containing Mary's tiny white coffin, pulled into the outskirts of the village, their neighbours and relatives poured out on to the single main street and applauded.

When they followed the coffin into the village's lavish 17th century basilica, the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin, the congregation rose and again applauded the couple.

Mrs Attard, 29, greeted friends she had not seen for more than six months. Her husband, a 44-year-old plasterer, sobbed.

It was a day of sadness but also one of reunion and reconciliation because a family which had been absent for so long were now back among their nearest and dearest. It was not, agreed relatives and community and religious leaders, a day for blame.

The Bishop of Gozo, where 95% of people are Catholics and abortion is considered evil, has had harsh criticism in the past for the ruling made in the British courts that the operation to separate the twins, born joined at the abdomen, had to take place although it meant certain death for Mary.

Bishop Nicholas Cauchi gave the homily during the funeral service as a mark of "solidarity" with the Attards, who had fiercely opposed the operation on religious grounds believing that nature should be allowed to take its course even after doctors had made it clear that both girls would eventually die if nothing was done.

The bishop said he was not going to use the homily to apportion blame but there was, nevertheless, a hint of bitterness in his words when he suggested that there were those who "perhaps didn't do enough so that the sacrifice of [Mary] could be avoided".

The Attards had considered bringing both Jodie, who is still being treated at St Mary's hospital in Manchester, and Mary's body back. They were persuaded to deal with the funeral first so that Jodie's arrival would not be marred.

Mary's body was flown to Malta and taken from there to Gozo, four miles away, at 2am yesterday on a private boat. A thunderstorm and torrential rain hit the island after daybreak but by afternoon blue sky and calm had returned.

Children from local schools, the girls in pink and white gowns, the boys in smart blue uniforms, greeted the hearse at the edge of the village. Four boys had been chosen to carry the coffin - Anthony Attard, the village mayor and an uncle of Mary, had been inundated with volunteers for the task. The coffin was so light that the young boys were easily able to carry it the few hundred yards to the basilica in the village square.

While the church bells rang, the coffin, bearing a silver plaque with Mary's real name - which cannot be revealed for legal reasons - and a simple inscription, "Died November 7 aged three months", was placed in front of the altar surrounded by dozens of bouquets.

At the end of the service the Attards thanked all those who had supported them through their ordeal, including staff at St Mary's.

Mr Attard said: "We must not forget Jodie who is still in hospital. We are sure she is with us here in spirit and we hope she will grow up and be able to come and live here in our community."

Traditionally winter funerals in Gozo are scheduled for late in the afternoon so that the body is buried just as dusk falls. But yesterday so many friends and relatives wanted to shake the hand of Mr Attard and hug his wife that it was already dark as they left the basilica to begin the 15 minute walk to the cemetery.

One onlooker said: "I suppose it's appropriate that it is so dark now, but we'll pray that with Jodie they will have a brighter future."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Girl attacked by knifeman |  Less call for coastguards |  Brain damage man wins £1.3m
fields.body:
Girl attacked by knifeman

A 17-year-old girl was yesterday recovering from multiple knife wounds to her face and upper body inflicted by a man who attacked her and her boyfriend as they sat in their car at the Common country park, Ditchling, East Sussex.

Less call for coastguards

Coastguards assisted 14,717 people in Britain last year, 3,000 fewer than in 1999, the maritime and coastguard agency said yesterday. The number of incidents dealt with by coastguards also fell, from 12,220 in 1999 to 12,008, while 234 people lost their lives, down from 251.

Brain damage man wins £1.3m

A man who suffered brain damage as a baby after a delay in diagnosing a chronic bowel condition was awarded £1.3m in an out-of-court settlement yesterday. The high court, sitting at Newcastle upon Tyne, was told Sunderland health authority admitted a breach of duty of care towards Brian Conlon, 20.

Two arrested over 'bomb' find

Two men aged 65 and 51 have been arrested following the discovery of bomb-making equipment at a house in Wroxham, Norfolk. They are not thought to be animal rights activists.

New watchdog members

The six members of the electoral commission, the new watchdog to oversee elections including political party funding, were announced yesterday. The chairman will be Sam Younger, a former BBC executive and Red Cross director general.

Hopes fade for fishermen

Hopes of finding fishermen Wayne Lowe, 22, and Richard Cooper, 18, from Southampton, were fading yesterday after their boat was found capsized in Southampton Water. They were last seen stuck in mud on Wednesday night.

Sinn Fein action over union flag

Sinn Fein is seeking a judicial review over Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson's decision to fly the union flag over Ulster buildings occupied by government ministers. Its application to have Mr Mandelson called for cross-examination will be considered at Belfast high court on Monday.

Ice warning after child dies

Police and safety campaigners have warned of the dangers of venturing on to ice following the death of David Miller, five, who fell into a frozen pond while chasing ducks near Cowie in Stirlingshire. He was pulled from the water by his mother, but was pronounced dead at Stirling Royal infirmary.

Boy, 15, wins farming award

A 15-year-old boy who saved up his £5-a-week pocket money to buy four cows, 14 sheep, 17 chickens and 15 acres to keep them on has been named Welsh young farmer of the year by the National Farmers' Union. Ben Wonnacott, from Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire, rises at 6am daily to feed his animals and muck out.

Prentice the defector dies

Lord "Reg" Prentice of Daventry, the former Labour minister who as Newham North East MP defected to the Tories in 1977, has died aged 77, Conservative central office said last night.

Hello! appoints Hall as chief

The celebrity magazine Hello! is to step up the circulation war with its rival, Richard Desmond's OK!, with the appointment as editor-in-chief of former News of the World editor Phil Hall. He said yesterday he would build upon Hello's "upmarket" readership.

Quickie divorce for Oasis star

Oasis frontman Noel Gallagher was granted a "quickie" divorce from Meg Mathews in London yesterday on the grounds of his adultery with his girlfriend, Sara MacDonald.
