webTitle: Comment: Babies sold on the net are lucky

fields.headline: Babies sold on the net are lucky
fields.standfirst:
If unwanted children get a home, the means to it don't matter

Special report: Babies for sale
More net news
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: If unwanted children get a home, the means to it don't matter.
fields.body:
Those who have objected to the purchase of Kimberley and Belinda - the twins who have come from America via the internet to the current care of Flintshire social services - have, from the prime minister and home secretary downwards, used variations of a phrase about "babies being bought and sold on the internet".

If we were to follow the practice of using italics to illustrate the moral emphasis, it's hard to know precisely where the wavy type would go. One possibility is "children being bought and sold on the internet". The other is "bought and sold on the internet" .

If the objection is the first - that the commercial aspect is reprehensible - it seems disingenuous of capitalist free-market politicians and commentators to express surprise that babies are traded. After decades of rhetoric suggesting that people should have the freedom to spend their money as they want, it's odd to think that the lovingly cherished market would somehow stop at the cot.

The government's argument would presumably be that credit-card adopters are abusing the system and that unwanted children should be allocated through official channels. And yet all recent British governments have happily accepted that the rich cardiac patient should buy a bypass, while the poor wait, with possibly fatal consequences, for the state to operate. It's hard to see why it's morally more repugnant for there to be a two-tier system for those who wish to foster or adopt, especially as the state-funded underbidders in this market suffer frustration and sadness rather than potential death.

I don't mean by this that a pro-capitalist government has to accept any manifestation of the market. An internet website which made it easy to hire Colombian contract killers would obviously be wrong because the consequence is the ending of a life. In baby-trading, there is a possibility that the "victim" will have a better life; not as nice as Leo Blair's, perhaps, but better than the one on offer from the birth family.

For some, the second emphasis will apply: "bought and sold on the internet." For demonisers of modernity, it seems particularly sick that an infant can be relocated through clicking keyboards. But why is computerised adoption any less reliable than the deciding of children's destinies through the filling in of forms in council offices? For a long time, babies have been internationally traded in shady handovers at border posts and orphanages. At least the internet leaves a trail of information.

Some of the confusion over these tug-of-money twins - the doubt about who owns them, the coming struggles in court - probably does result from the use of unofficial channels. But the approved routes have a poor record. Council-supervised fostering and adoption has, in the recent Bradley case and others, brought tabloid scandal and legal argument. Numerous children have been raped and abused in state-run institutions.

The lesson here is that, of all human activities, the one most resistant to legislation and regulation is the parental instinct. Most of the things that politicians want to stop - crime, blood sports, smoking, drink-driving - are regarded by large numbers of people as repugnant.

However, those moral quandaries raised through infertility and family expansion - surrogate motherhood, the sale of sperm and ovums, illegal adoption and fostering - are subject to sympathy from all except the most hardhearted. I would personally draw the line at the parents of dead children being permitted to clone them - or the artificial impregnation of women with rabbit-sized litters - but, beyond that, those involved are usually, however clumsily, trying to give and receive love. There may eventually be terrible consequences - psychologically damaged or delinquent children - but these notoriously result also from marital procreation.

Most issues of public discussion - hunting, Tony Blair, football match fixing, the fourth edition of EastEnders - offer handy opinions on either side: A/B, pro/anti. The internet twins are the kind of subject on which you want to summon to a seance Wittgenstein, Freud, Plato, and St Augustine. Try, for example, this simple multiple-choice.

Kimberley and Belinda stand the best chance of safe and successful lives with:

a) their birth mother

b) either of the two adoptive couples or a third one

c) in the care of British or American authorities.

These are all the devil's alternatives. Were the twins able to vote, they would surely ask for that choice on US ballot papers: "None of the above."

Much of what has been written about the internet twins echoes the tone of the condemnation of the similar, semi-official, internet-driven trade in organs and body-parts from the poor. But there's a vast difference between asset-stripping living bodies and trying to give a home to homeless children.

The crucial distinction is that few people have an unwanted kidney or a cornea they never meant to be there. Millions of people have unwanted children. What happens to those children is largely a matter of luck. It's perfectly possible that Kimberley and Belinda had good luck when they were sold on the internet, and bad luck when they were seized by Flintshire social workers.

fields.headline: When you're reaching for the moon
fields.standfirst: David Hunt on small steps you can take now that will add up to sizeable nest eggs later
fields.trailText: David Hunt on small steps you can take now that will add up to sizeable nest eggs later.
fields.body:
For many basic-rate taxpayers, end of year tax planning simply boils down to: "Do I have enough spare cash to pop something into an Isa, and, if so, which Isa should I go for - cash or equity?"

After last year's poor stock market performance, the decision about which way to go this year could be even harder. The tax benefits of a cash Isa are easy to see - the investor gets the gross rate of interest.

The benefits of buying equities through an Isa are not so obvious, especially for the basic-rate taxpayer. Isas offer investors tax breaks on income and capital gains. For the basic-rate taxpayer, these can mean little, at least in the short term.

"Generally, the CGT advantage is negligible for the basic-rate taxpayer," admits Charles Timm, managing director of The Isa Shop, a firm of financial advisers. "If they use their annual CGT allowances sensibly they should be OK as they will probably be within the tax-free zone, and not face a bill." The annual CGT allowance is £7,200 a year, a level usually increased each year in line with inflation.

But advisers point out that while the basic-rate taxpayer may not be bothered by CGT today, who knows what his or her position will be in, say, 10 or 20 years' time. A small investment in one year can grow into a sizeable fund over time, especially if the investor has used the tax-free Pep/Isa allowance each year.

Steve Hancy, an independent financial adviser at the Falcon Group, gives an example of how this has worked in practice. He quotes an investment of £6,000 in an average UK Growth unit trust back in 1990-91. Over 10 years the value of the investment would have grown to more than £20,000, which would have given a basic-rate taxpayer a potential CGT bill of nearly £1,400.

On the income tax side, the short-term benefits of equity Isas are equally questionable. "In the first year or so it's touch and go as to whether the cost of putting money into an equity Isa is worth it," says Nigel Legge, joint chief executive of fund group Liontrust. But he qualifies this: "Over time it's a different matter. The longer term benefits can be phenomenal."

Charles Timm agrees: "The huge benefit of investing in Isas is not for capital gains in themselves, but in building up capital which can be converted into tax-free income at some later date, probably in retirement."

Isas fall into the "use them or lose them" category of tax breaks. And an investor using an allowance just once could be forgiven for wondering what all the fuss is about. It is a different matter for those who invest the maximum or substantial sums each year.

Mr Timm says he can point to several clients who have used their Pep and Isa provisions over the years and have built up funds of £250,000 and more: "Even if the CGT benefit may be minimal for 95% of the population, the wonderful thing is being able to retire and convert all that growth into tax-free income."

But in some cases - especially certain investment trusts bought through savings schemes - the cost of an Isa wrapper can outweigh the income tax savings on dividends. And for many the short-term tax position of equity Isas is getting worse - pointing further to the long-term CGT relief being more worthwhile.

Up until April 5 1999 any dividends paid on shares held in a Pep were eligible for a tax credit of 20%. This was subsequently reduced to 10% for Isas and will disappear completely from April 2004. This tax change hits most at investors in equity income funds but is largely irrelevant to funds aiming for capital growth where the shares held often return little, if anything, by way of dividends.

A number of investors have sidestepped this change by investing in corporate bond funds, whose returns are paid as "interest" not dividends, and the full 20% tax credit can still be reclaimed.

webTitle: Diary: Little comic relief in celebrity greed

fields.headline: Little comic relief in celebrity greed
fields.trailText: I popped into the Comic Relief offices and found it bustling, full of young persons working hard for nothing.
fields.body:
 I popped into the Comic Relief offices, next to the MI6 building, this week (during Wine Relief, several big retailers will again be giving 10% of the price of selected bottles to the charity this year), and found it bustling, full of young persons working hard for nothing, or else for a tiny fraction of the amount Dale Winton's agent negotiated for him to front six half-hour programmes designed to publicise Comic Relief before the night itself - when, admittedly, Mr Winton will work for nothing.

Whatever the rationale, you have to wonder whether the BBC needs to cough up £90,000 - the total annual licence fee paid by a small market town - in order to secure the services for three hours' airtime of this drab, effeminate, smug, preening, condescending nonentity. Are we so desperately short of talent in this country?

But I suspect most people have no idea how incredibly greedy many celebrities are. I used to know a south London businessman who organised a lot of charity events. He told me he was appalled at the demands made by some TV stars, including many of the most famous. Commonly they would require £1,000 to, say, open a fete, but then insist on another five grand in an envelope, so they could cheat the taxman as well as stiffing the charity. "But," he said, "you have to get them to come along or else the punters won't turn up."

 Of course, I have absolutely no objection to the BBC spending money on me. On Sunday we were invited to Alan Yentob's excellent 2001 party. About half the guests were famous, and those of us in the other half were there to admire them. The most touching sight of all was the Two Ronnies, who haven't worked together in decades, chatting happily and animatedly to each other for nearly two hours.

Ronnie Barker looks very old now but he seemed to glow with the pleasure of being with Ronnie Corbett (who is even tinier than you think. So is Melinda Messenger. Or most of her.) One of the great showbiz myths is that all double acts hate each other, so it was rather heart-warming to see it isn't true. Poor Ben Elton looked like a hunted man. Lots of comedians dislike plenty of other comedians, but his decision to get involved with George W Bush's inauguration today seems to have thrown him into some terrible comic Gehenna from which he may never return.

 In its desperate attempt to stop us going to our doctors, the NHS has put a truly weird ad into some publications. I was shown it in Front, the most laddish of all the lads' mags. It shows five snaps of young men in the final stages of inebriation. Two are throwing up, in vivid colour. One is lying on his bed, smeared with cake and ice cream, one appears about to throw up, and the other has fallen asleep on a filthy carpet littered with empty bottles. "It might be the turkey trots or the common hangover," says the caption. "Either way, a pharmacist is qualified to give advice and help you cleanse your poisoned carcass. Unless, of course, it's serious, in which case they'll recommend a doctor. Or maybe a coroner." In other words, whatever you do, don't bother us.

This truly revolting ad is printed next to a page of similar shots, only this time advertising the cause rather than the cure: WKD, a drink made from Irn Bru and vodka, probably the only alcoholic beverage which makes you throw up before your boozing session, at the very thought of drinking it.

 I see there's a trial scheme in Devon by which revellers leaving pubs and clubs in residential areas at a late hour are given lollipops at the door. Few of us can resist a free lollipop and while they don't stop car doors slamming, they make it almost impossible to shout or sing raucous ballads. My colleague Chris Moncrieff, who has worked for the Press Association in the Commons since Gladstone's second administration, thinks the idea should be adopted at Westminster - and MPs given the lollipops by the serjeant at arms as they enter the chamber.

 My watchword has always been that you should never trust anyone called Simon. This week the BBC showed Blood On The Carpet, about the time Matthew Bannister arrived at Radio 1 and sacked all the egomaniacal dinosaur disc jockeys, including Simon Bates, who now crops up on Classic FM doing his "Our Tune" turn. The tune usually turns out to be the Four Seasons or Pachelbel's Canon. (I'd love it if someone wrote: "As we gazed into each other's eyes, the orchestra was playing Schoenberg's Erwartung. So please, Simon, let me hear it again...")

At my school in Leicester one of the consolations of being called Simon - not thought the most macho monicker at the time - was that I was in De Montfort house, and so shared a name with this great parliamentarian. Now it turns out that he was a rabid anti-semite, and the town council has decided to have nothing more to do with his memory. Ah, well, at least it proves my watchword.

 I met Auberon Waugh only a few times, though I knew enough about him to sense he was not quite the saintly figure depicted in some of the press this week. But that's journalists for you; when politicians or academics die we can be sharp, detached, and even coruscating. But when one of our own goes, then we send the solemn funeral procession off down Whitehall with black-plumed horses leading the way.

I can say, though, he was as charming as depicted, and also quite pleasingly vague. I spoke to him early last year when he phoned to ask me to write for his magazine, the Literary Review. I said I expected he'd need me to email the article. He sounded distressed. "Oh, yes, I suppose you should," he said in a distracted sort of way. I asked for the email address, and the note of near panic grew as he asked someone to find it. Finally he had it on a bit of paper. "It's, er, litrev, mmm, l-i-t-r-e-v, and then there's a sort of curly thing, perhaps you know what that is..."

webTitle: Comment: Wheeler buys into the celebrity circuit

fields.headline: Wheeler buys into the celebrity circuit
fields.standfirst:
IG Index owner's £5m donation to the Tories marks him out as a man who can take it on the chin

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: IG Index owner's £5m donation to the Tories marks him out as a man who can take it on the chin.
fields.body:
So Labour is now the party of publishers and greengrocers, Conservative the party of bookmakers. The brouhaha about political funding could encourage an unprecedented national interest in the nature of entrepreneurship.

Stuart Wheeler's £5m donation to the Tories will seem appropriate to many City types, for his spreadbetting firm IG Index became a dealing room institution during Margaret Thatcher's heyday. Opening an account with IG or its rival Sporting Index was a 1980s rite of passage. Manhood was measured by the stoicism with which a broker bore his losses on West Indies runs or Chelsea corners.

Almost every newspaper spiced up its report of Mr Wheeler's largesse with a reference to IG's odds on the outcome of the upcoming general election. The prices quoted on the number of seats to be won suggest Labour will romp home once more. A case of Man Utd v Carlisle, rather than an Old Firm derby.

Mr Wheeler may or may not be backing a loser. There is no inconsistency, however, between IG's election prices and its founder's belief in a William Hague premiership. The skill of IG's price-makers lies in reflecting the current balance of market opinion. The spreadbetting business premise is identical to that of market-making in the stock market - simply to reflect the prevailing balance of supply and demand and not to bet outright on possible outcomes.

More scary for many will be the realisation that Mr Wheeler may not actually care too greatly that he could be backing a loser. There will be much speculation that political gifts of this magnitude cannot come "no strings attached". Such cynicism is understandable. After all, there is now a fair smattering of ermine hanging off the shoulders of donors to both the Labour and Conservative parties. But one must allow for the rather peculiar nature of entrepreneurs.

The pursuit of wealth is rather like the London marathon. The starting line is crowded with competitors of all shapes, sizes, ages and backgrounds. The vast majority have no hope of featuring at the finish. Only a few harbour any realistic dreams of winning rather than merely taking part.

Those with genuine hopes of triumphing in the race to riches seem - at least to my outsider's eye - to draw sustenance from wealth simply as numbers, rather than as a means to another end. After all, the point at which most families' needs could be met is passed long before the runners hang up their corporate trainers. What is it that keeps them going?

British entrepreneurs tend only rarely to catch the public eye. This is not (yet) America, where the pursuit of riches is lauded as vindication of the entire socio-economic and political system. Here it is only celebrity industrialists, such as Richard Branson or Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who enjoy prolonged spells in the limelight. Others only do so fleetingly, and then often for reasons of notoriety rather than success.

Most recently Greg Hutchins, former chief executive of Tomkins, springs to mind. His corporate derring-do in the 1980s never made him a tabloid name. Recent alleged abuse of the corporate expense account did. Fifteen minutes of fame indeed.

It is when the chips are down that the mettle of the entrepreneur is revealed. Fear of failure is a powerful motivating force. The actions of executives are often best understood through an analysis of the possible consequences of cock-up rather than of success.

In the quoted company arena this is manifested in corporate paranoia about falling share prices. More sellers than buyers is interpreted as disapproval of a company's strategy, a negative view of its prospects, and a vote against its management.

If I had a pound for every time a chief executive complained about the price of his company's shares, or moaned that investors misunderstood him and his company... Well, you know the story.

Company directors read far too much into the day-to-day fluctuations of their share prices. They are also prone to introspection and, as a consequence, fail to recognise the broader economic and market forces beyond their control.

A falling price is less often a vote of no confidence than they imagine. But if the pursuit of wealth does become no more than an obsessive race to make a big number bigger, a share price will stand as the ultimate arbiter of success - and a very public one at that.

Floating one's company on the stock exchange places a monetary value on an entrepreneur's success. It can also allow him to pocket some of his past work in hard cash. But a market listing brings aggravation and risk. So to choose public rather than private status is to decide not to put a tick in the "no publicity" box.

Mr Wheeler floated IG Index on the London exchange last year. This may have allowed him to make the donation announced this week - having one's wealth tied up in unquoted equity can make it difficult to write a big cheque.

The flotation was publicised with cheesy photographs of Mr Wheeler wearing a footie shirt over his pinstripes, emblazoned with his company's share price. This looks like one entrepreneur who has decided that celebrity may prove to be one motivation to stay in the race.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities.

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

webTitle: Clinton signals his aim to stay in public life

fields.headline: Clinton signals his aim to stay in public life
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: He will not have to be dragged from the White House, as some recent cartoons have suggested, but Bill Clinton leaves office just before noon today with obvious reluctance to fade away from public life.
fields.body:
He will not have to be dragged from the White House, as some recent cartoons have suggested, but Bill Clinton leaves office just before noon today with obvious reluctance to fade away from public life.

At 54, the youngest ex-US president since Teddy Roosevelt nearly a century ago will not head home to Arkansas but to a rally in New York to begin what many believe will be a liberal government in exile.

He has reportedly been studying the examples of former ex-presidents, including Roosevelt, John Quincy Adams, Herbert Hoover and Jimmy Carter, but he has not made up his mind which, if any, to emulate. He apparently admires Hoover and Carter most for their reinvention as statesmen.

Claiming to have presided over "an era of great American renewal", Mr Clinton said in a farewell speech from the White House: "My days in this office are nearly through, but my days of service, I hope, are not."

The White House said he had the day off yesterday and spent much of his time supervising the packing of his files and souvenirs, deciding which should go to the new family house in Chappaqua, New York, and which should be put into storage in Arkansas to await the construction of the Clinton library and public policy centre.

In between those duties he was reported to be padding around the carpeted corridors of power, doing what he has always done best, schmoozing, back-slapping and glad-handing at a string of staff goodbye parties.

Today Bill and Senator Hillary Clinton will smile broadly and welcome George and Laura Bush to the White House. According to the White House press secretary, Jake Siewert, they will sit down to coffee or tea for an hour, presumably making small talk about the building's domestic arrangements, before leaving for the noon inaugural ceremony in front of the Capitol building.

At 12.45, President Bush will say goodbye and the Clintons will board the presidential helicopter, normally known as Marine One but renamed Nighthawk One for this occasion, because it will no longer be transporting a president. Similarly, when the Clintons arrive at Andrews air force base for their flight to New York they will be boarding not Air Force One, but Special Air Mission One.

Mr Clinton's life as a private citizen is scheduled to begin at 3.05pm, when SAM One lands at New York's John F Kennedy airport. Here the new life will pretty much resemble the old. His supporters will gather in a huge hangar for an hour-long rally, at which the ex-president may provide more hints of his political plans before taking a helicopter ride to the New York suburbs.

As always with the Clintons, it will be glamorous affair. How sadly different it will be, however, for his faithful deputy, Al Gore, who - but for a handful of hanging chads - would be up there instead of George Bush, taking the oath of office.

Today Mr Gore will have to sit and watch it all, and then take the lonely drive across the Potomac river with his wife Tipper to the family home in Arlington, Virginia. There he will have all the time in the world to ponder what might have been.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: How do we know non-governmental organisations do the right   thing?
fields.body:
The Romans had a phrase for it: "Quis custodiet ipsos custodes?" - "Who guards the guardians?" The question implies a lack of confidence in those appointed to positions of trust - looking after public funds, for example. The question, long applied to politicians, police forces and judges, could also be applied to campaigning groups.

The proliferation of non-governmental organisations or NGOs, has been a striking trend in recent decades. And the evidence suggests that the public invests a great deal more trust in NGOs like Amnesty and Greenpeace than in politicians or business people. Research by Edelman Public Relations found almost one-third of Europeans trusting NGOs to do the right thing, with just one-fifth trusting national governments, 15% business and 11% the media. Strikingly, three-quarters of all respondents said they thought NGO influence had grown.

Fine, but how do we know that such groups do the right thing? There are various answers. One is that not-for-profit groups often have trustees with responsibility to keep things above board. But, at a time when growing numbers of companies have been responding to NGO demands for greater corporate accountability and transparency, what are NGOs doing to ensure they operate in the same goldfish bowl?

This is a question increasingly raised by business people. Where they once demanded to know who NGOs represented, now they want to know whether NGOs practise what they preach. We are not an NGO, but this is an issue to which SustainAbility became sensitive five years ago. As a founder-signatory of the International Chamber of Commerce's Business Charter for Sustainable Development in 1991, we encouraged the business world to begin environmental reporting. It took five years to realise that this also applied to us.

In 1996 we published a self-assessment report called Environmentalism Is Not Enough, reviewing our performance against the 16 ICC principles. One of these requires companies to evaluate the impact of their products and services. Products are not too difficult to deal with, but what about services? What do you measure if you are dedicated to changing people's hearts and minds?

There are few answers as yet, but a number of NGOs have produced useful environ mental reports. Forum for the Future published one recently and the UK end of World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) has just launched its first externally verified environmental report. This covers such things as emissions of greenhouse gases, but deputy chief executive Leslie Jones notes that thorny issues still to be addressed include the "service effects" and social impacts of WWF's work.

The service effects are direct environmental impacts linked with WWF's core conservation activities. But there are other issues NGOs must address. In our report we stressed the need to evolve new ways of measuring the impact of our work on the thinking and priorities of the public and client companies. The questions are on our website. But a key issue for mainstream NGOs, and increasingly for companies, relates to lobbying. Who are they lobbying, on what issues, with what outcomes in mind? In this sense, reports like WWF's are still eco-efficiency, rather than eco-effectiveness reports. Progress, certainly, but recall the case of Caesar's wife. Like NGOs, she wielded huge influence, but knew she had to be seen to be whiter than white.

 John Elkington is chairman of SustainAbility and co-author of The Global Reporters: The First International Survey of Corporate Sustainability Reporting.

The service effects are direct environmental impacts linked with WWF's core conservation activities. But there are other issues NGOs must address. In our report we stressed the need to evolve new ways of measuring the impact of our work on the thinking and priorities of the public and client companies. The questions are on our website. But a key issue for mainstream NGOs, and increasingly for companies, relates to lobbying. Who are they lobbying, on what issues, with what outcomes in mind? In this sense, reports like WWF's are still eco-efficiency, rather than eco-effectiveness reports. Progress, certainly, but recall the case of Caesar's wife. Like NGOs, she wielded huge influence, but knew she had to be seen to be whiter than white.  John Elkington is chairman of SustainAbility and co-author of The Global Reporters: The First International Survey of Corporate Sustainability Reporting.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Angus Fletcher, joint chief of the Jim Henson Television Group
fields.trailText: Angus Fletcher, joint chief of the Jim Henson Television Group.
fields.body:
How did you land your first job?

Hundreds of letters, many calls, several informal chats until I was finally given a break.

What was your first job?

Script reading for Central Television back in 1986. Without a story and a script we in television have nothing, so it was a great education.

What was your greatest mistake?

Yesterday, today or tomorrow?

Which programme would you most like to have made?

The completely wonderful Edge of Darkness, directed by Martin Campbell starring Joe Don Baker and Bob Peck; a benchmark for good drama.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

That they are better at what they do than I am. . .

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

Yes, our offices are an old conservatory-style warehouse. Seriously, what television outfit would last without a fair number of women taking charge?

What management wisdom is most over-rated?

That which does not come from an experienced practitioner.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

Broadband, the bandwidth technology which will enable video and film to be streamed down a phone line to PCs and mobile phones. A "converged" world is an easier world and will have a dramatic effect on the entire media business.

What one lesson would you pass on to trainee managers?

Learn the art of communication and put it into practice.

Who do you most respect in the industry?

Anyone who creates change and manages it successfully - the realisation of a vision.

Who is your favourite politician?

The one who thinks before he speaks.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

Excellent!

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

A cold, clear night and the five minutes before I fire a major firework show. Pure theatre: first night with no rehearsal!

What annoys you most?

Fools in high places.

How do you relax?

Designing and firing son-et-lumiere firework shows

What was your last cultural experience?

Designing and firing a son-et-lumiere to mark the new year at Alnwick Castle in Northumberland for 15,000 people.

What is your favourite city?

I don't like cities, but LA has it all: sun, sea and stretch limos.

What is your greatest regret?

Leaving my sister's teddy bear at Colombo airport in 1965, although I think I have now been forgiven!

What is your biggest fear?

That people really believe what they see on television.

What would you really like to have been?

A foreign correspondent in the mould of the late, great James Cameron.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Jules Wright's big break

fields.headline: How Miss Julie made her way in easy stages
fields.standfirst: Jules Wright came to England from Oz with a psychology degree and a love of theatre. How did this lead her into the trendy restaurant business? Michael Edmands tracks her route to the kitchen
fields.trailText: Jules Wright came to England from Oz with a psychology degree and a love of theatre. How did this lead her into the trendy restaurant business? Michael Edmands tracks her route to the kitchen.
fields.body:
Opposite the oldest pub on the Thames, the Prospect of Whitby on Wapping High Street (circa 1543) is a symbol of our Victorian industrial past. The hydraulic power station, built in 1890 and closed in l977, once lifted Tower Bridge and moved the revolving stage of the Palladium.

It stood derelict until seven years ago when a feisty educational psychologist-cum-theatrical director, Jules Wright, fell in love with it and is turning it into the Wapping Project Arts Centre. It's been a roller-coaster ride for our Miss Julie since she arrived with her husband, fleeing Australia and the draft, back in 1973.

She was adopted by a family from a suburb of Adelaide called Birkenhead "very much like the one in England", she says. She was always a bright child: "I was spoiled by my grandmother but sadly never knew my grandfather." He was George Grandison, Australian hero and first world war Victoria Cross winner. Dad was a boilermaker in the docks and a strong union man.

"In school I was very good at science but by the time I was 14 had discovered the lure of the footlights when I was chosen for the school play," she says. "I just loved being on the stage and I met Joshua, a star hockey player, who was 16 and one day would be my husband. I had made these rock cakes and Josh polished them all off."

At Adelaide university she studied educational psychology. "I was the first in the family to go to university and it was very important to them. They all looked up to the teaching profession and so that's the path I set out on," she says. She married Joshua a year later when she was 19. "He was studying to be an architect but the Vietnam war was on and he thought he might be drafted, so we decided to come to England," she says.

When Joshua was offered a job in Bristol they jumped at the chance. But not before Ms Wright had applied to RADA and had been accepted but let it lapse. "We were a bit frightened of London, I just couldn't believe how big it was after Adelaide," she says. In Bristol she found a postgraduate drama course at the University with just one place available and got it. "I was still stage-struck and when you have a dream, you must take steps to make it come true," she says.

Clutching her PhD she headed back to London and her break. Joan Littlewood's successor at the Stratford East, Claire Venables, was looking for an Arts Council trainee to learn directing. "That's when I became Jules," Ms Wright says. "I was already using my given name Julie on my Commonwealth grant for my PhD." After learning the ropes on tour, she was given the chance to direct on the main stage and while there was noticed by the Royal Court.

"I jumped at the chance because it was another working-class theatre. I had grown up listening to my father's politics and union meetings at the house. I felt empathy with what was happening at Stratford East and the Royal Court," she says. Out of this background she started up, with associates like Glenda Jackson, the Women's Playhouse Trust to put on controversial plays in the West End. "We were always funded privately," she says, "But we had lots of interest from young Tory investors from the City who put up some of the money."

By 1988 she decided the trust had a rock-solid base and began to look at property to fix up and to sell for the cause. She says: "Just don't get the idea I find golden apples. I work really hard." It paid off when London Docklands Development Corp came looking for someone to encourage the arts as part of the redevelopment of the rejuvenated area.

"They drove me around to all sorts of places. By the afternoon I was weary, but they said just see this last one. I looked around this ancient disused power station full of machinery and covered in moss and said to myself 'I've gotta have this place'. " With her full-of-beans Aussie personality she haggled the price down to £750,000, although it will eventually take £4m to complete the exhibition and performance space. The architects are SHED 54 headed by Joshua Wright.

"We have fantastic spaces and plan a small theatre and a jazz club. The restaurant will turn over nearly £1m this year. But we also don't want to tear everything down. We want to leave the marks of those who once worked here," she says.

fields.headline: Getting to the business angels
fields.trailText: Also known as informal venture capitalists, business angels are people looking to invest in high-growth, early-stage businesses at the pre-flotation phase.
fields.body:
Also known as informal venture capitalists, business angels are people looking to invest in high-growth, early-stage businesses at the pre-flotation phase. A study carried out at Southampton University recently showed that since 1997 more than £600m has been invested by angels in more than 600 businesses.

It also found that investors who are part of the National Business Angels Network, a dating agency which matches investor with a business seeking capital, have up to £70m to invest.

Angels rarely invest less than £50,000 or more than £1.5m and, as they tend to take a personal interest in the business, they generally invest in companies within a 50-mile radius of their area. The investors also tend to be sector specific, with IT, internet, telecoms and scientific or technical instrument manufacturers being the most popular. "The average investment is for 36 months because the tax breaks kick in after three years. The individual can give advice, although this does not have to be followed, and indeed most angels take a non-exec directorship, so they are legally committed to the business," says Michael Harmer, NBAN spokesman. More than 60% of angels are millionaires.

"The great trick is to get an angel who is long on the strengths on which you are short, so you can work together rather than trying to fight. They tend to be cashed-out entrepreneurs who have made their money and are in it for the adventure, for the sheer buzz, as much as for a return on capital," he says.

Individuals need to produce a business plan which will then have to be approved by a partner of the NBAN, some of whom charge for the service and others who are not-for-profit organisations which do not. For £150 the national organisation will then advertise the business in its monthly bulletin, which is distributed to all potential investors, and its website.

This month's publication features businesses such as a computer games development firm in London which needs £300,000 and would like an angel with financial marketing or sales experience and in return for a negotiable equity stake; an East Anglian genealogical research agency which is seeking £70,000 and a growing narrow boat operator in the west midlands in need of a capital injection of £60,000.

The Southampton University survey also found that some potential investors eventually shy away from making a financial commitment because the business plans contained unrealistic expectations, the entrepreneurs lacked credibility or the growth prospects for the business were too limited.

"This underlines the need for business angel networks to focus more effort on getting businesses 'investor ready' before promoting them to investors," says Professor Colin Mason of the university.

 National Business Angels Network, tel 020 7329 2929.

Princely sums as a last resort

The Prince's Trust calls itself a "lender of last resort" for 18 to 30-year-olds whose loan requests have been turned down by a bank. But it also encourages applications for money from disabled people, ex-offenders and ethnic minorites: this year people from each of these groups accounted for 30% of all applications approved.

Provided the person has a solid business plan, has conducted market research and manages to convince a panel that they have the determination and ability to carry the plan through, the Trust is very open-minded about the kinds of businesses which it funds; anything from internet start-ups to yoga schools.

"We fund a business in East Anglia run by a man taking peregrine falcons to places with a problem with pigeons and seagulls. He unleashes them and the pigeons fly off. A man running another of our businesses discovered that battery chickens, usually killed once they have stopped laying, start laying again if you put them back into the open and feed them. So he gets his chickens free and sells the eggs: it's ecologically friendly and makes a profit," says John Attree, executive director of the Trust's business division.

Loans are for a maximum of £5,000 and have to be repaid in equal instalments over three years at 3%, although from next April repayments over the first six months can be just £20 a month. There is also the possibility of a grant of up to £1,500 and a grant may also be given for market research.

Businesses are also assigned a mentor, someone with enterprise experience or other specialist knowledge, with whom they meet regularly and to whom they have to file basic monthly accounts. "On average, 60% of Prince's Trust businesses are still trading in the third year," says Mr Attree.

Small can be bountiful

The Small Business Service, spun off from the DTI earlier this year, administers a number of schemes which offer funding for start-ups.

The Small Firms Loan Guarantee Scheme was set up in 1981 to help businesses with a viable proposition which have been refused funding by a bank. Since then it has overseen 71,000 loans totalling around £2.5bn. The loans are available from between two and 10 years and for £5,000 to £100,000 through a standard lender (banks or venture financiers) with the SBS providing the lender with the necessary backing. In return for guaranteeing 70% of the loan, the business pays an extra 1.5% (or just 0.5% if a fixed-rate interest loan is chosen) a year on the amount outstanding. To be eligible, your business must be UK-based and with an annual turnover of no more than £1.5m, or £3m if you are a manufacturer.

SBS Smart Awards are designed to help people convert a good business idea into a commercial reality. Past recipients have included businesses developing airport runway lighting systems, a new kind of hedge cutter and a business which has developed an improved system to detect faults in tyres. The awards are aimed more at product research, develop ment and marketing rather than general business management. For feasibility studies Smart provides grants of up to £45,000, while development projects are given up to 30% of costs to a maximum of £150,000. To be eligible companies must employ fewer than 50 people or 250 employees if a development grant is being applied for.

 Small Business Service, tel: 020 7215 5363 or Business Advice Online

Where else to go

Shell livewire
This is a business support service for young entrepreneurs (aged 16-30) which is sponsored by Shell. It gives information on business planning, provides a networking service and offers a £10,000 prize for the start-up of the year; previous winners have included the group who make Innocent smoothie drinks.

DTI Biotechnology Finance Advisory Service
The DTI Biotechnology Finance Advisory Service provides free advice on funding to biotechnology entrepreneurs. It will identify potential sources of private sector funds and appropriate government grants.

DTI Enterprise Grant
This is another DTI initiative, this time to fund small businesses in Enterprise Grant areas. Up to 15% of fixed capital costs - that is, expenditure on equipment, machinery and buildings -may be granted. The maximum grant is £75,000 and high growth businesses which will provide jobs for the area are favoured. Your business case must show that the company could not trade without the money.

webTitle: College coup: New home next door to Tate

fields.headline: College coup: New home next door to Tate
fields.trailText: When all the silver came out and the myriad chandeliers blazed, passersby used to gaze up wondering if the sumptuous riverside rooms were some millionaire's playground.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
When all the silver came out and the myriad chandeliers blazed, passersby used to gaze up wondering if the sumptuous riverside rooms were some millionaire's playground.

In fact, the vast rooms, divided by a 20ft high folding screen of carved solid oak, were an army mess, part of a site off limits to the public for over a century, the Army Medical College (above), next door to Tate Britain at Millbank in London. Work will soon begin to transform it into a new home for the Chelsea College of Art.

Colin Cina, head of the Chelsea college, paces the oak panelled rooms trying not to feel smug. After six months of agonising, the government decided just before Christmas to accept the £32m bid from the college for the listed buildings.

There had been a feeding frenzy among property developers to get hold of the site, being disposed of by the Ministry of Defence.

In the end it came down to two bids: the college versus one of the richest men in the world, the Aga Khan, who wanted to create an Islamic cultural and study centre.

The development will transform the site, through an ambitious joint programme with the Tate.

When the security fence comes down the parade ground, which has been a car park for decades, and the narrow road dividing the two institutions will be landscaped as a sculpture park. There are plans for open air arts events.

The Chelsea college is at present scattered across four sites. The medical college buildings will bring all the students and staff together for the first time.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Alternative ways to invest

fields.headline: Free enterprise - if you can afford it
fields.standfirst: Banks have turned you down, venture capitalists think you're too small so how do you bring your business brainwave to life? Liz Stuart looks elsewhere for finance
fields.trailText: Banks have turned you down, venture capitalists think you're too small so how do you bring your business brainwave to life? Liz Stuart looks elsewhere for finance.
fields.body:
You have been to the bank but your credit rating is too poor and you do not have sufficient business experience to get a loan. You've braved a venture capital group, but they tell you that their minimum lending is £3m, while you only want to borrow £150,000.

So what is the next step if you are one of the 1.4m people (one in adult in 30) looking to fund a small business start-up without your own personal fortune?

There are sources of cash if traditional lending channels are closed to you. Wealthy individuals looking for some entrepreneurial excitement can become business angels overnight and a source of seed corn capital. Body Shop founder Anita Roddick famously started up her Sussex - based business with a loan from such a person.

Trusts and grants from bodies promoting economic regeneration in a specific geographical area are another source of funding, along with organisations such as the Prince's Trust which explicitly promotes itself as a lender of last resort, with added extras, such as the assigning of a business mentor to help weather the storms of the first few years of trading.

If a new government initiative unveiled this week is to be taken at face value, there could be no better time than now to set up a firm of your own. The idea behind the Think Small First is that by 2005 the UK will be the best place in the world to start a business.

This rather nebulous ideal will be backed by a package of information, support, access to consultancy services and enterprise training, with more than 30 governmental departments signing up to it, including some with no immediate connection with enterprise, such as the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries and the Department of Culture, Media and Sport.

David Irwin, chief executive of the Small Business Service says: "There is no doubt that finance is the number one issue for small businesses. You've braved a venture capital group, but they tell you that their minimum lending is £3m, while you only want to borrow £150,000. fields.headline: Kabarett celebrates subversive century
fields.trailText: This should have been a very special week for Berlin. Thursday saw the 100th anniversary of the city's first cabaret performance.
fields.body:
This should have been a very special week for Berlin. Thursday saw the 100th anniversary of the city's first cabaret performance.

Yet the date might have gone by unmarked had it not been for the promptings of a British academic, Joanne McNally, who wrote a paper three years ago noting that the anniversary was approaching and suggesting what might be done about it.

In the end, academics from around the world flew to Berlin for a symposium, there was an exhibition on the first 15 years of cabaret and there was a live show with stars from all over Germany - yet the event was so strapped for cash that the performers gave their services free.

What that shows us about Berlin, I suspect, is that its tourist authorities are unable to see what it is about the city that is of interest to others.

What it shows about cabaret - or more correctly Kabarett - is that it has managed to keep a suitably uneasy relationship with the authorities and business.

Authentic German cabaret is performed satire and the German language makes a clear distinction between Kabarett and cabaret - which takes in everything from variety shows to erotic spectacle.

Kabarett can include stand-up comedy - jokes about the foreign minister Joschka Fischer's firebrand past were popular this week - sketches, song and dance and even poems.

It has survived Nazism and Communism. In East Germany, where kabarett was immensely popular, performers were encouraged to poke fun at the west, but they also targeted their Communist masters - a dangerous pursuit during the cold war.

There was even Kabarett in the concentration camps. Some of the best pre-war performers were Jewish, and sometimes shows were put on in an attempt to raise the morale of their fellow inmates. At other times, it seems, they were held at the behest of their guards. Much of the evidence has been brought together in a documentary to be screened in Berlin tomorrow. Its German name means "Death Dance".

The programme notes explain that almost none of those who joked in the shadow of the gas ovens survived to joke again.

webTitle: Leader: Twins should return to the US

fields.headline: Time to go home
fields.standfirst:
The twins should be returned to the US

Special report: Babies for sale
fields.trailText: The twins should be returned to the US.
fields.body:
Belatedly, the battle over the infant twins has finally begun to concentrate on the two people who should have been the focus from the very beginning: the babies. An emergency protection order, which will last for eight days with a possible extension for seven more, has been approved by a magistrate. The twins are in the care of Flintshire social services, pending a review by the high court on what should happen to these infant American citizens.

Until now, the media has been overwhelmingly concerned with the needs and rights of five adults - four who wanted to adopt the children, and a fifth, the natural mother who gave them up. Alan and Judith Kilshaw, the British couple who obtained an Arkansas adoption order, were still conducting their media circus yesterday. They spoke of their "sleepless night" since losing their babies, of the trauma of the empty room and of how much they loved them.

ut by seeming to have more love for the media than for the children, they have lost public support. In a TV poll yesterday, the public voted two to one in favour of placing the babies in care. One abiding image of this saga was the sight of the twins in their separate cots, pushed to the wall of the Kilshaws' hotel bedroom to make room for the television teams. Intervention had to be early, if it was to be effective. The longer the delay, the greater disruption the twins could suffer.

The best place to untangle the multiple party claims and varied jurisdictions is the high court. Strong signals have been sent by a senior Arkansas judge that the American adoption order could be invalid because of lies by the birth mother. That would effectively end the Kilshaws' claims and open the way to the babies being returned to the US, which is where they ought to be. Had the UK ratified the Hague convention, the Kilshaws could have been stopped from bringing them here.

In the US, a rising proportion of adoption deals (almost 40%) are private. Here, they are rightly banned. The convention would stop unsuitable couples from exploiting private deals overseas. This sad saga shows just what can happen when adoption procedures fail to put children first.

fields.headline: The ex-wives club
fields.standfirst: Perhaps there's something to be said for looking like the Ugly Sisters' mastiff
fields.trailText: Perhaps there's something to be said for looking like the Ugly Sisters' mastiff
fields.body:
"Dulcie and I really bonded while you were away, Gordon! Didn't we, Dulcie?" Elaine turns to me, glowing. She's had her roots re-done. Her eyes sparkle Caribbean blue. The thick mascara, the pearl stud earrings - just a minute! Is she turning into a Diana, while I increasingly resemble a hound? I shrug.

"Whatever bonding means." In our case it meant going to bed together. Nothing sapphic. We were just drunk and cold. Gordon rolls his eyes fastidiously at the thought of his ex-wives bonding. But the aunt beams. She evidently enjoyed her Highland fling.

"Did you see the cathedral where Madonna was married, Auntie?" I enquire, settling the aunt in her favourite armchair.

"Och no, but I did see it all in the magazine. Elaine, dearrr , sometimes you look a bit like Madonna. Don't you think so, Gorrrdon ?"

He shrugs. Elaine looks crushed. Aunt pities Elaine. And I must rush to the rescue, because I have taken the aunt's penny, although, to be honest, I loved her extravagantly long before the cheque. "I remember Gordon saying Elaine looked a bit like Marilyn Monroe," I lie. Elaine is mollified, aunt satisfied. Gordon glares at me. The cash-for-questions scandal was nothing. They should try cash-for-compliments. Uneasy lies the tongue that took the bung.

We all sit down to tea together. "Shall I be mother?" offers Elaine deferentially. "It's a heavy teapot, and Dulcie's been complaining about arthritis in her wrist."

" Arrrthrrritis?! " Aunt pounces. "You must trrry my copperrr brrracelet! "

"Actually, the arthritis is in my big toe," I confess - which is why I have to wear schoolmarmish lace-ups all the time. Elaine wears twinkly little red shoes with a sexy heel. Aunt stares sadly at my feet. She wishes there was a pair of copper shoes she could offer.

Suddenly recall horrid fairy tale about a young girl who puts on a pair of red shoes, and then cannot stop dancing, dancing, dancing, until her feet have to be cut off. Wonder if this is symbolic of the relentless treadmill of youth and beauty, which arrives with the menarche? If so, perhaps there is something to be said for looking like the Ugly Sisters' faithful old mastiff, while Elaine queens it in the Cinderella role.

The aunt pats my hand with her aged claw, upon which the veins, age spots and purple patches mingle as in a rather beautiful old tapestry. Yes! The beauty of antiquity! Put that in your pipe and smoke it, Elaine, you ravishing young git! Smile ingratiatingly at aunt, exposing my long, brown teeth, like the pipes of some 17th-century organ gleaming in the gloaming. I shall become a trainee great aunt myself.

"Oh dear!" sighs Elaine, perhaps sensing a disadvantage, "I feel so terrible, descending on you like this - outstaying my welcome. You've been so kind to us, Dulcie, in our hour of need - homeless!" The blue eyes swim beneath the mascara. "Abandoned by Tom! I still can't believe it!" Tears fall. The aunt soothes. Gordon switches on the TV, selects Teletext, and scans the sports results - a male attempt at therapy.

"Henry's away for the whole term!" I assure Elaine swiftly. "You can have his room for as long as you like."

Harriet returns from the park with little Sandy, who cuddles up to his mother. Mother and Child with Lolly - a subject sanctified by centuries of great art.

Phone rings, and Harriet announces, "It's Tom." Elaine rushes to the phone and plunges into a frenzy of furious effing and blinding. Aunt looks offended.

Gordon turns the TV sound up. I hustle Harriet into the kitchen. "What's it worth to have a no swearing rule?" I whisper. Harriet names her sum and the deal is done. We shall woo the aunt with delicate utterance. Elaine stands revealed as a foul-mouthed slut.

"Don't worry, Mum!" Harriet embraces me. "I'm sure Dad'll never go back to Elaine. It's obvious he finds her todally, like, embarrassing. And anyway you're still pretty, so there!" Wires disastrously crossed, but accept the dear girl's loyal hug with gratitude.

But were Gordon and Elaine to go off together again, that would get them out of my hair and aunt's sympathies would return to me in trumps. Because then I'd be the poignant abandoned one. Make urgent plans to slip some testosterone into Gordon's tea.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Pensions and taxation

fields.headline: Crunch time for carry forward
fields.standfirst: Personal plan-holders take note: a useful tool is about to disappear. Rachel Stevenson reports
fields.trailText: Personal plan-holders take note: a useful tool is about to disappear. Rachel Stevenson reports.
fields.body:
A valuable tax planning tool vanishes on April 5, when the rule allowing personal pension-holders to "carry forward" surplus tax relief to a subsequent tax year ends.

Most people with personal pensions do not make the maximum contributions they are entitled to, perhaps because of cash flow problems or not having enough ready money for a lump-sum contribution.

But in a year when you do have the extra cash for your pension you can make your maximum contribution and then make up six years of unused relief from past years. This can be useful for personal pension purchasers with volatile earnings - anyone from authors to actors or those who might have big bonuses one year and very little the next.

This process, confusingly, is called carry forward. From April 6 2001 you will no longer be able to carry forward unused contributions. But you will continue to be able to "carry back" contributions. This is where you can treat a payment as if it had been made in the last tax year, which is useful if you were previously a lower rate tax payer.

You must fully make all the contributions for the current year before you can carry forward any previous years. You can then go back six years and calculate any unused relief - the difference between the maximum contribution and that already paid.

Independent financial adviser William Sallitt of Carrington Investment Consultants says people thinking about using carry forward should not wait until the last minute, but take advantage of the lull in the equity market.

"With the current low stock market levels and imminent changes in pension legislation, people should seriously consider taking advantage of 'carry-back/carry-forward' before it is too late," he says. "There is a bit of paperwork to do, but an accountant or IFA should be able to help and give advice on how much you can realistically invest."

But Mr Sallitt says be sure to get your request in early as many advisers are bombarded on the last day of the tax year with people deciding to invest. You have to know your earnings for this and previous years. The tax relief depends on your tax status in the year you make the contribution, not the years in which you have unused relief.

The changes only relate to personal pensions. They do not affect those with the old-style retirement annuity policies (also known as section 226 plans) sold before April 1988.

It is possible to pay a contribution before April 6 and carry this back to 1999-00. Doing this now will mean the contribution is treated as being in the 99-00 tax year, where the rate of relief is 23% instead of the current 22%.

Pension consultant Gary Ford at IFA Wentworth Rossays: "Combine this with carry forward relief and you can use up all unused relief from 93-94. But you must submit your claim before January 31 2002."

Rethink your risk profile

At a time when the government is trying to increase funding in pension plans through its low charging stakeholder product, the closure of Equitable Life to new business and the subsequent likely fall-off in likely investment returns has left a lot people wanting reassurance that pensions are a safe investment.

IFA Tom McPhail of Torquil Clark says: "A pension is not some strange mythical beast. It is just an investment with special tax treatment. Anyone who doesn't understand how pensions and with-profits funds work should really get some advice."

He advises people with little pension experience to look at lifestyle investment strategy.

Your pension will then follow a simple risk profile, which is traditionally equities when you are reasonably young and have little to lose, managed funds in middle age for more security, and the safety of gilts and cash in the run-up to retirement.

Web link-ups

Online information fund information provider trustnet.com is launching a new, free, service to help investors get to grips with venture capital trusts - tax saving funds which invest in start-up and other new companies.

Nearly £1bn has been invested in the 50 or so VCTs launched so far and the site gives details on each, including links to each VCT's website.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Ways to save

fields.headline: A baker's dozen to bring you a prosperous financial new year
fields.trailText: There's a lot to do before the end of the tax year to take best advantage of inland revenue concessions. Here's a quick baker's dozen of ways to save money:
fields.body:
There's a lot to do before the end of the tax year to take best advantage of inland revenue concessions. Here's a quick baker's dozen of ways to save money:

 Check your inland revenue PAYE tax codes - make sure allowances are claimed.

 Think about topping up your company pension using additional voluntary contributions (AVC). Personal pension purchasers should use carry forward and carry back rules.

 Make sure the business mileage of your company car exceeds the 2,500 - or 18,000-mile limits. Tax rates are lower above those two bands.

 If your employer pays towards your petrol costs, it might be better if it ceases to do so from April 6.

 If you have money on deposit which you may need to withdraw at a moment's notice, why not put it in a cash mini Isa? (As long as you're not taking out a maxi Isa.) It will earn a better rate of interest, tax-free.

 Think about rolling over a maturing Tessa into a Tessa-only Isa to keep growing those tax-free benefits.

 Why not move your investments into the name of a spouse or partner? This will ensure you both use up your personal allowances and basic-rate bands for income and capital gains.

 Use the "bed and Isa technique", a way of using up your annual £7,200 capital gains tax exemption. Shares can be bought by a third party such as an Isa - or even your spouse.

 You don't have to be a millionaire to take advantage of the enterprise investment scheme (EIS) - minimum subscriptions start at around £2,000 a year. You invest directly into growing businesses, getting 20% income tax relief plus tax-free gains. But there can be big risks.

 Top-rate taxpayers can claim back higher-rate tax on donations to registered charities under Gift Aid. If you paid £78, the charity would claim back £22, while you could claim £40. Once you register with a charity, or the umbrella Charities Aid Foundation, future payments to that good cause are outside the tax net.

 Reduce inheritance tax bills with potentially exempt transfers. These include the £3,000 annual transfer (plus the unused amount from the previous year), £250 a year to any number of people, and limited gifts on marriage.

 While a £2m donation to your favourite political party may be beyond your means, you can at least reduce your inheritance tax liability by making a donation now.

To winkle out potentially trivial causes (cynics might say they all are) the party you give to must have either two MPs in the House of Commons, or one MP and at least 150,000 votes at the last general election.

Besides the big three, this includes the Scottish Nationalists, Plaid Cymru, the Ulster Unionists, SDLP, DUP and Sinn Fein. It does not include the Greens or the UK Independence party.

 You can claim tax relief against rent received on furnished accommodation in your own house under the rent a room scheme. The allowance for the current tax year is £4,250.

If you rent out property elsewhere, don't forget you can claim 10% of the rent received against tax as a wear and tear allowance.

Time for a Tessa treat

Savers can take a one-way, tax-free bet on the stock market by rolling over maturing Tessas into special shares-linked accounts. But they are few and far between.

HSBC's Performance Plus Isa promises returns linked to the UK stock market, with maximum tax-free gains of 60% possible over the five-year life of the product.

The previous issue turned £9,000 into around £13,950.

And Birmingham Midshires is also following the shares route. Its equity-linked Isa will track the performance of the FTSE-100 over the five-year investment period, after which customers who have kept the product will be eligible for a return of up to 100% of FTSE-100 growth.

Both HSBC and Birmingham Midshires promise to repay the original capital if share prices fall.

Personal pension purchasers should use carry forward and carry back rules.  Make sure the business mileage of your company car exceeds the 2,500 - or 18,000-mile limits. Tax rates are lower above those two bands.  If your employer pays towards your petrol costs, it might be better if it ceases to do so from April 6.  If you have money on deposit which you may need to withdraw at a moment's notice, why not put it in a cash mini Isa? (As long as you're not taking out a maxi Isa.) It will earn a better rate of interest, tax-free.  Think about rolling over a maturing Tessa into a Tessa-only Isa to keep growing those tax-free benefits.  Why not move your investments into the name of a spouse or partner? This will ensure you both use up your personal allowances and basic-rate bands for income and capital gains.  Use the "bed and Isa technique", a way of using up your annual £7,200 capital gains tax exemption. Shares can be bought by a third party such as an Isa - or even your spouse.  You don't have to be a millionaire to take advantage of the enterprise investment scheme (EIS) - minimum subscriptions start at around £2,000 a year. You invest directly into growing businesses, getting 20% income tax relief plus tax-free gains. But there can be big risks.  Top-rate taxpayers can claim back higher-rate tax on donations to registered charities under Gift Aid. If you paid £78, the charity would claim back £22, while you could claim £40. Once you register with a charity, or the umbrella Charities Aid Foundation, future payments to that good cause are outside the tax net.  Reduce inheritance tax bills with potentially exempt transfers. These include the £3,000 annual transfer (plus the unused amount from the previous year), £250 a year to any number of people, and limited gifts on marriage.  While a £2m donation to your favourite political party may be beyond your means, you can at least reduce your inheritance tax liability by making a donation now. To winkle out potentially trivial causes (cynics might say they all are) the party you give to must have either two MPs in the House of Commons, or one MP and at least 150,000 votes at the last general election. Besides the big three, this includes the Scottish Nationalists, Plaid Cymru, the Ulster Unionists, SDLP, DUP and Sinn Fein. It does not include the Greens or the UK Independence party.  You can claim tax relief against rent received on furnished accommodation in your own house under the rent a room scheme. The allowance for the current tax year is £4,250. If you rent out property elsewhere, don't forget you can claim 10% of the rent received against tax as a wear and tear allowance. Time for a Tessa treat Savers can take a one-way, tax-free bet on the stock market by rolling over maturing Tessas into special shares-linked accounts. But they are few and far between. HSBC's Performance Plus Isa promises returns linked to the UK stock market, with maximum tax-free gains of 60% possible over the five-year life of the product. The previous issue turned £9,000 into around £13,950. And Birmingham Midshires is also following the shares route. Its equity-linked Isa will track the performance of the FTSE-100 over the five-year investment period, after which customers who have kept the product will be eligible for a return of up to 100% of FTSE-100 growth. Both HSBC and Birmingham Midshires promise to repay the original capital if share prices fall.

fields.headline: The Questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Melinda Messenger
fields.trailText: Melinda Messenger
fields.body:
Melinda Messenger was born in Swindon in 1971. She worked in marketing before becoming a Page Three model. She has acted, and is a television presenter for ITV's Baby Baby and Channel 5's Fort Boyard. Her video, The Melinda Messenger Back Into Shape Workout, was recently released. She is married with one son, and has homes in London and Wiltshire.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Walking through fields on a fresh day for as long as I want.

What is your greatest fear?
The dark. I've hated it since I was little.

What vehicles do you own?
A BMW tourer five series (whatever that means, but Wayne [her husband] assures me it's an important detail.)

What makes you depressed?
Lack of kindness to others.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
I try not to dislike anything, as it all has a useful purpose.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Biting off my split ends.

What is your favourite smell?
Toast, and the morning air.

What is your favourite book?
Illusions, by Richard Bach.

How did you vote in the last election?
Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?
Not sure yet. It depends on who will benefit the country the most.

Should the royal family be scrapped?
They shouldn't be scrapped, but they should pay more taxes to contribute.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
No - if one innocent person dies then we are all liable for capital punishment.

For what cause would you die?
I would die to protect my son.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes, but I don't believe it's in human nature to be monogamous.

Have you ever said, 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes - but because I wanted to mean it.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Being able to fly - I could go anywhere at any time and make enough money to retire.

What keeps you awake at night?
Indigestion.

How would you like to die?
Old and happy, and after I've said goodbye to everyone I want to.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
To take nothing for granted and never to assume, and to take pleasure in the 'real' things in life.

fields.headline: Rollover to hit the jackpot
fields.standfirst: Maximise your gains by reinvesting maturing accounts, writes Nick Pandya
fields.trailText: Maximise your gains by reinvesting maturing accounts, writes Nick Pandya.
fields.body:
Astute savers who in 1991 took advantage of John Major's invention while chancellor - the tax exempt special savings accounts (Tessas) - are now getting ready for some tasty returns.

The gains are safe as well as being outside the income tax net, unlike many investments in stock market-related funds.

But the returns already chalked up and the amount savers could get by reinvesting now vary immensely - it could be the difference between Gucci and the Grattans catalogue.

According to a survey by HSBC Bank, 4m Tessa investors don't know the rules on reinvesting maturing funds and could lose the tax break if they do not reinvest their funds within six months of maturity.

One way Tessa holders approaching maturity have to preserve the tax-free status of their investment is by putting their maturing funds into a Tessa-only Isa.

One top-paying Tessa-only Isa that allows instant access to your money is available from Britannia building society, which currently pays 6.85% on a deposit of just £1.

The Northern Rock has a similar account paying 7.05% but savers have to give 30 days' notice to make a withdrawal. For savers with at least £1,000 the Portman building society pays a fraction more at 7.3% but demands 45 days' notice.

Maturing Tessa funds do not affect other tax-free Isas so investors are also entitled to save up to £7,000 in a year in a stand-alone Isa. That means that someone with a Tessa maturing this year can stash up to £16,000 away in tax-free savings.

But with big gaps between best and the worst - smaller building societies have the best performance record - rolling over an old Tessa lets savers take a new, and penalty-free, look at where their money is deposited.

Moving your Tessa to an alternative provider should be painless. Firstly withdraw your Tessa savings at maturity, asking your old bank to give you a cheque made payable to your new bank. And more importantly, ask your old bank for a Tessa maturity certificate, then go to the bank or building society where you want to open a new Tessa-only Isa.

Once the capital - a maximum £9,000 - has been reinvested, savers have to think about what to do with the interest, which cannot go into a Tessa replacement.

One potential tax-free home is the mini cash Isa, where interest grows without any inland revenue involvement. This has a £3,000 limit - roughly in line with the tax-free interest gained over the past five years in most Tessas.

But there are drawbacks. You will not be able to take out a maxi Isa in that year, because under Isa rules you cannot hold a mini and a maxi Isa in the same tax year.

But should you choose to invest in a Tessa-only Isa, you can still invest the maximum £7,000 in a maxi stocks and shares-linked Isa.

Mini cash Isa rules are more flexible than Tessas, which stipulated that you leave your capital untouched for five years. With an Isa, there is no such requirement, so you are free to withdraw your money as you wish.

But remember that withdrawing cash has an impact on how much you can invest in the rest of the tax year. If you want to open a mini cash Isa, you have until April 5.
