fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.standfirst: Sauvignons to savour and Riojas to relish
fields.trailText: Sauvignons to savour and Riojas to relish
fields.body:
All those readers who emailed me via the website (superplonk.com) before Christmas would have been better advised to have sent smoke signals or carrier pigeons. I got the messages and replied, well in time (I thought) for Christmas. Unfortunately, instead of entering in a subject for each one, as I later found out I am meant to do when sending missives direct from the website, I left the 'subject' box empty as usual, and all my responses became suspended in cyberspace. Coming to terms with the new millennium and its seductive marvels is not as congenial as I thought. I'm sorry. It won't happen again.

Let us also hope that the kind of vintages that New Zealand endured in 1998 and 1999 are also things of the past. El Niño was held responsible for all the warm nights that frustrated the build-up of the lovely mineral acids that this blessed nation's sauvignon blancs enjoy, but the 2000 vintage promises, with certain vineyards, a return to form. Not all vineyards, though - Cloudy Bay's Sauvignon 2000 I cannot rate higher than 14.5 points out of 20 (it is available at around £12 from regional wine merchants). Dashwood Sauvignon Blanc 2000, at £6.99, however, is much more exciting and rates 17 points. There is more dash than wood, of course - the fruit is balanced, subtly rich, finely acidic - and there's a wonderfully classy finish. Oddbins has it, as it does another fascinating white, Chateau de Nages Cuvée Joseph Torres Blanc Costières de Nimes 1998 (16.5 points, £6.99), which has a subtle, smoky edge and even some nice pale tannins. From Argentina, Oddbins has Vina Amalia Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £6.99), which is very open and full of rich, good-hearted cheer.

Two terrific Oddbins reds are Vino Nobile di Montepulciano Fattori del Cerro 1997 (17 points, £7.49) and Aradon Rioja 1999 (16.5 points, £4.49). The Italian is joyously jammy yet complexly original and so beguilingly well-textured (fine tannins, here) that it defines what red wine of a certain type is. An alien visitor enquiring, 'What is wine?' can confidently be given a glass of this and nothing more need be said. The rioja is a simply wonderful specimen - juicy yet dry, joyous yet serious, soft yet not gooey.

At Somerfield, you don't pay Oddbins prices - but then, you don't get Oddbins wines (or arts graduates in jeans to make you feel ancient). Somerfield has Trivento Syrah 1999 (16 points, on offer at £2.99 until January 30), from Argentina, which offers tannins, tension, fruit, style, and personality - at less than three quid, this is a minor masterpiece. Argentine Sangiovese 2000 (16.5 points, on offer at £3.29 until January 30) is also superbly gluggable.

Montepulciano d'Abruzzo 1998 (14 points, on offer at £2.99 until January 30) is a fruit-packed missile to throw at parties, as is the mildly lemony Vin de Pays des Chateaux de l'Ardeche Blanc 1999 (14.5 points, £2.29 until January 30) - and, no, that £2.29 is not a printing error. More substantial, on Somerfield's white side, is Argentine Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, on offer at £3.29 until January 30), which has wonderfully rich, buttery fruit and an almost savoury depth. Somerfield also has Cono Sur Pinot Noir 1999 (16.5 points, £4.99, also at Tesco and Asda), from Chile, which is extraordinary for the money. The aroma is of wild raspberries and truffles, the fruit has touches of cassis and morello cherry, and the finish recalls the farmyard. I've encountered £100 Richebourgs with less feel for what pinot is about.

Tesco has Isla Negra Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (16.5 points, £5.49), from Chile, which, thanks to its rich tannins, is gorgeously meaty without being too gravy-like. Goiya Giaan 1999 (16 points, £3.99, at Tesco and Safeway), from South Africa, is very ripe and rich, firmly textured, and parades delicious plums, blackcurrants and spice. It really gushes with flavour while managing to retain a serious depth. A very entertaining Italian white at certain branches of Tesco is 'I Portali' Basilicata Greco 1999 (16 points, £4.99), a splendidly vigorous chardonnay of dry, mineral freshness and rich crispness, offering a rewardingly individual approach to an increasingly gimmickly vinified (and packaged) grape.

fields.headline: The Knowledge
fields.standfirst: Time
fields.trailText: Time
fields.body:
The subject
'The indefinite continued progress of existence, events, etc, in past, present and future regarded as a whole; the progress of this as affecting persons or things' (Concise Oxford Dictionary). Cooks need to worry about the part after the semicolon.

The basics
You have two ways of knowing how long something needs to cook: experience or instruction. It's more likely to be a combination of the two. But what if...

The details
...the experience is deficient? Fear not, mon brave. Good instruction will fill the gap. Timings: an approximate figure. Essential supplement: a precise description of what you're aiming for. But does it always come that way? Ha! Here's a snippet from Rick Stein's Fruits Of The Sea: 'add the monkfish and fry for three minutes.' Now, does that mean exactly three minutes, not three-and-a-half, even if our fish is thicker or colder? Does it also mean that we have to use the same hob that Mr Stein used, and the same pan? If not, the Knowledge thinks we should be told. At the very least, we should be told how the fish might look when its three minutes of flame have ended. And this example of imprecision masquerading as precision is just one of hundreds in the Knowledge cookbook library. Briefly: time, in recipes, don't mean nothin'. A chef once replied, when asked how long he cooked a certain dish, 'Till it's done.'

Where to buy
Time is not sold in any shop. Some people live on the borrowed version. But most kitchens are chock-a-block with timers on ovens, microwaves, etc. If you need reinforcements, digital timers (beep, beep, beep) can be bought any place.

The easy way out
Ignore recipes and learn, as Elizabeth David puts it, to rely on 'the evidence of your five senses'.

fields.headline: Make mine a ...
fields.standfirst: Sauza Hornitos
fields.trailText: Sauza Hornitos
fields.body:
Or sowser orrneetoz, as it would be pronounced in Mexico, where this super-premium tequila is the best-selling brand. That super-premium tag means that it is made from 100% blue agave, the fleshy cactus-like plant from which tequila is produced, and is reposado - that is, rested or aged - in oak for up to six months, to give it a smoother texture than your basic slamming tequila. Good enough to drink on its own (it has a sweet, slightly earthy flavour with a spicy white pepper kick), it also makes an ace margarita (one shot Hornitos/one shot triple sec/one shot lime, all shaken over ice and served in a salt-rimmed glass).

Who drinks it? Well, mainly Americans, who consume more than 1,000 times as much tequila per head as we do in the UK. But Hornitos is drunk by wealthy urban males rather than 'frat boys' (fraternity boys - ie, college students). Here, you can get it from Oddbins, priced £17.99. Which, given the current agave shortage in Mexico, is a bit of a bargain.

fields.headline: Less is more
fields.standfirst: The secret of good cooking has a lot to do with knowing when to leave well alone. Jeremy Lee kicks off an occasional series to show that often, the fewer the ingredients, the better the dish.
fields.trailText: The secret of good cooking has a lot to do with knowing when to leave well alone. Jeremy Lee kicks off an occasional series to show that often, the fewer the ingredients, the better the dish.
fields.body:
'Six?!" I said, incredulously. "Six," he said, emphatically. "Sounds dangerously populist, if you don't mind my saying so."

"Six."

In spite of my protests, a meal consisting of three courses made up of dishes with no more than six ingredients each (although, none too generously, I was allowed not to count basics such as oils and seasoning in that number) was firmly on the agenda. My initial thoughts on this theme are pretty unprintable - after all, that number has more in common with the hairline of a child of the devil than good grub.

Sure, great food is little more than a simple matter of good ingredients cooked well - inventive thought, quirk and novelty are best left in the hands of toy manufacturers - but the creation of teeny-weeny recipes that are supposed to have the cook in the kitchen for just 10 minutes yet still be able to produce a dinner that will knock your socks off are on the whole, and in the politest terms, a complete nonsense. Or so I huffed.

Of course, there are some grand dishes with scant ingredients that do require only the minimum of preparation. A risotto of leeks, even using a stock cube, that hated lump of poison, takes 35-40 minutes to bring to fruition. Omelettes, on the other hand, are quick, yet curiously absent from daily life; the fact that they require a skill achieved through plenty of practice appears unworthy of mention - some chopped herbs, a little truffle, smoked haddock even, simply and elegantly accompany this greatly neglected dish.

A little more thought can bring to mind other great dishes that require few ingredients and not much more effort than bending down at the oven now and again. To pop a roast in the oven requires little more than a good butcher and skill in timing. Liberal seasoning with sea salt and freshly ground pepper are all that is required, along with some roast potatoes, perhaps, and a salad. Hamburgers, likewise, spring to mind as a possibility, as do watercress soup, moules marinières and fried fish . . .

Gosh, now I come to think about it, there are loads of lovely dishes, all with six ingredients or fewer. So, to start, I think we'll have some prawns, not least because there is much satisfaction in peeling them and then leaving them to steep in bread and oil and a little garlic. That's it, more or less - all that's left is to skewer and grill them. Quite delicious, and delightfully free of quirk.

It is an oddity that those countries, such as France or Italy, with many a grand cooking tradition also have a surfeit of sublimely simple one-course meals that may consist of nothing more than a few thin slices of cured meats, a bowl of olives, some bread and a bottle of wine; some cheese and fruit may feature, also, if you're going to push the boat out. Then again, in those countries you can, generally, buy very good stuff for such a feast, but it is difficult to pay dear old Blighty the same compliment, not least because the survival rates of a good butcher continue to plummet dramatically.

That said, spare ribs do seem to be something of a constant, here, although they are generally reserved for a severe charring on a savage barbecue. When treated with a degree of respect, however, they become notable. And when made with the ribs of a superior breed of pig or cow, they are great. To accompany them, some mashed potatoes flavoured with Parmesan, which speak for themselves, and a salad, if desired.

And for pudding? Oranges in a caramel-flavoured syrup are a refreshing and delicious finish, as well as simplicity itself to prepare.

Such a meal makes a convincing argument for the delights of the simple approach. In this case, less is certainly more. As ever, the secret - how often do I say this? - lies in the quality of the raw materials. Even when they number only six, ingredients of top quality require minimum handling and embellishment, so long as this is done in a sympathetic manner. The results are revelatory - to me, at any rate.

All recipes serve six.

Grilled Prawn Skewers
A great recipe from the great Marcella Hazan. The end result is a testament to keeping it simple. 900g plump prawns
3 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil
3 tbsp vegetable oil
75g fine, white breadcrumbs
2 cloves garlic, chopped very fine
2 tsp flat-leaf parsley, picked and chopped very fine
Sea salt and black pepper

Shell the prawns, but leave their tails on. With a small, sharp knife, remove the dark vein that runs along their backs. Wash the tails in cold water and then pat dry with a tea towel. Put the cleaned, prepared prawns in a roomy bowl.

Add as much of the olive oil and vegetable oil, in equal parts, and the breadcrumbs as you need to coat them evenly but lightly all over - you may not require all of the oil and breadcrumbs indicated in the ingredient list, but if you have a large number of very small prawns you may need more of each (in which case, ensure that you use olive and vegetable oil in equal quantities).

Add the garlic, parsley, salt and pepper to the bowl, and toss thoroughly. Allow the prawns to steep in their coating for at least half an hour, and preferably for two hours.

Heat a ridged griddle pan. Skewer the prawns tightly (on toothpicks, say) curling one end inwards and pushing the skewer through at three points, which will prevent the prawns from slipping from the skewer when you turn them. Cook the prawns briefly on the griddle, about two minutes, depending on their size and the intensity of the heat, turning frequently.

Spare ribs roasted with sage and white wine treviso-style
If you've been reduced to poverty and misery after the wanton indulgence of the December bender, this marvellous dish from Marcella Hazan (yes, her again, but you can never have too much of a good thing) soothes and satisfies. Serve with the Parmesan mash below.
4 tbsp vegetable oil
1.35kg rack spare ribs, divided into single ribs
3 cloves garlic, peeled and cut into thin slices
2 tbsp fresh sage, chopped
250ml dry white wine
Salt and black pepper

Take a heavy-bottomed pan large enough to accommodate all the ribs without crowding them. Put in the oil and turn the heat to medium-high. When the oil is hot, put in the ribs, and turn them as they cook until they are browned all over.

Add the garlic and sage, and as soon as the garlic turns a very pale blond add the wine. After the wine has simmered briskly for 15-20 seconds, reduce the heat to a simmer, then add salt and pepper and cover the pan with the lid slightly askew. Cook for about 40 minutes, turning the ribs from time to time, until their fleshiest part feels very tender when prodded with a fork and comes easily away from the bone. If the liquid in the pan looks like evaporating entirely, which is likely, add a couple of tablespoons of water from time to time, to keep the ribs moist.

Transfer the cooked ribs to a warm serving platter using a slotted spoon or spatula. Tip the pan and spoon off about a third of the liquefied pork fat. Leave more than you usually would when degreasing a pan, because you'll need it to season the Parmesan mash.

Add 100ml water to the pan and raise the heat, scraping the bottom of the pan with a wooden spoon to dislodge any cooking residues stuck there. Pour the resulting dark, dense juices over the ribs and serve at once.

Mashed potatoes bolognese-style, with milk and parmesan

500g best mashing potatoes (Maris Piper, or somesuch)
50g unsalted butter, cut into small cubes
6 tbsp Parmesan, freshly grated
Sea salt
Nutmeg
100ml whole milk

Scrub the potatoes clean (do not peel them), and put them in a large pot of salted water. Bring to the boil and simmer until cooked through. Do not pierce the potatoes too often, as the skin may break. Drain and peel while still hot.

Place a pan of water on a moderate heat and set a heatproof bowl over it. Put the butter in the bowl, then put the potatoes through a mouli, or mash them, and mix with the melting butter. In another pan, warm the milk, ensuring that it does not boil. Begin beating the potatoes, adding a little milk at a time, then mix in the cheese and any extra milk, if required. Add salt and a little grated nutmeg, and serve immediately.

Caramelised oranges
In honour of oranges being so good at this time of year. This most simple of desserts is delicious and refreshing.

12 oranges
320g caster sugar
150ml cold water
Grand Marnier

Pare the rind from six of the oranges and cut it into very thin strips. Place a small pan of water on to boil, drop in the prepared rind, simmer for a minute, then drain under cold running water. Peel the remaining oranges, discarding the pith, and slice the flesh of all 12 oranges into segments. Remove any pips, then rearrange the fruit into their original orange shape, securing them with cocktail sticks. Put the oranges into a handsome serving bowl.

Put the sugar in a heavy-bottomed pot and pour in just enough water in which to dissolve it. Over a moderate heat, melt the sugar, stirring all the while, until it forms a syrup, and continue cooking, stirring all the while, until the syrup becomes a rich dark caramel. Cover your hand and forearm with a cloth, to avoid painful splashes, and pour the 150ml of cold water into the pan, averting your face as you do so: the hot caramel will react very violently. Simmer until all the caramel has melted, and then add a generous splash of Grand Marnier. Pour the syrup over the oranges and, when the syrup has cooled down, sprinkle over the blanched rind, cover and refrigerate. Serve chilled.

Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Your article, Talking Heads (January 13), glossed over the fact that therapy seems to be the preserve of the middle classes.
fields.body:
Your article, Talking Heads (January 13), glossed over the fact that therapy seems to be the preserve of the middle classes. It is often those who cannot afford therapy who need it the most. It's a shame that Madeleine Reiss didn't explore this issue, as there are cheaper, efficient alternatives available, such as co-counselling.
Stephane Jaggers
London NW3

Thanks for your excellent article on psychological treatments. Unusually for a journalist writing about psychotherapy, Madeleine Reiss seems really to know her stuff. The piece was objective, rational, unemotive and supported by scientific evidence - a (cognitive-behavioural) psychologist's dream.
Sarah Holroyd
West Horsley, Surrey

'One in three Britons is currently depressed' (Julie Burchill, January 13). I'm amazed: who'd have thought that she was so widely read?
Ron Graves
Prenton, Cheshire

So, Julie Burchill 'never liked the idea of depression much'. Neither do I. Most of us who suffer (or have suffered) don't. I guess with all that time on my hands, next time I'll just choose some other mental health problem.
Sandra Wright
Copplestone, Devon

It is piquant that Lynette Gwyn-Jones's rambling defence of Brighton council's performance (Dear Weekend, January 13) should have appeared on the same day as it was reported that the High Court had forbidden its cost-cutting plans to close a home for autistic children. The campaign to save the home had given parents intolerable added distress.

Everybody is now asking about the size of the council's legal bill. The irony is compounded by another announcement that day - the council is to host a conference of councils at the Barbican...on ethics and standards in council work.
Christopher Hawtree
Hove, Sussex

Kevin Bell, you don't need to get punctures in 2001, or for the past several years (Dear Weekend, January 13). Put Slime tyre sealant in your tyres and never have one again. I wouldn't be without it. Ask at your local bike shop now.
Nick Wiseman
Oakley, Hants

Following Style Slave's advice (January 13), I obtained the chunky ceramic bowl and filled it with hot comfort food. Now the outlet of my dishwasher is solid with Lancashire hotpot. Was I meant to eat it, too, or is that not stylish?
Maggy Simms
Blackburn

I note from your fashion pages on January 13 that one of the pairs of trousers costs £69 from a shop in Nottingham. In order to keep your readers totally informed, perhaps you should point out that to purchase these, the return train fare from London to Nottingham costs something over £30. Most of your readers will therefore prefer to stay in town and buy trousers from Harvey Nichols instead.
Gilbert Green
Leicester

Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
Email: weekend@theguardian.com.
Fax: 020-7239 9935.

webTitle: Extract from A Heartbreaking Work Of Staggering Genius  by Dave Eggers

fields.headline: On second thoughts
fields.standfirst: If you've written your first book - a very candid memoir - and you're expecting a hostile reaction and talk of betrayal, it catches you unawares when the book becomes a runaway bestseller and suddenly you're a hero. Especially if there are still a few things that you might have done differently... Dave Eggers looks back
fields.trailText: If you've written your first book - a very candid memoir - and you're expecting a hostile reaction and talk of betrayal, it catches you unawares when the book becomes a runaway bestseller and suddenly you're a hero. Especially if there are still a few things that you might have done differently... Dave Eggers looks back
fields.body:
 A Heartbreaking Work Of Staggering Genius was Dave Eggers' true, or almost all true, memoir of his life acting as quasi parent to his young brother, Toph, after their mother and father died. The book was an astonishing critical and popular success both in the US and in Britain. In the months following publication, Eggers has had time to mull over what he did, what he put in, what he left out, and respond to readers, admirers and naysayers. He has made a few changes to the original text for a new edition, but mostly what he has done is to add an extra chunk. These are some extracts from this latest instalment, Mistakes We Knew We Were Making.

This appendix was supposed to, and almost did, accompany the original hardcover edition of the book. A version of it was nearly complete, when its author made the mistake of telling a writer friend about it, with, let's admit, a certain smugness. I was, I figured, the first to think of adding a corrective appendix to a nonfiction work, one meant to illuminate the many factual and temporal fudgings necessary to keep this, or really any, work of nonfiction from dragging around in arcana and endless explanations of who was exactly where, and when, etc. So: the corrective appendix was being prepared, and was to follow the original text, a few pages after the final "finally".

But upon telling this writer-friend about the idea, she said, while looking much too ravishing over an open candle and with wet hair, "Oh, right, like Mary McCarthy." There was, in the distance, the sound of thunder, and of lightning striking, presumably, a kitten. "Um, what do you mean, pray tell, Just like Mary McCarthy?" I thought, while, fear-stricken, managing only "Huh?" She noted that McCarthy had done almost the same thing in Memories Of A Catholic Girlhood, a book about which I was of course unware, because I am a moron. She explained that after each chapter recounting various episodes from McCarthy's youth, there was a slightly shorter chapter, set in italics, wherein the author dismantled the narrative, in favour of the unshaped truth.

Each corrective chapter, the writer-friend pointed out, began with something like: Well, it didn't happen exactly that way... And this was exactly my goal in adding the appendix in the first place: it afforded the opportunity to be completely factual about things that in the narrative had to be compressed or altered slightly so the book could continue apace. But after this illuminating dinner, I sought and found a copy of McCarthy's book (paperback edition with horrific cover), and after reading McCarthy's perfect execution of the idea, I abandoned my own appendix, not wanting to invest too much in a notion already used. And besides, I felt, the stupid goddamn book was obviously long enough. Thus, about 40 pages of prime appendix were scrapped. But now, about eight brutal and then exhilarating and then more-brutal-than-before months after the book was originally published, I've gone ahead and finished the appendix, for better or worse.

Many names have been changed

Yes, and I've taken out the phone numbers, too. Writing the first edition, I placed much weight on employing as many real names as possible, using their actual working phone numbers, everything, to prove a point that one could be completely factual, and still tell a story that felt and read novelistic, somewhat timeless, at least fluid. Changing all the names or, worse, making it all fictional (semi-autobiographical) seemed cowardly and silly. And so before publication I approached people whose names were used, and asked their permission. All readily agreed, but now, many of the people who initially said yes have had second thoughts. A typical conversation before publication: "Is it okay to use your real name?" "Sure, why not?" Typical conversation a month after publication: "Would it be possible to remove my name?" "Of course. Why?" "Well, no offence, but I really didn't think anyone would see the damn book."

A slightly different thing happened with the three friends who allowed the usage of their phone numbers. I assumed that after a few months, those whose numbers were listed would have been so besieged by creative teenagers at sleepovers that they'd have to change their numbers, a service I promised to pay for. And yet: approximate number of copies of this book sold in hardcover form: 200,000; approximate number of readers of this book, considering library use and pass-along: maybe 400,000; thus, how weird is this: Number of calls Marny received: 7 Number of calls Kirsten received: 12 Total calls for KC: 5 Total number of calls: 24. Those that did call often hung up; those that spoke were very nice. But overall, a remarkable thing: a gaspingly low percentage of phoners, especially given just how easy and convenient telephone use can be.

My guess is that a majority of people either a) assumed the numbers were phoney or outdated; b) were exceedingly polite and respectful of the privacy of nonfictional book characters; or c) never actually made it that far into the book, a failure for which I cast no outward blame. The fault, of course, is mine. Why, then, have we changed most of the names in the book? Because I've lost my taste for this sort of courage. I thought it was courageous to write about these things, and I thought it was equally courageous for my friends and me to use our names and phone numbers, and to allow our exploits and sexploits to be recounted in print for the consumption of our parents and aunts and nephews.

But now, when so many have asked for name-changes, and so many have been shocked by who/how many have seen all these words, I've decided to let most of the people - save some primary characters - breathe easier and live freer, by allowing them to slip back into semi-fictional personae. In a few cases, where I had originally lashed out at real people in backhanded ways, and used their real names in doing so, I have removed or softened these parts, because in the last year I've also, almost completely, lost my taste for blood.

One of the things that mercifully isn't covered in the book is the author's truly iffy and semi-brief career as a cartoonist. For the entire time covered in the book, I was doing a weekly cartoon for SF Weekly, a newspaper published a few blocks from the offices of Might [a magazine Eggers and some friends were producing in San Francisco]. The cartoon, as Might did, sought to engage its readers, to provoke interaction, however glancing, and thus had an abiding curiosity in how people would react to solicitations placed within its clumsily rendered borders.

Accordingly, one of its favourite experiments involved the giving away of the original artwork used in the cartoon, via the trunk of my car. At the time, after our Civic was crushed by the SUV en route to my sister's Kiss-featuring wedding, we bought a 1972 BMW 2002, a truly funny and perfect car, coloured chartreuse. And so I made an offer to the readers, that if they should see the car parked on any city street, that they should open the trunk, which would be unlocked always, and inside they would find drawings used in published cartoons. They could take a drawing, sign a register indicating who they were and what they took, and then they could go on their way, merrily. It worked. In a few weeks, all the artwork was gone, and everyone had signed their names.

So then, drunk on trust, I started leaving not only the trunk open but all the cars' doors unlocked. And in about six months of this, never was anything stolen or the car other-wise molested, outside of the pollution littered under the car's windshield wipers by the city's vigilant and efficient and completely evil meter maids, venal and carnivorous people in ridiculous helmets, may they and their overlords all burn in Hell eternally with much crackling and bubbling and searing of melted flesh. The point is that trust is usually rewarded, even though trust is sometimes violated, horribly. Trust is fun. It is fun to trust strangers. It is fun to risk what you can reasonably risk - like, your car, or your reputation - on the trust of people you know only through something ephemeral shared, something like taste in books or cartoons, or having watched people suffer.

The kayak trip

Also removed was a fantastic scene - 100 per cent true - featuring most of the book's primary characters, and a whale. We had been given a chance to try out, for free, a new hearty tourist's tour - a kayak trip around Angel Island. It's hilly, heavily forested but, since the early 1900s - when it served as sort of a West Coast Ellis Island - an uninhabited and largely uneventful rock, dumped in the middle of San Francisco Bay. Asserting our freedom to leave the office on any day or at any time, four of us from work went at noon, took a ferry from Fisherman's Wharf and once at the island, we paired up: Marny and I in one kayak, Moodie and Zev in another. The guide, in a single-seater, rounded out the party, and we set out. The guide's name was not Bart, but we will be calling him Bart. Ocean kayaking is very often very boring. Whereas whitewater kayaking has built-in interest, involving foam and speed enjoyed without having to self-generate that speed, ocean kayaking (which is essentially what a Bay kayak trip is) is akin to cross-country skiing - the pace is slow, the sights are unchanging and the work is tedious. And speed, really the only reason to partake in any sport, is almost impossible to achieve to any satisfactory degree.

The day was blue and yellow, and there was no wind. About halfway around the island, my shoulders already hurt like a mother; I was having some kind of rotator cuff problem. Naturally I thought of Jim McMahon [American footballer] and his own rotator cuff problems. Then thought of his headbands. And his part in The Super Bowl Shuffle, the now-wildly underrated football anthem from 1984. Then of Walter Payton, easily one of the most graceful athletes in any sport ever, in whose body cancer was already taking root, growing, planning expansion, sprawling, though no one yet knew it.

Then. There! About a thousand yards into the Bay, toward the city, a sudden plume of steam, coming from a shiny grey-black sliver rounded over the water's surface. A whale. Fuck me, a whale, someone said. Almost surely someone said that. Then it disappeared. Then someone said: Holy shit. Then: Jesus fuck. We paddled furiously toward it, making our way to the site of breach, and when we got there, we waited. It was silly, really: we knew the whale was gone, so to look for it in the precise location it had appeared would assume that it was just bobbing in place, below us, which of course it was not. Whales do not bob in place; whales are on the move, whales have places to go. But still we waited, because we are dumb people who do dumb things.

It was bright. The city was white to our left, and the ocean was straight ahead, a few miles west. The water was still, and we rested our paddles on the kayaks. Our legs were underwater but dry. Our faces were getting burned. We took handfuls of the Bay's cold and wet our faces and our necks. We scanned the surface for a break. Then: it came up again, this time about 500 yards toward the ocean. Same plume, same huge grey-black back breaking the surface, turning like a slow, dull bandsaw. Goddamn, someone said. Again we sped toward the location of its last appearance. Bart was excited. Bart had been kayaking in the Bay for years and years, and had never seen anything like this, a whale, in person, not 500 yards away. We arrived where we had last seen it: nothing. We felt stupid again, but less stupid than before: maybe he, the whale, knew we were here, watching him; maybe our chasing him had induced his second appearance. Whales are smart, and if whales are smart, surely they enjoy these kinds of chasing games, as do all smart animals, like dogs, and dolphins, and many others I could name but will not, including those known as pigs, a kind of animal which everyone claims is smart, without any impressive behavioural evidence to back it up.

So we waited. Three, five minutes. Then, into the Bay, again: the plume, the back, holy Jesus. A third appearance, this time 300 yards from its last. We didn't know what to do: follow it again? Just wait for the next breach? Wouldn't we have a better chance of a close-up visit if we stayed put? We decided to paddle halfway toward it, and then wait. We did, and once there, we put our paddles down, exhausted. My rotator cuff ached. I thought of Jim McMahon again. And then of Jim McMahon's sunglasses, which were big, and wrapped around his head - in the early 80s, a new and mysterious thing. Who was he playing for now? Was he still so intriguingly rebellious? We were in the middle of the Bay, a few inches out of the water, on a blue and yellow day, and we were chasing a whale. We looked at each other and grinned. But we were tired. We were tired, and were thinking that we really should get moving, toward the beach, where we planned to have our lunch.

We were arranged like this [the guide nearest the last sighting of the whale, one kayak parallell with him and the other bridging the other two kayaks, looking like a kayak stonehenge]: Again we waited. This time about 10 minutes. We were content, because we were tired, and because we were already satisfied, having seen a whale, while kayaking, in the Bay, near our homes, in our city, on a clear day while we were young.

Now. See the "x"? [The "x" is between the two parallell kayaks] That's where the motherfucker came up. He surfaced right between us. Not three feet away from our kayak. Much closer to Bart's. More than close. It was under Bart's kayak, not just under it but under it in such a way that when it surfaced, Bart's kayak was on top of the whale. It scared the piss out of us. I yelped. Everyone else made more civilised sounds. Gasps. I thought the whale might eat us. Then Bart, God bless him, while he was being lifted from the water by this 40ft monster, had the presence of mind to reach down and touch it. The whale - God, thinking about it now, it seems like it was there, between us all, for hours - it had this big dull eye, and the eye was looking at us, and the whale's whole back was bumped and barnacled, a thousand years old, and his mouth could have crushed us all, toothless though, the thing hardly an animal and more like a huge rough rock, a big rubbery rock rolling under us... And then it sunk from under Bart's kayak, setting the kayak's shiny fibreglass bottom back upon the surface, and in a second it was gone.

And right then, if I was ever unsure of it before, I was certain that we had been marked. When a whale surfaces between your kayaks - chooses, among any of 2 or 3 million places in a Bay to breach, chooses a spot between your tiny plastic kayaks - this giant ancient creature, who very well might be some kind of alien, a billion years old and maybe the creator of the whole world and everything in it (why not?), has come from the blue-grey depths to terrify you - that means everything is possible. No one can need more proof than that.

Accordingly, one of its favourite experiments involved the giving away of the original artwork used in the cartoon, via the trunk of my car. At the time, after our Civic was crushed by the SUV en route to my sister's Kiss-featuring wedding, we bought a 1972 BMW 2002, a truly funny and perfect car, coloured chartreuse. The point is that trust is usually rewarded, even though trust is sometimes violated, horribly. Trust is fun. It is fun to trust strangers. webTitle: Bush blows in on a chill wind of change

fields.headline: Bush blows in on a chill wind of change
fields.standfirst:
Democrats get blunt warning from new US leader

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Democrats get blunt warning from new US leader.
fields.body:
Steady rain and sleet, and even snow, are forecast for George Bush's presidential inauguration today in Washington. But even a blanket of winter weather cannot conceal the profound change of political and cultural direction in the capital as Mr Bush moves into the White House at the start of his four-year term.

Officials were considering whether the forecast storms would be bad enough to require them to move Mr Bush's swearing-in ceremony inside the Capitol building, before fewer than 1,000 guests. The last time that happened was Ronald Reagan's second inauguration in 1985.

Mr Bush told an interviewer yesterday that he was "not backing off" from his conservative political convictions. He had a blunt message for Democrats in the divided US Congress: They should work with the new administration "or they're going to be left behind".

To those who believe that he "stole" the November 2000 election and is not entitled to appoint conservatives such as the putative attorney general, John Ashcroft, to his cabinet, he had an equally brusque response. "Too bad," he told Fox television. "I'm going to."

As Washington geared up for the change of regime, which will come at midday when the chief justice, William Rehnquist, administers the oath of office, a federal judge ruled that thousands of protesters must submit to unprecedented security checks before gaining access to streets in the centre of Washington. Some 750,000 people had been expected in the city centre before the weather took a hand.

The outward signs of the new regime are everywhere to be seen in the capital, nevertheless. Airports reported record numbers of private jets arriving in town, delaying commercial flights into Washington by up to three hours. Every stretch limo on the eastern seaboard is parked outside the city's hotels, and Stetsons and snakeskin boots are visible at every turn.

Mr Bush was guest of honour at a succession of candlelight dinners last night for more than 6,000 supporters who each contributed more than $2,500 to the $40m inaugural budget. He and his wife Laura were due to end the evening at the "Texas black tie and boots" ball costing $1.8m.

Every presidential inauguration tells a story of how the new man would like to be seen. Jimmy Carter refused to take the limo down Pennsylvania Avenue and walked to the door of the White House. Ronald Reagan, surrounded himself with Hollywood ostentation, implicitly proclaiming the opening of the "greed is good" decade.

Bill Clinton's inaugural festivities, eight years ago, marked the arrival of the rock 'n' roll generation in the seats of power. Chuck Berry played guitar, Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen sang and Mr Clinton joined in, riffing on the sax in his shades, marking the arrival of the first hedonist in the White House.

The aesthetics of Mr Bush's inaugural celebrations have been more ambiguous. These have been days of partying in Washington, but the relatively subdued tone, compared with earlier transitions, is an unmistakeable reminder of the circumstances in which the new president is taking office. Mr Bush's low key message is that the important thing is to get on with the job.

Two years ago, the appearance of the Latino star Ricky Martin at an inaugural event would have appeared a very Bush-like statement about ethnic inclusiveness, This week it seemed merely middle of the road. Yesterday's concert in Washington "celebrating US youth" featured a succession of B-list acts. The celeb factor for this inaugural event is one of the lowest on record.

Many Republicans are relaxed with the absence of Really Big Names from the inaugural weekend concerts and balls. Hollywood is Clintonland these days, so the Bush people affect disdain for the celeb worship which became a hallmark of the outgoing era. When Frank Sinatra orchestrated the entertainment industry celebs' parade for Mr Reagan 20 years ago, on the other hand, Republicans had no such scruples.

The public events in Washington this weekend have also had their disingenuous side. Early reports said that the British stand-up comic Ben Elton would appear. The thought of the leftie Ben as part of a Bush lineup seemed hard to believe, and so it proved. He never showed up, because he was never going to.

Nor did Van Morrison, who had been improbably touted as part of the Bush celebrations. "Reports that Van Morrison will be performing or attending the inauguration ceremonies are false," said a press release from his record company.

Star turns

The celebrities who entertained presidents:

Bush era: Ricky Martin, Marie Osmond, ZZ Top

Clinton era: Bruce Springsteen, Chuck Berry, Stevie Wonder

Reagan era: Frank Sinatra, Donny Osmond, Sylvester Stallone

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Fringe benefits for tax planning

fields.headline: Pick a perk that counts
fields.standfirst: Not all company incentives are a good idea, says Phillip Inman
fields.trailText: Not all company incentives are a good idea, says Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
Some companies offer every perk under the sun - non-contributory pension, company car, share incentive scheme and health insurance. There might even be clothing allowances, subsidised canteens and free loans for items such as travel season tickets.

Why don't they just pay more on the monthly salary slip? The answer is that little extras for a large workforce can add up to huge tax and national insurance savings for employers. But some perks are of less value than you might think.

Some FTSE-100 companies, law firms and accountancy firms have turned the provision of perks into an art form. Complex charts show how one can be traded for another or turned into cash based on a system that allocates a certain amount of points to each perk.

But the end of the tax year is looming and the implications of opting for one or all perks need to be considered carefully.

Company pensions are a winner. Even if you join one of the new group personal pension schemes the tax benefits are positive - all pension contributions are liable for full tax relief at your top rate.

Group personal pensions are low-cost alternatives to standard pension schemes and companies which adopt them tend to pay only small contributions or none at all, except to cancel out the pension's management costs.

The schemes will gain a new push from low-cost stakeholder plans. They remain an improvement on an individual personal pension or no pension at all - although if the company is giving very little, you have to be sure that a pension package with its long-term money lock-up is what is best suited to you. But if your employer is generous, it is a difficult to turn it down.

Share incentive schemes can also prove valuable. Government-recognised save as you earn share option schemes involve saving a specified sum each month for a set period of three or five years after options in the company have been issued.

If the share options were set at £1 and the shares reached £3 at the end of the period, a saving of £100 a month would result in a gain of £7,200 in three years. If the share price sinks to 50p, the employee can take the cash plus interest at building society rates.

Aesop (all employee share option plans) are problematic. They are usually treated like bonuses and involve issuing free shares in a company. The scheme runs for five years, when the employee must exercise them or keep them going. It is a gamble because the option to take cash with interest does not exist. The shares might be worth £10 each or 10p. But whatever their value, there is no income tax, national insurance or capital gains tax.

John Whiting, of the accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, says exercising options early can result in a hefty tax bill. "The full tax advantages only accrue after five years," he warns.

Other perks are even more problematic. Currently, company car drivers need to make sure they clock up more than 2,500 miles a year to start reducing the amount of tax on the value of the perk. Tax is also reduced if the car is more than four years old.

The chancellor wants to shift people out of company cars and is changing the rules in 2002 so that tax reductions will depend on whether the car is new, small and has low CO 2 emissions.

Health insurance provided by a company can also prove to be a costly mistake as some companies fail to win large discounts for their employees.

The answer is that little extras for a large workforce can add up to huge tax and national insurance savings for employers. But some perks are of less value than you might think. Some FTSE-100 companies, law firms and accountancy firms have turned the provision of perks into an art form. Complex charts show how one can be traded for another or turned into cash based on a system that allocates a certain amount of points to each perk. But the end of the tax year is looming and the implications of opting for one or all perks need to be considered carefully. Company pensions are a winner. Even if you join one of the new group personal pension schemes the tax benefits are positive - all pension contributions are liable for full tax relief at your top rate. Group personal pensions are low-cost alternatives to standard pension schemes and companies which adopt them tend to pay only small contributions or none at all, except to cancel out the pension's management costs. The schemes will gain a new push from low-cost stakeholder plans. They remain an improvement on an individual personal pension or no pension at all - although if the company is giving very little, you have to be sure that a pension package with its long-term money lock-up is what is best suited to you. But if your employer is generous, it is a difficult to turn it down. Share incentive schemes can also prove valuable. Government-recognised save as you earn share option schemes involve saving a specified sum each month for a set period of three or five years after options in the company have been issued. If the share options were set at £1 and the shares reached £3 at the end of the period, a saving of £100 a month would result in a gain of £7,200 in three years. If the share price sinks to 50p, the employee can take the cash plus interest at building society rates. Aesop (all employee share option plans) are problematic. They are usually treated like bonuses and involve issuing free shares in a company. The scheme runs for five years, when the employee must exercise them or keep them going. It is a gamble because the option to take cash with interest does not exist. The shares might be worth £10 each or 10p. But whatever their value, there is no income tax, national insurance or capital gains tax. John Whiting, of the accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers, says exercising options early can result in a hefty tax bill. "The full tax advantages only accrue after five years," he warns. Other perks are even more problematic. Currently, company car drivers need to make sure they clock up more than 2,500 miles a year to start reducing the amount of tax on the value of the perk. Tax is also reduced if the car is more than four years old. The chancellor wants to shift people out of company cars and is changing the rules in 2002 so that tax reductions will depend on whether the car is new, small and has low CO 2 emissions. Health insurance provided by a company can also prove to be a costly mistake as some companies fail to win large discounts for their employees.

fields.headline: Morality at a price
fields.standfirst: Ethical fund managers are hoping the rapid growth in socially responsible investment will continue despite last year's poor performance. Patrick Collinson investigates
fields.trailText: Ethical fund managers are hoping the rapid growth in socially responsible investment will continue despite last year's poor performance. Patrick Collinson investigates.
fields.body:
The promoters of ethical funds have fought long and hard to convince the public that buying an ethical investment does not mean sacrificing financial performance. Except it didn't quite work out that way last year.

As the table here reveals, many large ethical funds suffered losses of around 8% last year, compared to the 2% average among UK-invested unit trusts. Only Jupiter's Environmental fund (up 14.9%) Aberdeen's Ethical fund (up 9.1%) and Norwich UK Ethical (up 3.2%) managed creditable performance. The ethical industry's flagship fund, Friends Provident Stewardship, slipped back 4.5% over the year.

The chief reason was poor returns on investments in technology companies. Many of the ethical funds were heavily weighted into software companies, partly because they meet the stringent environmental tests required by the funds - but their share prices fell sharply during the dot.com blowout.

Ethical fund managers hope last year's poor performance will not hold back the rapid growth in socially responsible investment (SRI) in the UK. In the past three years, total assets in ethical investments have more than doubled according to the Ethical Investment Research Service.

Aberdeen Asset Management believes that recent legislation, obliging pension fund trustees to take into account ethical and environmental considerations, will further focus attention on the companies that meet ethical standards - and push up their share price.

Aberdeen's head of SRI, Andrew Peston adds: "Fears over global warming, increased levels of pollution, child labour and genetically modified foods have led to an increased interest in ethical investing in recent years."

One of the big new areas of ethical investment activity, according to Norwich Union, is likely to be screening out packaging and chemical companies which produce and use endochrine-disrupting chemicals. In other words, the chemicals believed to be responsible for cutting sperm counts in men and disrupting reproduction among animals.

NU this week launched six ethical funds, to be managed by a team of fund managers and researchers who formerly worked at Henderson Investors. What's more, NU's parent group, CGNU, is promising to bring ethical criteria to the fore across the entire £200bn that it manages.

Meanwhile Amnesty International has teamed up with a firm of financial advisers, the Ethical Investment Cooperative, to offer an Ethical Individual Savings Account which will invest in a wide range of ethical funds. EIC will donate 1.5% of the amount invested in the ISA to Amnesty International.

fields.headline: The search for growth
fields.standfirst: Investment trusts are a cheap and cheerful long-term savings vehicle, Robin Stoddart advises
fields.trailText: Investment trusts are a cheap and cheerful long-term savings vehicle, Robin Stoddart advises.
fields.body:
Investment trusts whose shares are available at a discount to the value of the shares they themselves hold are obviously cheap. Given managers that are on the ball and switching fairly regularly from stocks with reduced potential to growth winners, appreciation above the market average will be achieved.

Discounts have narrowed lately because active managers have shown their worth during the technology boom and bust and the return to favour of profitable dividend-paying organisations like banks and some suppliers of material goods. Previously there was a tendency to go for index-tracking funds.

Investment trusts' expenses are generally low, though incentive payments may be deductible in successful high-growth funds. Some of these may be at a premium on asset value, as most continental European specialists are at present. Purchases are best delayed or unit funds preferred when prices are so clearly too high. Selling should be considered when prices are toppy and capital gains tax concessions are a factor. But long-term investment through a well-managed equity fund is what most private investors require.

A telling reason why average discounts have narrowed is the activity of mainly American predators, so-called arbitrageurs. They took out stakes in investment trusts with discounts ranging above a fifth in some cases. Proposals for the break-up of the fund involving repayment near the full cash value of holdings could then be forcefully put. Timely liquidations of a large Scottish fund and one of Fleming's specialist Asian investment trusts were achieved a few years ago.

Just lately arbitrageurs have been content to stir things up so that more-or-less voluntary buy-backs of shares by the existing management have occurred. This week, the longest-established investment trust and one of the handful of giant internationalist funds based in the UK, Foreign & Colonial, announced the repurchase for cancellation of 4% of its share capital. This was largely to clear out the holding of ST Partners , the arbitrage group that has become active in threatening some of the largest funds with proposals for returning cash. Scottish Investment Trust has also received a break-up proposal, which the board of the independent fund firmly rejects, while Bankers Trust has bought back ST Partners' holding of around 7%.

More buy-backs for cancellation will be mooted at forthcoming annual general meetings of shareholders. In Foreign & Colonial's case, the recent repurchases added 1.2p a share to asset value. The management lost dynamism after management shares were created and control passed into German banking hands through their sale. Appreciation last year was 10%, a commendable performance, though other funds in the group with a narrower geographical remit often suffered badly.

Most of the billionaire funds going for global growth have doubled over five years and their shares stand at discounts of around 11% on underlying values. The narrowing of the discount and higher dividends produced some fair returns last year, though yields of 1.1% on F&C rising to 1.6% on the next largest, Witan, are nothing to write home about. Most of these funds have small stakes in early growth companies and venture capital investors, primarily based in the US. Those that have gone for higher income and yields have often suffered on the capital appreciation front. As usual, a small and newer fund heads the performance table, but RIT Capital Partners, a medium-to-large fund, is consistently a top performer thanks to strategic holdings on both sides of the Atlantic.

Unit trusts, though almost invariably much smaller, have shown slower growth because of heavier charges. These make buying and selling easier as they bypass stock market share dealing direct by the unit holder. Baillie Gifford, Britannic and Bank of Ireland came not far short of doubling returns for investors in their global growth units over five years, but the average increase was only around 50%. Few unit funds in the sector have more than £100m under management. Fidelity is the exception and, thanks to its international spread and Wall Street experience, achieved returns of around 125% over five years for pension fund and retail investors.

UK investment trusts failed lamentably to foresee the 10-year record boom in the US stock market and economy, with software and other technology to the fore. Previously they achieved best returns when investing overseas benefited from the weakness of sterling. Performance in Japan and most emerging markets has often been disastrous, but Europe became a fruitful scene a few years ago. Finding growth leaders throughout the world, particularly in stable western economies, is the proper target of established funds.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Ski posters auctions

fields.headline: Why ski poster prices are now snowballing
fields.standfirst: The work of famous artists, commissioned to help attract crowds to winter sports, is doing well in the salerooms. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: The work of famous artists, commissioned to help attract crowds to winter sports, is doing well in the salerooms. Stewart Dalby reports.
fields.body:
Some years back I went skiing with my family in Belgium. "Belgium!" everyone shrieked. "You can't go skiing in Belgium, it's one of the low countries." Not true. We went to an area called Les Hautes Fanges near the Ardennes close to a village called Robertville one February.

Okay, so it was not the Alps. But there was a pretty decent downhill and some nursery slopes where the children learned to ski. It was a wonderful holiday because it was an unfashionable spot and therefore very cheap.

I do not, however, expect to see a Belgium poster at Christie's, South Kensington's annual ski sale on February 22. But there is a poster advertising Poland as a skiing location. It features two male skiers against a stark grey sky and could fetch up to £800.

This reflects the way these specialist sales have grown in popularity, the manner in which they have diversified and the fact that prices have risen steadily since Christie's launched them four years ago. Prices begin at £250 and top out at £11,000 this year, but the moving average within this range has been drifting steadily upwards over the four years. This, in turn, reflects the growing enthusiasm in Britain for continental skiing holidays.

Ski posters are the continental equivalent of the British railway poster popularised before World War Two. In those days, before everyone had cars, most people went on holiday by train and the many railway companies commissioned artists to design colourful posters extolling the virtues of seaside resorts, trains and landscapes. These are actively collected. Many were not made to last; they were torn down at the end of a season or pasted over. Thus those in a good condition have an increasing rarity value.

Similarly with ski posters. As the sport grew in popularity, railway companies such as the Paris Lyon Mediterranean Railway (PLM) commissioned famous artists of the day, including Auguste Matisse, to produce a number of popular images.

Skiing is a much younger sport than is often realised. It is thought that skis were first used for sport in Norway in the late nineteenth century. Modern skiing for pleasure first took place in the traditional villages of Switzerland, which were already summer holiday resorts.

Murren in the Jungrau region of Switzerland was considered one of the birthplaces of modern alpine skiing and the "ski package holiday" thanks to a British Methodist minister, Henry Lunn. Murren was already a well known summer holiday destination, so Lunn's main task was to persuade the railways to stay open during the winter. Just as the most expensive film posters tend, on the whole, to be those connected with successful films - James Bond and the like - the most sought after ski posters are those related to the most popular resorts, such as Chamonix, St Moritz, Gstaad, and Klosters.

Nicolette White, the specialist organising the 250-lot sale at Christie's, says a special feature this year is that some posters have come out of the woodwork and have not been seen before.

Also, in her opinion, there are some particularly fine images from St Moritz. The ones she has not come across before include a Caux lithograph which is linen backed and painted by Anton Reckziegel (1865-1936.) and estimated at £1,000 to £1,500.

Another is anonymous and a lithograph of Gstaad, the Royal Hotel and Winter Palace. This is in good condition and is given an A-minus rating. A third by an artist named Huszar and entitled A Winter Season in Oslo, is a lithograph in colours printed by Emil, Oslo. Again in good condition it ranks an A, but is more modestly priced - it is expected to fetch £600-£800. But you never know.

Two years ago in the Febru ary 1999 sale, a lithograph in colours painted by Francisco Tamagno was estimated at £2,000 to £4,000. In the event it sold for £12,600, a record for Christie's. This year there is another almost exactly the same. It portrays a man and a woman in white pullovers and balaclavas soaring in mid air above the tree line. It is entitled Chamonix, Mont Blanc, Sports D'Hiver Ski-Luge-Patin Bobsleigh. Tamagno was an artist employed by the PLM railway so presumably a fair number were printed. Once again, this one is in good condition with an A rating.

This is one of the striking things about these ski posters: how well preserved they are compared with, say, the general run of British railway posters. Ski posters sold well in general poster sales, but there were not many of them. Now, with these specialist sales, Christie's seems to have created a market. They are popular and in demand and it is obviously worth people on the continent dusting them off and offering them for auction. There seems little danger the Tamagno is under-estimated; this time it is on offer at £9,000 to £11,000

 For further information telephone Christie's South Kensington 020 7 581 7611 or visit Christie's.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Second homes abroad

fields.headline: There's a place in the sun
fields.standfirst: More and more Brits are seeking second homes overseas. Elizabeth Langton looks at the prices and pitfalls
fields.trailText: More and more Brits are seeking second homes overseas. Elizabeth Langton looks at the prices and pitfalls.
fields.body:
As the cold weather bites deeper into British bones, the prospect of owning a bolt-hole somewhere warm and sunny is increasingly attractive. Now, according to Eurotunnel, more than 400,000 UK residents have a second home on the continent.

But buyers calculating whether they can afford to buy abroad (the strong pound has brought it within the reach of many) need to build the cost of travelling to and from their home into the equation. Bargain airfares look tempting now, but soon add up when multiplied by the number of visits homeowners make during a year.

Eurotunnel has brought France closer to travellers in the south-east and this weekend is launching an initiative to encourage more people to buy across the channel. The Property Owners' Club is being set up to cut the cost of regular cross-channel travel. Members will be able to purchase between 5-10 economy return tickets or mini-breaks or a combination "carnet" style ticket - valid for a year and flexible enough to allow members to change travel plans up to 24 hours before they travel.

Fares on offer are as low as £125 for an economy return an £85 for a mini-break. Benefits include automatic enrolment in Privilege Plus, the highest level of Eurotunnel's Points Plus loyalty scheme. Members receive points for every pound they spend, redeemable for future travel. There is an extra 10% off additional bookings and use of the fast-track Club Class check-in. David Wells, managing director of Abbey National France, says: "Interest from UK customers wanting to buy in France is at record levels and there's still no sign of the market slowing," he says. Mr Wells attributes the interest to the strong pound and the fact that house prices in France, although rising, do so at a slower rate than in the UK. The average price of a house in the Dordogne is £76,000 compared to £129,000 in the south of England.

What has changed is the type of property UK househunters are interested in, and location. "Not that long ago people were interested in older properties ripe for renovation in the north. Now they want to buy in higher-priced areas like the south of France. Places like the Dordogne remain popular, but have been overtaken by the Cote d'Azur, and the ski areas."

France's proximity makes the country particularly attractive, but organisers of the International Property Show, (Feb 10-11 Olympia, London) say Spain is still a strong favourite with British buyers.

How much buyers are willing to spend has changed. Five years ago the average spend was £50-£60,000. It has now risen to between £150,000-£200,000 in Spain and Portugal.

Abbey National's research shows that the average price of a two-bedroom apartment on the Costa Brava ranges from £58,000-£96,000 and in Tenerife from £77,000-£204,000. Tuscany has long been a favourite with well-off Brits and prices are on par with those in the UK. The average price of a two-bedroom flat there is £50,000, but is £36,600 in Umbria.

In a warm climate it is easy to fall in love with a property that wouldn't merit a second glance back home. Mr Wells warns: "Buyers should be careful to compare what's on the market before committing themselves." Although property prices may appear reasonable, the cost of buying abroad is often higher. In France, buyers need to take account of VAT, notaire fees (the lawyer who deals with the sale and purchase), taxes and other costs - usually 12-15% above the purchase price, says Mr Wells.

In France, a draft agreement is the first stage in buying a property. These are either a "promesse de vente" or a "compromis de vente". With the former the buyer is granted the option to buy in a set time and with a deposit of 10%. A "compromis de vente" binds both the purchaser and the vendor, subject to the contract conditions being fulfilled. With this agreement the vendor can enforce the sale. When all the contract conditions have been fulfilled the sale finishes with a deed produced by the notaire called an "acte de vente".

Abbey National produces a free guide to buying abroad while the Woolwich runs a French operation that offers a complete mortgage and second home buying service. Mr Wells says: "Buyers come to us for help through what is potentially a complicated process. We try to make it as straightforward as we can."

 Vive La France Exhibition, London Olympia, Jan 20-21. The International Property Show, Feb 10-11, Cumberland Hotel, London.

Mr Wells attributes the interest to the strong pound and the fact that house prices in France, although rising, do so at a slower rate than in the UK. The average price of a house in the Dordogne is £76,000 compared to £129,000 in the south of England. What has changed is the type of property UK househunters are interested in, and location. "Not that long ago people were interested in older properties ripe for renovation in the north. Now they want to buy in higher-priced areas like the south of France. Places like the Dordogne remain popular, but have been overtaken by the Cote d'Azur, and the ski areas." France's proximity makes the country particularly attractive, but organisers of the International Property Show, (Feb 10-11 Olympia, London) say Spain is still a strong favourite with British buyers. How much buyers are willing to spend has changed. Five years ago the average spend was £50-£60,000. It has now risen to between £150,000-£200,000 in Spain and Portugal. Abbey National's research shows that the average price of a two-bedroom apartment on the Costa Brava ranges from £58,000-£96,000 and in Tenerife from £77,000-£204,000. Tuscany has long been a favourite with well-off Brits and prices are on par with those in the UK. The average price of a two-bedroom flat there is £50,000, but is £36,600 in Umbria. In a warm climate it is easy to fall in love with a property that wouldn't merit a second glance back home. Mr Wells warns: "Buyers should be careful to compare what's on the market before committing themselves." Although property prices may appear reasonable, the cost of buying abroad is often higher. In France, buyers need to take account of VAT, notaire fees (the lawyer who deals with the sale and purchase), taxes and other costs - usually 12-15% above the purchase price, says Mr Wells. In France, a draft agreement is the first stage in buying a property. These are either a "promesse de vente" or a "compromis de vente". With the former the buyer is granted the option to buy in a set time and with a deposit of 10%. A "compromis de vente" binds both the purchaser and the vendor, subject to the contract conditions being fulfilled. With this agreement the vendor can enforce the sale. When all the contract conditions have been fulfilled the sale finishes with a deed produced by the notaire called an "acte de vente". Abbey National produces a free guide to buying abroad while the Woolwich runs a French operation that offers a complete mortgage and second home buying service. Mr Wells says: "Buyers come to us for help through what is potentially a complicated process. We try to make it as straightforward as we can."  Vive La France Exhibition, London Olympia, Jan 20-21. The International Property Show, Feb 10-11, Cumberland Hotel, London.

webTitle: Roads plan 'could destroy Brazilian Amazon by 2020'

fields.headline: Roads plan 'could destroy Brazilian Amazon by 2020'
fields.standfirst: Researchers say project imperils 95% of world's biggest wilderness.
fields.trailText: Brazil's plan to develop its Amazon rainforest by improving the area's infrastructure will cause environmental devastation that far outweighs any economic advantage, a report in the US magazine Science said yesterday.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Brazil's plan to develop its Amazon rainforest by improving the area's infrastructure will cause environmental devastation that far outweighs any economic advantage, a report in the US magazine Science said yesterday.

The plan, Advance Brazil, which will see £27bn spent over seven years on roads, hydroelectric dams, railways and waterways, could leave only 5% of the rainforest intact by 2020.

US and Brazilian researchers spent five years using satellite images and computer modelling to estimate the destruction of the Brazilian Amazon, which contains about 40% of the world's tropical rainforest.

"If these development plans go through, we'll lose the largest remaining wilderness on Earth and a huge amount of the world's remaining biodiversity. And that, of course, doesn't even consider the enormous impacts on the car bon cycle, global climate and greenhouse warming," said Scott Bergen, a forecast scientist at Oregon State University.

According to the report the most optimistic levels of deforestation will leave 28% destroyed, 28% untouched and the remainder with different degrees of destruction.

"The Brazilian Amazon plays vital roles in maintaining biodiversity, regional hydrology and climate," said the report by the research team, led by William Laurance of the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. "It also has the world's highest absolute rate of forest destruction,currently averaging nearly 2m hectares[about 8,000 square miles] a year."

Mark Cochrane, of Michigan State University, said: "We're trying to map out the implications to let [Brazil] know what the consequences are."

Since the government started building the Transamazon Highway three decades ago to link the jungle wilderness to the populated coastal areas, Brazil has had contradictory attitudes towards its last great frontier. It wants to harness it as a resource, yet is aware of the risks of deforestation and the wrath this incurs abroad.

Migration to the Brazilian Amazon has led to a big rise in its population over the last century to about 12m, according to provisional figures.

"We cannot leave the local population living in a glass bowl just for the benefit of rainforest preservation," said Jose Paulo Silveira of the department of planning and strategic investments. "We need to keep on developing."

He added that there was no intention to build new roads, just to improve existing ones: "We accept suggestions, but I don't entirely trust the precision of the study because of the data it used - some of which is out of date."

The Science report suggests the industrialisation is shortsighted because Brazil could lose up to £1.4bn a year in selling carbon credits - a practice which allows countries to meet pollution reduction targets by buying the unused quotas of other nations.

Mr Cochrane said deforestation was more subtle than the levelling of whole areas. "When you view these forests from a distance they look OK, but when you stand in them, you can see they've been thinned, and that they've changed," he said. "It's like they have holes punched in them. These holes can make a rainforest dry out."

Roads once confined to the Amazon's perimeter are now penetrating to its heart, bringing people that further stress the forest, he said.

"Unfortunately, there is little government control in the Amazonian frontier," added Mr Laurance. "Illegal logging and land-clearing are rampant. New roads that cut into the frontier almost always initiate a process of spontaneous colonisation, logging, hunting and land speculation that is almost impossible to stop."

webTitle: Three held over Taj Mahal stunt

fields.headline: Three held over Taj Mahal stunt
fields.trailText: They had come to see one of the world's most famous monuments. But when the three backpackers discovered that the Taj Mahal was closed yesterday, for the first time ever on a Friday, they took matters into their own hands.
fields.body:
They had come to see one of the world's most famous monuments. But when the three backpackers discovered that the Taj Mahal was closed yesterday, for the first time ever on a Friday, they took matters into their own hands.

After checking that the coast was clear, they shinned up a wall before dropping down into the deserted Taj complex for a private visit - an experience normally reserved only for VIPs.

They then started making their way to the mausoleum and the Taj's formal gardens. It was here that their luck ran out. They were picked up by security guards, carted off to Agra police station, and charged with breaking into an ancient monument.

Their daring mission came three months after the body responsible for looking after the Taj - the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) - decided to hike admission prices for foreigners from 20p to around £14.The monument remained free on Friday after protests from Agra's Muslims.

Last week, however, the ASI decided to shut the Taj for the first time on Fridays and open it on Mondays instead. The move - designed to extract maximum revenue from visiting tourists - proved so unpopular yesterday that hundreds of foreigners and locals turned up at the police station to protest. They were charged by officers wielding sticks known as lathis, and reportedly responded by pelting the police with stones.

Last night Agra police confirmed that Tony Skarberg, 24, from Sweden, Andy Ibrahim, 19, from France, and Lo Yong Gil, 30, from South Korea, would spend a night in the cells before being produced in court later today under the Indian penal code.

"They were caught breaking into the Taj compound," an Agra police spokesman confirmed. "They climbed over a wall to get in. They have been arrested and will be produced tomorrow."

The ASI's peremptory decision to increase prices at the Taj and at other archaeological sites across India has proved deeply unpopular with foreign visitors, tour operators and local touts. Several cheap guesthouses in Agra have gone bust while many backpackers are now skipping the Taj completely.

Officials have said the extra money generated from higher admission prices will be ploughed back into India's 3,606 mostly crumbling heritage sites. They have defended the fact that Indians pay only a fraction of the admission price charged to tourists by pointing out that neighbouring Sri Lanka and Nepal have the same policy.
