fields.headline: Vacant possession, except for the spook
fields.standfirst: Buyers who unwittingly purchase a house with a reputation for being haunted have a right to legal redress, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: Buyers who unwittingly purchase a house with a reputation for being haunted have a right to legal redress, says Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
Failing to disclose the presence of a poltergeist may not sound the most promising basis for a legal action but a leading academic lawyer, relying on American authorities, has suggested such failures could end up in the courts.

Strictly speaking, what may need to be disclosed is not that a house is haunted, but that it has acquired a reputation for being so. Few judges would be willing to make determinations about the paranormal, but establishing that a belief has grown up about a property is a more earthbound issue.

Professor Mark Pawlowski of Greenwich University, writing in the Solicitors Journal, cites a New York case involving a $650,000 Victorian-style house sold by Helen Ackley. She had rather revelled in what she believed was the haunted status of her property, making numerous reports of ghosts to local papers and the Readers' Digest. True or not, most of her neighbours believed them.

When she came to sell the property to Jeffrey Stambovsky, she became uncharacteristically coy about the extra-terrestrial going-on. His suspicions were aroused when neighbours kept refusing his invitations to pop in for a drink and would remark on how brave he had been to buy the house. When the truth emerged the state Appeal Court decided that, as Ms Ackley had given the house its reputation, her lawyers' protestations that poltergeists do not exist were of no avail and he was entitled to his money back.

The same principle would probably apply in England. A Swansea solicitor recalled a case where his client bought a house that he came to believe was haunted. The solicitor advised the client that he could either try to sue the vendor on the basis that he hadn't actually got the promised vacant possession of the property, or have it exorcised. He selected exorcism: cheaper and more certain than litigation.

Rather different was the claim brought in 1999 by a Mr and Mrs Smith in Derbyshire. They claimed that their £41,000 cottage was haunted by an "evil presence" and a boy with piggy eyes. Mrs Smith even believed a ghost had raped her. Their claim was robustly rejected by the county court judge who found no evidence that the house had ever been haunted, and who was sceptical about claims that it had a reputation for being so.

Currently, when most properties are sold, in addition to specific queries such as the ownership of fences, buyers or their solicitors formally ask the sellers: "Is there any other information which you think the buyer may have a right to know?" It is certainly arguable that if the house has a local reputation that might affect its value this needs to be mentioned.

Professor Pawlowski says that if a murder has taken place it could have an impact on value. He cites a Californian case where the court allowed a buyer's claim on that basis after he found a family had been massacred in the property he had bought.

The problem frequently arises in Cranley Gardens, Muswell Hill, where serial killer Dennis Nilsen literally flushed away many of his vic tims. Jonathan and Sara Black viewed a flat in that house last year, oblivious to its history. "We thought the seller reacted very strangely when we asked casually about the drains, demanding to know why we were so curious," says Jonathan.

When they mentioned this to the estate agent, he rather sheepishly admitted that Nilsen had lived there. "It did put us off the flat," Jonathan, a solicitor, adds, "And had we bought it without being told, I would certainly have considered taking legal action."

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Kabila flown home before state funeral

fields.headline: Kabila flown home before state funeral
fields.standfirst: Assassinated Congolese leader unmourned at home and abroad as tensions continue to unsettle central Africa.
fields.trailText: Laurent Kabila's body is to be flown home today ahead of elaborate preparations for his burial, after the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo finally admitted that he had been murdered by what it said was a lone assassin.
fields.body:
Laurent Kabila's body is to be flown home today ahead of elaborate preparations for his burial, after the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo finally admitted that he had been murdered by what it said was a lone assassin.

The late president's son, Major General Joseph Kabila, was officially elevated yesterday from being the temporary leader to "permanent responsibilities as head of the government and the army". He will be sworn in once his father is buried.

The government declared 30 days of mourning ahead of the arrival of Mr Kabila's corpse in the southern city of Lubumbashi, the capital of Katanga province, where he was born. After a memorial service, the body will be flown to Kinshasa tomorrow for a state funeral next week.

The government urged the Congolese people to remain calm "despite the dramatic situation", and appealed to the security forces to "keep their discipline". Some expatriates were leaving on the few flights out of Kinshasa, but the capital was quiet with a large number of troops on the streets.

Kabila's assassination was widely condemned by other African leaders but he was rarely mourned. Leaders at the Franco-African summit in Cameroon observed a minute's silence "in memory of our dear brother", but few were prepared to speak favourably of him.

Togo's foreign minister, Koffi Panou, summed up the mood by saying "we disapprove of the manner" of the death, but he declined to express regret at the president's passing.

"What do you want me to say?" another African minister said. "If I rejoice in his death, that would be undiplomatic, and if I say I regret it, I would be a hypocrite."

Nelson Mandela hoped the killing would persuade the belligerents in Congo's war to seek peace. "Tragic as the violent death of President Kabila is, we trust that this provides the opportunity for the government, the armed opposition and the unarmed opposition to sit down as compatriots and place the common good of their country's people paramount in their considerations," he said.

After two days of falsely claiming that Kabila was alive, the government continued to insist that he was shot by a lowly bodyguard who acted on his own and who was then himself killed. But there was considerable scepticism in Kinshasa's diplomatic circles at that explanation.

"It's all too convenient to heap it all on one man who is conveniently dead and to say you've no idea why he did it," said one foreign diplomat. "There were some powerful people in that room when Kabila was shot and some of them had very good reasons to want him dead. So did others who, you might say, were just outside the door. I don't think there are many people around here who believe it was the bodyguard."

In the war in the east of the country, Ugandan-backed rebels about 600 miles northeast of the capital reported bombing raids by government forces. Fighting was also reported near the eastern town of Bunia, but that was believed to be the result of a local dispute.

Uganda's government appealed to Kabila's son to convene a national conference to lay the ground for a new political system in Congo and end the war.

"The government of Uganda will be prepared to work with whomsoever assumes effective leadership in Kinshasa to establish peace in the region," a statement said.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Taxpayer left bankrupt

fields.headline: Three times a loser
fields.standfirst: Final costs treble for man left bankrupt by the the Inland Revenue. Phillip Inman reports
fields.trailText: Final costs treble for man left bankrupt by the the Inland Revenue. Phillip Inman reports.
fields.body:
A taxpayer who was bankrupted for his failure to pay an alleged £38,000 tax bill last week saw the final cost of his dispute with the Inland Revenue rise to £127,000 after the government and the accountants handling the case added their charges.

Patrick Cullinane says he was distraught when he learned that the costs of the bankruptcy had more than trebled, leaving him penniless. Mr Cullinane was made bankrupt in 1996 after a decade-long battle with the Inland Revenue. The City firm of accountants KPMG were appointed to oversee the liquidation of his only asset, a three-bedroom house in north London, in order to pay the claimed debt.

After several attempts to stop the repossession of his home he was thrown out in March 1999. The house was sold for £127,000 with a £22,000 mortgage with the Abbey National bank still outstanding. That rose by £4,000 over 15 years.

The mortgage was repaid out of the sale funds. Eighteen months later he discovered that a raft of other costs including the estate agency commission on the sale of his house, VAT, other taxes, bailiffs' bills and a near £40,000 invoice from KPMG had eaten away the rest of the money. Ironically, the Inland Revenue received just over £18,000, less than half what it wanted.

Mr Cullinane hoped to continue his fight against the Revenue with any funds remaining from his bankruptcy. When he was told the costs of settling the debts had soared and wiped out the remaining funds, he was devastated. "It is outrageous that they have taken away everything I have. I must now carry on living with my sister and I have no money to employ a lawyer to fight my case."

The Official Receiver, which oversees bankruptcies on behalf of the government, said in a letter to the two creditors that the case was simple and considered managing the bankruptcy itself. But it allowed KPMG to take on the task instead. With the agreement of the Revenue, KPMG was allowed to make its own charges rather than stick to the Official Receiver's scale of charges, which are considerably lower.

The Inland Revenue, the only active creditor, said in a statement it was standard practice to use KPMG, commonly called one of the Big Five accountancy firms: "KPMG and its insolvency practitioners are well respected and there is nothing unusual in their appointment as trustee in bankruptcy in this case."

The dispute began in 1983 when Mr Cullinane was a stage hand working in the film industry. He attempted to claim back income tax after taking a job where he was put on the emergency tax rate. But instead of receiving a tidy lump sum at the end of the tax year he became the subject of an investigation by a local tax inspector.

He employed an accountant to establish why the Inland Revenue had a problem, but he failed to make much headway. After three years Mr Cullinane could no longer afford to pay accountancy fees. Then, in 1990, the Special Commissioners, who act as a court for tax disputes, were presented with evidence by the Inland Revenue that he had failed to declare rental income from tenants staying in his house on his tax returns. It said an extra kitchen and bathroom had been built for the purpose of renting the property.

Mr Cullinane has denied the charges, saying that income he received was money owed by a previous employer and social security payments. He had only one kitchen and bathroom, he says. Despite his denials, the Revenue pressed ahead with a bankruptcy order to recover the tax. It has subsequently conceded that all the money going through Mr Cullinane's bank account was either taxed at source or not liable for tax, but maintains that he must have received rental income by other means.

Mr Cullinane has attempted on several occasions to force the Revenue to disclose what evidence there is to support this assertion, but it has so far refused.

The Taxpayers Charter has proved little help in his campaign to view his tax file. Mr Cullinane's supporters have even offered to pay the Revenue any administration costs it might incur collecting the information, but to no avail.

Where the money went

Receipts and payments account in the bankruptcy for the period from June 6,1997 to November 2000

Official Receiver's disbursements £527.35

Mortgage redemption £26,128.19

Cheque/payable order fees £7.80

Secretary of State fees £10,313.23

Petitioner's costs £2,188.66

Trustees fees £32,306.65

Trustee's expenses £2,800.21

Irrecoverable VAT £10,229.66

Agents/valuers fees £8,886.22

Agents fees £1,765.17

Legal fees £13,749.25

Other property expenses £15.00

Insurance of assets £54.43

Inland Revenue preferential claim £393.87

Inland Revenue unsecured claim £17,634.31

Total: £127,000.00

Receipts from property: £127,000.00

Balance: Nil

Patrick Cullinane says he was distraught when he learned that the costs of the bankruptcy had more than trebled, leaving him penniless. Mr Cullinane was made bankrupt in 1996 after a decade-long battle with the Inland Revenue. The City firm of accountants KPMG were appointed to oversee the liquidation of his only asset, a three-bedroom house in north London, in order to pay the claimed debt. After several attempts to stop the repossession of his home he was thrown out in March 1999. The house was sold for £127,000 with a £22,000 mortgage with the Abbey National bank still outstanding. That rose by £4,000 over 15 years. The mortgage was repaid out of the sale funds. Eighteen months later he discovered that a raft of other costs including the estate agency commission on the sale of his house, VAT, other taxes, bailiffs' bills and a near £40,000 invoice from KPMG had eaten away the rest of the money. Ironically, the Inland Revenue received just over £18,000, less than half what it wanted. Mr Cullinane hoped to continue his fight against the Revenue with any funds remaining from his bankruptcy. When he was told the costs of settling the debts had soared and wiped out the remaining funds, he was devastated. "It is outrageous that they have taken away everything I have. I must now carry on living with my sister and I have no money to employ a lawyer to fight my case." The Official Receiver, which oversees bankruptcies on behalf of the government, said in a letter to the two creditors that the case was simple and considered managing the bankruptcy itself. But it allowed KPMG to take on the task instead. With the agreement of the Revenue, KPMG was allowed to make its own charges rather than stick to the Official Receiver's scale of charges, which are considerably lower. The Inland Revenue, the only active creditor, said in a statement it was standard practice to use KPMG, commonly called one of the Big Five accountancy firms: "KPMG and its insolvency practitioners are well respected and there is nothing unusual in their appointment as trustee in bankruptcy in this case." The dispute began in 1983 when Mr Cullinane was a stage hand working in the film industry. He attempted to claim back income tax after taking a job where he was put on the emergency tax rate. But instead of receiving a tidy lump sum at the end of the tax year he became the subject of an investigation by a local tax inspector. He employed an accountant to establish why the Inland Revenue had a problem, but he failed to make much headway. After three years Mr Cullinane could no longer afford to pay accountancy fees. Then, in 1990, the Special Commissioners, who act as a court for tax disputes, were presented with evidence by the Inland Revenue that he had failed to declare rental income from tenants staying in his house on his tax returns. It said an extra kitchen and bathroom had been built for the purpose of renting the property. Mr Cullinane has denied the charges, saying that income he received was money owed by a previous employer and social security payments. He had only one kitchen and bathroom, he says. Despite his denials, the Revenue pressed ahead with a bankruptcy order to recover the tax. It has subsequently conceded that all the money going through Mr Cullinane's bank account was either taxed at source or not liable for tax, but maintains that he must have received rental income by other means. Mr Cullinane has attempted on several occasions to force the Revenue to disclose what evidence there is to support this assertion, but it has so far refused. The Taxpayers Charter has proved little help in his campaign to view his tax file. Mr Cullinane's supporters have even offered to pay the Revenue any administration costs it might incur collecting the information, but to no avail. webTitle: Carlyle set to lose Tim Jackson

fields.headline: Carlyle set to lose Tim Jackson
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Tim Jackson, founder of online auctioneer QXL.com, is understood to be close to quitting his position as managing director of the European internet investment arm of the American venture capital firm, Carlyle Group.
fields.body:
Tim Jackson, founder of online auctioneer QXL.com, is understood to be close to quitting his position as managing director of the European internet investment arm of the American venture capital firm, Carlyle Group.

His resignation would be the second high profile departure from Carlyle Internet Partners Europe (CIPE) in less than a month after Jean-Bernard Tellio left at Christmas.

Mr Tellio, another managing director at the firm who previously handled the internet investments of French billionaire Bernard Arnault, is thought to have disagreed with the main board over the future direction of its $700m European fund.

Carlyle sources say Mr Jackson is already negotiating to cut down his role at the fund, but friends believe he will quit altogether. "I think Tim will go," said one. "It was only ever a part-time job, really, and these investment teams have a habit of changing."

Carlyle recruited Mr Jackson last year to take advantage of his extensive European expertise and contacts, built up during his time with QXL and as a newspaper columnist covering the internet.

It had hoped to bring established US internet firms to Europe but that never really happened and Mr Tellio, who has strong US contacts, decided to leave as a result. He plans to invest money on behalf of technology entrepreneurs.

CIPE is preparing to shift its investment away from firms in the battered e-commerce sector towards more specialised wireless and software technologies. Most of its investments are performing well but some, like the Israeli firm Yazam which owns the networking group First Tuesday, have fallen on hard times.

Mr Jackson's firm, QXL, has been unable to escape the e-commerce backlash and has seen its share price fall around 90% from its former highs.

Yesterday QXL confirmed a new funding package to secure its medium term future.

Carlyle has more than $10bn (£6.8bn) under management. Its investors include the financier, George Soros.

fields.headline: Local gulf between rich and the poor
fields.standfirst: Household survey highlights area disparity in wealth to rival traditional north-south divide. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Household survey highlights area disparity in wealth to rival traditional north-south divide. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
What is the poorest part of Britain, where average household income barely scrapes over £9,000 a year? What is the sixth richest part of Britain, where average incomes top £46,000 a year? The surprise answer is that both are districts of Merseyside: Vauxhall in central Liverpool and Heswall on the Wirral.

The figures, compiled in the "Wealth of the Nation" report by income data specialists CACI, cast a new light on the north/south divide. They reveal that although the income gap between north and south is wide and growing, it masks the huge disparities within each region of Britain.

For example, the residents of Manchester have an average household income of £19,800 a year, a long way behind the £33,400 average in Surrey, Britain's richest county. But a large number of northern towns and cities outstrip the household incomes of towns in the so-called prosperous south.

Stockport's postcode, for example, is on a par with Tunbridge Wells, while incomes in Harrogate, Crewe, Warrington, Preston and Huddersfield postcodes all outstrip prosperous southern postal areas such as Bath, Bournemouth and Colchester.

CACI chief executive Greg Bradford says: "The average levels of household income in the north are biased by the pockets of extremely low income levels which mark large Northern towns."

An analysis of the richest and poorest areas in Britain on a region-by-region basis, prepared exclusively for Jobs & Money by CACI, reveals that poor north/rich south is a gross oversimplification. In the North East, the TS15 postcode in central Middlesborough has an average household income of £9,870 but in nearby Stockton on Tees, residents in the TS175 postal district enjoy incomes averaging £37,776, placing them amongst the richest in Britain. The south-east figures are distorted by huge variations in London. While Portsmouth P014 is listed as the lowest income areas in the region, pockets of south east London are lower and among the lowest in the UK.

The CACI figures, based on 4m households, claim to be the largest and most comprehensive survey of household income in the UK. It also believes they are a better indicator of the financial health of Britain than traditional indicators such as the unemployment figures and movements in house prices. It shows that average household income in the UK has risen strongly in the past four years and now stands at £23,200, up 19.6% on 1996 and up 8.6% on 1998.

Average incomes by county

The ten richest counties are all in the south, although Cheshire comes in at eleventh. The lowest is not in the north, but the far south - Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly, at £17,700. Surrey enjoyed a 12.5% increase in average incomes in the last two years, while the Western Isles saw average income fall.

Average incomes by postcode area

London and its surrounds dominate the top ten ranking. Residents of London with the W postcode have average household incomes of £34,200 (up 13.4% since 1998), followed by Kingston upon Thames, SW London, Slough and Guildford. Lowest were Sunderland, Truro, the Outer Hebrides, Plymouth and Sheffield, all with average incomes below £19,000. The area with the fastest rise in in comes over the past two years was Harrow - up 19%.

Where the wealthiest live

The CACI figures also identify the areas which have the highest proportion of households earning over £100,000 and the areas with a high proportion of households earning less than £10,000. Top is the London EC2Y 5 postcode, which contains the high-rise Barbican development, where 10.6% of the residents earn more than £100,000 a year. Second is NW6 3 (South Hampstead) and SW1 H9 (St James's Park). Outside of London, Chalfont St Peter in Buckinghamshire and Igtham, near Sevenoaks in Kent, also have nearly a tenth of residents earning £100,000 a year.

Where the poorest live

The biggest concentration of poverty is Liverpool. The L16 postcode area in central Liverpool has 65.8% of households earning less than £10,000 a year. There are two more Liverpool postcodes in the bottom-ten table, which it shares with two districts in Bradford where two-thirds of the population earn total house- hold income below £10,000. Newtown in Birmingham B19 also falls into the bottom ten.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Bulk buy home loans

fields.headline: It's collective bargaining
fields.standfirst: A new type of mortgage deal allows people to pool their purchasing power and get a lower rate plus other perks. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: A new type of mortgage deal allows people to pool their purchasing power and get a lower rate plus other perks. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
A new type of mortgage deal where people pool their buying power to get a cheaper rate was launched this week.

"Bulk-buy" home loans are the brainchild of mortgage broker Charcol. How they work is that the more people who apply, the lower the rate you'll pay. Charcol this week unveiled its first three bulk-buy mortgages - a two-year discounted rate loan, a two-year fixed rate, and a flexible fixed rate aimed at people looking to remortgage.

Teaming up with other people in order to drive down costs has obvious attractions, but it's fair to say that the concept of collective buying hasn't exactly set the retail world alight so far. The best-known player in this field is online retailer LetsBuyIt.com - whose advertising campaign features ants - which has run into highly-publicised financial difficulties.

The company's business model won praise but in the end it wasn't able to deliver the goods. Perhaps it's simply because most of us prefer to browse in shops and showrooms when buying products LetsBuyIt.com has specialised in, such as electrical items and toys. But some experts argue that less tangible products such as mortgages and pensions lend themselves much better to collective buying over the net or phone.

Charcol isn't too fazed by LetsBuyIt.com's woes and is confident that bulk-buy mortgages will be a hit. All three of its new mortgages work in the same way: each offers what it says is a "market leading" rate even before any reductions are made or benefits added. Each time the number of people applying for the deals passes a set level the rate is cut slightly or an extra perk is added.

After two weeks (or if the mortgage sells out before then), provided enough people have applied, everyone gets the mortgage at the discounted rate. There is an upfront £49 reservation fee but you can pull out and have this refunded if you decide not to proceed because not enough people have signed up. People will be able to check levels of take-up by logging on to Charcol Online.

The first three deals are:

 A loan giving 2.55% off the standard variable rate for the first year and a 2.45% discount in the second year (giving an initial rate of 5.19% and then 5.29%) from Birm ingham Midshires. The deal is available to those with a deposit of 5%-plus, but there is a £299 arrangement fee and early redemption penalties for the first two years. Provided enough people come forward, the discount in the second year will be upped to 2.5% and up to £400 cashback will be thrown in.

 A loan fixed at 5.45% for two years for those able to stump up a deposit of at least 25%, or 5.65% for those who can only manage a 10% deposit. The lender is GMAC, the loans business owned by General Motors. There is a £295 arrangement fee and no redemption penalties. The bulk-buy enhancements would see the rates cut to 5.39%/5.59% and up to £385 of cashback provided.

 A flexible deal only open to people remortgaging, fixed at 5.59% for two years, funded by the Woolwich. You need a deposit of 10%-plus, and there is no arrangement fee, but there are redemption penalties within the two years. The perks, provided enough people apply, include up to £650 cashback.

Charcol says that as the service develops it plans to offer a range of bulk-buy deals. However, a situation could develop where those interested will wait for someone else to make the first move. A spokeswoman concedes there is a "possibility" that everyone will wait for everyone else to act. "I'm sure some people will hang back to see what happens," she says. "But all of these are market-leading products."

Mortgages aren't the only area where you can group together to drive down costs. Independent financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown has a website allowing people to pool purchasing power to get the best deal on per sonal pensions. HL Pensions is launching a new offer enabling people to buy a stakeholder-compliant personal pension free of all charges until April and which after that has a maximum annual management charge of 0.8% - significantly less than many providers will be charging once the stakeholder pension regime comes into force.

It can offer such attractive terms because it can go to the insurance company and buy on behalf of a large number of individuals. More than 150 people have registered for the offer since the last once closed at the beginning of December.

Stakeholder pensions are a new type of personal pension which go on sale on April 6. With these, the maximum amount a company can charge you for managing your funds is 1% a year and they will be portable. The pension offered by Bristol-based Hargreaves Lansdown beats many of the stakeholder minimum terms - the annual charge starts at 0.8% and starts falling once the fund value reaches £10,000. The offer is open until the end of February.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Taxman was wrong but 'didn't care'

fields.headline: Taxman was wrong but 'didn't care'
fields.standfirst: Vital documents remained unseen despite court ruling, reveals Phillip Inman
fields.trailText: Vital documents remained unseen despite court ruling, reveals Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
Neil Woodward is hopping mad. This week he discovered the Inland Revenue failed to send him 1,700 documents relevant to his tax dispute despite a court ruling that insisted he be given his entire tax file.

Following a campaign supported by the Guardian Mr Woodward, a building contractor, is the first person in recent times to overturn a bankruptcy order obtained by the Inland Revenue for unpaid taxes.

After a battle lasting 15 years Mr Woodward's decision to keep fighting was vindicated when the court of appeal said in 1999 there was evidence the Inland Revenue had failed to calculate cor rectly rollover tax relief on his properties. The Revenue agreed to nullify the bankruptcy after the court of appeal said enough evidence had emerged during the dispute that Mr Woodward's tax bill was six times bigger than it should have been.

Since then Mr Woodward has been compiling a case against the Revenue for compensation. He says the Revenue consistently refused to check the calculation of his tax and instituted a cover-up, throwing a blanket over his tax affairs and fending him off with technical arguments.

"The Revenue thought I would go away," he says. "A report by [accountants] Deloitte & Touche showed that it would have taken the Revenue six hours to work out my tax bill. If they had done that I would never have been made bankrupt. But internal memos show that Revenue officers were aware the tax claim on me might be wrong. They didn't check because of the 'time and expense required', the memo says."

Now he wants the Revenue to pay £5m to compensate him for trauma and disruption to his life and £2m for loss of income, interest and costs. Following his bankruptcy he lost his business, became unemployed for the first time and relations with his family became strained.

In a further court action last year he won the right to see all documents relevant to his case held by the Revenue in order to discover what the agency knew and when. But hundreds of documents remained in the Revenue's headquarters in Somerset House. He says he knew further documents existed but never imagined that 1,700 had been squirreled away.

"Lots of the documents are crucial. One has a name on that didn't appear on the one sent to me originally. If we had seen the name then I would have called them as a witness. That might have been a turning point. The Revenue has already lost the original computations that show how they calculated my tax in the first place. This person might have thrown some light on what went on."

In response the Revenue said that the impending court case prevented it from commenting on the specifics of the case: "If Mr Woodward has any concerns they can be addressed to the judge at the forthcoming trial."

Wider concerns for other taxpayers centre on the way the Revenue has ignored the taxpayers' charter and handled internal investigations, says Mr Woodward. "My complaints were continually passed back to the people who dealt with the case originally. At no point were other officers asked to look into my case. There needs to be an independent body that investigates complaints against the Revenue," he says.

In 1999 a parliamentary committee considered forcing the Inland Revenue to pass internal investigations to a separate body after a high-profile corruption case involving a senior tax inspector. Michael Allcock, one of the Revenue's most successful investigators, was imprisoned for five years for fraud in 1997. He had consistently ridden roughshod over internal regulations.

The Treasury select committee heard allegations that senior officers sanctioned his activities. Afterwards, the committee told the Revenue to strengthen internal monitoring, but stepped back from instituting an independent complaints procedure.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: The Equitable crisis

fields.headline: Trust is in the balance
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow Radio 4's Money Box programme will broadcast a special report into Equitable Life, exposing secret government meetings ahead of the shock closure of the company and revealing the true extent of its liabilities. Until now, the guarantees that have cost the company £1.5bn and led to its downfall were believed to cover 90,000 people. Money Box presenter Paul Lewis reveals the true figure to be 190,000
fields.trailText: Tomorrow Radio 4's Money Box programme will broadcast a special report into Equitable Life, exposing secret government meetings ahead of the shock closure of the company and revealing the true extent of its liabilities. Until now, the guarantees that have cost the company £1.5bn and led to its downfall were believed to cover 90,000 people. Money Box presenter Paul Lewis reveals the true figure to be 190,000.
fields.body:
On Wednesday December 6, senior officials of the Treasury, the Bank of England and the Financial Services Authority met in emergency session. The Tri-Partite Standing Committee is only called together to discuss events which could threaten the financial stability of Britain. The members knew by then, though the public did not, that Equitable Life, Britain's oldest mutual insurance company, was doomed in its present form.

Senior managers at Prudential - the last company in the race to buy Equitable - had decided internally not to go ahead with the sale. It was frightened off by the unlimited liability of the company to 90,000 individual policyholders whose guarantees had been upheld in the House of Lords in July.

With no buyer, Equitable could fail, and the officials met to manage the disaster ahead of the announcement of Equitable's closure 24 hours later.

It was indeed a Wednesday full of woe for Thursday's child, Equitable. It had so far to go on Thursday 16 September 1762 when 11 men met in the City of London and approved the foundation deed of the Association of Equitable Assurances on Life and Survivorships. Using the work of James Dodson, a respected mathematician who had worked out the combination of life expectancy and statistics which form the foundations of the modern life assurance business - the science of the actuary - Equitable Life offered fixed premiums and - in a promise that was to echo down the generations - a guaranteed payout on death.

Over the next 238 years professional middle England poured in money, first for life insurance, then for savings and pensions. From 1957 Equitable extended the concept of guarantees - promising fixed levels of pension up to 50 years into the future.

As a mutual society with no shareholders run for the benefit of members, Equitable seemed to have found the holy grail - low charges, high returns and low risk. Doctors, lawyers, teachers, civil servants, politicians, and journalists put their faith and money into Equitable. What they didn't know was that the actuaries who ran Equitable - no company had more per square foot - valued this pension promise at zero.

Those same actuaries (motto: "making financial sense of the future") failed to spot two trends - falling interest rates and rising life expectancy. Together those changes cut in half the pensions that could be bought on the market. And suddenly the Equitable promise, which the actuaries had valued at zero, became an attractive option.

But as people retired and tried to claim it, the lawyers stepped forward with a scheme to cut back the pension fund paid to those with the guarantees. They still got their higher percentage, but of a smaller fund, driving down their net pensions to the same level that could be bought on the open market.

So confident was the company that this wheeze was watertight that when its view was challenged it paid for a court case to prove it was right. But in July 2000, five Law Lords unanimously found the opposite, leaving Equitable with an unlimited liability to 90,000 individual members and - Money Box has discovered - 100,000 company pensioners.

The insurance policy it had taken out in the 1980s against the potential £1.5bn cost of the guarantees would not pay up. In a wonderful stroke of irony, the world's oldest mutual insurer had failed to cover itself against the House of Lords overturning its lawyers' interpretation of the law.

There was nowhere to turn for the money but to the other 850,000 members who had no guarantee. Within an hour of the Law Lords' decision, the company told them it was taking all their investment growth from January to July to pay the bill. In a final gamble it put the company up for sale, hoping to recoup the cost and repay members.

But 20 weeks later on Thursday 7 December, when Prudential formally pulled out, the Equitable Board considered the views of the Tri-Partite committee and made the decision that was announced to the world at 7.30 am next morning. Equitable Life, the world's oldest mutual life assurance society, would close to new business, cut back on its investment returns, and penalise anyone who left by keeping 10% of their savings.

The president, John Sclater, said it was "a sad day". Managing director Alan Nash resigned, solaced only by his £200,000 pay-off and a pension of nearly £100,000 a year for life. Finance director Chris Headdon took charge and 12 days later the president and seven other directors said they would resign when replacements could be found - presumably, people who knew the meaning of the word "guarantee".

But was the House of Lords the iceberg that came out of the dark to hole the safest savings vessel on the seas?

Money Box has been told that the disaster was not only predictable but predicted. And while Equitable was telling the world that the cost of the disaster would only be £50m, it was busy signing up thousands of new members to pay the cost. Mary Francis, director general of the trade body the Association of British Insurers, told us that Equitable "took a bet on future interest rates, which was not a wise decision".

The president of the Faculty of Actuaries told us that this unprecedented failure could damage confidence in his profession - he has launched the first-ever inquiry into what the actuaries did wrong. A professor of banking told us that "risk management at Equitable Life was primitive in the extreme" and "the accounts gave no clue what was really going on".

The fall-out continues. Four separate inquiries have been launched; as well as the actuaries, accountants, and the Financial services Authority are all looking at what they did wrong and the Treasury Select Committee is investigating what everyone did wrong.

This week people at the highest level in government, in regulation, in the law, are struggling to find a rescue deal which can only be days away. No one knows if it will work. But if the lawyers, politicians, and regulators cannot sort out the problems of the insurance company which they trusted with their money, what hope is there for the rest of us?

 Paul Lewis presents Money Box on Radio 4, Saturdays at noon. A Money Box Special, An Inequitable Life, is on Radio 4, Sunday 21 January 5pm, repeated Thursday 25 January 8pm and after that on the internet at Money Box.

'Amnesty' gives pension scheme members a glimmer of hope
Rupert Jones

As talks continue about trying to find a solution to the Equitable Life crisis, there was a small slice of good news for people in company pension schemes provided by the insurer.

It has been revealed that Equitable has introduced an "amnesty" allowing members of these schemes to carry on paying in for the moment while reserving the right to take out contributions paid in between December 8 2000 and March 31 2001 and transfer them to another pension provider.

In other words, members can keep paying in while they mull over their options, and if they decide at the end of March to move to another provider, Equitable will let them withdraw the money paid in between these two dates.

Scheme trustees must inform Equitable by this Friday if they want to take up the offer, which applies to 2,000 company schemes and 4,000 AVC top-up schemes provided by Equitable.

It has granted the amnesty in order to give scheme trustees time to consult members if they wish to keep their money invested in Equitable's with-profits fund following the predictions of lower investment growth in future.

Equitable is reportedly talking with several companies about the possible sale of parts or all of the business, and is also still discussing proposals put for ward by a policyholders' action group that would cap the insurer's liabilities.

Financial Services Authority - tel 0845 606 1234

Action groups

Equitable Life Members Help Group

webTitle: Market forces: No particular place to go

fields.headline: No particular place to go
fields.trailText: On the commute home last night, senior market participants were no doubt reflecting on one of the London market's more indecisive sessions.
fields.body:
On the commute home last night, senior market participants were no doubt reflecting on one of the London market's more indecisive sessions.

It had all started so brightly. Encouraged by the Nasdaq composite's strong Thursday night advance - the tech index closed at a five-week high - and solid figures from Microsoft and fibreoptics equipment maker Nortel, leading shares quickly rose 50 points.

But, as has been the trend over recent weeks, it quickly fizzled out. A mixed start on Wall Street, which confounded early, confident predictions of further gains in New York, was enough to undermine London's fragile confidence.

Of course, it was not simple. A big switch out of defensive issues like banks and pharmaceuticals and into tech and telecom stocks also hit the FTSE 100.

With the Nasdaq appearing to have bottomed out and stock prices discounting further earnings disappointments, buyers are emerging for firms such as Autonomy, up 190p to £23.75, Energis, 35p higher at 578p and Colt Telecom, 100p better at £17.70.

The final scores showed the FTSE 100 little changed, down 0.6 points at 6,209.3, as the buoyancy of tech and telecom shares was offset by weakness in the likes of AstraZeneca, down 105p to £30 and Royal Bank of Scotland, off 78p to £15.80. Over the week, the blue chip index gained 44 points

Elsewhere, the FTSE Techmark added 61.01 to 2,787.65 with Bookham Technology, up 248p to £14.52p, and BATM, 20p higher at 168.5p, topping the performance charts.

Dealers said the solid figures from Nortel had encouraged punters to have a nibble.

Celltech was again among the best blue chip performers, rising 62p to £12.62p, yesterday on the back of a Goldman Sachs recommendation.

The broker reckons Celltech's drug for arthritis, CDP 870, could be a significant cash generator, and has yet to be reflected in its share price.

Reuters news agency finished of its best levels, up 42p to £11.42, hit by unsourced speculation that the demerger of its online brokerage division Institnet has been pulled.

On the down side, ICI, the speciality chemicals company, shed 32p to 470p, hit by events on the other side of the Atlantic - where rival Union Carbide warned on profits late on Thursday night.

Coming on top of warnings from Quaker Chemical Corp, Hercules, and Valspar this week, analysts are starting to wonder if ICI can meet its profits forecasts.

Among second line companies, buyers were climbing on board Arriva, 0.75p better at 279.5p, on the back of whispers that Guy Hands's Principal Finance Unit at Japanese investment bank Nomura is running the slide rule over the transport company.

There was a concerted effort to get the takeover story going again at Chubb, off 2p to 166p. Chatter at the wine bar level suggests that an offer for the security specialist from US conglomerate Tyco International is on the way.

Frozen food retailer Iceland slipped 30p to 257.5p, unsettled by speculation of a profits warning. Although sources close the company played down the chatter, traders were remained unconvinced.

In the meantime Medisys dropped 14.5p to 117.5p as analysts at brokers Granville Baird and Nomura were said to have taken the red pen to earnings forecasts following news of a slower than expected roll-out of its safety syringe.

Dataflex Holdings slipped 1.5p to 154.5p, but dealers reckon it could report slightly better than expected interim figures next Thursday.

On the Alternative Investment Market, investment house EVC Christows moved up 0.75p to 7.25p - with dealers citing the group's attractive fundamentals.

Although Christows has £35m in cash and £12m worth realisable assets, it had a market capitalisation of only £45.6m before yesterday's gain.

fields.headline: Wharf's royal returns
fields.trailText: When Prince Alwaleed bin Talal sold most of his stake in Canary Wharf earlier this week, the headlines concentrated on the 500% return the world richest business man - that is, outside the US - had made on his investment. Little was said about the impact on the company.
fields.body:
When Prince Alwaleed bin Talal sold most of his stake in Canary Wharf earlier this week, the headlines concentrated on the 500% return the world richest business man - that is, outside the US - had made on his investment. Little was said about the impact on the company.

According to Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which yesterday upgraded its rating on the Docklands estate to "buy", the sale by the Prince has removed another slice of the perceived stock overhang that has been depressing the shares since they reached their peak of 547p in October.

After the Prince's disposal - he sold 26.6m shares, or just under 4% of the issued share capital - the holding of backers funding chairman Paul Reichmann's buyback of the estate from its bankers in 1995 has fallen to 30%.

Schroder has a target of 607p for Canary Wharf shares, which closed last night at 489p.

fields.headline: At this price?  ML Laboratories
fields.trailText: Manchester millionaire Kevin Leech may have won the hearts of tourists by snapping up Land's End, John O' Groats and the Needles Pleasure Park, but his biotech company, ML Laboratories, is losing its popularity battle in the City.
fields.body:
Manchester millionaire Kevin Leech may have won the hearts of tourists by snapping up Land's End, John O' Groats and the Needles Pleasure Park, but his biotech company, ML Laboratories, is losing its popularity battle in the City.

Unlike most biotech firms, ML has five products on the market - including a kidney dialysis fluid, several asthma inhalers and a gel to prevent post-operative adhesions. But its shares have fallen from a peak of 263p to just 103.5p this year.

Analysts complain that the business has a diffuse collection of interests. Erling Refsum of Nomura says: "You could almost call it an incubator - it tends to sort of pick up odd things with nothing much in common."

There are also doubts about the management. Neither Mr Leech, who owns 48% of the business, nor chief executive Stuart Sim has a scientific background. Biotech investors worry that they spend too much time on other business ventures.

Despite its good record in taking products through regulatory hurdles, ML is still losing money. Interim losses rose from £6.9m to £11.8m. This is partly due to poorly negotiated partnership deals - ML's breakthrough product was Extraneal, a kidney dialysis solution which has a longer lasting effect than its rivals. It has a 25% market share in Europe, but ML gets just 10% of the revenue under a marketing deal with Baxter Healthcare. ML's peak annual income from the product is unlikely to exceed £7m.

ML is burning £9m of cash a year and has just £14m left. It arranged a convertible loan from NM Rothschild this week for a further £7.5m, but that means the bank could have a claim on shares in the future.

Rothschild is "considering options" for ML in a strategic review. A sale of some subsidiaries, a complete break-up or a management buyout are all possibilities.

ML is capitalised at a modest £162m. But the shares should be given a wide berth.
fields.bodyText: Manchester millionaire Kevin Leech may have won the hearts of tourists by snapping up Land's End, John O' Groats and the Needles Pleasure Park, but his biotech company, ML Laboratories, is losing its popularity battle in the City. Unlike most biotech firms, ML has five products on the market - including a kidney dialysis fluid, several asthma inhalers and a gel to prevent post-operative adhesions. But its shares have fallen from a peak of 263p to just 103.5p this year. Analysts complain that the business has a diffuse collection of interests. Erling Refsum of Nomura says: "You could almost call it an incubator - it tends to sort of pick up odd things with nothing much in common." There are also doubts about the management. Neither Mr Leech, who owns 48% of the business, nor chief executive Stuart Sim has a scientific background. Biotech investors worry that they spend too much time on other business ventures. Despite its good record in taking products through regulatory hurdles, ML is still losing money. Interim losses rose from £6.9m to £11.8m. This is partly due to poorly negotiated partnership deals - ML's breakthrough product was Extraneal, a kidney dialysis solution which has a longer lasting effect than its rivals. It has a 25% market share in Europe, but ML gets just 10% of the revenue under a marketing deal with Baxter Healthcare. ML's peak annual income from the product is unlikely to exceed £7m. ML is burning £9m of cash a year and has just £14m left. It arranged a convertible loan from NM Rothschild this week for a further £7.5m, but that means the bank could have a claim on shares in the future. Rothschild is "considering options" for ML in a strategic review. A sale of some subsidiaries, a complete break-up or a management buyout are all possibilities. ML is capitalised at a modest £162m. But the shares should be given a wide berth.

fields.trailText: There is only one way to settle the dispute about the merits of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Letters, January 19). Ask Nancy Banks-Smith. If She Who Is Never Wrong actually likes it, I shall be forced to revise my opinion that it is rather dull and greatly overrated by the critics.
fields.body:
There is only one way to settle the dispute about the merits of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Letters, January 19). Ask Nancy Banks-Smith. If She Who Is Never Wrong actually likes it, I shall be forced to revise my opinion that it is rather dull and greatly overrated by the critics.

John Macdonald
Glasgow

Who says Jackie Chan's films are meritless B-movies (Crashing bore, G2, January 16)? He's made some of the most exciting action films ever, and he does his stunts for real, unlike Crouching Tiger, Unhidden Wires.

Nik Devlin
London

Has the awful thought occurred to Margaret Henry (Letters, January 19) that an honours list of those that have refused one may be a very short list indeed. I nominate Jean Chretien as an honorary member for refusing to allow one to be bestowed on Conrad Black.

Sidney Akers
Worcester
Sidneyakers@aol.com

After reading Peter Bradshaw's article about the TV show he has created with David Baddiel ('You cannot be serious', January 19) I was glad to learn that it is still possible to enter the world of TV or radio comedy via that traditional route of getting together with people one knew from Cambridge.

Lou George
Kendal, Cumbria

On the topic of equal opportunity snowpeople (Letters, January 17) many years ago Edinburgh University Experimental Arts Society attempted to construct a black snowwoman. We discovered that it is surprisingly difficult to mould an anatomically correct female figure out of snow, and that black emulsion paint merely congeals if you try to paint snow with it.

Roger Musson
Edinburgh

fields.headline: In place of poverty
fields.trailText: Stuart Wheeler, the most recent and most generous of the fat cat donors to offer to fund our democratic process (Tory glee at record £5m gift, January 18) probably reflects the views of similar donors when he says that there is no difference between owning £90m and £85m.
fields.body:
Stuart Wheeler, the most recent and most generous of the fat cat donors to offer to fund our democratic process (Tory glee at record £5m gift, January 18) probably reflects the views of similar donors when he says that there is no difference between owning £90m and £85m. He also says that he has experienced situations where £100 would have made a major difference to his life and that he appreciates that there is a limit to what any household requires.

What more eloquent argument could there be for increasing tax rates significantly for top earners and using the proceeds to improve the living conditions of the poorest. The rich wouldn't miss it, it would alleviate real misery for many and it would create a more inclusive society. There might even be enough left over to fund election campaigns in a more fair and transparent way.

Mr Wheeler says that he would turn down an honour or position offered to him as a consequence of his donation. This is hardly a great sacrifice. With so much spare wealth he can have the ear of anyone in power and he can afford to pay advertisers to influence the views of the rest of us. This is a disproportionate degree of control for any one person to exercise in a democracy. That is what he would lose if he were to allow his money to be taken in tax. Over to you, chancellor.

webTitle: Letter: Waugh: controversial to the last

fields.headline: Waugh: controversial to the last
fields.trailText: In an earnest piece (Ghastly man, January 19) Polly Toynbee has registered her own views on the sad death of a humorous journalist a few days ago.
fields.body:
In an earnest piece (Ghastly man, January 19) Polly Toynbee has registered her own views on the sad death of a humorous journalist a few days ago. "We might let Auberon Waugh rest in peace," she sighs, "were it not for the mighty damage his clan has done to British political life, journalism and discourse in the post war years."

This was illustrated by a lightly coloured pen drawing of my father's corpse being sluiced down a lavatory, in much the same way as one might expect pee, paper (of a certain sort) and other matter, to disappear on a daily basis. Regular readers, who respect the Comment and Analysis pages, may have thought that the illustration was to be taken equally seriously as Ms Toynbee's high-minded and heartfelt article. Rest assured.

Auberon Waugh's "clan" does not intend to compound the mighty damage it has already done to this country by disposing of his body in this unhygienic manner. We shall ensure that all health and safety regulations are observed when the great man is buried in Somerset on Wednesday.

Alexander Waugh
Milverton, Somerset

If Auberon Waugh were already in his grave, he would be spinning with joy over my old friend Polly Toynbee's vicious, class war assault upon him. He used to love her attacks. But this one is something else. It is so intemperate, so boorish, so reeking in hatred of all those who dare to question Toynbee's own orthodoxies, that I think Bron would see it as a real classic.

Toynbee describes one of the targets of Bron's attacks, Grey Gowrie, as "cringing" because he praised Waugh as "the greatest journalist of my generation". Might one dare to suggest that Gowrie shows rather more sense of humour, generosity of spirit and less of a thin skin than Polly does ? She assails "the old world of El Vino's wine bar in Fleet Street where leftwing lambs and rightwing lions downed their differences in bottles of champagne". Puzzling this, because one of the greatest of the quaffers there was Peter Jenkins, Toynbee's late, great and beloved husband, a superb quondam columnist for this paper. I don't think he would have seen himself as either a "leftwing lamb" or "rightwing lion". In trying to construct the Waugh "coterie" that has inflicted so much damage on Britain, she ignores the point made in most of the obituaries that there was (alas) no one else like Bron. Even she is forced to admit that among his so-called "clan" he was "unique" for his anti-Americanism and support for the European Union. Unable to face the serious arguments against how "Europe" now works, Toynbee instead abuses anyone against the EU as positing "a brave little England of crusty-living upper-class eccentrics". But was it "upper-class eccentrics" who created "the spirit of anti-Europeanism" that Toynbee acknowledges "pervades" the country ? Of course not. Perhaps the mass of ordinary people understand realities better than ivory-towered Toynbee. We should all be grateful. Bron must even now be waving a faxed copy of this tirade at St Peter himself, the better to establish that he really does deserve admission. Alas, poor Polly.

William Shawcross
London

Well said, Polly Toynbee. I too have been astounded by the posthumous glorification of a man whose snobbery and ignorance did incalculable damage to literary life in Britain.

When my first novel became a bestseller, I was invited to lunch at the Literary Review and seated between Waugh and another braying fogey in a tweed jacket. Conversation was a severe challenge to my social skills. My book was full of filthy sex, they assumed. Not as filthy as all that, I replied; a book club sale had just been agreed on the basis that the work was within acceptable norms of eroticism. Envy flashed green around the table. Did I know a book club could add 10,000 to sales? How many had been ordered? I had to admit to 80,000 copies. They fell silent. Having spotted their concern for traditional values in worship, I tried to float the issue of the hymns sung at school assemblies. It seemed that these men of letters did not waste their intellect on talking to their children. Another silence. Waugh launched a fresh attack and demanded to know why I continued my job as a television critic despite my literary success. I cared about television, I answered. But the pay must be terrible, he argued. So now I could afford to do the job, I explained. Waugh and his crony swiftly moved to comparing their earnings from journalism. The crony earned twice as much as Waugh. Silence now endured to the end of the meal, when I committed the final outrage of thanking the cooks. They shuddered with distaste and never asked me back. The tacky, phoney elitism which this coterie promotes has driven our best writers out of the country and poisoned the atmosphere of our intellectual life. It's time they got the contempt they deserve.

Celia Brayfield
London

Waugh may have had his failings and annoying eccentricities but he gave unstinting support to amateur poets. He awarded very generous prizes (provided by sponsors) in the Literary Review poetry competition. Many a struggling rhymester will remember him with affection.

John O'Byrne
Dublin

My immediate reaction on hearing of Waugh's death was to punch the air and exclaim "good riddance!" But Polly Toynbee's reply to all the sickly and sycophantic obituaries put into words exactly how I really felt about this vile man.

Eamonn Duffy
Welwyn Garden City, Herts

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Guardian Investment Challenge result

fields.headline: So close - but children are the real winners
fields.trailText: A retired geography teacher from Cumbria has topped the 5,000 entrants in the Guardian/Barnardo's Investment Challenge - and beaten the returns achieved by the vast majority of City financial experts - to scoop the £10,000 first prize.
fields.body:
A retired geography teacher from Cumbria has topped the 5,000 entrants in the Guardian/Barnardo's Investment Challenge - and beaten the returns achieved by the vast majority of City financial experts - to scoop the £10,000 first prize.

Michael Barron, 56, from the village of Dalston, near Carlisle, saw his selection of funds rise in value by nearly 10% during 2000, a remarkable achievement during one of the worst years for stock market investment in decades. A self-declared investment amateur, Mr Barron's spread of fund selections strongly outperformed the -2% that the £1 trillion UK investment industry managed on average last year.

But the biggest winner will be children's charity Barnardo's, which stands to pick up around £100,000 from the Challenge, generously donated by the unit trust and investment trust companies listed opposite. The money will go to support its vital work in projects around Britain.

Last year we asked Jobs & Money readers to select from the list opposite the five funds they thought would be the fastest growing during 2000. At the end of the year the winner would be the one whose portfolio of funds achieved the highest investment performance.

Many readers plumped for technology funds, which were racing ahead at the beginning of last year. But after early gains of 20-30%, the dot.com blowout saw the funds fall back to end the year 20-25% down.

Others pinned their hopes on a recovery in the Far East after the 1997/98 economic crisis, or believed that Japan was about to pull out of its long slump. But their hopes were cruelly dashed, and optimistically named portfolios such as Asiaboom, EastIsBest and Eastern Promise saw quite the reverse. Over the year the typical portfolio of Far East funds fell by 30-40%.

Mr Barron pipped the others in a close-run race by choosing a selection of income funds plus a European and an American fund. His selections were Credit Suisse Transatlantic (up 16.83%), Jupiter Income (up 10.35%), Axa Sun Life Higher Income (up 9.29%), TU European (up 7.63%) and Schroder High Yield Bond fund (up 4.28%).

Was it luck or judgment that led to Mr Barron picking a winning combination? "I'm not really a buyer of shares or funds. All I've ever done is invest a lump sum from a maturing endowment policy," he says.

But Mr Barron decided to put some effort into selecting his investments for the Challenge, which goes to show that a little bit of research, plus a dollop of luck, can steer even investment amateurs to success. "I did closely go through all 52 of the funds The Guardian listed and chose according to their performance over the past one and three years."

He says three decisions stood him in good stead. "Firstly, I decided to steer clear of the Far East as I did not think there was going to be a recovery in the short term. Secondly, I didn't like the look of hi-tech; I thought it was a bubble about to burst. My third decision was that America still looked promising, which is why I picked Transatlantic. The name seemed to sum up exactly what I wanted."

He also compiled a portfolio that was cautiously geared towards income funds, which invest in a selection of high yielding shares and bonds, which performed well last year as big investors moved out of racy "growth" stocks into safer "value" stocks and bonds.

But it was only a late gallop by Mr Barron's portfolio that pushed him over the winning line ahead of the pack. At the end of October, Mr Barron was ninth on the leader board, and by end November had edged up to sixth before leaping into first place at the end of December.

Sadly for Shivani Parikh, who had held first place in both October and November, her portfolio slipped back to end fifth of the nearly 5,000 entries into the Challenge.

The competition was so closely fought that Jobs & Money called in fund measurement experts Standard & Poor's to verify the figures. Standard & Poor's has the investment industry's most comprehensive database of funds, compiling figures on 51,000 funds in 52 countries.

Jobs & Money writers also took part in the Challenge, but this week were looking rather shame-faced about the results. The best any of us managed was a return of 1.9%, while the worst was -24%. At least this was ahead of the investment advisers we contacted a year ago; not one managed to put together a positive portfolio.

The key to staying one step ahead

Don't put all your eggs in one basket, don't expect an instant fortune and don't follow fashion; these are the lessons for small investors from the Guardian Investment Challenge.

Advisers recommend first-time punters should opt for international general trusts which balance and diversify risk. Witan, an international general trust which entered the Challenge, managed a creditable 1% gain over the year when the average trust fell by a tenth.

Our winner managed to avoid the worst of the market setbacks last year by spreading his investments across three UK-based income funds, an American fund and a European fund, and checking past performance figures. One of the easiest ways to do so is to log on to a free website from Standard & Poor's which contains data plus research going back 10 years.

The best advice last year was not to follow fashion -which in investment terms meant steering clear of technology funds. Investing in technology over the long term is probably a wise decision, but jumping into a specialist area as your first investment is not.

The top-performing fund in the Challenge, and one picked by Mr Barron, was Credit Suisse Transatlantic. It sidestepped the dot.com fallout this year because it will only invest in companies with good cash flow.

Transatlantic manager Sheryl Hempel says: "We were underweight in technology throughout the year, and the names that we did own we bought only very selectively. We have a model in which we are looking for investments with good cash flow and the dot.coms simply don't work on that analysis."

But the good news is that Credit Suisse, which was in defensive, safe stocks last year, believes that fears of a "hard landing" this year in the US are misplaced. "We are more positive than most. We expect a hard landing for corporate profits, but not the economy. We see it bouncing back fairly quickly in the second half of the year," says Ms Hempel.

fields.headline: No relief
fields.trailText: On Wednesday, a plane of Oxfam emergency water equipment landed in El Salvador to help those made homeless by the earthquake. It will take months - if not years - to rebuild people's lives and will cost a lot of money.
fields.body:
On Wednesday, a plane of Oxfam emergency water equipment landed in El Salvador to help those made homeless by the earthquake. It will take months - if not years - to rebuild people's lives and will cost a lot of money.

In 1998, Honduras also suffered a devastating natural disaster - Hurricane Mitch. Two-thirds of the £142m aid package promised by the EU remains unspent in Brussels and Hondurans continue to live in temporary shelters.

International donors meet in Madrid next month to evaluate their response to the hurricane. Donors must ensure that the people of El Salvador do not suffer similar mistakes.

fields.headline: Into care in prime time
fields.trailText: There is no earthly way that Flintshire social services staff could have completed their assessment of the Kilshaw twins in the time before they decided to remove them (Social services take internet twins into care, January 19).
fields.body:
There is no earthly way that Flintshire social services staff could have completed their assessment of the Kilshaw twins in the time before they decided to remove them (Social services take internet twins into care, January 19).

The most substantial evidence available to them was probably the best time at which to organise their snatch to catch prime time television.

This is very appropriate in a case where children's futures seem to have been predominantly affected by the views of the tabloid press.

Michael Dempsey
London
michaeld@tinyworld.co.uk

Will the judge charged with deciding "ownership" of these two children go for the most sensible option and award custody to the one constant force in their lives thus far? Not for nothing are they called the internet twins...

Chris Coates
London
noonuck@hotmail.com

So, this couple have stained their characters by believing in paranormal nonsense (Day when social services said 'that's enough', January 19). I assume they would be deemed normal had they believed in mainstream religious nonsense?

Dan Hakstege
Cradley Heath

fields.headline: A lesson from teachers
fields.trailText: Will Woodward's analysis of the teacher shortage (Pretty vacant, January 18) is careful, patient and professional. He is too kind, though, to treat union and government figures simply as alternative estimates in a confusing world.
fields.body:
Will Woodward's analysis of the teacher shortage (Pretty vacant, January 18) is careful, patient and professional. He is too kind, though, to treat union and government figures simply as alternative estimates in a confusing world.

The record over the past three years shows that government spokespersons have systematically scoffed at union reports of shortages, until the sudden introduction of training salaries. "The candour shown by David Blunkett" on that occasion was in stark contrast to the institutional dishonesty which had hitherto characterised government statements on recruitment.

They have been similarly coy on two related issues. There is a desperate need to support new recruits once they have started to teach. Government guidelines acknowledge this, but induction arrangements have not been efficiently introduced, monitored or enforced. And large numbers of older teachers are only too happy to take retirement when they can. I know; I was one of them.

Until we get an honest acknowledgment of what teachers' working conditions are like, and how government can contrive to improve them rather than disrupt them, this situation is unlikely to improve.

fields.headline: Brown plays down government surplus
fields.trailText: The government's finances sank deeply into the red last month but economists are still forecasting a huge surplus for the year as a whole.
fields.body:
The government's finances sank deeply into the red last month but economists are still forecasting a huge surplus for the year as a whole.

The office for national statistics said public finances suffered a net cash outflow of £9.5bn, the biggest deficit to date for any December. This was mainly due to a £5bn bill for interest payments on government debt.

However, the healthy underlying state of the Treasury's coffers gives the chancellor, Gordon Brown, ample scope to cut taxes in March's pre-election Budget, said analysts.

The government's preferred measure of budget deficit was in the red by a more modest £2.7bn. For the fiscal year to date, the Treasury is running a surplus of just over £4bn, the best since monthly records began in 1993-94.

Mr Brown has forecast a surplus of £10bn for the year, although most City analysts expect it to be larger.

Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics, said: "The cumulative PSNB surplus of over £4bn in the first nine months points to a full year figure of £15bn or so, suggesting that Mr Brown will have £5bn-odd to give away in the March Budget."

Ross Walker, at Royal Bank of Scotland, said the government's forecast was "cautious in the extreme" and would be beaten by an even bigger margin. "We expect the surplus for the current financial year to come in around £18bn - almost double the government's forecast," he said.

The Treasury said the figures were turning out much as Mr Brown had forecast in November's pre-Budget report.

A source said that after a slow start, current spending on government programmes had picked up and was now growing slightly ahead of plan, excluding social security and debt interest payments.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Aim-listed motor retailer DC Cook called in the receivers yesterday after experiencing cashflow problems. Shares were suspended at 9p, valuing the group at £7.9m.
fields.body:
Motor retailer in receivership

Aim-listed motor retailer DC Cook called in the receivers yesterday after experiencing cashflow problems. Shares were suspended at 9p, valuing the group at £7.9m. "All parts of the group remain trading normally: we will be having exploratory talks with the manufacturers to try to make sure that all customers' deposits on cars can be honoured," said Nigel Ruddock of Grant Thornton, which has been appointed receiver.

The group, which employs 700 and operates 27 franchises, made a pretax loss of £6.3m for the year to the end of April 2000, on sales of £266.1m. It also has bank debts in excess of £27m.

Letsbuyit.com wins reprieve

Struggling online retailer Letsbuyit.com has won a last-minute reprieve against a bankruptcy application filed by the firm's Dutch court-appointed trustees. The district court of Amsterdam yesterday gave the company six days to secure €4m (£2.5m) in additional funding. It is thought that management has already found €2.5m. Primus-Online, net retailing arm of German Metro group, yesterday said it was in talks about buying Letsbuyit's claimed 750,000 customers for DM1 per customer. The trustees, from the legal firm Van Doorne, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday and have described the management of Letsbuyit as "deplorable".

£528m offer for Beazer

The tit-for-tat bidding war in the house building industry continued yesterday as Persimmon made an indicative offer of £528m for its smaller rival, Beazer. The 185p a share proposal included 92.5p in cash, with the remainder to be paid in shares. It could mean the end of Beazer's plans to for a "merger of equals" with Bryant to create a combined business, Domus.

Inflation falls in Irish Republic

The annual rate of inflation in the Irish Republic dropped by more than a full percentage point last month to a new level of 5.9%. That was down from 7% - a 16-year high - in November and followed finance minister Charlie McCreevy's early December budget, which cut the duty payable on fuel and reduced VAT rates as well as income tax. In view of the budget strategy, a large decrease in the price rise rate had been anticipated in Dublin after a number of months that saw the inflation level reach well over double the European Union average.

The tax-cutting element of successive budgets has been criticised by the European commission because of its tendency to put up inflation - and, coincidentally, the minister was meeting his EU counterparts yesterday for talks on economic policy.

AstraZeneca sells dental unit

Anglo-Swedish pharmaceuticals group AstraZeneca said yesterday it was selling its dental local anaesthetics unit to US dental products maker Dentsply in a deal worth $136.5m (£93m). Astra's shares, which have outperformed the sector by17% in the past 12 months, fell 86p to £30.24 yesterday.

fields.headline: Body Shop director resigns
fields.trailText: The Body Shop director responsible for products and marketing resigned unexpectedly yesterday, just a week after the company blamed poor products for a dip in Christmas sales and was forced to issue a profit warning.
fields.body:
The Body Shop director responsible for products and marketing resigned unexpectedly yesterday, just a week after the company blamed poor products for a dip in Christmas sales and was forced to issue a profit warning.

Susan Falk, an American, joined Body Shop 18 months ago and held the marketing job for only nine months. She was promoted to the boardroom when the previous marketing director, Donald Damask, left after 10 months in the post.

She was on a one-year contract and is likely to receive a pay-off of some £350,000.

Body Shop chief executive Patrick Gournay, who was brought in to revitalise the ailing green brand two and a half years ago, will take over Ms Falk's marketing and product development roles.

Her departure came exactly a week after Mr Gournay was forced to issue a profits warning. He said profits would be up to 15% below last year's levels and blamed the failure of new products to meet expectations. Like-for-like UK Christmas sales were down 2%.

The environment oriented cosmetics company admitted it had moved too quickly in introducing a series of new ranges. Mr Gournay said: "In our rush to get new products on the market we were probably too radical."

Body Shop's shares closed down 0.5p at 90.5p yesterday, and have tumbled 25% in the course of just over a week.
